DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the Denver-datelined obituary on Temple Buell, fourth item in PM-Deaths on Jan. 6, may wish to use the following, which provides more background on Buell's endowment to Colorado Women's College.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press obituary of Denver architect and developer Temple Hoyne Buell, who died last Friday at age 94, did not give full background on the $25 million donation he made to Colorado Women's College during the 1960s. Buell was persuaded by his second wife, Virginia Bennett Crocker, to donate a $25 million trust to Colorado Women's College, which then was renamed Temple Buell College. But the school's other donors, apparently unaware that Buell's contribution was to be posthumous, began diverting their contributions elsewhere. This prompted the school's trustees to break off the arrangement with Buell and change the school's name back to Colorado Women's College. The east Denver college later was dissolved because of financial problems, and the campus now is owned by the University of Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Truckers Cram Cabs with Comforts of Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: On the road hardly means roughing it as truckers haul their own chandeliers, fax machines and microwave ovens along with products going to market across country. ``You can just about put anything you want in there,'' said Steve Bombela of United Truck and Body in Des Moines, which makes cabs and does customizing for semi-trucks. The longer cabs contain a sleeping unit behind the front seat that can be furnished with just about anything a trucker can dream up. Steve Blunt, 37, president of Steve Blunt Trucking Inc. of Des Moines, owns ``The Bird,'' a 70-foot long customized Kenworth Aerodyne. He spent $70,000 getting the truck just the way he wanted it. It is painted with two, 17-foot, air-brushed blue firebirds from the hood to the tip of the trailer. The sleeper has a bath with shower, foldaway tables, a central vacuuming system and a kitchen with sink, two-burner stove, microwave and customized cabinets. There are refrigerators in both the cab and the sleeper. The sleeping compartment for two has a 15-inch remote control color television, a VCR and a cellular telephone. A stereo system with 28 speakers provides cruising music. ``You've got to have some tunes,'' said Blunt, whose drivers transport boxed beef to New York City and Boston. He likes the shower best. More husband and wife teams are buying the big cabs since deregulation eased restrictions on truck length, according to Kenworth Mid-Iowa in Des Moines. About 10 percent of the company's business is in the big Kenworth Aerodyne. The cab and sleeper costs $90,000 to $100,000, without extras, and is about the fanciest cab sold. It also is the largest, measuring 110 inches by 96 inches. It comes with a button and tuck padded interior and upper and lower bunks and a full-sized 42-inch bed. Bombela said his deluxe cabs and sleepers cost about $25,000. For that price, Bombela's company installs a shower, a microwave, refrigerator, color television, flush toilet, sink, oak cabinets, water holding tanks and generator. For a little extra money, they will install water beds. ``We put in showers, flush toilets, computers, fax machines ... even chandeliers.'' But some truckers don't like the big cabs despite the added comfort, he said. The large units, with extras, can add a thousand pounds, a concern for truckers faced with weight limitations. And the trucks are more difficult to drive because the wheel base is stretched to accommodate the sleepers, he said. Paul Swesey, 27, of Panora, spent $40,000 to customize his truck because he ``likes the show.'' Swesey is a household goods mover and spends more than three-quarters of the year on the road, sometimes not getting home for months at a time. ``I go into a neighborhood and all the people want to see it. They've never seen a truck like this one before,'' he said. It has a fax machine, phone and modem, computer with dual disk drives, printer, microwave, sink with hot and cold water, portable toilet, built in alarm clock, television and VCR with wireless remote. The central vacuuming system is ``really slick,'' he said. He also has a 5-kilowatt generator ``so even when it's 20 below you can stay nice and warm without idling the engine,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Simmons Named AP Bureau Chief in Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: Bill Simmons, state capitol reporter for The Associated Press in Little Rock, Ark., for nearly 20 years, has been named chief of bureau for Arkansas by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. Simmons, 48, succeeds Kristin Gazlay, who has been named special projects editor at AP's New York headquarters. The changes take effect Jan. 22. Simmons, a North Little Rock native, attended Little Rock University and worked for the Arkansas Gazette as a copy boy and sports writer. He joined AP in 1962, transferred to Detroit for two years, and returned to Little Rock in 1968, where he served as news editor. He has covered the state capitol regularly since 1970, including the administrations of five governors. Gazlay, 31, has been bureau chief in Little Rock since 1987. She spent four years as news editor and assistant chief of bureau in Dallas and was correspondent in San Antonio for a year. She is a graduate of Southern Methodist University and joined the AP in Dallas in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Stables Now a Mental Hospital for Dissidents, the Insane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thurday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Behind rows of ornate houses in this village southeast of Bucharest stands a snowbound collection of former stables that dictator Nicolae Ceausescu turned into a frigid warehouse for the insane. A staff member and others say security police used to round up dissidents and ``undesirables'' and detain them at this mental hospital for weeks during political events, such as the visit of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1987. The dissidents, alcoholics, and homeless people _ the undesirables of Ceausescu's ``Golden Era'' for Romania _ are gone after Ceausescu's ouster in popular revolution and execution Dec. 25. But 140 people suffering from mental illness still huddle against the cold inside the drafty building. ``The conditions are terrible,'' said Stefana Dancu, one of two pyschiatric nurses. ``This is a dirty, isolated and unhealthy place.'' In the women's section, 90 women share 70 beds, she said. While all 50 male patients have their own bed, they must share a single bathroom. The wards are rows of tightly packed hospital-white beds set on bare unvarnished wooden floors in dim, narrow, drafty and barely heated rooms. Many of the patients spend their days on their beds, fully dressed and wrapped in coarse, heavy olive-drab wool blankets. ``The patients can have a bath once a week if there is any hot water,'' said Ms. Dancu. In the morning they have tea and bread or biscuits. In the evening there is cabbage and potatoes or beans and horrible black coffee. ``There is never any meat,'' said Ms. Dancu. ``There are fresh vegetables only in the summer. The only fruit is small apples that we have only sometimes.'' ``Until 15 years ago this was a stable,'' she said, adding that she does not know why it was transformed into a hospital for the insane. A decision on its future has been put off until after a reorganization at the main psychiatric hospital in Bucharest, 18 miles away, she said. Healthy dissidents and ``undesirables,'' brought to the hospital by the militia, suffered alongside the mentally ill, Ms. Dancu said. They were admitted during Communist Party congresses and major political events, with many drugged despite not being ill, she said. When the event ended, the doctor would say the treatment was over, Ms. Dancu added. Dr. Marin Stancu, the only psychiatrist assigned to the asylum, said the militia brought 153 patients there in 1987, 62 in 1988 and 45 in 1989. But he insisted all of those people suffered from some mental illness. ``There were no healthy people here,'' he insisted. Another pyschiatrist and a police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were told dissidents were brought to the asylum in Cula. But they said the could not show any proof. Reporters were not allowed to look at hospital records to try to trace former patients. Stancu said the militia would bring people to the hospital with a card that said they were being admitted ``for diagnosis or for disturbing the public order.'' ``Ceausescu didn't like to see these people on the streets,'' said Stancu. ``They were unemployed people and gypsies and infirmed people,'' he added while continuing to insist that they were also mentally ill. ``Most of those people were brought here because they wanted to leave the country,'' said Ms. Dancu, who said she was assigned to work in the asylum more than three years ago after applying for permission to emigrate to Canada. Stancu and the nurse said the patients brought in by the militia were designated M-313, a code they said referred to the decree that allowed the militia to a bring people to a mental hospital. When Ms. Dancu was asked if she thought Stancu should be a doctor, she said: ``No.'' ``For this job you have to feel,'' she said. Stancu remained silent when he was asked if he ever complained that the militia could just bring patients to the asylum. When asked why he didn't refuse to accept such patients he replied: ``I did my job as a doctor and I treated them like people. I couldn't refuse because they were sick people.''

DOC.HEAD: Richard Wagner's Great-Grandson Seeks to Improve Composer's Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The music of German composer Richard Wagner, a self-declared anti-Semite whose operas blared over loudspeakers in Nazi death camps, is taboo in Israel. But Gottfried Wagner maintains that his great-grandfather's music was exploited by the Nazis, and he is touring the Jewish state to rectify what he calls the distorted image of the 19th century composer. ``Wagner's message was exactly the opposite of what the Nazis stood for,'' said the 42-year-old musicologist. He added, however, that he empathized with Jews who responded to the music with anguish and anger. ``I understand completely if Israelis reject Wagner,'' he said in an interview. ``Many Jews went to their deaths in the camps while having to listen to his music.'' His campaign, including media interviews and a university lecture series, has renewed debate on whether to rescind the unofficial boycott which has kept Wagner's operas off Israel's airwaves. In the past, all efforts to break the boycott have been met with stormy protest, although many Israelis say they listen to Wagner at home. When after a 1981 Israel Philharmonic Orchestra concert, conductor Zubin Mehta announced as an encore the prelude to the Wagner opera ``Tristan and Isolde,'' the audience cied ``Shame!'' An usher rushed to the stage, pulled up his shirt to show Nazi-inflicted scars and shouted, ``Play Wagner on my body!'' Avi Shoshani, the orchestra's general secretary, said Wednesday he regretted that Wagner's music was still off-limits. ``It's a big loss. Our orchestra would have played it magnificently. It's a whole important segment in the history of music we are not touching,'' Shoshani said. But Menahem Fogel, a spokesman for the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem, said Wagner should not be played as long Holocaust survivors are alive. ``One has to consider the sensitivities of the people who lived through that period,'' he said. Shai Burstyn, head of the musicology department at Tel Aviv University, said Richard Wagner held anti-Semitic views, although they should be seen in the context of the times. ``I'm separating between the man and his music,'' said Burstyn, whose department sponsored the lecture series. ``There was hardly a 19th century composer who was not an anti-Semite.'' In an 1850 pamphlet, titled ``The Jew in Music,'' Richard Wagner railed against what he considered the undue influence of Jews in Germany's music circles. ``The pamphlet is shameful, but you can't draw a straight line from this to Auschwitz,'' Gottfried Wagner said. He said his great-grandfather was an ambitious man, who lashed out because he felt the music establishment was withholding recognition of his achievements. Despite the prejudice expressed in the pamphlet, the central message of his work, especially of the operatic cycle ``The Ring of the Nibelung,'' is one of hope, Wagner said. ``He felt that men have to choose between love and destruction. He hoped that future generations would learn from the mistakes of the past and opt for love, not destruction,'' Wagner said. This message was perverted when Hitler came to power 50 years after the composer's death, Wagner said. Hitler befriended Winifred Wagner, Gottfried's grandmother and a driving force at the Bayreuth Festival of Wagnerian music during the Third Reich. The Nazi dictator and the Wagner clan subsequently turned the composer's operatic protagonists, anti-heroes who always met tragic ends, into ``blond Aryan monsters,'' he said. Wagner said he distanced himself from the family early on. He conducted research on German Jewish culture and wrote a doctoral dissertation on German Jewish composer Kurt Weill. Wagner, who lives in Cerro Maggiore, Italy, and also works as a stage and TV director, said he came to Israel to begin a dialogue about his great-grandfather. However, he said, a matter-of-fact discussion about the composer might only be possible in another 20 years. In the meantime, he said, he was not pushing too hard for an end of the Wagner ban. ``This is up to the Israelis, especially the victims of the Holocaust.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Military Leaders to Meet With Other Nations
DOC.TEXT: A possible split in the Kremlin's military alliance will be on the agenda Tuesday when top military officers from the United States, Soviet Union and 33 other nations hold a first-of-a-kind meeting in Vienna. U.S. delegates, headed by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will press their Soviet counterparts to explain what one American official called ``discrepancies'' between Soviet military doctrine and deployment and production levels. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has proclaimed a doctrine of ``reasonable sufficiency'' based on a more defensive posture, declaring unilateral troop cuts and a willingness to conclude a multinational agreement to reduce conventional armies in Europe this year. But Gorbachev's words and deeds have been outstripped by the political revolution sweeping Eastern Europe and the demands of some of the new non-communist governments. U.S. analysts say more changes are inevitable in the Warsaw Pact alliance. ``No one could have foreseen the dramatic events which have swept over Eastern Europe during the past 12 months,'' said a statement issued by John J. Maresca, chairman of the U.S. delegation to the conference, entitled ``Confidence and Security Building Measures in Europe.'' ``Many of the political and security relationships which have become so familiar over the last four decades are being challenged in new ways every day, and it has become increasingly difficult to anticipate events,'' Maresca said. A senior U.S. official, briefing reporters, said the Eastern European countries ``are expressing very different views.'' Warsaw Pact ``discipline isn't what it used to be.'' ``Given the changes in Eastern Europe, this (conference) has taken on great significance.'' But ``we can't guarantee any dramatic results'' from the seminar, said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be further identified. Powell and his Soviet counterpart, Chief of Staff Mikhail A. Moiseyev, will stay in Vienna for the first few days of the three-week seminar, officials said. The session will mark the first time that top military officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, plus the neutral and non-aligned states of Europe, will sit down to discuss their intentions, plans and arsenals, U.S. officials said. ``We view the seminar itself as a confidence-building measure,'' said the senior official. U.S. delegates also have some pointed questions about Soviet troop deployments and production, he said. ``Until very recently, Soviet production of tanks remained the same, even higher'' than it was before Gorbachev declared unilateral troop reductions and a new military doctrine, the official said. Tank production has since declined, however, and the official said other questionable areas included ``supply of fuel oils and munition stocks stationed on the frontier.'' Pressed for specifics, the official would say only, ``in some cases they haven't changed. Let's leave it at that.'' The military seminar starts a month before Secretary of State James A. Baker III travels to Ottawa, Canada, for a discussion among the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations on President Bush's ``open skies'' proposal for sanctioned spy plane missions across other nations. The senior U.S. official said there was no direct tie between the military seminar and the ``open skies'' meeting, although the official said the two subjects ``mesh.''

DOC.HEAD: After the Iron Curtain's Fall, Do the People Know How to Rule?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, who is vacationing; Powel in 1st and 24th grafs is correct. Also moved in advance as b0265. ^An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: When the authors of the Constitution finished work in Philadelphia in 1787, a Mrs. Powel called out to Benjamin Franklin: ``Well, doctor, what have we got _ a republic or a monarchy?'' ``A republic, if you can keep it,'' Franklin replied. Now the people of Eastern Europe, having overthrown their despots in the revolutions of 1989, can also ask, ``What have we got?'' For the first time in nearly half a century, they've got the opportunity to establish self-government and its economic counterpart, capitalism. But can they keep it? Do they know how these institutions work after decades of one-party government and state-run economies? Is the drive toward self-government and a free-market system instinctive or must it be learned? Both are based on harnessed self-interest (or, some might say, on greed.) Sounds natural. But even if people grasp the rudiments, some experts think that building the structures to allow democracy and capitalism to function is going to take a struggle, take years and carry risks _ including the risk that in overthrowing communism the people could yet embrace fascism, with its father-figure appeal. ``People want liberty naturally, but the working out of institutions is a very complicated process,'' says Richard Pipes, professor of Russian history at Harvard and a former adviser on Eastern Europe in Ronald Reagan's White House. ``The Russians in 1917 were wild for liberty and democracy, but it collapsed in a matter of months because they didn't have the traditions, the institutions,'' he says. ``In some countries of Eastern Europe some traditions of democracy survive _ in Czechoslovakia and to a lesser extent Poland and Hungary and maybe East Germany. There wouldn't be much in Romania or Bulgaria.'' On the other hand, says Pipes, it is only normal for people to want to run their own lives. To test that theory, think of the opposite, he says: Who would opt for slavery? Robert Conquest, a specialist on the Soviet Union at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University, suspects East Europe's economic rebirth will be more troublesome than its political renewal. In politics, he says, ``they can go back to their old constitutions,'' but on the economic front ``they're stuck with these apparatuses of uselessness.'' In a system that guaranteed a job to everyone, no one worked hard. Postwar Germany had no trouble adapting to democracy. Konrad Adenauer, first chancellor of West Germany, knew how it worked, Conquest notes. ``He had been mayor of Cologne before Hitler.'' Government Professor Harvey Mansfield Jr. of Harvard worries that fascism could beckon if democracy founders in East Europe. Democracy, he says, concerns itself with ``petty questions _ survival and comfort and not something higher'' while in the prewar years ``fascism gave the promise of something higher _ the regeneration of the human race by getting rid of weaklings. There was an idealism in fascism that one shouldn't underestimate.'' Conquest doubts fascism's likely appeal. In East Europe, he says, ``I think the attraction of democratic liberty is very, very great. They have a higher opinion of the West than the West does.'' Economist Murray Weidenbaum, who served on a mission to survey Poland's economy for President Bush, thinks that while all people ``have the entrepreneurial profit-seeking instinct,'' that doesn't mean capitalism will catch hold easily. ``They have to learn business infrastructure, like cost accounting, contract law, preparation of financial statements _ that isn't instinctive.'' Nobel Prize economist Paul A. Samuelson of MIT agrees. ``The market structure is a very channeled form of greed,'' he says. ``If people insist on putting sand in sugar or if people blandly borrow $1,000 one hour and declare bankruptcy the next, that makes a market system that works very badly.'' Adds Weidenbaum: ``The Poles see the benefits of capitalism but don't see the costs. That's one of the concerns I have. I don't know if they realize that capitalism is not a profit system but a profit-or-loss system. In the best of times, thousands of companies go broke.'' Similarly, Mansfield worries that East Europeans could botch the construction of democratic structures. France, he notes, had to try out four republics before coming around to its present Fifth Republic, which seems to be working. Even in 1787, when Benjamin Franklin answered Mrs. Powel's question, the Constitution represented a second attempt. The Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union of 1781 had been a flop. And, notes Pipes, ``the people who founded this republic were English in their culture, which had overthrown despotism and experienced revolution. We were the beneficiaries of that.'' On the other hand, he says, East Europeans ``are so fed up with depotism of any kind, right or left, that you're going to se a tremendous desire for democracy and capitalism.''
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has been covering democracy in
DOC.TEXT: Washington for 21 years.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Say Job Stress Affects Health, Personal Relationships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 1 p.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: About half of Americans say job stress affects their health, personal relationships or their ability to do their job, according to a Gallup poll released today. The poll also found less than half, or 41 percent, of the nation's workers are on a career or job path they had planned. The rest have their jobs due to chance, were influenced by family or friends or took the only job they could find. The survey of 1,350 people was conducted for the National Occupational Information Coordinating Committee, a panel Congress created to make better use of job information. The poll, which asked a variety of job-related questions, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Other findings showed nearly one-third of the work force expects to change jobs within the next three years and that 65 percent said that given a chance to start over, they would try to get more information about career options. Of employed adults who responded, 25 percent said job stress or pressure had interfered with their off-the-job relationships, 20 percent said it had affected their physical health and 20 percent said it had affected their ability to do their job. But responding to the same question, 48 percent reported little or no job stress over the past year. The totals exceeded 100 percent because of multiple responses. Sharon Dannan, research director at the Cleveland-based 9 to 5, National Association of Working Women, said more Americans are probably suffering from job-related stress than admit it. ``There's lots of people who probably don't realize that's what it is, that their job is full of interruptions, or that they have multiple bosses telling them it's priority work, and that it's driving them nuts,'' she said. The poll showed that 41 percent of the employed respondents consciously chose their career path; 18 percent got started through chance circumstances; 12 percent took the only job available; and the rest were either influenced by friends or relatives. Juliette Lester, executive director of the committee, said the results showing fewer than half of Americans are on planned job paths demonstrates the need for government and job counselors to improve the way they educate the public about careers. The poll also showed 40 percent said higher pay would give them an incentive to accomplish more at work; 31 percent cited more recognition. Other incentives included additional training, chance for advancement and more control over their job.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Interest in Panama High, China Low
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 8 a.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's secret diplomacy with China is still a secret to many Americans, according to a survey of public interest in the news released today. The Times Mirror News Interest Index for January showed only 6 percent of those polled said they followed ``very closely'' news of a December visit to China by two top administration officials. Another 18 percent said they followed the story fairly closely. Leading the public interest's in December was the U.S. invasion of Panama, which the survey said was followed closely by 60 percent of readers. That made it the fourth most closely followed news event since Times Mirror began the measurements in 1986. News of the bloody revolution in Romania was followed very attentively only by 28 percent of those responding. Even among the groups usually most interested in foreign affairs, interest in the China story was relatively slack, with 35 percent of those over 50 years old and 33 percent of college graduates saying they paid close attention. That contrasts sharply with the interest shown in developments in China earlier in the year. The midsummer Times Mirror survey found 47 percent of those polled showed sharp interest in developments in China, including the violent crackdown on massive pro-democracy demonstrations. Bush sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to China in December to lay the groundwork for normalizing relations again in the wake of the Beijing regime's June move against demonstrators. The mission was announced after Scowcroft and Eagleburger arrived in the Chinese capital. Later, it was disclosed Scowcroft had traveled to Beijing barely a month after the Tiananmen Square crackdown. The missions brought sharp criticism from some in both parties who said the president's conciliatory approach didn't match harshness of China's brutal crackdown. Among those under 30, only 3 percent said they followed the controversy very closely. Among non-whites, the proportion was 9 percent. The Panama story has been exceeded in public interest as measured by the survey only by the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, last October's San Francisco earthquake and the rescue in 1987 of Jessica McClure from a Texas well. The earthquake was followed closely by nearly three-quarters of those surveyed in early November, making it the most closely watched news story of the year, according to the poll. Earlier in 1989, Hurricane Hugo's devastation of Caribbean islands and the Carolinas was followed closely by 60 percent of those surveyed. The top interest the survey found in a Washington story last year was the summer's controversy over flag burning, which was followed closely by 51 percent. The Supreme Court's ruling giving states greater power to regulate abortion was followed closely by 47 percent. Asked what most interested them most in the Panama story, most of those interviewed said it was the effort to take Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega into custody. The survey results indicated the ongoing political changes in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary drew close attention from 29 percent of those polled, 1 percentage point more than the events in Romania. Fifty-six percent said they believed the invasion of Panama was the most important thing to happen last month. Political change in East Bloc countries in general was cited by 18 percent and the revolution in Romania specifically by 5 percent. Asked to recall people in the news, 76 percent came up with the name of Noriega. He was followed by Bush with 58 percent. Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev was named by 16 percent and the late Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu by 12 percent. The latest survey results are based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 4-7 by the Gallup Organization under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates among 1,207 adults, 18 or older. The Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, which sponsors the survey, said it is subject to sampling and other random errors of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leaders Say Yonkers Decision May Have Limited Impact
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court ruling that let public officials escape fines for defying a federal judge's order to end racial discrimination is regrettable but may have limited impact, civil rights leaders say. ``I think the decision is more significant as a political symbol than legally,'' said Steven Shapiro, a lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union. ``It will be perceived as a further step away from the court's commitment to civil rights.'' The high court split 5-4 Wednesday in overturning fines against four Yonkers, N.Y., councilmen who blocked a housing desegregation plan. ``We do not regard this as a particularly injurious decision as the Supreme Court also let stand the ability of a lower court to fine a city that chooses to defy its orders,'' said Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP. Ralph Neas, head of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, said the ruling is ``regrettable'' but ``does not appear to be a measurable cutback in civil rights law.'' Shapiro noted that the high court handed civil rights forces a series of defeats in 1989 when it limited affirmative action, made it tougher to prove job discrimination and restricted remedies for on-the-job racial harassment. Those decisions touched off angry protests by civil rights leaders. The Yonkers councilmen, one of them now mayor, celebrated the decision with champagne. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said the judge who imposed the fines exceeded his authority. The judge should have waited to see whether potentially bankrupting penalties against the city would force adoption of the desegregation plan before even considering fining the councilmen, Rehnquist said. Justice William J. Brennan, in a dissenting opinion, lamented that the ruling may encourage defiant public officials in other bias cases. He said the majority was ``blind to the scourge of racism in Yonkers.'' In other action Wednesday, the court: _Ruled 5-4 in an Illinois case that statements a criminal defendant makes after an unlawful arrest may not be used by prosecutors to contradict a defense witness' trial testimony. _Unanimously limited the ability of multinational corporations to challenge state taxes in federal court. In the Yonkers case, Rehnquist noted the court previously left intact fines against the city. ``There can be no question about the liability of the city of Yonkers for racial discrimination,'' he said. Brennan wrote: ``I worry that the court's message will have the unintended effect of emboldening recalcitrant officials continually to test the ultimate reach of the remedial authority of the federal courts.'' The ruling will not be the last word this year from the court on the powers of federal judges to combat segregation. In a case from Kansas City, Mo., that is expected to be decided by July, the court is studying a judge's order to increase property taxes to help pay for desegregating that city's schools. The Yonkers case attracted national attention in the summer of 1988 as the defiant councilmen were threatened with jail as well as fines, and the city faced possible bankruptcy for refusing to obey U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand's desegregation orders. Faced with massive layoffs of city workers, the city council reversed itself and on Sept. 10, 1988, voted to comply with Sand's order to build 1,000 low-cost omes to desegregate middle-class areas of the city just north of New York City. But Yonkers still had to pay $819,000 in contempt fines. Fines of $3,500 against each of the four councilmen will be returned to them. The Yonkers case stems from a Justice Department lawsuit begun by the Carter administration in its waning days in 1980. The Bush administration has said Sand acted properly in fining the councilmen as well as the city. The four councilmen were Edward Fagan, Nicholas V. Longo, Peter Chema and Henry Spallone. ``One thing is certain: We used the American court system and the American court system made the determination that a federal judge overstepped his power,'' Spallone, now mayor, said after the ruling. ``I don't think it's the end. I think it's the beginning.'' Joining Rehnquist in the majority opinion were Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Brennan was joined in his dissent by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Fear Cash Grain Farmers May Lose Income
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Department analysts say many farmers who depend on selling grain crops for cash could be in serious financial trouble this year, despite a general improvement in the nation's agricultural sector. ``Right now, the farms that we're most concerned about, in terms of their ability to prosper, are the traditional cash grain farmers, wheat and corn producers in particular,'' said Gregory Hanson of the department's Economic Research Service. Corn producers, perhaps more than others, are in jeopardy from possible low market prices later this year, Hanson said Wednesday in a telephone interview. Within the USDA agency, analysts are ``projecting corn prices down about 50 cents a bushel between the second quarter of 1990 and the fourth quarter'' when the harvests come into the market, he said. That is assuming that crops will have good weather and that per-acre yields will continue their upward trend. ``If that should happen while the farm debate (in Congress) is in high gear, that could have an impact in itself,'' Hanson said. The USDA says its recent five-day average shows corn prices at $2.24 per bushel. The analysts project prices could drop to about $1.74 per bushel by fall. New farm legislation is in the works to replace the 1985 farm law, which reduced federal price support and target price benefits on major commodities. Hanson was asked to elaborate on a comment in the January issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. The report said: ``If the 1990 farm bill continues to lower target prices in the spirit of the 1985 farm bill, government payments could continue falling and impose financial strains on vulnerable operators in the years to come.'' According to USDA's forecasts, net cash income ``will likely exceed $50 billion for the fourth consecutive year'' in 1990, up 2 percent to 4 percent from 1989. That is simply money left over from gross cash income after paying cash expenses. However, another method shows that net farm income _ which take into account changes in inventory values, depreciation and other items during a calendar year _ may drop 2 percent to 5 percent from $48 billion in 1989. As an example of the impact of lowering target prices, Hanson said that under the 1985 farm law the target price for corn was reduced each year by about 10 cents per bushel. The purpose of the target price system is to provide income protection for farmers. If market prices average below the target, direct payments are made to help make up the difference. Costs of direct subsidies rose to $16.7 billion in 1987 before dropping to $14.5 billion in 1988 and about $11 billion in 1989. According to USDA projections the payments may be in the range of $8 billion to $11 billion in 1990. Hanson said the 1988 drought, by driving prices up substantially, to some extent ``obscured the impact'' of the downgrading of target prices and other changes allowed by the 1985 law. ``But now, we're saying that net farm income is likely to fall 2 to 5 percent in 1990. Had government payments stayed level _ or had those declines in target prices not occurred _ net farm income would be up, I'm sure, in 1990,'' he said. ``It's definitely having an impact, there's no question about it.'' The administration is seeking greater flexibility in 1990 farm legislation to give farmers greater planting choices. Negotiations under the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade also are aimed at freer global trade policies and more export access for U.S. farm products. Even so, as President Bush told the American Farm Bureau Federation earlier this week in Florida, the administration promises to ``maintain a safety net to protect farmers from conditions beyond their control.'' Hanson said the farm bill debate has many complicated dimensions. Some argue that since farm income is so high and the financial crisis of the early 1980s is over, there is no need for federal programs to protect farmers. ``On the other hand, people say direct payments have already fallen from $17 billion in 1987 to maybe as low as $9 billion in 1990 and that farmers have already taken their hit,'' he said. Another side is represented by the Office of Management and Budget, where White House budget cutters are seeking ways to reduce the government's spending deficit. Putting the squeeze on farm programs is one of the ways. ``So you not only have non-farm legislators wondering whether this transfer (subsidy) program make any sense, but you have OMB trying to wield their knives,'' Hanson said. Meanwhile, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter _ and his predecessors for many years _ have been talking long and hard about the benefits of freer trade and the importance of the Uruguay Round of GATT talks that will conclude at the end of this year. ``That is having an effect,'' Hanson said. ``You can sense it. On the other hand, one of the things learned in the 1980s _ and brought home by the drought _ is that farm production and farm prices remain highly unstable, they vary greatly from year to year.'' Thus, he added, ``It's just comforting, if you're a producer, to know that the government is there to help redress some of those down cycles.''

DOC.HEAD: Nine S&Ls On Sale Today
DOC.TEXT: Arizona's largest thrift and eight other savings associations are being offered for sale today by the government agency created to manage President Bush's savings and loan bailout. The institutions, under the control of the Resolution Trust Corp., are in seven states and hold assets totaling $13.5 billion. The biggest is Western Savings and Loan Association of Phoenix, a victim of the collapse in Arizona real estate prices. Western was seized by regulators June 15. On Sept. 30, it had $5.83 billion in assets and $4.43 million in 426,137 deposit accounts. At the time of its takeover, Western was the 38th largest S&L in the nation. The nine S&Ls being sold are advertised in today's Wall Street Journal, RTC spokesman Stephen J. Katsanos said Wednesday. The other institutions and their total assets as of Sept. 30 are: _Horizon Federal Savings and Loan Association, Southampton, Pa., $2.22 billion. _Gill Savings Association, Hondo, Texas, $1.25 billion. _American Federal Savings and Loan Association, Colorado Springs, Colo., $880 million. _Bexar Savings Association, San Antonio, Texas, $820 million. _Blue Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Kansas City, Mo., $788 million. _Anchor Federal Savings and Loan Association, Kansas City, Kan., $748 million. _Royal Palm Federal Savings and Loan Association, West Palm Beach, Fla., $535 million. _Otero Savings, Colorado Springs, Colo., $482 million. Also, about 40 other thrifts will be put on the auction block next week, each with assets of less than $500 million, Katsanos said. Since its creation in August, the RTC has sold 37 bankrupt S&Ls, with $10 billion in assets, leaving 285 with $105 billion in assets still in its charge. It expects to take over another 200 in coming months. Earlier, the agency invited bids on 18 S&Ls, with assets totaling $13 billion, and expects to complete the sales within several weeks, Katsanos said. The RTC hopes to close the sales of the nine to be offered today and the 40 to be offered next week early in the April-June quarter. If all goes as planned, that would bring the count of institutions handled to about 104. The sale announcement came as pressure mounts on the agency to speed up the pace of rescues. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., who heads a House task force overseeing the bailout, has criticized the administration for failing to move faster. Katsanos said the sale of S&Ls being offered today and next week have been planned for several months. ``We have been moving these as expeditiously as can be done,'' he said. He warned that when the latest batch of sales is finished, the RTC will face a cash crunch unless the Bush administration and Congress agree on a plan to raise $50 billion to $100 billion in additional financing. Under the original $50 billion bailout plan, the RTC has received $24 billion and will get another $4 billion to $5 billion from a debt sale scheduled Jan. 23. However, the administration says the agency needs an additional $50 billion to $100 billion in working capital that later would be repaid by selling assets from the bankrupt S&Ls.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Ordered to Double Reserves on Argentine Loans
DOC.TEXT: Federal banking agencies are ordering the nation's largest banks to more than double reserves set aside for anticipated losses on loans to economically troubled Argentina. The order, expected to depress industry earnings in the fourth quarter, requires banks to hold reserves of at least 35 percent of the loan amount, up from 15 percent, said a Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. official who spoke Wednesday on condition of anonymity. It is unclear how the decision will affect individual banks. Some likely already have loss reserves large enough to cover 35 percent of their loans to Argentina. But others, such as Citicorp and BankAmerica Corp. of San Francisco, have proportionately smaller loss reserves for Third World debt than competitors. Jim Mitchell, a spokesman for BankAmerica Corp., said the bank was aware of the new reserve requirement but declined to say what the effect would be on his institution. ``A discussion of our LDC (less developed country) reserve coverage and related issues will be a routine part of our (fourth-quarter) earnings announcement, which we expect to make next week,'' he said. BankAmerica Corp.'s stock was unchanged Wednesday at $27.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices fell for the shares of several other large banks. Chase Manhattan closed at $31.50, down 37{ cents; Chemical Bank, $30.12{, down 12{ cents; Citicorp, $27, down 25 cents; and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, $32.25, down $1. In the third quarter, the nation's 12,800 commercial banks collectively recorded a $744 million loss, the first in two years. The industry was pushed into the red by $5.3 billion in Third World debt losses at five large banks. The decision on Argentina loans likely will produce another disappointing report for the fourth quarter. It stems from a recommendation from the Interagency Country Review Committee, which coordinates Third World lending matters among banking agencies, including the FDIC, the Federal Reserve Board and the Comptroller of the Currency. The committee customarily does not announce its decisions. Argentina, which owed $6.2 billion to U.S. banks at the end of September, is Latin America's fourth-largest debtor to U.S. financial institutions. The three largest debtors are: Brazil, which owes them $19.1 billion; Mexico, $15.7 billion; and Venezuela, $6.9 billion. Mexico has scrupulously kept up its payments, but both Brazil and Argentina are in arrears. Argentina's economy has deteriorated sharply recently, beset by hyperinflation. Its currency, the austral, has lost 99 percent of its value over the past year. On Monday, prices of the leading stocks on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged 53 percent after the exchange was closed for more than a week.

DOC.HEAD: Latin American Debts Drop to US Banks
DOC.TEXT: Latin American countries are cutting into their debt to U.S. banks even as the nations' debt to the rest of the world increases, according to a government report. The debt of Latin American countries to U.S. banks declined by some $2.4 billion in the three months ending in September 1989, falling to $48.3 billion, the Federal Reserve reported Wednesday. Though Latin American debt to the world has been rising steadily, banks in the United States have been accepting repayments and new lending has not kept up with the payments. In September 1984, five years before the period of the new report, Latin nations owed U.S. banks just less than $74 billion, the report noted. But since then, the total owed to U.S. banks by Brazil, the Third World's biggest debtor, has fallen from about $24.6 billion to $19.1 billion. Mexico owed some $25.9 billion five years ago. By last September, Mexico's debt was down to $15.7 billion. Mexico has kept scrupulously up with its interest payments despite falling wages and living standards. The debt has also been reduced by what are called ``debt-equity'' swaps. Debts to U.S. banks are due in dollars. Sometimes debtor governments will allow the banks to take payment in their own currency and use the money to buy local industry. Chile has used this device extensively. Other debtor governments are less enthusiastic, both because they dislike seeing foreigners own more of their countries' assets and because such deals add to the local currency in circulation, boosting inflation. Runaway prices are a problem in Brazil and Argentina. There have also been reductions in the amount owed to American banks by troubled debtors outside Latin America. The Federal Reserve said Nigeria cut its American bank debt from about $1.5 billion to $486 million over five years. The Philippines' total was down from $5.1 billion to $3.2 billion. So far, there has been no reduction as a result of the strategy announced last March by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. An agreement announced in October on Costa Rica is expected to reduce its $4.5 billion debt by $1 billion. A bigger deal for Mexico has not been completed. According to the World Bank, Latin American debt has risen worldwide _ including debts to the World Bank _ from $377 billion in 1984 to $434 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors' Diagnosis: Sloppy City Needs Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: A cleanup was prescribed and then administered by doctors who said city residents were collectively down in the dumps because of its litter. Dr. Ben Singletary said the two or three dozen doctors who collected 3,800 pounds of trash in November along Interstate 20 plan another pickup Jan. 20 because ``today, it looks like a hog pen.'' The Shreveport Medical Society decided a year ago that the city's slovenly appearance was psychologically harmful because it was a constant reminder of hard economic times, said Singletary, president of the society. ``About this time last year we began looking at our city and surrounding area,'' Singletary said Tuesday. ``What is wrong? We knew we were economically depressed. ``Finally, after weeks of looking at this we came up with the conclusion that we're all emotionally depressed, a little whipped down, a whipped dog.'' In addition to the trash pickup, Singletary said, the society plans to raise an 11-flag display at six entrances into the city limits, plant crape myrtles along the highway and make sure the grass stays mowed.

DOC.HEAD: Special Bicycle for Girl Who Can't Walk
DOC.TEXT: Not all of Santa's toy makers work at the North Pole. Some work in a place called Spring Lake. At least that's how Greg and Helen Garvey regard their co-workers at Weber Precision Grinding Co. who built a special tricycle for their daughter. Three-year-old Kandi Garvey was born with spina bifida and can't walk. On Christmas, she Kandi found the maroon tricycle, its pedals operated by the hands instead of the feet, under the tree. ``She had all kinds of presents, dolls and books and toys, but it was the tricycle that caught her eye,'' Mrs. Garvey said. ``She said `Mom, Santa brought me a bike,' and she wanted to get on it right away.'' Ken Sutton took the lead in rebuilding a standard tricycle during his breaks at Weber. ``Basically, I took the pedals off the wheels and put them on the handlebars,'' he said. ``It was pretty easy.''

DOC.HEAD: Female Soldiers Eligible for Decorations, not Infantry Badge
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon will consider women who fought in Panama for several decorations honoring valor but not for the Combat Infantryman Badge. None of several hundred women who served in the Panama operation serve in infantry units, a requirement to be considered for the Combat Infantryman Badge, Army spokesman, Maj. Joe Padilla, said Wednesday. ``They will be eligible for decorations and awards for valor _ the Bronze Star, Silver Star, Distinguished Service Cross, and the Medal of Honor,'' Padilla said. But the major said, ``A person has to see action and has to be a member of an infantry unit'' to be eligible for the Combat Infantryman Badge. About 9,000 of the 26,000 troops involved in the invasion were in the infantry, Padilla said, but not all will receive the Combat Infantryman Badge. Under Army policy, women are excluded from military specialties, such as the infantry, that are deemed combat-related. The issue has drawn attention in light of the actions of Capt. Linda Bray, who commanded the 988th Military Police Company when it seized the Panamanian Defense Forces canine unit during the Dec. 20 invasion. In that encounter, as well as others, female soldiers came under and returned fire. Padilla said it is up to the Army's chain of command to make decisions awarding medals and each case is reviewed individually.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner Says States, Public to Pay More Transportation Costs
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says it will propose shifting more of the cost of the nation's transportation system to state and local governments, individual users and the private sector. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said in a speech Wednesday that his department's blueprint for improving the country's highways, bridges, rail lines, airports and harbors proposes to ``move the action closer to the people.'' He said portions of the new strategy ``will be reflected in the administration's 1991 budget proposal and in a number of actions the Department of Transportation will be taking over the next few weeks and months.'' David Prosperi, a spokesman for Skinner, said details of the proposals will be released with the administration's budget request and President Bush's State of the Union address later this month. But Skinner was clear about the administration's intentions. ``First of all, we envision a stronger, healthier partnership among federal, state and local governments,'' Skinner said at an annual meeting of the Transportation Research Board, which acts as an independent adviser to the government. But having a less intrusive federal government would also mean shifting the financial burden, Skinner said. ``At the same time, a healthier partnership goes hand-in-hand with reduced dependence on federal money,'' he said. ``We believe federal recipients of federal transportation aid should pay a larger share of project costs.'' In addition, he said, ``We're going to be looking for new and creative ways to apply the time-tested user fee principle. ``We intend to recover from users the maximum practical share of costs they impose. This includes recovering federal costs from user groups that are now getting a free ride. We also want to make it easier for other levels of government to levy user fees for transportation improvements.'' A third strategy, he said, would ``stimulate more private investment in transportation'' such as toll roads. The five-point strategy also calls for regulatory changes, such as having railroad workers covered by workers' compensation, and promoting new technology and research and development. The Reagan administration had advocated such fees, but it was repeatedly rebuffed by Congress in efforts to impose user fees on recreational boaters and others who benefit from Coast Guard services. Administration officials have said they do not view the user fees as taxes so they would not violate the president's pledge of no new taxes. Last month, administration sources floated the idea of imposing fees on recreational vehicles and equipment to pay for conservation. Republican lawmakers have proposed letting local airports impose a departure fee, or ``head tax,'' to help pay for air transportation improvements. Airline passengers already pay an 8 percent federal ticket tax. On another subject, Skinner defended the department's ambitious air traffic modernization plan against calls by a private pilots' organization for a congressional investigation. The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association said Wednesday the National Airspace System plan is over budget and behind schedule and using outdated technology. Skinner said he is satisfied with the program and blames any problems on the unprecedented growth in air traffic. ``That system will not only allow us to enhance our capacity to handle it,'' Skinner said. ``It will develop the technology and expertise that American companies will sell all over the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Ferraro Considering Political Comeback
DOC.TEXT: Geraldine Ferraro, the first woman to win a slot on a major party's presidential ticket, says she's considering a political comeback. Ferraro, Walter Mondale's running mate on the 1984 Democratic ticket, is weighing a challenge to New York Republican Sen. Alfonse D'Amato. The former three-term congresswoman says she isn't worried that a political campaign would resurrect hurtful stories about her or her family. ``I don't think there's very much that the people of this state or this nation don't know about me or about my family,'' Ferraro said Wednesday in a telephone interview from New York. Ferraro was hounded by questions about her family's finances during the 1984 campaign. She later complained that her political fame hurt her family and led to harsher court treatment of her husband and son. Her husband, John Zaccaro, pleaded guilty in 1985 to a misdemeanor charge in a real estate deal. Her son, John Zaccaro Jr., later was convicted of selling a quarter-gram of cocaine while at Middlebury College in Vermont. ``I would love to back in Washington, I would love to be part of the decision-making process with reference to what's going on in this country,'' said Ferraro, 54, who lives in the New York City borough of Queens. A race against Rep. Thomas Manton, who holds Ferraro's former seat, is out of the question, she said. ``I endorsed him and he is a Democrat who represents my district very, very well.'' D'Amato's second term ends in 1992. Recent polls show his popularity is slipping, primarily because of reports that he used his influence to steer money from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to friends nd political supporters. The Senate ethics committee has hired an outside counsel to decide whether it should launch a full-scale investigation of D'Amato. Ferraro flirted with the idea of taking on D'Amato in 1986, but pulled back, citing personal reasons. Wednesday, Ferraro said she ruled out that Senate race because she feared the power of Attorney General Edwin Meese III. The Justice Department was investigating complaints that she had failed to fully disclose her husband's finances while she was in Congress. ``That investigation continued well past the campaign, nursed by people within the Justice Department, and I found out later that Ed Meese had personal interest in it and was tying it to my political decisions,'' she said. ``I did not doubt for one minute that he would use it politically against me.'' The 22-month investigation ended with the department deciding there was no basis for a criminal or civil action.

DOC.HEAD: United States Withholds Funds From U.N. Food Agency
DOC.TEXT: The United States, angry at a U.N. agriculture organization that supported the Palestine Liberation Organization, is sharply cutting its contribution to the body and may pull out altogether. The State Department announced Wednesday it would pay the ``$18 million necessary to retain our vote'' in the Food and Agriculture Organization, said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The United States was supposed to pay $61.4 million, or 25 percent of the agency's budget, in 1989. ``We will reassess our participation in the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization during 1990,'' Tutwiler said. The FAO's resolution last November, adopted by 96 members with 14 abstentions and only the United States and Israel opposing, called for the organization to provide Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories with assistance ``in close cooperation with the PLO.'' It also criticized Israel's ``confiscation of Palestinian land and the expropriation of Palestinian water resources.'' The United States argued the resolution was political and inconsistent with the organization's goal of providing agricultural assistance to developing nations. In Rome, an FAO official said the U.S. decision to cut funds was ``unfair and unjustified.'' The official, who asked not to be named, said the resolution ``doesn't say the FAO must work through the PLO'' and claimed the United States misunderstood the reasoning behind the adopted language. The United States issued several appeals and requests to the FAO last fall to modify the resolution, which was presented by Arab states, but U.S. officials complain their calls were largely ignored. The United States was also angered by the budget adopted at the meeting, which projected a 3 percent growth for 1990 and 1991, said a State Department official. The United States had sought a budget freeze pending reforms, the official said. The governing council also denied U.S. representative Dan Amstutz his right to chair the FAO council under a rotation system, compounding U.S. anger, the U.S. official said. The United States has clashed repeatedly with the United Nations and its affiliated agencies over their budgets and their support for the PLO. The United States is the member most in arrears to the U.N. Last October, it delivered a $65 million check to the organization, reducing its debt to $635 million. The debt began to accrue in 1985, when President Reagan withheld some dues from the U.N. to protest what he said was the body's anti-American bias, its overblown budget and inefficient administration. The United Nations did enact some reforms, but Congress last fall turned down the administration's request for an additional $46 million to pay some of the back dues.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Hears Safety Arguments on Children's Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: An Institute of Medicine panel is sorting through conflicting opinions on the safety of the vaccine that prevents whooping cough amid claims the government is wrongly downplaying the risks. The panel heard testimony Wednesday from medical and legal experts as part of a congressionally-required review of possible problems with the vaccine. Experts with the American Academy of Pediatrics told the review committee no scientific evidence proves the vaccine can cause brain damage or death, and if it does cause such effects, they are rare _ less than 1 in 300,000. But others said more than 1,000 reported cases of severe reaction to the vaccine should warrant caution and highlight the need for a safer vaccine, which they say is now available in other countries. The Institute of Medicine panel of 12 medical and public health experts was formed at the request of the Department of Health and Human Services to review information on possible problems from vaccines against pertussis, or whooping cough, and rubella, better known as German measles. Jeffrey H. Schwartz, a Washington lawyer who says his daughter's death from a seizure in 1984 was diagnosed as caused by the pertussis vaccine, charged the government is engaged in ``a conspiracy of silence and denial'' by withholding information about the danger of the vaccine. Government public health officials, in their zeal to promote mass immunizations to wipe out contagious diseases, are deliberately understating the severe side effects the pertussis vaccine can cause, said Schwartz. Schwartz spoke on behalf of Dissatisfied Parents Together, a nationwide group of parents whose children have been injured or killed by vaccines. His group was instrumental in pushing through the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act of 1986, which required the vaccine review and established a federal compensation program for families. The whooping cough vaccine is usually given with the vaccines for diphtheria and tetanus, which together are referred to as the DPT vaccine, to children in a series of four shots beginning at around 2 months. It is required by state laws for admission to school. ``We have not advocated that parents not get the vaccine,'' Schwartz said. ``But we are pushing for a safer vaccine'' and more caution in giving the vaccine to children who have a family history of seizures or have had a severe reaction to an earlier DPT shot. Dr. Stanley Plotkin, an official of the American Academy of Pediatrics and a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, said there is no scientific data that shows the pertussis vaccine causes severe neurological damage or death. However, the vaccine can bring to light or exacerbate pre-existing conditions, he said. He disputed contentions that a pertussis vaccine being used in Japan is safer and as effective as the one used in the United States. Applications to approve this vaccine are pending at the Food and Drug Administration. Plotkin also downplayed reports that arthritis may be associated with the rubella vaccine when given to adult women. He said that in about 25 percent of the cases, women have ``aches and pains'' but that the symptoms usually last only for a few days. ``We have no reason to believe it's anything more than that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: David Goerlitz, whose macho good looks earned him thousands as a model for Winston cigarettes, has turned on the tobacco industry's attempts to make smoking look pretty. He said his 3{-pack-a-day smoking habit led to a stroke. ``I was paid $2,500 a day to hang off this mountain to make (smoking) look rugged and make it look successful, make it look prosperous, make it look wonderful,'' the 40-year-old Goerlitz said Wednesday. ``All these ads are nothing more than mere lies.'' Goerlitz, the ``Winston man'' from 1981 to 1987, was the headliner for a forum on New York's new statewide smoking law, which took effect Jan. 1 and prohibits smoking in auditoriums, elevators, gymnasiums, food stores, shared taxicabs and limousines. Goerlitz showed several of the poster ads he made while a model for R.J. Reynolds, which makes Winstons. ``I'm not proud of this part of my life, folks,'' said Goerlitz. ``I'm not proud of who I am in these ads.'' Many school children were in the audience to hear his presentation. ``What you don't see is the man behind the myth ... being paid $75,000 to $100,000 a year to glamorize a product that I was addicted to for 23 years,'' he said. Goerlitz said the stroke has taken away feeling in his left leg and the left side of his face and has robbed him of his ability to taste food.

Yelena Bonner, widow of Soviet Nobel Peace Prize winner Andrei Sakharov, will speak at a peace forum organized by former Vice President Walter Mondale. Bonner and Sakharov, himself, confirmed their joint engagement at the 1990 Peace Prize Forum at Augsburg College on Dec. 11, just three days before he died, college officials said. The officials renewed the offer to Bonner last week, and she accepted. ``It is singularly appropriate that Dr. Bonner should participate in the forum,'' college president Charles Anderson said this week. ``Throughout her life, Dr. Bonner, like Dr. Sakharov, has passionately embraced the causes of peace and human rights.'' Augsburg officials were awaiting word on whether the Dalai Lama, the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner, will speak at the forum, scheduled for Feb. 17. Other speakers will include former President Carter; Peter Duffy, chairman of the executive committee of Amnesty International; Max Kampelman, former ambassador and arms negotiator and current chairman of Freedom House; Flora Lewis, foreign correspondent for The New York Times, and Geir Lundestad, executive director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute. The Peace Prize Forum, in its second year, is sponsored by the Norwegian Nobel Institute and five U.S. Midwestern liberal arts colleges founded by Norwegian immigrants.

Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca told about 130 first-graders that if they learn to read well they'll have friends for life _ books. ``The most important things you'll own are your books,'' Iacocca said Wednesday. ``You treat them like they're your treasures because they are.'' Iacocca spoke at the Danforth Magnet School during ceremonies to kick off Running Start, a new national reading program. Syracuse is one of 10 school districts around the country instituting the reading program. Reading is Fundamental, Inc. developed the three-year program with a $2.1 million grant from the Chrysler Corporation Fund. About 2,400 first-graders will participate in it in Syracuse. The program also will held in Highland Park, Mich.; Pontiac, Mich.; St. Louis; Huntsville, Ala.; Toledo, Ohio; Kokomo, Ind.; Savannah, Ga.; Phoenix, Ariz. and Newark, Del.

The former president of a local NAACP chapter filed a $10 million libel lawsuit against Arsenio Hall for the second time, accusing the talk show host of racist and obscene slurs. Willis Edwards, who recently resigned as president of the Beverly Hills-Hollywood chapter, also named Rolling Stone magazine as a defendant in Tuesday's lawsuit. Edwards said he was libeled and slandered when Hall described him in a Rolling Stone interview as a pimp and a phony. A spokeswoman for Hall did not return a telephone message seeking comment. John Jordan, a spokesman for Rolling Stone, said magazine officials had no knowledge of the lawsuit and would not comment. In January 1989, Edwards sued Hall for $10 million for libel after Hall allegedly told a radio interviewer that Edwards had tried to extort $40,000 from Hall to block publicity that Hall failed to hire black writers, directors or producers for his show. Edwards announced his resignation last month, on the night of the NAACP's Image Awards for black achievement in entertainment. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had opened an investigation into his alleged mismanagement of the chapter several days earlier.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Bryant Gumbel, anchor of NBC's ``Today'' show since 1982, will return to NBC Sports next weekend as host of its golf coverage. Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports and a senior vice president of NBC in charge of ``Today,'' said Gumbel would be host of at least six tournaments this year, replacing Vin Scully, who quit after seven years as network golf host. Gumbel started his television career in 1972 as a sportscaster with KNBC-TV in Los Angeles, moved to NBC Sports in 1975 and to ``Today'' in January 1982. ``For about 12 years now, golf has been my passion and I play golf as often as I can,'' Gumbel, who has a 13 handicap, said in a statement. Ebersol said Gumbel's golf tour activities would cause him to miss only three days of the ``Today'' show.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks to Soothe Colombian Anger With Call to Barco
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is seeking to personally soothe what an official called Colombia's ``political sensitivities'' that erupted in anger over reports the United States was planning an antidrug blockade off Colombia. Bush on Wednesday telephoned President Virgilio Barco to disavow intention of a blockade and ``to express regret over the recent misunderstanding'' caused by press reports about U.S. plans for antidrug efforts off South America, the White House said. Although officials earlier said plans were being set for what one Pentagon source called a ``virtual sea and air blockade'' of Colombia to interdict drugs, Bush denied that was the intention. ``The president assured President Barco that the U.S. never intended to conduct any activities within Colombian territorial waters, that no U.S. actions would be taken without the full cooperation and consent of the Colombian government, that no `blockade' was ever contemplated and that he had not authorized naval maneuvers, as incorrectly described in the press,'' according to a statement by White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk. Last week, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater confirmed the United States would undertake stepped-up interdiction efforts, but would not specifically comment on a blockade. The intensified controversy arose over the weekend when Colombian press reports said two Navy ships, the guided-missile cruiser USS Virginia and the aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy, were steaming toward Colombia to begin the blockade. Administration officials insisted those ships, which had sailed from Norfolk, Va., Thursday, were merely undertaking routine maneuvers in the Atlantic. They said Bush had not yet agreed to any increased interdiction plan and discussions were still pending with Colombia. One source said, however, the Kennedy was selected to lead the seaborne antidrug effort off Colombia _ if and when a decision is made to undertake the effort. Another official said on Wednesday that the reports created a furor because no definite decision had actually been made before the news reports, and the Colombians believed they had not been informed. ``There are certain political sensitivities. You want to hear about it directly and not hear about it in the newspapers,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The source said consultations with the Colombians over increasing Navy involvement in drug interdiction were now on a ``back burner,'' although other cooperative antidrug efforts were still being discussed. That includes the Feb. 15 drug summit in Colombia to be attended by Bush, Barco and the presidents of Peru and Bolivia. A preliminary meeting to draft communiques and agreements for the participants to sign is currently going on in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. The matter was particularly sensitive for Bush, coming after he was criticized by Latin American nations for the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama. Officials said reports of further military action off Colombia, even though part of the antidrug effort, revived concerns about the U.S. historical heavy-handedness toward its southern neighbors. Bush, in his telephone call, ``explained that the U.S. had intended a cooperative effort with Colombia that could compliment President Barco's courageous and determined effort to break up the narcotics cartels and bring traffickers to justice,'' the White House said. The two presidents agreed ``it was most unfortunate that inaccurate and confusing reports of tentative U.S. proposals for cooperation with the Colombian government had created such a false impression,'' Popadiuk said in his statement. Barco, according to the statement, told Bush he ``regretted the erroneous press stories'' and said ``he always knew that President Bush would never approve actions which impinged on Colombian sovereignty.''

DOC.HEAD: Naval Observatory Astronomers Search for Theoretical 10th Planet
DOC.TEXT: Astronomers at the U.S. Naval Observatory are narrowing their solar system search for a 10th planet, a mysterious, phantom giant that has long captured the speculation and interest of stargazers. Speculation about the existence of another planet evolved because something, perhaps a massive object orbiting the sun on the outer edge of the solar system, is giving a gravitational nudge that disrupts the predicted orbits of Uranus and Neptune, said astronomer R.S. Harrington. ``We are still incapable of predicting the location of Uranus,'' Harrington said Wednesday. ``It's clear something is wrong in the outer solar system.'' Astronomers have theorized since the beginning of the century that some additional planets existed beyond the orbits of Neptune. The theory sprang from observations that Uranus failed to orbit the sun with the majestic and mathematical symmetry experts expected. That led to a search that resulted in the 1930 discovery of Pluto, the ninth known planet in the solar system. Further searching revealed in 1978 that a moon was orbiting Pluto. But Harrington said calculations later showed the combined mass of Pluto and its moon are about 1,000 times too small to account for the detected, but unexplained irregularity of the Neptune and Uranus orbits. ``Something is there and we've got to look,'' Harrington said. Some astronomers have attributed the abnormal orbit of Uranus and Neptune to errors in calculation. However, Harrington said a model of the solar system created by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, which guided the Voyager spacecraft near both Uranus and Neptune, still is not consistent with recent observations on the position of Uranus. He said the JPL data seemed to be in agreement for a time, but new observations show Uranus is deviating from the expected path. ``Our current evidence is that the data is still off,'' he said. ``We still do not understand the outer solar system.'' A search for Planet X is under way in Washington, the main office of the Naval Observatory, and at the Black Birch Astrometric Observatory near Blenheim, New Zealand. Harrington said the search has been narrowed using a computer. A number of theoretical 10-planet solar systems were simulated in a Naval Observatory computer to determine where Planet X had to be to produce the effects seen on the orbits of Uranus and Neptune. That relatively small area of the heavens will be searched in April and May by an astrographic telescope at Black Birch. The telescope will take pictures of the target area on successive nights and the photos will be sent to Washington for study. Harrington said he would use a machine called the blink comparator to look for the phantom planet. A blink comparator flashes back and forth between two photo plates, causing an apparent motion to the observer if any point of light in the twin photos has changed position from one night to the next. Planet X, Harrington said, is thought to be three to five times larger than Earth and moving in an orbit about three times farther from the sun than Neptune or Pluto. That would make the phantom planet about as visible as Pluto, a planet seen only by sophisticated telescopes. A planet in such a distant orbit would take about 1,000 years to circle the sun. Even with the new techniques, Harrington said he was far from certain that Planet X will be found. ``I have no better than a 50-50 confidence level that this thing is there,'' he said. Harrington discussed the Planet X search on the opening day of the 175th national meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

DOC.HEAD: Glasnost Glamour: One Part Soviet, Nine Parts Capitalist
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: American-made jeans once were a principal currency of the black market in Moscow. Now, Americans can get ``Soviet'' blue jeans in the United States _ for $65 a pair. The jeans, on sale since November at some U.S. stores, are manufactured in Hong Kong and Italy by U.S. and Italian companies. But there is a Soviet component, said Lucio Dalla Gasperina, executive vice president of Seattle Pacific Industries, one of the manufacturers. ``It's very Russian,'' Gasperina said. ``It's the concept, the attitude, the association with the Soviets, the Russian letters. It's industrial. Utilitarian.'' Real Soviets do play a role in the product, which was on display Wednesday at a fashion show at the Red Zone discotheque. Six freelance designers in Moscow ``suggest'' colors, fabric and designs, Gasperina said. Although they're promoted as ``glasnost glamour'' and their label bears the word ``Soviet,'' they can't be purchased in Moscow. In addition to denim jeans, the Soviet line includes cotton workshirts, jackets, sweatshirts and T-shirts in black, white, red, mustard and olive green _ all adorned with Cyrillic letters, red stars, and industrial trappings like miniature screwdrivers hanging from belt loops. ``Two years ago if we had done this, people would have thrown rocks through Macy's windows,'' one of the stores that carries the line, said Gasperina. ``Now, all of a sudden, the Soviet Union is OK. They're accepted. They're a player.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 38,170.13, up 473.62 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Attack Cost-Sharing Plan For Cleaning Air
DOC.TEXT: Governors of three states that have little pollution are complaining that states with dirty air are trying to take advantage of subsidies for cleaning up their power plants while enjoying low electric rates. ``They can do like we have ... clean up and still be economically viable,'' Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich, co-chairman of the Alliance for Acid Rain Control, said Wednesday. The group released a study saying that three-fourths of the 25 utilities targeted for the largest reductions in the first phase of a cleanup proposed by President Bush had electric rates below the national average in 1987. Sixty percent of the 25 utilities had rates at least 10 percent below the average and one company's rates were 75 percent below the average, the group said. Twenty percent had rates above the average, the highest by a margin of 12 percent. The 25 utilities are located in 11 midwestern and southern states. The study used a composite of industrial, commercial and residential rates for comparisons. The alliance describes itself as a nationwide organization of governors, academics, environmentalists and business executives. The governors tend to come from low-polluting states. Bush proposed cutting sulfur dioxide emissions, a major cause of acid rain, by 10 million tons nationwide by the year 2000. This would represent a reduction of about 43 percent from the estimated total of more than 23 million tons a year. His plan, which is expected to go to the Senate floor later this month, would force states with the highest emissions to pay the largest share of the cleanup costs.
