High-pollution states worried about a potential loss of jobs want to spread the costs around, which would result in cleaner states paying more. ``We're paying for California and Texas to bail out the S&L's but they don't want to pay for their share of the sulfur dioxide emissions in the country,'' said Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., in response to the study. Sharp, whose home state is a major sulfur dioxide polluter, is chairman of the energy and power subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The subcommittee is considering a House version of the president's plan. Sulfur dioxide and other emissions turn into acids high in the atmosphere and can fall as acid rain, fog or snow up to several hundreds of miles downwind. Environmentalists blame this acidity for the destruction of aquatic life in lakes and streams and some say it is responsible for the death of red spruce forests at high altitudes in the East. Cost-sharing plans being advanced in Congress would raise electric rates $2 a month nationwide, according to the alliance. Perpich and the governors of Wisconsin and Wyoming said power plants in their states had taken extensive steps to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions. The nation's 10 dirtiest power plants produce more than half the nation's sulfur-dioxide emissions, but they have invested only $2.9 billion in air-pollution controls, less than a fifth of the $16.4 billion spent nationwide, according to the alliance's study.

DOC.HEAD: Approval Withdrawn for Jarvik Device
DOC.TEXT: The Jarvik artificial heart, which once stirred hope for critically ill heart patients, is being recalled because of ``serious deficiencies'' with the way the device is manufactured. The Food and Drug Administration withdrew approval for all uses of the artificial heart in humans because of problems in quality control, monitoring of research sites, training of workers and reports of adverse reactions in patients, an agency spokesman said Wednesday. ``The agency felt the deficiencies were great enough that risks to patients were outweighing benefits,'' said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. Symbion Inc. of Tempe, Ariz., had received FDA approval allowing its artificial heart to be used experimentally both as a permanent artificial heart and as a temporary bridge for people awaiting a human heart transplant. Approvals for both uses of the artificial heart were revoked, as was the company's approval for an acute ventricular assist device. The company's designation for its artificial heart formerly known as the Jarvik-7 is the Symbion J-7. The developer, Dr. Robert Jarvik, is no longer associated with Symbion. While Symbion sold the only approved permanent artificial heart, other companies have approvals for devices that are used as temporary bridges. The Jarvik-7, made of plastics, fibers and metal, was first used seven year ago amid much excitement when it was implanted in a dying heart patient named Barney Clark. FDA conducted two inspections of Symbion's facilities last year and found ``some serious deficiencies,'' Nesbit said. ``Some aspects of manufacturing quality were found to be poor enough to endanger patients,'' he said, and that the company had failed to report unexpected adverse events to the FDA as required. He said the agency also found research sites were not being monitored properly and that servicing of equipment and training of personnel was inadequate. Symbion had received approval to implant its permanent heart in as many as seven people as part of a continuing experiment. Nesbit said the company could discuss the problems with the FDA and correct them, but he declined to say how likely it was that the FDA would reconsider its decision. The letter was sent to the company on Monday. Symbion issued a statement saying it had received the FDA notice and would ``release further information at the appropriate time.'' Last week a 57-year-old Missouri woman, who held the record for living the longest on an artificial heart before receiving a human heart transplant, died of a heart attack. Carolyn Stadler of St. Charles had lived 440 days with the artificial heart before receiving a human heart, her second, last fall. There have been only a handful of artificial hearts used in humans, and recipients have been plagued by clotting and strokes. Interest in the artificial heart remains high because experts believe 20,000 to 75,000 Americans could use a transplant, but there are not enough donors. In 1988, there were 1,630 transplants in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Women Get More Kick From Alcohol Than Men Do
DOC.TEXT: Drink for drink, women get drunker than men. Now scientists believe they know why: Men have more stomach for booze. A study published today found that men typically make higher amounts of a substance that breaks down alcohol in the stomach before it reaches the bloodstream. As a result, men feel fewer effects of alcohol, even when men and women the same size drink the same amount. ``I am convinced that there are sex differences in handling alcohol,'' commented Dr. Judith Gavaler of the University of Pittsburgh. ``This is a very important study for all of us doing research in alcohol. This will change the way we approach this subject.'' Researchers said the study also underscores concerns about drinking during pregnancy, provides an explanation on the effects of drinking on an empty stomach and could be used to help set safe drinking levels for men and women. ``The implication of this is that when it comes to social drinking, women should be more careful than men for a given amount of alcohol when driving or operating equipment,'' said Dr. Charles S. Lieber, a co-author of the study. Lieber, director of the Alcohol Research and Treatment Center at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center, said the findings also help explain why women alcoholics are especially prone to liver disease. The study, conducted on 20 men and 23 women, was directed by Dr. Mario Frezza of the University School of Medicine in Trieste, Italy, and published in the New England Journal of Medicine. It found that women absorb about one-third more alcohol into their blood than men do. The researchers believe this is largely explained by the fact that non-alcoholic women produce about 30 percent less of the protective substance than non-alcoholic men do. Heavy drinking seems to hinder the body's ability to make the substance, an enzyme called alcohol dehydrogenase. While alcoholic men produce less than social drinkers, the difference was most dramatic in alcoholic women. They make virtually none. ``In alcoholic women, there is for all practical purposes no gastric protection anymore,'' said Lieber. ``Therefore, when an alcoholic woman drinks alcohol, she has the same blood level as when she is given that amount of alcohol intravenously. This may explain what is already known _ that womenare much more susceptible than men to alcoholic liver disease.'' In an accompanying editorial, Drs. Steven Schenker and K. Vincent Speeg of the University of Texas at San Antonio called the results ``exciting.'' They said the theory may explain, at least in part, the higher risk in women of harmful effects of alcohol. Another researcher, Dr. David Van Theil of the University of Pittsburgh, agreed: ``I think it's an important observation that suggests that alcohol metabolism in the stomach is different between men and women and as a result there are differences in potential toxicity for men and women.'' The study also gives an explanation for another bit of popular drinking wisdom: why people feel fewer effects of alcohol if they drink on a full stomach. If they drink when their bellies are empty, the alcohol passes quickly through the stomach into the small intestine, where it is absorbed into the bloodstream. However, when the stomach is full, alcohol stays in the stomach longer, so the enzyme has more time to work on it. Dr. Domenic Ciraulo of New England Medical Center said the findings also underscore concerns about drinking durring pregnancy. The findings suggest that the amount of alcohol reaching the fetus may be higher than previously thought. ``Even at low levels, alcohol may not be safe at all,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Separate Pact Between Hungarians, Poles and Czechoslovaks? ^An AP Extra
By TONY SMITH
DOC.TEXT: Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia are discussing a proposal to link, in a free-market arrangement, economies long stifled by Communist controls and lack of access to Western markets and capital. The plan to create an independent trade bloc of the three countries that are peacefully casting off one-party Communist rule is still tentative _ and there are formidable barriers. First, they must redefine their membership in the Soviet-led trading organization, Comecon, which is now grappling with a complete overhaul. Comecon could by 1991 be trading in hard currency and at world market prices, abandoning trade relationships that ignored free market mechanisms and were based on the non-convertible Soviet ruble. Planning officials from Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia used this week's Comecon summit in Sofia for first consultations Wednesday on their plan for closer integration. They kept mum about results. But officials from all three countries, aware of the looming potential of a confederated East and West Germany, have openly advocated closer cooperation among Comecon countries of a similar size and economic development. Hungarian Deputy Premier Peter Medgyessy envisions integration of the Hungarian, Polish and Czechoslovak economies beginning with a free trade agreement, followed by joint trade policy decisions, free flow of capital and labor, harmonized financial systems and a convertible accounting unit. ``Hungary was once a lonely long-distance runner in its criticisms of Comecon, but we have become more numerous,'' he told a news conference Tuesday. ``We think in the same way,'' he said of the three countries. Czechoslovakia and Hungary boast two of the more successful economies in Eastern Europe, and Poland has become a pioneer in free-market reforms. Poland's Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Eastern Europe's only non-Communist premier, spoke of ``trying new solutions'' in his Sofia speech to the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance _ as Comecon is formally known. A ``smaller group of countries'' could form an ``economic laboratory'' to test the free-market reforms and economic integration, he suggested. Both are sorely needed by the bloc's stagnant, centrally-planned economies, badly ailing 41 years after Comecon was created by Josef Stalin as a means for exploiting Soviet client states and keeping them in the fold. Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary backed each other solidly in Sofia, according to delegates to the closed-door meetings. While delegates from other countries agreed only that the bloc wasn't working and needed an overhaul, the three put forward concrete proposals. Czechoslovakia said before the Sofia summit that Comecon faced extinction if it didn't adopt reforms, and promptly presented a draft of new rules to members for approval. Countering a Soviet proposal that Comecon's own executive committee should discuss changes, Poland recommended an ad-hoc commission of two members from each delegation. The suggestion was accepted. But it's unclear whether the commission will make decisions within two to three months and swiftly present them to another summit. Comecon agreed only that its next summit will take place in Budapest, but rejected Prague's push for a promise it would convene before June. Close cooperation between Budapest, Prague and Warsaw _ the latter have already worked out a new exchange agreement for their own trade _ could leave less-developed Comecon members, and even the Soviet Union, far behind in the economic race. Members of East Germany's delegation in Sofia said Comecon reforms should not be detrimental to any members. For years, East Berlin has profited from special trade and credit lines to West Germany, advantages not enjoyed by any other Comecon member. But Romania, Bulgaria and non-European Comecon members Cuba, Mongolia and Vietnam could miss the reform train because they're unable, or unwilling, to make radical advances. ``Romania couldn't possibly have any reservations concerning the desire of two or three countries to organize such a circle,'' said Lilian Poida, a Comecon delegate from Romania, whose people ousted and executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu just last month. ``We are no longer dependent on ideology or constrained by economic models and welcome any move to stimulate trade,'' she said. But she couldn't say how Romania would react if such a system were implemented in the near future, as Romania's impoverished economy will not be able to liberalize soon and could get left behind. Emerging from Communist central planning and dependence on the Soviet Union will not be easy for the three pioneers either. They are well aware that four decades of squashed initiative, discouraged productivity, skewed production, and drained hard currency reserves are a powerful brake on progress. ``Reasonable cooperation can only start with stable economies,'' said Vladimir Dlouhy, Czechoslovak deputy prime minister. ``We will have to think carefully before entering into close cooperation with a country that has triple-digit inflation,'' he said, referring to Poland. Also, Poland and Hungary together owe at least $50 billion to foreign creditors. Czechoslovakia's foreign debt, by contrast, is much more modest, at around $7 billion. Medgyessy suggested that one way around the problem could be help from the World Bank or International Monetary Fund. But it's not clear whether Czechoslovakia would risk its potentially good credit rating with these institutions _ where it is applying for membership _ for the sake of cooperation with Poland and Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Discover Heat, Oranges and Newspapers with News
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Constanta Palulescu patted her blue shopping bag and said with a delighted smile, ``I have bought meat from Holland.'' Ms. Palulescu and other Romanians are discovering nearly three weeks after the revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu that daily life has been changed by simple things like good imported meat, oranges and bananas, heat in their homes and newspapers that actually contain news. That does not mean Bucharest has become a consumer's paradise. People have to stand in line to buy many items, including bread, meat, cigarettes and newspapers. In the city's Dristor sector, a neighborhood of endless rows of 10-story concrete apartment buildings, a clerk in an appliance store wore a scarf over her ears and a fur hat to ward off the chill inside the store. But Elena Lazerecu, a worker in the Romanian mint, said the government was turning up the heat in homes, which often were iceboxes under Ceausescu and his harsh economic policies. ``We have a bit of heating, a bit of hot water and happiness,'' said Mrs. Lazerecu, a 34-year-old mother of two.She also noted that although there were still lines at stores, they were shorter and shoppers did not have to present ration cards for sugar and cooking oil. ``You just have to wait a half hour or three-quarters of an hour in line. It's a lot less,'' she said. Her husband, Dimitri, a 39-year-old mechanic, said he expected a big change in his life from the provisional government's promise to shorten the work week from six to five days. ``I will have time to be with my family, to take a walk,'' he said. Laura Apostolou, a curly-haired 16-year-old, said she thought the most important change since Ceausescu's regime was overthrown Dec. 22 was in what Romanians had learned about their country. ``In the press, television, radio, everything is more open,'' she said. Holding a newspaper in her hand, Miss Apostolou noted that before the revolt few people read the government-run papers. Now, many wait in line to buy them. ``Under Ceausescu we had lines for meat. Now we have lines for newspapers,'' she said. Miss Apostolou, who hopes to become an economist, said she also expected changes in her high school classes. ``We used to study a lot of Marxism,'' she said. ``In history, we had to study whatever Congresses he held.'' Miss Apostolou and many Romanians say ``he,'' or ``him'' to refer to Ceausescu, who was executed Christmas Day along with his wife, Elena, for ``grave crimes'' including genocide. For many, the taste of freedom has only raised expectations for more openness. In Dristor, on icy sidewalks below the bulky concrete apartment buildings, people talk about their hopes to be able to travel abroad freely, to have foreign magazines and newspapers. Under Ceausescu, it was illegal to bring a radio into Romania. Typewriters had to be registered so authorities could track any dissident writings. People's passports were kept by the police, who had to be informed months in advance by anyone wishing to travel abroad. Caution and skepticism remain from the 24 years of Ceausescu's reign. Romanians are excited to see the first oranges and bananas in their stores in years, but they worry that the small pleasures they have so quickly become accustomed to will disappear. Ms. Palulescu, so happy with her purchase of imported meat, said she hopes her countrymen do not expect too much too soon in economic improvements. ``We can't change everything overnight. It's normal to have a gradual change. We have to have the necessary understanding to let time pass,'' said the 63-year-old retired economist, who had worked for the city government. She said Romanians will have to work very hard if they want a free and prosperous land. She would be willing to come out of retirement if she were needed, Ms. Palulescu said. ``I would not have said that a month ago,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Early Lead Exposure Causes Permanent Learning Disability
DOC.TEXT: The effects of brain damage caused by childhood lead exposure linger into adulthood and may be an important reason why teen-agers have trouble in school, researchers report today. The 11-year study, which followed a group of Massachusetts students through their school years, found that those who had been exposed to lead early in life have trouble reading and finishing high school. While other studies have shown that lead causes mental impairment in childhood, the latest work demonstrates that youngsters fail to outgrow these problems. ``We think this study, the longest followup on record, shows that the effects of lead are permanent and are reflected in real-life success,'' said Dr. Herbert L. Needleman of the University of Pittsburgh. ``For young adults, their main task is getting an education. This study shows that they have a seven times higher rate of not graduating from high school and a six times higher rate of reading disability'' after early childhood lead exposure. Exposure to lead, which now comes mainly from old paint and water pipes, also was linked with low grades, poor coordination and high absenteeism, among other problems, during the teen-age years. ``What it means to me,'' Needleman said, ``is that a pretty sizable percentage of school failure in young adults is related to early lead exposure.'' Needleman's study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, began with measurements of the lead content of baby teeth shed by 132 first- and second-graders in Chelsea and Somerville. They were tested in the first and fifth grades and when they reached age 19. Childhood exposure to lead has fallen sharply since the early 1970s, when the subjects were babies. The improvement has resulted largely from the introduction of unleaded gasoline and from removal of lead-based paint in houses. ``I think in part, these data serve as confirmation of the wisdom of some of the public health measures taken in the past few years to reduce community exposure to lead,'' said co-author Dr. David Bellinger of Children's Hospital in Boston. ``They serve as an indication that we should continue in those efforts.'' In the study, doctors compared the behavior and school records of those with high or low levels of exposure. Those with high exposure were estimated to have had average blood levels of 34 micrograms per deciliter. At the time, levels above 30 micrograms per deciliter were considered hazardous. Scientists now believe that lead levels are elevated when they exceed 10 to 15 micrograms. The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry estimates that 3 million to 4 million American children have at least this much lead in their bodies. Lead harms the brain by interferring with the normal growth and development of the central nervous system. Despite their school problems, the youngsters with highest lead exposure were not considered retarded, and appeared normal.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rebounded sharply in Thursday's afternoon session, while the dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen. The U.S. currency closed at 145.27 yen, down 0.03 yen from Wednesday's close of 145.30 yen. It opened at 145.23 yen and ranged between 145.10 yen and 145.50 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average regained a hefty 473.62 points, or 1.26 percent, ending the day at 38,170.13. Thursday's gain was the largest single-day increase since Oct. 17, when the index rebounded 527.39 points from following a huge loss that stemmed from the Oct. 13 mini-crash on the New York stock market. The Nikkei recovered in the afternoon as market players' spirits were buoyed by a rumor that the Soviet Union may agree to return four disputed islands that Japan claims as its northernmost territories, said a dealer with Nomura Securities, Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. The rumor had it that a resolution to the long-standing dispute could be reached in talks slated for Monday between Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and former foreign minister Shintaro Abe. In currency trading, the dollar-yen rate shifted little after a surge in the dollar earlier this week. Sentiment for the dollar remained bullish, but market players were reluctant to push the U.S. unit higher for fear of another central bank intervention, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. The Bank of Japan has actively sold dollars in the two days to support the yen. Market rumors that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold the dollar for yen Wednesday, and news of t the resignation of the executive vice president and chief financial officer of Campeau Corp. and its retailing units, Federated Department Stores and Allied, also deepened the market's wait-and-see mood, Kanai said. ``But the dollar is basically strong, as buying of the (West German) mark has slowed and the yen isn't attracting anybody,'' Kanai said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Expresses Impatience Over Inaction on Mideast Talks
DOC.TEXT: An apparently impatient Secretary of State James A. Baker III is telling Arabs and Israelis that other areas of the world are clamoring for his attention while they bicker about opening Mideast peace talks. The statement, issued through spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler, appeared to be a veiled warning to the two sides to come to terms on holding talks here or risk losing U.S. help in mediating their dispute. Baker hopes to bring the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers to Washington soon to discuss holding an election among Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and in Gaza. But sparring over whether the Palestine Liberation Organization should have a role has delayed the setting of a date. ``There are many other areas in the world clamoring for his attention, areas where the circumstances are producing change,'' Tutwiler said. ``We hope to see the same kind of impulse that will produce change in the Middle East and we're prepared to do all we can to promote it.'' Earlier, Baker talked on the telephone with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. On Monday he spoke with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel Meguid.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Time Warner Deputy General Counsel to SEC
DOC.TEXT: On the same day he went from being general counsel at Time Inc. to deputy general counsel at the newly merged Time Warner Inc., Philip R. Lochner Jr., was nominated by President Bush for a spot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wednesday's nomination to a post on the federal agency that regulates the nation's stock and bonds markets is subject to confirmation by the Senate. ``Phil Lochner has an excellent resume. He appears to have the potential to make an outstanding SEC commissioner,'' said Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee that will question the nominee at a confirmation hearing. Lochner had been general counsel of Time Inc. before the merger with Warner Communications Inc., which took effect Wednesday, when his title was changed to deputy general counsel. Reached at Time Warner's New York office, Lochner declined to comment on the SEC nomination.
DOC.HEAD: Banking Committee Staff Chief Leaving
DOC.TEXT: The staff director of the Senate Banking Committee is announcing his departure less than a month after consumer advocate Ralph Nader demanded his resignation, but Kevin Gottlieb says the timing is coincidental. Gottlieb said Wednesday his decision to leave had ``not the slightest'' connection with Nader's criticism of him for accepting $85,000 in consulting fees from the American Bankers Association prior to joining the Banking Committee staff. ``We've got a natural break period between the first session of the 101st Congress and the second session,'' he said. ``It's the time to make a move.'' Gottlieb, 47, will step aside March 1 and be replaced by committee general counsel Steve Harris, said Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., the panel's chairman. Gottlieb said he had done nothing wrong. He said the Senate Ethics Committee, at his request, was reviewing how he listed his outside income on financial statements. When he became staff director last year, Gottlieb said, it was with the understanding that he would remain only until Congress enacted the savings and loan reform bill that became law in August. He said he stayed longer than expected because Riegle asked him to direct the establishment of oversight mechanisms and plan the committee's 1990 agenda. Gottlieb, an adjunct professor at Michigan State University, said he had worked with the Senate for most of the past 12 years and was ready to return to teaching and his Washington-based policy analysis company.

DOC.HEAD: Thre Bombs Explode at University
DOC.TEXT: Three bombs exploded on the Oakland University campus, leading school officials to cancel today's classes while police investigated. No injuries were reported and no threats were received before Wednesday's explosions. No suspects nor motive were known, said Jim Llewellyn, spokesman for the 12,000-student school about 30 miles north of Detroit. Llewellyn said the university would remain closed today while the investigation continued. The first explosion occurred about 5:15 p.m. on the fourth floor of the Kresge Library, Llewellyn said. Several books were damaged, but there was no fire and several students on the floor escaped, he said. About the same time, an explosion in the library parking lot damaged a parked car, Llewellyn said. About 7 p.m., a bomb exploded in the parking lot but caused no known damage, he said. State police investigators were at the scene Wednesday night.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Involves Possible Rape at South Dakota Governor's Home
DOC.TEXT: The brief item in the Nov. 30 city police log read: ``Forcible rape no weapon Governor's mansion. Four boys at mansion raped her.'' Six weeks later, what happened at the home of Gov. George Mickelson remains a mystery, but the investigation has become a major topic of discussion throughout this sparsely populated farm state. Police and court officials, citing a state law that keeps names and charges against juveniles secret, have refused to discuss their investigation into the alleged drinking party among a small group of teen-agers at the mansion on the night of Nov. 28. Mickelson has limited his comment to saying the probe is a private matter. The special prosecutor in the case says delinquency petitions have been filed against three juveniles, but he won't say who they are or what laws they allegedly violated. An 18-year-old, David Ebach, has been charged as an adult with underage drinking but has yet to appear for a hearing. Ebach, starting quarterback on Pierre's high school football team, is a friend of the governor's 17-year-old son, David. Despite the secrecy, rumors and hints about the investigation dominate conversation in the capital city of 12,000 people and across the state of 700,000. Many Pierre residents know who was at the mansion. A source close to the investigation said a small group of high school students, including the young Mickelson, were drinking at the mansion while the governor was in Washington, D.C., attending a U.S. Department of Agriculture conference, and his wife, Linda, was in Texas on vacation. David Mickelson is the only other permanent resident of the gray, two-story house across a pond from the Capitol. A school official has confirmed that the alleged rape victim is a high school student in Fort Pierre, a small town across the Missouri River. Mickelson, a Republican, has refused to disclose his son's whereabouts on the night of the reported rape or to discuss David's possible involvement. On Dec. 13, two days after the first news report about the allegation, Mickelson and his wife issued a brief statement: ``Our family is going through one of the most agonizing times we have ever experienced. We have always held closely to the principle that it is not how you fall that counts the most, but how you get up and carry on.'' The story has been on front pages across the state ever since, but what details have emerged are sketchy. A hearing for the juveniles will begin Jan. 22 with arguments on a defense motion to keep the proceedings secret. Several news organizations oppose the motion. Republican politicians have understandably refrained from speaking about the case, but minority Democrats also have been restrained. The issue won't alter work in the legislative session that began this week, said Senate Minority Leader Roger McKellips. He said of the governor, ``I respect the way he's handled it.'' The county prosecutor and local judges bowed out of the case, which was turned over to Special Prosecutor Craig Kennedy, a Democrat from a county 220 miles away. Circuit Judge Marshall Young of Rapid City, who was named by the state Supreme Court to hear the juvenile cases, is a former president of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges and is considered an expert on juvenile law. Sentencing for juveniles in the state can range from probation to confinement in the state reform school until age 21. In the case of the most serious crimes the prosecutor could ask to have the juvenile tried as an adult. Mickelson, who took office in 1987 and is expected to run for re-election this year, is a lawyer and former speaker of the state House whose father George T. Mickelson, served as governor from 1946-1950. The current governor was 5 years old when his family first lived in the mansion.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Resists Pressure to Change Bank Laws
DOC.TEXT: The new government is resisting U.S. pressure to change banking secrecy laws to prevent drug traffickers from laundering their ill-gotten profits. On Wednesday, the two countries signed an accord on fighting drug trafficking, which U.S. officials say ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega allowed to flourish while he ruled. But Panamanian officials balked at altering banking laws that have made their country an international banking center. ``They want us to simply open our books and we cannot let them do that,'' Eduardo Lasso Valdez, president of the Bankers Association, told The Associated Press. Noriega, overthrown in last month's U.S. invasion, is imprisoned in Miami awaiting trial on drug charges that include laundering drug money. The new government is led by men elected in May balloting that Noriega nullified. The drug-fighting agreement covers U.S. assistance to help Panama structure its agencies to fight drug trafficking; exchange information; investigate and prosecute laundering drug profits; and destroy drug crops, processing sites and laboratories. The agreement was signed by Ramon Lima, vice minister of government and justice, and Melvin Levitsky, U.S. assistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters. Levitsky said he would recommend that President Bush certify Panama as a nation committed to fighting the drug trade, a step that would enable Panama to get special consideration in trade and assistance. But the two countries remain at odds over the issue of drug money laundering. Panamanian bankers insist drug money laundering has never been a problem. The international banking center, with more than 101 banks, is patterned after that of Switzerland, providing coded accounts and protecting confidentiality. ``Anything we do to affect confidentiality of the system would destroy the banking center,'' Lasso said. ``We think we have enough safeguards now to prevent money laundering.'' Levitsky disagreed. ``Money laundering was an important aspect of drug trafficking through Panama'' under Noriega, he said. Panamanian banks limit to $50,000 the amount of cash that an individual may deposit at one time, and bankers say claims of money laundering here were exaggerated. One bank's license was revoked five years ago. Another bank agreed to pay a $5 million fine following U.S. charges it took part in money laundering by accepting large transfers from a U.S. bank. In other developments Wednesday, the head of immigration under Noriega left the Vatican embassy Wednesday and gave up to U.S. troops. Belgica de Castillo left of her own accord along with her husband, Carlos Castillo, said the Rev. Joseph Spiteri. Panama's new government has said eight former immigration officials, including Mrs. Castillo, were being charged with corruption for selling visas and passports. The Castillos sought refuge shortly after the U.S. invasion on Dec. 20. Noriega himself was in the embassy for 10 days until his Jan. 3 surrender. Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Panamanians linked to Noriega have taken refuge in the embassies of Bolivia, Ecuador, Peru, Cuba and the Vatican. All but the Bolivian mission are surrounded by U.S. troops. Two of the 12 Panamanians in the Peruvian Embassy were suspects in the killing of Maj. Moises Giroldi, who led an unsuccessful coup attempt against Noriega on Oct. 3, said Attorney General Rogelio Cruz. He did not identify them but said Panama would tell Peru they do not qualify for asylum since they ``are not being persecuted politically.'' Noriega's family is in the Cuban Embassy. Linares said Panama was considering their request for safe conduct to the Dominican Republic but must first decide whether they can be charged with any offenses. The head of Noriega's personal security force, Capt. Eliezer Gaytan, was still inside the Vatican embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Continue Search for Motive In Stuart Murder
DOC.TEXT: From the beginning, the stunning disclosure a week ago today that Charles Stuart had committed suicide after becoming the prime suspect in his pregnant wife's slaying seemed to demand a grand motive. But drugs are out, and adultery and the theory that another man fathered the child are waning. Money is now the focus. These are the major pieces of the puzzle:
DOC.HEAD: THE SETUP
DOC.TEXT: The drama began Oct. 23 with Stuart's frantic call on a car phone to a police dispatcher, saying he and his wife had been shot. Stuart says he and his wife had left a hospital childbirth class. The transcript of the call grabs the nation's attention. Stuart's 30-year-old wife, Carol, dies within hours. At her funeral, attended by Gov. Michael Dukakis and Mayor Raymond Flynn, an emotional, loving letter from Stuart is read. Seventeen days after the shooting, the baby dies, Stuart by his side.
DOC.HEAD: THE HOAX
DOC.TEXT: Stuart tells police he and his wife were attacked by a black man who forced his way into their car. Police, using Stuart's description, comb the inner-city Mission Hill neighborhood where the shooting occurred. In November, news reports say William ``Willie'' Bennett, a black resident with a long criminal record, has been identified as a prime suspect. In December, Stuart reportedly picks Bennett out of a lineup. Bennett is later cleared.
DOC.HEAD: THE LAST NIGHT
DOC.TEXT: Two convenience store clerks near the Braintree hotel where Stuart stayed the night before his apparent suicide said he came in about 2 a.m., bought some items and seemed troubled. ``He had a kind of psycho look in his eyes, and he was grinning from ear to ear. It was a face you wouldn't forget,'' said Stephen Newcomb, 38, of Braintree. ``He was very freaky _ you know, like when you look in someone's eyes and you can just tell something's wrong. He was very up, very bubbly and very friendly, but very weird.'' ``In all honesty, he didn't look like he had it all together,'' said John Pemberton, 20, of Randolph. Stuart checked into the Sheraton-Tara Hotel before midnight Jan. 3. A clerk said Stuart registered under his own name and used his credit card to pay for the bill. A concierge said Stuart asked for, and got, a wake-up call at 4:30 a.m.
DOC.HEAD: THE COVERUP
DOC.TEXT: Unknown to investigators, Stuart told his younger brother, Matthew, to come to the killing scene. Matthew Stuart later tells authorities his brother passed him Mrs. Stuart's handbag, containing several personal items and a pistol. The gun and the bag are thrown separately into the Pines River in suburban Revere. Matthew Stuart told other family members and friends what he knew. Transcripts of phone conversations at the Revere Fire Department, where another brother, Michael Stuart, is a firefighter, indicate that Michael Stuart, his wife and a sister knew before last week's revelations that Charles Stuart was involved in the crime. Another sister and Stuart's parents apparently did not know.
DOC.HEAD: THE SCHEME CRUMBLES
DOC.TEXT: As the weeks progress, rumors start circulating about Charles Stuart's involvement. On Jan. 2, Stuart meets his attorney for the last time. The next day, Matthew Stuart tells investigators of his role, but says he didn't know Carol Stuart had been slain or that his brother had been shot when he went to the scene. District Attorney Newman Flanagan instructs officers to arrest Charles Stuart. On the morning of Jan. 4, Charles Stuart, 30, jumps into Boston Harbor, killing himself. Divers recover Mrs. Stuart's handbag the same day. Five days later, they find a .38-caliber nickel-plated, snub-nose revolver recently reported stolen from the fur shop where Stuart worked.
DOC.HEAD: THE AFTERMATH
DOC.TEXT: In the hectic days following Stuart's suicide, prosecutors order a crackdown, their sensitivities heightened by anger in the black community over the handling of Bennett as a suspect. Sources provide information that often proves to be off the mark.
DOC.HEAD: DRUGS
DOC.TEXT: Investigators dispute reports drugs were involved, and an autopsy shows no illegal drugs in Charles Stuart's system. A physician who treated him knocks down reports that he was treated for cocaine addiction.
DOC.HEAD: ANOTHER WOMAN
DOC.TEXT: After Stuart's suicide, rumors abound about his relationship with a 22-year-old woman who worked at the fur store. The young woman's attorney denies she had a romantic relationship with Stuart.
DOC.HEAD: THE BABY
DOC.TEXT: Authorities investigate whether the Stuart baby might have had a different father. But the theory is downplayed after preliminary tests show the boy and Charles Stuart had the same blood type.
DOC.HEAD: MONEY
DOC.TEXT: A final motive, money, is checked on several fronts. Rumors that Stuart stole furs from the store where he worked are discounted by the store owner. The Boston Globe reported Wednesday that Stuart may have been looking to open a restaurant. An unidentified friend of Stuart's, interviewed Wednesday on WCVB-TV, says Stuart told him he wanted to kill his pregnant wife because he was worried the baby would thwart his plan to open the restaurant: ``The pregnancy was an unwanted thing.'' The Boston Herald says it obtained a credit risk profile of Stuart that said he had ``excessive credit obligations ... (and) excessive delinquent credit obligations.'' It also comes out that Stuart collected $82,000 from an insurance policy on his wife, and had another policy on Mrs. Stuart for $100,000 that was being processed when he committed suicide. But a report that he also was due to receive $480,000 from another policy is denied by the company named as the provider.
DOC.HEAD: NEXT?
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury is to convene Friday to hear testimony on the case.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up Sharply, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index, ending a five-day decline, rose sharply today on a Soviet-related rumor and easier margin conditions, while the dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, which had declined more than 1,200 points so far this year, fell another 87.86 points this morning. But it ended up with a 473.62-point gain for the day, the biggest one-day climb since the 527.39-point rebound Oct. 17 after New York's minor crash. It closed at 38,170.13. Massive buy orders in Tokyo's afternoon session came amid a rumor that the Soviet Union might agree to return four disputed islands seized from Japan at the end of World War II, said a dealer with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. So far, the Soviet Union has been adamant about keeping the islands. ``Soviet-related rumors like this are likely to keep influencing the market this year,'' the dealer said. ``That's partly because economic fundamentals are unlikely to change here. Especially, there is little chance for interest rates to be lowered.'' Lower interest rates tend to encourage stock investment. Also today, in a step to encourage buying and rejuvenate the market, the Tokyo Stock Exchange eased margin trading requirements by starting to assess securities used as collateral at 60 percent of their real value rather than the previous 50 percent. Trading was moderate, with first section volume estimated at 600 million shares, up from Wednesday's 500 million. Trading house and electric power plant issues attracted buyers. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 145.27 yen, down 0.03 yen from Wednesday's close of 145.30 yen. It opened at 145.23 yen and ranged between 145.10 yen and 145.50 yen. Trading was quiet in the absence of market-affecting news, said Masafumi Koyama, a trader with the Bank of Tokyo. Some $7.16 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from the previous day's $10.2 billion. Although market players expected the dollar to remain strong, they were reluctant to push it higher because of rumors that the U.S. Federal Reserve had sold dollars overnight to check the American currency's rise, he said. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said participants' fear of further Japanese central bank intervention in support of the yen also made them reluctant to buy more dollars. The Bank of Japan has been actively selling dollars in recent days.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Cautioned on China Normalization
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle has cautioned Japan's top trade official against a go-it-alone policy of regularizing trade and loans with China. Beijing's easing of martial law is a positive development but normalcy has not yet been restored after last summer's bloody crackdown on democracy demonstrations, Quayle told Hikaru Matsunaga on Wednesday, according to Japanese Embassy spokesman Noriyuki Shikata. The Japanese minister of international trade and industry planned today to describe to administration economic officials Japan's new program of import incentives to ease its huge trade surplus and become an ``import superpower,'' a goal voiced to President Bush here last year by visiting Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Quayle was said to have told Matsunaga more action is needed by China to ease repression and this requires that the United States, Japan and outside countries coordinate their China policies. Quayle said that the more countries cooperate on China, ``the more positive action can be expected from the Chinese,'' Shikata said. This cooperation should include a common policy on resuming multimillion dollar World Bank credits to China, cut off after the midyear upheaval there, Quayle was quoted by both U.S. and Japanese officials as saying. Bush continues to stand for free trade as opposed to managed trade and import quotas with Japan urged by some in Congress, Matsunaga was told during an hour-long meeting with Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's council of economic advisers. Protectionist sentiment can be expected, however, when the U.S. trade deficit eases with Europe but not with Japan, Shikata said Boskin told Matsunaga. While the Bush administration appreciates the tax incentives and tariff cuts of the ``import superpower'' program, U.S. officials continue to feel Japan needs major structural changes in its system of business and distribution favoring established domestic producers, Boskin was quoted as saying. For its part, he added, the United States is trying to make some of the changes urged by Japan at the two countries' ongoing structural talks. These include boosting the low U.S. savings rate, reducing the budget deficit and improving the educational system, Shikata quoted him as saying. Matsunaga told Quayle and Boskin the structural talks would resume after Japan's parliamentary elections in February. The minister said he is optimistic Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party would retain its lower house majority, said an administration official who insisted on anonymity. The minister planned to leave Friday for Tokyo after meetings Thursday with Secretary of State James Baker III, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Environment Protection Administrator William Reilly.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Announces Movie About Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: The sensational Stuart murder case will be featured in a television movie by CBS, the network announced. ``CBS has been involved with this story from the start,'' Norman Powell, vice president of CBS Entertainment Productions, said Wednesday. ``We have the best sources and are dedicated to producing a film that is both responsible and moving.'' A CBS crew from ``Rescue 911'' was with the ambulance that responded to Charles Stuart's frantic call for help on his car phone the night he and his wife, Carol, were shot after leaving a Oct. 23 childbirth class. Last week, Stuart committed suicide after he was implicated by one of his brothers. The network said the executive producer of the film will be Arnold Shapiro of ``Rescue 911.'' It did not say when the movie would be broadcast. Aside from CBS, publishing houses also report that writers have proposed books about the case.

DOC.HEAD: School Wall Blown Down By Storm Was Poorly Designed, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Design flaws left a school cafeteria wall too weak to withstand a windstorm that toppled it onto dozens of children two months ago, killing nine, a state report concluded. The report said the state's school districts must take a closer look at their building designs and at how they warn schools about approaching bad weather. ``We are determined to learn whatever we can from this awful experience,'' state Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol said following Wednesday's release of the report by the state's Disaster Preparedness Commission on the Nov. 16 collapse at East Coldenham Elementary School in Newburgh. Sobol said he will push for a new state law requiring periodic inspections of schools and will toughen the Education Department's reviews of new school construction. The storm struck the school with 100 mph winds, blowing down a 55-foot-long by 25-foot-high wall consisting of a masonry structure surrounded by a series of metal-framed windows. Nine children who were eating lunch were killed in the hail of brick, concrete and glass. Fifteen students were injured. ``This wall, unfortunately, was not adequately designed,'' said Richard Tomasetti, an engineer hired by the state to investigate. Tomasetti said the masonry was not supported by lateral or vertical bracing and was not tested for strength. When the school was built in 1959, a state building code requiring such bracing did not apply to schools; it now does. The state's Office of Professional Discipline is investigating the school's architect, John Clark of Hyde Park, Sobol said. Clark was not in his office Wednesday afternoon and was unavailable for comment. He repeatedly has refused to respond to reporters' questions since the disaster. A lawyer for six of the dead children and 13 of the injured youngsters has filed a notice of claim that he intends to sue Clark and the Valley Central School District. He said the report helps the families' cases. ``This is not an act of God,'' lawyer Howard Finkelstein said. ``God did not build the wall. There are human failings that took place for which someone is going to be responsible.'' David Worby, attorney for the Valley Central School District, said criticism of the district was unjustified. He said state officials approved the construction and never let the district know it was unsafe. ``We, the school, are teachers. We are not builders, or architects or engineers or state inspectors. We are in that school teaching. If there was a problem and a danger and we were supposed to be warned, we were not,'' he said. The National Weather Service termed the storm a tornado. Weather experts hired by the state concluded that it was a ``strong downburst'' of wind. The commission chairman, Dr. David Axelrod, said the damaging effect of the winds was the same regardless of the type of storm. He said weather warnings had been conveyed to local school districts through both the state police and state education officials, but none reached the school. Axelrod also said there is some question what effect the warnings would have had. He said school officials might have sent more students to the cafeteria under the mistaken impression it was safe.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Claims New Attacks, ``Liberated Villages''
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed today that they launched new attacks and seized villages near Cambodia's second-largest town after shelling it last week. Khmer Rouge army radio said that after smashing strategic government positions near Battambang on Friday and Saturday, the guerrillas continued attacks along the Sangke River in the ``east Battambang town battlefield.'' It claimed the guerrillas ``liberated'' 38 villages, killed or wounded government soldiers and ``freed'' 65 commune and village officials. Another broadcast said that on Sunday and Tuesday guerrillas attacked a six-mile stretch from Varin to Sre Noy in Siem Reap province, which borders Battambang province. The reports could not be verified and previous such claims have proved exaggerated. The Khmer Rouge is the largest of three guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnam-installed government. Its recent advances have spread fears of a return to power of the group that massacred Cambodians during its 3{-year rule of terror and famine before Vietnam invaded in late 1978. A Phnom Penh newspaper editor who has close contacts with the government said Wednesday that fighting in the Battambang area was limited to villages six to nine miles away. The city was quiet Wednesday, said Khieu Kanharith, reached by telephone. The government radio has said troops repelled up to 200 guerrillas who attacked through four suburbs of the town at midnight Friday to try to blow up a bridge. Also, Khieu confirmed that several plastic explosives went off in the streets of Phnom Penh on Friday and Saturday, the eve of National Day, but said there were no injuries or damage. He denied Khmer Rouge claims that grenades were used and that the blasts had forced President Heng Samrin to flee to Vietnam, which says it pulled its last troops out of Cambodia in September. The guerrillas also had claimed the explosions killed or wounded some Vietnamese and others near an office of the Communist Party. In New Delhi, an Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman said Wednesday the Indian mission in Phnom Penh did not mention the reported flight of the leaders and certainly would have if it was true. Indonesia's Foreign Minister Ali Alatas, a main organizer of past Cambodian peace talks, met Wednesday in Bangkok with leaders of the three guerrilla groups to try to revive the peace process but gave no indication of progress. Under most detailed review is Australia's proposal for an interim U.N. authority in Cambodia. The government's SPK news agency said that at talks in Cambodia this week, Premier Hun Sen and Australian envoy Michael Costello ``agreed to the central idea that the United Nations should be involved in the interim administration of Cambodia in the period leading up to free and fair elections,'' but that the guerrillas had to give up the Cambodian seat they hold at the United Nations. They recognized that such involvement could take many forms and that detailed negotiations would be required, said the report dated Monday and seen in Bangkok today. Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who heads the guerrilla coalition, has said he would agree to the resistance vacating the U.N. seat if the resistance and Hun Sen governments were simultaneously dismantled and replaced by the U.N. authority.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Protests Statements on NBC Program
DOC.TEXT: @LaserPhoto MO3

The portrayal of Mexican law enforcement in the NBC miniseries ``Drug Wars'' was unfair and statements following the broadcast that drug corruption is entrenched in Mexico are inaccurate, the government says. ``President Carlos Salinas de Gortari considers the fight against drugs a national priority,'' Mexico's Foreign Ministry said in a statement Wednesday. The television miniseries, a dramatization of the 1985 slaying in Mexico of U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena, was broadcast Sunday through Tuesday nights. Lloyd Siegel, executive producer for special broadcasts at NBC News, said the Mexican Embassy in Washington had declined to have a representative interviewed for one of the 15-minute news segments that followed the program each night. Nonetheless, Siegel said, Mexico's efforts to combat drug trafficking, especially in the last year, were praised in other interviews and the network's reporting was accurate. Gustavo Gonzalez, legal adviser to the Mexican Embassy, said Mexican officials declined to be interviewed partly because they were apprehensive that any statements they made could be used by attorneys representing the men charged with Camarena's murder. The Camarena case caused a major increase in tensions between the United States and Mexico because of accusations that Mexican law enforcement officials were in league with the killers, helped cover up the crime and permitted suspects to escape. The Salinas administration, which took office on Dec. 1, 1988, has tried to reduce tensions by making a strong effort to fight drug trafficking and focusing the U.S.-Mexico relationship on economic matters. President Bush and other U.S. officials have praised the approach. The Foreign Ministry noted that Camarena's killers were sentenced to long prison terms last month in Guadalajara, where Camarena was the local DEA agent. The mastermind, Rafael Caro Quintero, was given a 40-year sentence for the killing and a 34-year sentence for other drug-related crimes. There is no parole in Mexico for drug-related crimes. ``The government of Mexico has reiterated its conviction that narcotics trafficking is an international crime that must be fought on a multilateral level,'' said the Foreign Ministry. Underscoring the point, the attorney general's office announced Wednesday that 13 men had been arrested for attempting to smuggle 1,650 pounds of cocaine to Houston. The men were presented to the press with the seized cocaine, two AR-15 and two AK-47 assault rifles. The attorney general's office said the group had planned to fly the cocaine into the United States from a clandestine airstrip in northern Mexico. Caro Quintero pioneered the Colombia-Mexico-U.S. smuggling route, known as ``the trampoline.'' The Salinas administration has played down the possible effect of the long-anticipated miniseries on U.S.-Mexico relations, saying the American audience would recognize it as a dramatization and fictionalization of events. ``It is part of the ratings wars, not the drug wars,'' said Agustin Barrios Gomez, Mexico's consul general in New York. But in Washington, Ambassador Gustavo Petricioli protested some statements made during the news segments. The statement said an assertion was made on the program that ``Mexico is just like Panama, and that drug corruption is deep and pervasive.'' ``Likewise, we categorically deny statements, lacking of any evidence, that top Mexican officials are involved in drug trafficking, and that corruption goes to the highest level of the Mexican government,'' the statement said. Like other NBC programs, ``Drug Wars'' appeared in English on Mexico City cable systems.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Flee Northwestern Floods
LaserColor SE2
DOC.TEXT: A carpet of flood waters lay across southwest Washington and northern Oregon today, closing part of a busy interstate highway and other roads and forcing about 3,000 people to flee their homes. The floods, which caused at least three deaths in southwestern Washington, were beginning to recede on the plains west of the Cascade Mountains late Wednesday. Bad weather also was blamed for two deaths in Oregon since a series of storms smashed ashore last weekend. Residents sandbagged riverbanks in some coastal Washington towns as they braced for the rivers to crest at harbor's edge today and Friday. ``This is potentially the worst flooding since the 1930s,'' said Sheriff Dennis Morrissette of Grays Harbor County. The deaths included a man whose body was found floating in the Centralia flood waters. A man whose car was swamped on a flooded section of Interstate 5 south of town also died, and a man drowned in his car north of Tacoma, authorities said. Twelve miles of I-5, the north-south artery linking Portland, Ore., and Seattle, was closed after flood waters covered a two-mile stretch near Centralia, the Department of Emergency Management reported. Rain also washed out the main north-south rail route used by Burlington Northern and Amtrak trains. Motorists were able to take a 60-mile detour around the I-5 closure but heavy trucks had to make a 100-mile detour through eastern Washington. The worst flooding was in Centralia, a community of about 11,000, where the Chehalis River crested 8.4 feet above flood stage by noon Wednesday and was not expected to fall below flood stage until noon Friday, the National Weather Service said. Among the 3,000 Lewis County evacuees today were 400 who fled after a waterlogged dike along the Skookumchuck River failed overnight, authorities said. ``The dike has been breached and they couldn't hold it back with sandbags,'' Fire Chief Chuck Newbury said Wednesday morning. ``It's just threatening property at the moment. ... We don't foresee any life-threatening problems.'' Gov. Booth Gardner said he planned to ask for federal assistance to deal with flood damage in Lewis County, which surrounds Centralia. The state Emergency Services Department said damage in King County, around Seattle, could run $4 million. Damage estimates for other affected counties were not immediately available. The flooding followed four days of winds and heavy rain. Rains eased or stopped Wednesday and the weather service predicted only scattered showers for the next few days. In Oregon, the swamped area west of Portland began to drain, and as floodwaters receded residents began cleaning up millions of dollars in damage. At the height of the flooding Tuesday, water was 6 feet deep on some roads. In Nehalem, a coastal town of 240 people about 75 miles west of Portland, the water level dropped from 2{ feet to less than 1 foot as the tide began receding Wednesday afternoon. Rugs dried on stoops in the sun and the sound of vacuums competed with that of the ocean as businesses up and down U.S. Highway 101 began salvaging their water-logged property. A herd of about 500 cattle was driven to higher ground by members of the Tillamook Volunteer Fire Department, Levesque said. Much of the county's prime dairy land was under water, and a few cattle were wandering around in water up to their tails. Carol Dillin of Portland General Electric Co. said Wednesday night that about 2,000 customers still were without electricity in the utility's service area. Three Pacific storms dumped a total of 8.2 inches of rain on Astoria, at the mouth of the Columbia River. More than half that amount fell during the 24 hours ending at 4 p.m. Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service. The Nehalem River crested Tuesday nearly 12 feet above flood stage, the highest level since records began being kept in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Two Japanese Who Fought for 40 years With Malaysian Communists Head Home
DOC.TEXT: Two Japanese men who fought for their country in World War II and then took up arms with Malaysian Communist guerrillas for more than 40 years were on their way home today. Shigeyuki Hashimoto, 71, and Kiyoaki Tanaka, 77, flew to Bangkok today from the southern Thai town of Hat Yai, near the Malaysian jungle border they left after the Communist insurgency was disbanded in December. Japanese reporters who accompanied the men quoted them as saying they joined the Communist Party of Malaysia to help the country gain independence from Britain. Independence came in 1957, but the insurgency continued. The two Japanese did not want to surrender before the party was disbanded because they feared that would hurt its morale, the reporters said. ``They said they never forgot about Japan and had wished to go back since the beginning,'' said Hiroshi Inomata, first secretary at the Japanese Embassy. ``But the time was not ripe for them to do that. They didn't want to surrender. Now that the peace agreement has been made, they are free to go.'' ``Tanaka said there are many good things and many bad thing about the years they spent in the jungle,'' Inomata said. ``They had many good friends who were quite cooperative and trusted each other. They said they will miss their friends and they promised to write letters.'' ``They said they are happy to be going home but I think they might have some uneasiness as well,'' he said. The Japanese reporters said the two, who joined the Communists in 1945 after serving in Japan's Imperial Army, knew of the enormous changes in Japan since World War II from their shortwave radio. The Japanese left the former Communist headquarters in the jungle on Wednesday and went to a military camp in Hat Yai. There, Hashimoto was met by two younger brothers and Tanaka by a daughter and his nephew. They also had a party with their former comrades before leaving Hat Yai, the reporters said. Hashimoto arrived at Bangkok airport in a wheelchair, clutching a walking stick and appearing very fragile. Tanaka also had a walking stick. Japanese Embassy officials helped Hashimoto out of the wheelchair and into a limousine for the ride to a hospital for a checkup along with Tanaka. They were to leave for Japan on Saturday. Hashimoto, from Kanagawa prefecture, adjoining Tokyo, is to stay at a hospital in Tokyo because of his high blood pressure while Tanaka will return to his hometown in Kumamoto prefecture in southern Japan, an embassy official said. He said Tanaka's wife was still alive. The embassy official, Hirofumi Takemoto, said the two men had worked for a private Japanese company in Malaysia before they joined the Japanese army during World War II. The Communist insurgency _ one of the world's longest _ officially ended with the signing Dec. 2 of a peace accord between the insurgents and Thai and Malaysian officials. British Commonwealth forces fought bloody battles with the insurgents during what was known as the 1948-1960 ``emergency.'' Fighting continued after that on a lesser scale, and the two Japanese told reporters they engaged in combat in the 1960s. Thai-Malaysian military strikes and a Thai amnesty badly hurt the movement, and its leader, Chin Peng, said only 1,200 guerrillas had been operating along the 375-mile Thai-Malaysian frontier in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Desegregation Ruling Questionable Victory
With PM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court's decision overturning fines against four city councilmen who defied a federal judge's housing desegregation order was hailed by the mayor as ``a triumph for democracy.'' But NAACP officials said Wednesday's 5-4 ruling by the nation's highest court had no effect on the desegregation order itself, and that portraying it as such would be a ``cruel hoax.'' Three of the councilmen gathered at City Hall to celebrate the decision with pink champagne. ``It's one helluva way to kick off the new year,'' said Councilman Peter Chema, one of the four whose defiance of U.S. District Leonard Sand's order in August 1988 put this city of 195,000 just north of New York City on the brink of bankruptcy. ``It's a triumph for democracy,'' said Mayor Henry Spallone, a former councilman who became mayor last November by defeating the incumbent who supported Sand's order. NAACP attorney Michael Sussman, however, said portraying the high court's ruling as a way to avoid building 1,000 units of court-ordered low- and moderate-income housing would represent a ``cruel hoax and false hope.'' The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is one of the plaintiffs in the decade-long desegregation case. ``The Supreme Court's decision, as disappointing as it may be, has absolutely no effect on the original Yonkers remedy order issued by Judge Sand,'' NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks said in a statement from the organization's Baltimore headquarters. ``That remains unaffected and represents the culmination of nine years spent in court by the NAACP, facing the recalcitrant city of Yonkers.'' Construction on the first 200 units of low-income housing was to begin within the next two months. Attorneys for the councilmen said it was unknown what action they would take in light of the decision. Sussman was confident construction would begin, and said the rest of the plan was being reworked. The Supreme Court said Sand exceeded his authority in imposing the fines. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said Sand acted too hastily in holding the councilmen in contempt. Rehnquist said the judge should have waited to see whether Sand's contempt ruling against the city succeeded in forcing compliance with the judge's desegregation order. In the summer of 1988, Sand threatened the councilmen with jail and fines and the city with bankruptcy if the council refused to obey his orders to build the housing. Council voted 4-3 against the plan, and Sand imposed the fines. With fines nearing $1 million and facing massive layoffs of city workers, City Council reversed itself and voted to comply with Sand's order. The city paid $189,000 in fines and the councilmen paid $3,500 each. Sand ordered the desegregation plan after finding that Yonkers had for 40 years deliberately concentrated virtually all subsidized housing in the southwest section of the city to keep blacks away from whites. In 1980, blacks represented 10.5 percent of Yonkers' 195,000 residents. Spallone ran for re-election last year on his record of opposing the housing and won decisively, as did Chema and Councilman Edward Fagan. The fourth defiant councilman, Nicholas Longo, lost a close election to a pro-housing candidate, Thomas Dickerson. The councilmen said Wednesday the ruling vindicated their right to vote their conscience, and Spallone pointed to their successful use of the court system. The decision ``adds a whole new impetus to continue the fight against the housing,'' Fagan said, who later acknowledged the ruling might have little effect. ``But it's an emotional boost,'' he said. ``We have to review other legal maneuvers. ``I'm looking forward to getting my money back,'' he added. Officials said attorneys would review whether a January 1988 consent decree in which the council agreed to build the housing was still binding; the vote was taken after Sand threatened to fine and jail the councilmen.

DOC.HEAD: ``Johnny'' Sylvester, Babe Ruth's Most Famous Fan, Dead at 74
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to fix typo in `wish'; INSERTS one graf after 8th, `The 1926 ...' to include Gehrig story; version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: John Dale ``Johnny'' Sylvester, who became the most famous little sick boy in America after Babe Ruth promised to smack a World Series homer for him _ and hit three _ has died 63 years later. He was 74. Sylvester died Monday at a Mineola hospital. No cause of death was given. In 1926, Sylvester was suffering from a serious infection of the forehead caused by a kick from a horse when he told his father, ``I wish I could see Babe Ruth wallop a homer before I die.'' The family sent telegrams to the New York Yankees while they were playing in St. Louis. Back came an airmail package containing two baseballs, one autographed by the St. Louis Cardinals, the other signed by several Yankees, including Ruth, who wrote, ``I'll knock a homer for you on Wednesday.'' Ruth hit three that day. In a follow-up note the day of Game 6, Ruth said he would ``try to knock you another homer, maybe two today,'' but went homerless. He hit one in Game 7 but it was not enough to prevent the Yankees from losing the Series. In fact, Ruth was caught stealing for the final out. Ruth visited the Essex Fells, N.J., boy at his bedside after the Series, a meeting at which Sylvester remarked, ``I'm sorry the Yanks lost.'' No miraculous recovery occurred, but the visit certainly did no harm. It took Sylvester three years before he fully recovered. Sylvester returned the gesture in 1948, visiting Ruth four months before the slugger died of cancer. The 1926 episode later was part of the movie ``The Babe Ruth Story,'' but the screen version stretched the truth by having Ruth make his home run promise at Sylvester's hospital bedside. The boy apparently was never hospitalized. Earlier, in the 1942 movie ``The Pride of the Yankees,'' Hollywood had stretched the tale even further with a promise of two home runs by Lou Gehrig. Sylvester served in the Navy in World War II and was later president of Amscomatic Inc., a manufacturer of packing machinery. He is survived by his son, John Jr., a sister, Ruth Elliott of Barrington R.I., and a brother, Horace C. Sylvester Jr., of Osterville, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Attorney Says He'll Investigate Civil Rights Allegations
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. attorney said he will investigate any allegations of civil rights violations stemming from the probe into the shooting of Charles Stuart and his pregnant wife, Carol. ``I'm not at this point suggesting that they exist, only that if there are allegations or complaints, we'll be willing to review them,'' U.S. Attorney Wayne Budd said Wednesday. Stuart, who was white, told police in October that a black man jumped in their car after he and his wife left a childbirth class, robbed them and shot them. Last week, Stuart was implicated by his brother and apparently committed suicide the next day. Budd met for nearly two hours Wednesday with four black and one Hispanic legislators. One of them, Rep. Shirley Owens-Hicks, said residents of the predominantly black Mission Hill section where the shootings were reported, complained of being illegally searched, intimidated and ``having their doors kicked in and having their apartments trashed'' by police. ``We are urging any individual in the black community who feels their civil rights were violated, directly or indirectly ... to be in touch with the U.S. attorney,'' said Rep. Byron Rushing. Budd said that to bring federal criminal charges of civil rights violations, the alleged victims must have suffered physical excesses or harm from touching by police. He said allegations of police harassment not involving touching would come under the jurisdiction of the state attorney general's office or could be pursued in civil suits.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says Hundreds Detained, Tortured in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has in the past seven years held hundreds of political opponents without trial, mainly Shiite Moslems, subjecting them to routine torture, Amnesty International charged today. More than 700 people were detained without trial there from 1983 to 1989, including at least 100 last year, the worldwide human rights organization said. The 27-page report on the oil-rich kingdom, which is dominated by Sunni Moslems, identified 66 people it said were being held without trial in three prisons. They included 20 alleged members of Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Shiite group suspected of holding Western hostages in Lebanon. ``A clear pattern of human rights violations _ including the use of torture _ has emerged in Saudi Arabia in recent years,'' Amnesty said. The Saudi royal family runs the country and bans all political parties and labor unions. No penal code or constitution exists. Legislation is based mainly on Islamic law and introduced by royal decree or ministerial regulations. Besides the Hezbollah followers, most of the detainees were suspected followers of the country's main Shiite opposition group, the Organization of Islamic Revolution, and another banned group, the Arab Socialist Action Party, the London-based rights group said. It said political detainees were routinely tortured into signing so-called confessions. Victims said favored methods were beating the soles of feet, sleep deprivation and suspension by the wrists from a ceiling or high window. Most detainees spend from 14 days to six months in solitary confinement before and during interrogation, Amnesty reported. It said people who balked at signing confessions and acknowledging them ``were interrogated again and tortured until they `changed their minds.''' Amnesty said it received reports of detainees dying in custody. The group said it protested to the Saudi government, but received no reply.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Abortion Clinic After Having a Baby
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old girl gave birth prematurely four days after undergoing an abortion procedure, according to a $10 million lawsuit filed against the doctor and nurse who performed the operation. The doctor told Tralishia Nicole Gillespie she was six or seven weeks pregnant when the abortion was performed Dec. 18 at a clinic. In fact she was in her 26th week, the girl's lawyer, Don Caulkins, said Wednesday. The abortion was unsuccessful and four days later, Ms. Gillespie suffered abdominal cramps and went to a hospital, where doctors examined her and detected a fetal heartbeat, Caulkins said. Ms. Gillespie was taken to Vanderbilt University Medical Center, where she delivered the 1{-pound baby in the hallway, Caulkins said. The 3-week-old girl, De'Angela Nicole Alexander, was in critical condition, hospital officials said Wednesday night. ``The survival rate for children born at 26 weeks is approximately 60 percent,'' said Dr. Frank Boehm, Vanderbilt's director of obstetrics, who delivered the girl. In the Circuit Court lawsuit, Dr. Karen J. Smiley and nurse Lola Oni of the Family Planning Clinic for Reproductive Health are charged with negligence and gross negligence for not properly diagnosing the age of the fetus and for attempting to perform the abortion, Caulkins said. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday by Joan Stover, the baby's grandmother, asks $5 million in compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages. There was no answer at Smiley's home or at the clinic when The Associated Press called for comment Wednesday night. Boehm said Smiley told him on Dec. 23 that she had done a pelvic examination on Ms. Gillespie before the procedure. The information that Ms. Gillespie provided about her last menstrual period would be consistent with her being about seven weeks pregnant, Boehm said. Boehm said it isn't uncommon for pregnant women to have menstrual bleeding. He said the attempted abortion ``more likely than not'' caused Ms. Gillespie to go into early labor. Ms. Gillespie underwent a suction abortion procedure that took about 30 minutes. She was given pain medication and sent home afterward, Caulkins said. An investigation is under way to determine if the clinic violated state health department rules, said Dr. Peggy Alsup, medical director of the department's Bureau of Manpower and Facilities. Caulkins said Ms. Gillespie is now undergoing psychiatric treatment. ``She's devastated, obviously. She would never have dreamed of having an abortion had she known it (the fetus) was 26 weeks old.'' Ms. Gillespie, who isn't married, wants to keep the baby, Caulkins said, adding that she and the father are engaged.

DOC.HEAD: Family Slain By Cult Remembered At Ecumenical Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 18th graf, `The two...' to UPDATE with report Lundgren named as killer, report his family received welfare payments in San Diego
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CD1
DOC.TEXT: Neighbors and strangers jammed a memorial service for a family of five who authorities say were shot and buried under a barn by a religious cult, possibly as a sacrifice. As about 250 people filled the small brick church Wednesday night to pay respects to the Avery family, authorities in Southern California said they arrested the last two members of the cult, ending a nationwide manhunt for 13 people accused in the slayings. Law officers stopped a pickup truck about 60 miles northeast of San Diego and arrested Daniel David Kraft and Kathryn Johnson, said agent James Stathes of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in California. In Kirtland, five pink candles burned at the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints for 49-year-old Dennis Avery; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters: Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7. Four ministers of different denominations addressed the mourners. ``The tragedy that has (hit) us has caused our ordered world to collapse for the time being, and we will never be the same again,'' said the Rev. Bruce Morrison, a United Church of Christ pastor. ``When unexpected tragedy disrupts our lives in the way in which this one has, we find ourselves plunged into mystery.'' Barbara Eckart, a member of the Reorganized Church in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland, said she didn't know the Averys because they seldom attended services, but felt the need to pray for them. ``I came to support the congregation, and because of the fact that it was an unfair thing that happened to them,'' she said. ``I feel that they didn't have anybody here.'' Authorities say the Averys moved to Kirtland from Missouri at the urging of a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church, Jeffrey Lundgren, and later joined his cult when he broke from the church.
