The Averys were killed apparently in an April 18 ritual sacrifice designed to ``cleanse'' the cult and allow it to relocate, authorities said. The Rev. Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the Reorganized Church, has said the slayings may have been prompted by disputes over money or sex, or in an effort to keep the Averys from leaving the cult. Until April, Lundgren rented the 15-acre farm where the bodies were found and where some of his followers had lived. Investigators said it appears the Averys, who lived nearby and were not as fervent as his other followers, were shot before the cult headed to West Virginia and eventually to a farm near Holden, Mo. The bodies were unearthed last week after police got an anonymous tip. All five had duct tape across their eyes and some had their hands and feet bound with the tape, authorities said. Officials in Lake County are seeking the extradition of Lundgren, his wife and son, and 10 others from California. Lundgren and the others have refused to waive the proceeding, which could take 90 days, officials said. The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer reported today that Mrs. Avery's mother received a short note from her daughter, apparently dashed off just hours before the five were shot, mentioning a planned move to Wyoming. The two arrested Wednesday, Kraft, 25, of Nauvoo, Ill., and Johnson, 36, of Holden, Mo., had eluded authorities since the arrests of Lundgren, 39; his wife, Alice, 38; and son, Damon, 19, at a motel Sunday in National City near San Diego. Eight others also have been detained. Other cult members implicated Lundgren as the triggerman in the deaths, a federal agent said in documents filed Wednesday in El Cajon Municipal Court. Also, a newspaper reported that Lundgren was drawing welfare checks in San Diego County for almost a month before his capture. He applied for welfare last month and received $940 in checks at a Chula Vista motel in December and earlier this month, the Los Angeles Times said. Ohio prosecutor Steven LaTourette said Lundgren and his son face five counts of aggravated murder. If convicted, they could face the death penalty. The others face a variety of charges including murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Authorities found an assortment of firearms and knives, thousands of rounds of ammunition, a .50-caliber rifle, gas masks and other equipment at two San Diego-area hotels and at a storage unit in nearby Chula Vista. The Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints is based in Independence, Mo. It has roots and some beliefs in common with the Salt Lake City-based Mormon Church, but is separate.

DOC.HEAD: Budget to Prolong Paternal Leave, Lower Abseenteism
DOC.TEXT: Mothers and fathers will be able to stay home with a newborn child for 15 months with full pay under the new budget proposed by the Social Democratic government. The leave covers just one parent, but the two can split the months between them. Parents are currently allowed to split 12 fully paid months after the birth of a child, after which they can receive $9.60 a day for three months. The budget bill, presented on Wednesday, also proposes to increase family allowances by $145 to $1,083 annually per child. Finance Minister Kjell-Olof Feldt said, however, that the government could reconsider the plan if unions continue pressing for higher wages, which rose by about 9 percent last year. In 1987, 7.5 percent of the paid parental leave was used by fathers. So this year, the budget bill sets aside nearly $500,000 for a campaign to inform fathers about their rights to use the social insurance and stay home. Sweden's high taxes make it difficult for a family to survive on one wage, and critics have said the system gives parents no choice but to leave small children to often understaffed nurseries. In another move, Feldt proposed to check soaring absenteeism by stricter control over people who call in sick to work. The budget presented to Parliament on Wednesday entailed few other changes to Sweden's generous social welfare system.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Upper Great Lakes; Warm Continues in South
DOC.TEXT: Gale-strength winds brought more snow to the upper Great Lakes today as a strong low-pressure system moved over Lake Superior. The Gulf states and southern Plains were expecting temperatures as much as 25 degrees warmer than usual. But the National Weather Service said the warm spell won't last. Cold air driven south by high pressure was to lower readings by as much as 35 degrees Friday. Strong southerly winds ahead of the approaching cold front caused temperatures to soar 40 to 50 degrees across the central states on Wednesday. Afternoon highs in the 70s were reported as far north as Nebraska and eastern Colorado. A total of 48 cities _ from International Falls, Minn., to Phoenix, Ariz. _ reported record high temperatures for the date. Strong, gusty winds prevailed in the north-central states as a Pacific front ushered in colder temperatures. Wednesday's winds hit 81 mph northwest of Denver; 78 mph at Boulder, Colo.; 67 mph at Bismarck, N.D. and 66 mph at Laramie, Wyo. International Falls was the nation's cold spot Wednesday with a low of 3 degrees below zero, yet managed to set a record high of 39 later in the day. Three cities in Nebraska and one in North Dakota reported record high temperatures for the month of January on Wednesday. Eight cities in North Dakota reported new record highs for the date. Freezing temperatures were mostly confined to the upper Great Lakes, where afternoon highs were in the 20s and lower 30s. New England expected sunshine early today, followed by afternoon clouds and a chance of flurries. Friday's forecast called for breezy and colder weather. Temperatures warmed into the 70s and 80s in southern parts of Florida, Arizona and California. The high for the nation Wednesday was 85 degrees at San Gabriel, Calif. DOC.HEAD: CBS Records Exec Issues Anti-Bigotry Memo
DOC.TEXT: The head of CBS Records, responding to complaints of anti-Semitism by a rap group carried by CBS, called on his employees to make sure that the company's recordings do not promote bigotry. In a memorandum dated Wednesday, Walter Yetnikoff did not name Public Enemy, the group whose newest record, ``Welcome to the Terrordome,'' has been assailed by Jewish groups as anti-Semitic. CBS distributes Public Enemy's recordings. Yetnikoff said some recent recordings ``have stirred strong reactions outside and within the industry suggesting that these songs validate and promote bigotry and intolerance.'' ``Traditionally, music has often served as an important sounding board for the expression of social criticism and rage, and also provides an outlet for artists to vent their feelings. It goes without saying that artists have the right of freedom of expression,'' Yetnikoff said. Still, ``When the issue is bigotry, there is a fine line of acceptable standards which no piece of music should cross,'' he said. The music industry should ``challenge people to recognize the evils of racism, bigotry, anti-Semitism and intolerance in any and all forms.'' In its record, Public Enemy implies that Jews crucified Jesus and claims that it has been crucified for the comments of Professor Griff, a non-performing group member who claimed in a newspaper interview that Jews were responsible for most of the wickedness in the world. The group's leader, Chuck D., denied that lyrics were anti-Semitic or that the lyrics involved Jews at all. But Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, who met with Yetnikoff, welcomed the memo as ``an important first step for the music industry as a whole. ``We hope that this will mark the beginning of a long overdue process in which not only CBS Records, but all major record producers will begin to live up to their responsibility of combating rather than validating bigotry in America,'' he said. Cooper also has attacked statements by Axl Rose of Guns 'N Roses as homophobic and racist. Cooper said he intended to write a letter to David Geffen at Geffen Records _ Guns 'N Roses' record company _ challenging him to follow Yetnikoff's lead.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Patrick Pasculli says New Yorkers who claim the Empire State is the birthplace of baseball are way off base. Pasculli announced Wednesday the formation of American Baseball Heritage Inc., a non-profit organization formed to pitch this mile-square city as baseball's home and lobby nationally for ``Baseball Day,'' to be celebrated annually June 19. Hoboken will create a museum to chronicle the contributions of Alexander J. Cartwright. Pasculli said the first game of baseball was played on Hoboken's Elysian Fields during the afternoon of June 19, 1846. He credits Cartwright _ a surveyor, amateur athlete and inventor _ with refining the game. ``Once and for all we're going to destroy the fabrication that Abner Doubleday invented the game, and that Cooperstown, N.Y., was its birthplace,'' Paculli told a news conference. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, however, disagrees. Cuomo signed a bill in April that will allow New Yorkers to order license plates donning the picture of a ball and the words, ``Birthplace of Baseball.'' Stephen Speiser, president of the Hoboken group, thinks Cuomo's out in left field. The game really evolved from the British games of cricket and rounders, Speiser said. Cartwright refined it, wrote down the rules, and umpired the first game, he said. League historians at the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown agree that Cartwright played an important role early in the game. But they say New York has a better claim than New Jersey, by at least a year, of fielding the first match.

California, move over. Florida, which boasts more vehicles than people, has earned the dubious title of the car capital of the world. The state has 12.8 million residents _ and 15.1 million vehicles, according to the latest statistics from Florida's Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles. California has only 8.5 vehicles for every 10 people. Florida also leads the nation in new car sales. Some Floridians have one car for pleasure and another for work. Tourists want rental cars. Families buy junkers for teens. People who winter in Florida keep a spare in the state. Even those who might not be able to afford a car need something to get around in because of inadequate public transportation. ``The biggest thing these numbers say is what a lousy public transportation system we have in Florida,'' said John DeGrove, of the Joint Center for Urban universities. J.D. Power & Associates, a California-based research firm, found that Floridians buy 87.34 new cars for every 1,000 people each year, nearly 50 percent above the national average.

Is southern Florida big enough for two Manuel Noriegas? Manuel E. Noriega, a U.S. Navy veteran living in Miami Beach, isn't sure. Noriega says he has been bothered by harassing telephone calls from people who apparently have him confused with his notorious namesake. ``They have been very nasty calls. I try to explain, `Look, you're talking to the wrong guy,''' said the 84-year-old native of Mexico. He is the only Manuel Noriega listed the telephone book covering Miami, where deposed Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega was arraigned last week on drug trafficking charges. The Miami Beach Noriega worked for the Latin American division of DuPont before retiring. He now heads an export business.

An enterprising poster maker who sold nearly 750,000 targets featuring the Ayatollah Khomeini a few years back now has Manuel Noriega in his sights. Mike McCormack's latest creation: the smiling face of a uniformed Noriega with a superimposed bull's eye. ``I've been getting a lot of requests for this one,'' said McCormack, who also has brought out target posters of U.S. Sen. Ted Kennedy, D-Mass., former President Jimmy Carter and former Chicago Mayor Jane Byrne. ``A lot of military people have been requesting the Noriega poster,'' he said. The former Panama dictator's government was toppled by a U.S. invasion last month. ``Most of them couldn't go in the invasion, so they figure this is the closest they can get to him,'' McCormack said. ``I guess a lot of people want to see him hung.'' The 17-by-32 inch posters will sell for $4 each when they go on the market in the coming days, first in southern Florida, where Noriega now faces federal drug charges.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Moving Toward Vaccine For Lyme Disease
DOC.TEXT: A vaccine to protect against Lyme disease could be available in five years, said the inventor of a vaccine that has protected laboratory animals against infection. Russell Johnson, a microbiologist at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, said negotiations with makers of human vaccines should conclude within a month, allowing research to apply the animal vaccine to humans. The vaccine was patented by the University of Minnesota, and its use has been licensed to Molecular Genetics of Minneapolis, Johnson said. The company is now negotiating with vaccine makers, he said. The vaccine, developed in 1986, protects hamsters from infection with Lyme disease, which is spread by ticks, said Russell Johnson, a microbiologist at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. A vaccine to protect dogs and other animals against Lyme disease could be ready for use in a year, said Johnson. Development of a human vaccine takes longer because of the higher standards such a vaccine must meet, he said. Johnson said he and his colleagues showed in 1986 that injecting dead Lyme disease bacteria into hamsters would protect them against infection. Last month, researchers at the University of Wisconsin used a slightly different technique to protect hamsters against Lyme disease. They first produced antibodies against Lyme disease bacteria by injecting the bacteria into a group of hamsters, said Ronald Schell, director of the research. They then extracted the antibodies and used them to protect another group of hamsters, which had been irradiated so that they would lose their normal immune systems and would therefore show the symptoms of Lyme disease. When hamsters were given the antibodies before being infected, they developed no sign of disease, said Ronald Schell, director of the research. The finding was announced by the university in December and a report appears in the January issue of Infection and Immunity. Schell criticized the federal government for not providing more financial support for research on Lyme disease. ``The state of research for Lyme disease is being hampered because of the lack of federal support,'' he said. ``We want to get rid of the disease, and it seems now it might be easier than we thought.'' Lyme disease, which is spread by ticks found on deer, mice and other mammals, usually begins with a characteristic bull's-eye rash, a red ring around a clear center. It causes arthritis-like inflammation of the joints and can cause damage to the nervous system. It can usually be treated with antibiotics. Between 1980 and 1988 some 14,000 cases were reported in the United States, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control. The actual numbers may be several times that, doctors say. More than one-third of the cases, or about 5,000, occurred in 1988. Most cases have been confined to the Northeast, Wisconsin and Minnesota.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Platforms Halt Production as Redoubt Flooding Threatens Terminal
DOC.TEXT: Earthquakes continued to rumble under Redoubt Volcano and oil producers shut down their platforms amid fears the tremors could send floodwaters cascading over an oil terminal on the Cook Inlet. Redoubt has been erupting since mid-December, sending corrosive ash as high as eight miles into the sky and melting glacier ice, producing muddy torrents of water that have overflowed the banks of the Drift River. The Drift River storage terminal, with 38 million gallons of oil stored in its tanks, sits on the banks of the inlet in the shadow of the volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. The terminal has been closed since Tuesday, and officials planned to remove most of its oil. Redoubt's last eruption was Monday, but seismologists said the volcano remains active, and that more flooding was possible in future eruptions. ``The quake activity indicates the volcano is relatively quiet for now and it does not appear to be building toward stronger eruptive activity,'' geologist Steve Brantley of the Alaska Volcano Observatory said Wednesday. Still, a major eruption like Monday's is possible, he said. Ten of the 15 platforms that pull oil from the Cook Inlet send their crude to the Drift River terminal for storage. With the terminal closed, eight of the 10 platforms have been forced to shut down, said Bill Lamoreaux, a regional supervisor with the state Department of Environmental Conservation. ``The other two platforms are (operating at) very low volume,'' Lamoreaux said. There have been fears the flooding could breach storage tanks, causing a spill of the dimensions of the March 24 wreck of the tanker Exxon Valdez, which released 11 million gallons of North Slope crude into Prince William Sound. Harold Mouser, manager of Cook Inlet Pipe Line Co., which operates the terminal, said the tanker Sansinena was standing by to remove the terminal's oil as soon as the procedure is ready. ``We do not have our equipment operational yet for loading the tanker. People there are working on it and have been working through the night,'' Mouser said Wednesday. Cook Inlet Pipeline Co. and the state agreed Tuesday to shut down the terminal and remove about 80 percent of the oil. The terminal probably will not resume operations until the company and the state can agree how to operate it safely under the continuing threat of Redoubt, Lamoreaux said. ``They recognize they had a heck of an inventory of crude oil,'' he said. ``The facility sits right on the shoreline of Cook Inlet. The tank farm is on the back side, but there's nothing to stop it if the contents were lost.'' ``I'll be feeling a lot better when the total volume is reduced.'' The production halt could cost the state of Alaska some money, said Chuck Logsden, a petroleum economist with the Department of Revenue. The affected fields contributed much of the $23.3 million in royalties Alaska collected last year from Cook Inlet production, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Worst-Dressed Fashion Frumps `A Parade of Terrors,'' Mr. Blackwell Says
DOC.TEXT: Mr. Blackwell, the acid-tongued clothes critic who crusades against crimes of fashion, has placed singer LaToya Jackson atop his most-wanted list, calling her ``Cher for the 1990s.'' And in case you think that's a compliment, think again. Cher also made Blackwell's 1989 10 Worst-Dressed Women list, along with eight other actresses, singers and a member of the British royal family. ``In leather and chains, she's Cher for the 1990s,'' the outspoken oracle of style said of Miss Jackson, who gained notoriety when she posed nude for Playboy magazine. ``If I had her face and body I'd stay in bed all day.'' Blackwell also had unkind words about the sartorial splendor of Roseanne Barr, Demi Moore, Kim Basinger, Princess Anne, Emily Lloyd, Daryl Hannah, Paula Abdul and, in a tie for 10th, Madonna and Sandra Bernhard. ``The finalists were a parade of terrors that make The Joker in `Batman' look positively conservative by comparison,'' said Blackwell. ``Ninety-nine percent of these people could be mistaken for a baglady.'' Blackwell reserved special dishonorable mention for singer Grace Jones, whom he termed ``Darth Vader's S&M fantasy in a martian birdcage.'' Blackwell, whose real name is Richard Sylvan Selzer, held court at his well-appointed Hancock Park home Wednesday to unveil the 30th annual Worst-Dressed Women list. Television's Miss Barr was zinged as a ``bowling alley reject,'' former brat-packer Miss Moore was ``a spandexed `Nightmare on Willis Street,''' and ``Batman'' star Miss Basinger was a ``parading peep-show (who) should be banished to the batcave.'' Princess Anne was reduced to ``lumpy, dumpy and frumpy,'' Cher to a ``bag of tattooed bones in a sequinned slingshot,'' Miss Hannah to a ``Vegas Venus on steroids,'' Miss Abdul to a ``fashion gypsy (who) dances in the light (and) dresses in the dark,'' and Madonna and Bernhard to ``the Mutt and Jeff of MTV: vampy, trampy ... and cartoon campy.'' While some have questioned Blackwell's fashion credentials, he boasts that he formerly designed dresses for a distinguished clientele, including Zsa Zsa Gabor and Marilyn Monroe, before devoting full attention to his yearly list. ``I was a fashion designer with 450 accounts all over the world, but I left it two years ago when the miniskirt came back,'' he said. Blackwell said he does the list so that ``people who want star status don't make a mistake and copy'' the fashion frumps. After reading off the fashion rap sheet, Blackwell turned his attention to a select group of woman he considers fashion paragons. His Top 10 list of Fabulous Fashion Independents included first lady Barbara Bush, Geena Davis, Ivana Trump, Angela Lansbury, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Liza Minnelli, Barbara Walters, Tina Brown, Princess Diana and Jacqueline Onassis. Blackwell said only two of his targets for disdain ever complained _ Beatrice Arthur and Dinah Shore. ``They were furious,'' he said. ``But most of them love to make the list. I never insult them as people. This is an observation of what they look like to me. ``I adore many of them as performers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Loss of Interferon Genes Linked with Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: A form of blood cancer that strikes children appears to be sometimes linked with genetic damage that hinders the body's ability to make interferon, according to a study published today. The researchers speculate that genes that oversee the body's production of interferon, a disease-fighting substance, may play a role in warding off the development of cancer. The researchers speculate that the interferon genes may act as regulators that stop the body's cells from becoming cancerous. The researchers, based at the University of Chicago, found an association between loss of the genes and development of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, the most common form of childhood leukemia. They tested 62 patients with this kind of leukemia and found that 29 percent of them were missing the interferon genes. Their work, directed by Dr. Manuel O. Diaz, was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. It adds to the growing list of cancers that have been associated with the presence or absence of particular genes. Some genes, known oncogenes, are though to trigger cancer. Cancer can also occur when other genes, known as anti-oncogenes, are missing. Interferon plays a variety of roles in regulating the body's immune defenses and controlling cell growth. The production of two forms of interferon, known as alpha and beta-1, are controlled by two genes that are close together on chromosome 9 in the body's library of genes. In the latest work, the researchers found that this section of the chromosome was frequently missing in those with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. However, they left open the possibility that some other gene in this region besides those that make interferon could also be the tumor-suppressing gene. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia accounts for about one-quarter of all childhood cancers. It strikes one in every 30,000 children.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Cargo Plane Left Panama Just Before Invasion, Says Published Report
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli C-130 cargo plane carrying ``evidence'' of Israel's ties to the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took off from Panama City about six hours before U.S. troops invaded last month, according to a published report today that cites U.S. intelligence sources. The Washington Times said its sources, which were not identified, said the plane's departure came about the time an ex-Israeli master spy was tipped about the impending U.S. strike and fled the country. The paper said its sources did not know whether the Israeli, Mike Harari, was on the plane and likewise did not have specifics on what ``evidence'' was on the plane. Harari has appeared on television in Israel since the U.S. invasion and rejected suggestions that he helped Noriega with the Panamanian Defense Forces. The paper quoted a spokeswoman at the Israeli embassy in Washington, Ruth Yaron, as saying on Wednesday that ``as far as we know'' no Israeli C-130 took off from Panama on Dec. 19. As to whether Israel sold arms in Panama, Mrs. Yaron was quoted as saying: ``Our policy is not to give any details as to whom or what we sell. We don't discuss it.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies before easing off again in moderately active European trading early today. Gold prices rose by around $5 an ounce. Dealers said the dollar came off early highs in late morning trading as investors sifted through a variety of economic and political signals, mainly involving Eastern Europe, in a search for direction. ``It's a difficult moment to define the dollar's strength,'' said a trader in Milan, Italy. ``It did regain against the (West German) mark, but now is proving unable to maintain those levels.'' Dealers said the dollar benefited earlier today when concerns about the course of developments in Eastern Europe pressured the West German currency. The dollar also benefited from nationalist unrest in the Soviet Union, they said. Traders attributed the dollar's relapse to market fears of central bank intervention and investors' generally reflective stance. In Tokyo, the dollar edged down 0.03 Japanese yen to a closing 145.27 yen. Later, in London, it fell further to 145.25 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6837 West German marks, up from 1.6795 _1.5175 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120 _5.7340 French francs, up from 5.7145 _1.9035 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8815 _1,257.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.00 _1.1575 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1585 In London, the British pound fell to $1.6553 from $1.6625 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $411.80 a troy ounce, up from $408.55 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $413.55. In Zurich, the noon bid price was $413.85, up from $409.25 bid late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $5.54 to close at a bid $409.62. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.33 a troy ounce, up from $5.30 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leaders Say Rural Poor Still Hurting After Hugo
DOC.TEXT: Although nearly four months have passed since Hurricane Hugo smashed into the coast, it might as well be the morning after for thousands of the rural poor, community leaders say. J.T. McLawhorn Jr., the president of the Columbia Urban League, said the organization recently canvassed 17 of the 24 counties declared disaster areas by the federal government. During the effort, financed by a state grant, they found thousands of people bit is still like the day after Hugo,'' McLawhorn reporters Wednesday. He urged the Federal Emergency Management Agency to extend its deadline for applying for disaster aid beyond Saturday, and called on state leaders to develop a comprehensive plan to help victims. McLawhorn said the state has gone to great lengths to tell the world the recovery is under way, but, ``That doesn't apply to thousands and thousands of poor people.'' He said the real test for the recovery is not whether the state restores tourism or its beaches but in how well the people of the state recover. ``If they are worse off after Hugo then we have failed,'' he said. Hurricane Hugo smashed into South Carolina on Sept. 21. It's 135 mph winds caused an estimated $5.9 billion damage and killed 29 people in South Carolina. One outreach worker said that in Williamsburg County, poor families are living in homes with gaping holes in the roofs. Jim Liles said three families living in storm-damaged homes were left homeless when the remainder of the structures burned down because of kerosene heaters or faulty electric systems. Some of the rural poor have not applied for FEMA aid because they are iliterate or are suspicious of the government bureaucracy, said Glenice Pearson of the Urban League. Some, she said, are living in dilapidated rental structures that landlords have shown little inclination to repair. She said there is no need to keep the FEMA disaster centers open, but people should be permitted to continue to apply for aid through state and local agencies. FEMA's deadline already has been extended twice and officials say it is unlikely to do so again. McLawhorn said many hurricane victims think responsibility for the recovery rests with FEMA. He said the agency has done a good job, but, ``The buck for the Hugo recovery doesn't stop with FEMA. ``We can't blame FEMA. We, individually and collectively, are going to be held responsible for this recovery,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``They've got to kill the hooligans, not to beat them.'' _ Nicolae Ceausescu from a newly released transcript of his final Politburo meeting, as he threatened his top army commanders with the firing squad for ignoring an order to kill protesters demanding an end to his dictatorship.

``He had a kind of psycho look in his eyes, and he was grinning from ear to ear. It was a face you wouldn't forget.'' _ Stephen Newcomb, a convenience store clerk in Braintree, Mass., who was one of the last people to see Charles Stuart on the morning of his apparent suicide. Stuart had become the prime suspect in his pregnant wife's slaying.

``We are only catching the dumb ones.'' _ Dick Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, on why the NCAA toughened its anti-drug program to include year-round testing of football players.

DOC.HEAD: Citizens Regain Unlimited Access to Tiananmen; But Soldiers Out In Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with government spokesman saying troops will remain in city. Picks up 4th pvs, `The lifting...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist authorities today gave people unlimited access to Tiananmen Square for the first time since they crushed the pro-democracy movement, but hundreds of soldiers marched through it in a show of force. The familiar appearance of troops on the huge plaza, which student-led protesters virtually took over last spring, reminded Beijing residents of the lethal force authorities used to clear it in June. Although the government lifted martial law on the city Wednesday, a spokesman said today there will be a ``small increase'' in troops stationed in the capital and its suburbs. Yuan Mu told a news conference the troops were needed ``to safeguard public security and peaceful work of the people.'' He did not say how many troops were involved. An estimated 150,000 moved into the city last summer. More than seven months of martial law in the city ended at midnight Wednesday. In announcing the change, Premier Li Peng said the decision to order troops to smash the pro-democracy movement had been ``timely, necessary and correct.'' The lifting of martial law was welcomed in the United States, Britain, Japan and other Western nations that have said normal ties cannot be restored until Beijing eases what the countries consider repressive policies. However, the end of martial law will have little effect on life in the city. Police replaced military guards on Beijing streets in October and anti-demonstration laws remain in effect. Students also remain under heavy surveillance. Chinese citizens had not had free access to Tiananmen Square since June 3-4, when soldiers killed hundreds of civilians on their way to clearing the 100-acre plaza of pro-democracy protesters. The square was closed after the massacre and gradually reopened; until today, soldiers and police had screened all visitors and the square was closed at night. Shortly before noon, up to 1,000 troops camped in the history museum on the east side of the square marched across the plaza, chanting and singing military songs. They disappeared into a walled compound on the other side of the Great Hall of the People west of Tiananmen. ``I thought martial law was over,'' said one of the several thousand people strolling around Tiananmen. People also watched workmen remove barricades to widen access to the square, and lined up to have their pictures taken by professional photographers, back in business for the first time in months. Steps to the revolutionary martyrs' monument in the center of the square, students' headquarters during their three-week occupation of Tiananmen, were not open to the public as before. Two armed police stood guard at the monument. ``It's good that things are back to normal,'' said a women from Inner Mongolia, touring the square with her child. But one middle-aged man from Nanjing said, ``We don't have happy feelings'' about the lifting of martial law. He said people now cannot speak out. ``We have to keep things in our hearts.'' ``We haven't forgotten the students,'' said a Beijing teacher. Premier Li, in a 10-minute speech delivered on national television Wednesday evening, said that by calling in the army last spring the government had saved China from ``the abyss of misery.'' He said martial law, which he ordered on May 20, could be lifted because ``China is now stable politically, economically and socially.'' But, he added, the party had not softened its opposition to ``attempts to subvert the socialist system.'' The People's Daily said today in a front-page editorial: ``We must never drop our guard'' in the face of continued threats from ``international reactionary elements.'' The masses must be educated in patriotism, collectivism and socialism ``and we should give timely and forceful blows to the reactionary forces' destructive activities,'' it said. The government refers to the student-led protests as a ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' aimed at overthrowing the Communist Party and the socialist system. Premier Li imposed martial law in Beijing for the first time in 40 years of Communist rule after hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in May to demand democratic reforms and an end to official corruption. The decision was met by widespread resistance, with tens of thousands of Beijing residents setting up barricades to block troop convoys from entering the city. Then troops shot their way into the city and crushed the demonstrations. The government has since launched a nationwide campaign to crush dissent. It has arrested thousands and required millions of students and workers to undergo the most intense political indoctrination since the ultra-leftist 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. Beijing streets and college campuses remained quiet after Li's speech Wednesday night. Several students said the lifting of martial law made no difference, and noted that tight campus security would remain.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Charged in Daughter's Suicide Goes to Jail
DOC.TEXT: A woman convicted of driving her teen-age daughter to suicide by forcing her to work as a striptease dancer has begun serving a one-year jail term after a judge denied her request for house arrest. Broward Circuit Judge Arthur J. Franza on Wednesday ordered Theresa Jackson to begin her sentence immediately. Ms. Jackson's daughter, 17-year-old Tina Mancini, shot herself to death in March 1986 in their Coral Springs home. Last month, a state appeals court upheld Ms. Jackson's 1987 convictions on charges of mental child abuse, forgery and procuring a sexual performance by a child. Ms. Jackson altered her daughter's identification and ordered her to perform at nude bars, then collected most of the earnings, according to testimony at her trial, believed to be the first in which a person was charged with mental child abuse in connection with a suicide. After serving the jail term, Ms. Jackson will be under house arrest for two years followed by three years of probation. Ms. Jackson, 43, who worked as a cab driver while she remained free on $4,500 bond during her appeal, described herself Wednesday as a ``very loving, caring, kind and giving'' mother. But she conceded others might not agree. Those who doubt her, she said, ``don't know the truth.'' She said she is writing a book on her daughter's suicide and the circumstamces leading up to it. Ms. Jackson maintained that her daughter wanted to work as a dancer, and that she was unable to stop her. Last year, a judge approved an agreement between the state and Ms. Jackson requiring her to share with the state and with her 18-year-old son whatever money she might earn from her story. Ms. Jackson said Wednesday that she misses her daughter. ``I think the emotional scars a suicide victim leaves behind are worse than the suicide itself,'' she said. ``It's not fair. They're in peace, and you're still thinking about them.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Says Gunships Took Only 10 Minutes to Destroy Noriega HQ
DOC.TEXT: Deposed dictator Manuel Noriega was friendly to airmen who flew him to jail in Miami, even autographing their flight chart, says the commander of Air Force units that spearheaded the invasion of Panama. The Defense Department lifted a blackout Wednesday on information about special forces that participated in Operation Just Cause, and Col. George Gray III, commander of the 1st Special Operations Wing headquartered at this Florida Panhandle base, spoke at lenght with reporters at a news conference. Gray said his AC-130 Spectre gunships took only 10 minutes to demolish Noriega's headquarters. Twenty-five special operations planes and helicopters participated in the invasion, Gray said, including the MC-130 Combat Talon that flew Noriega out of Panama. ``He was very friendly towards the crew,'' Gray said. Noriega wrote ``Happy voyage'' in Spanish on the flight chart and then signed it ``M. Noriega.'' More than 500 personnel and all of the aircraft except two gunships already stationed in Panama were deployed from Hurlburt and adjacent Eglin Air Force Base. Gray said about 200 of his troops remain in Panama but their primary mission was completed Dec. 20, the first day of the invasion. ``We essentially spearheaded the operation,'' Gray said. ``We were to be there first to knock out Mr. Noriega's command and control and to eliminate any threats to our aircraft involved in airdropping the (Army) Rangers'' at two airfields. The U.S. planes knocked out anti-aircraft artillery at the three targets, he said. Gray's airmen suffered no combat casualties and the only damage was a single small-arms round that struck one of the aircraft. He declined to say how many gunships were used in the assault on the headquarters of the Panama Defense Forces, known as the Comandancia, but 11 AC-130s were involved in the overall operation. He said the gunships had only 10 minutes to accomplish their mission at the Comandancia, blasting it with 105 mm Howitzers and rapid-fire 40 mm cannons, before ground forces arrived. There were reports of extensive damage and some casualties in the surrounding neighborhood, also attacked by artillery from the ground. ``The rules of engagement for us were very, very clear: absolute minimum civilian casualties, absolute minimum collateral damage,'' Gray said. ``And the only way to do that is by employing a surgical firepower platform such as the AC-130. All rounds were on target within the Comandancia.'' Gray said the firepower demonstrated by the gunships, armed versions of the C-130 transport, probably intimidated other Panamanian troops into surrendering. ``After they saw the destruction of the Comandancia, I think they very quickly realized they didn't want to take us on,'' Gray said. ``We gave them the opportunity to surrender. We would pay them a visit and they chose to surrender.'' The gunships probably saved many American lives, Gray said. But some lives may have been lost because one of the planes had to return to Hurlburt with problems in its fire control equipment. Overall, Gray said of his units' performance, ``It was done absolutely to perfection. If I had to do everything again I probably wouldn't have changed anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Cast Left Without Costumes When Outfits Taken to Dump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES spelling of `accidentally.'
DOC.TEXT: The cast of ``Les Miserables'' got caught with its pants down when costumes from one scene in the musical were accidentally thrown in the garbage. The costumes were placed in plastic trash bags Sunday to be taken to the cleaners. But an employee of the Benedum Center for Performing Arts, where the touring show of the Broadway musical is being performed, mistakenly added those bags to the theater's garbage and all of it was taken to the dump Tuesday. Actors wear raggedy outfits typical of clothing worn by street rebels from the French Revolution. The wardrobe director, Jerry Wolf, confirmed the costumes _ worth about $50,000 _ were discarded inadvertently. The show went on as scheduled without the costumes, and replacement clothing was sent from New York.

DOC.HEAD: Famous Lawyers Consider Joining Noriega Defense Team
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 11, `Sonnett and ...' and 15, `Houston attorney ...' to CORRECT spelling of `Noriega.'
DOC.TEXT: Some of the nation's most formidable courtroom warriors are being lured to the legal battle of Manuel Noriega, drawn by the klieg lights focused on what could be one of the great trials of the era. They include defense attorneys who have worked some famous cases of the last decade, with clients such as New York subway gunman Bernhard Goetz, reputed Mafia chieftain John Gotti and an army officer allegedly linked to the assassination of El Salvador's archbishop. ``Manuel Noriega may or may not have a trial, but he should be assured the best the American justice system allows,'' said New York attorney Barry Slotnick, who said he would decide this week whether to join the case. The changes in the defense team appear to hinge on Slotnick, 50, whose clients have included Goetz and Gotti. Slotnick said he was contacted by Noriega representatives and asked to defend the deposed Panamanian dictator, who faces 145 years in prison and fines up to $1.1 million if convicted. A February 1988 indictment charges Noriega with taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombian cocaine dealers to turn his nation into a way station for smugglers. As co-counsel, Slotnick is seeking prominent Miami defense attorney Neal Sonnett, who withdrew from the Noriega case earlier this month, citing differences with other defense lawyers. Sonnett's clients have included Hernan Botero, a Colombian extradited to Florida and convicted for laundering $56 million in drug money; Lebanese-born arms dealer Sarkis Soghanalian, and Alvaro Saravia, at one time sought for extradition to El Salvador, where he was accused of complicity in the 1980 assassination of Roman Catholic Archbishop Oscar Romero. The Salvadoran government later dropped its request. Sonnett, 47, said Wednesday he would ``give high consideration'' to returning to the case with Slotnick. ``This case will present some of the most challenging issues raised in an American court of law. It's any attorney's dream to be part of it,'' said Sonnett, president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers. Sonnett and Slotnick say they have no desire to oust Noriega's present defense team, led by Frank Rubino and Steven Kollin. But Sonnett, who objected to statements about the case by the other defense attorneys, said clear lines of authority would be drawn if he rejoined. While defense attorneys will not discuss how they will be compensated, Slotnick said he will not represent Noriega for free. ``This case will require extensive resources and it will be conducted in the great tradition of the American free enterprise system ... we will get paid,'' he said. Kollin and Rubino did not return telephone calls to their offices by The Associated Press on Wednesday. Houston lawyer Richard ``Racehorse'' Haynes also has been contacted by an unidentified Noriega representative and is considering joining the Noriega case. Haynes' assistant, Judy Fogarty, said there is no deadline for a decision by Haynes, 62, who gained national attention for winning two murder acquittals for Texas tycoon T. Cullen Davis in the 1970s. Davis was accused of shooting his estranged wife and killing her lover and 12-year-old daughter. As for the prosecution, a Bush administration official told the AP that Justice Department officials may give U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen the choice of running his office or taking the lead prosecution role in Noriega's trial. A spokeswoman at Lehtinen's office, Diane Cossin, refused to comment on the report, saying the team has not been announced. Noriega, 51, has been held in a basement apartment in the Miami federal courthouse since arriving in the United States last Thursday. He awaits a Jan. 26 bond hearing.

DOC.HEAD: No-confidence Debate Opens in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties today debated the first no-confidence motion against the president, accusing his year-old government of failing to restore peace and condoning violence by paramilitary groups. President Ranasinghe Premadasa's United National Party was expected to have no trouble defeating the motion in a vote expected to take place Friday night. The motion was presented by the Sri Lanka Freedom Party, which is headed by former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike. Premadasa's party has 124 of Parliament's 225 seats. Mrs. Bandaranaike's party and three other parties supporting the no-confidence motion have a total of 84 seats. Most of the remaining seats are held by legislators who have said they will not support the no-confidence motion. At least 6,500 people have been killed in Sri Lanka's ethnic and political wars since Premadasa took office Jan. 2, 1989, according to tallies kept by the military. The no-confidence motion said Premadasa's government had failed to restore peace, order and normalcy. It accused the government of permitting and encouraging illegal paramilitary groups to kidnap, torture and murder civilians. The motion also charged that the government had mismanaged the economy, ignored corruption and discriminated against political opponents. The United National Party has been in power since 1977 when it defeated Mrs. Bandaranaike's Freedom Party. In 1983, a revolt by Tamil separatists in northeastern Sri Lanka plunged the once-idyllic island nation into a vicious spiral of massacre, murder and mayhem. By 1987, efforts to make peace with the Tamil minority had spawned a backlash by ultranationalist Sinhalese against their fellow Sinhalese who control the government. More than 11,000 people have died in the 7-year-old Tamil war, while at least 6,000 more have been killed in the past 2{ years in the internal Sinhalese battle. Sinhalese account for 75 percent of the country's 16 million people. Tamils comprise 18 percent and say the Sinhalese discriminate against them in jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Begin Dismantling Border Fences with Romania
DOC.TEXT: Soviet border guards have begun tearing down the barbed wire barricades along the tightly controlled Romanian border, a KGB official said. The official Tass news agency quoted Georgy Lavranchuk, head of the KGB in the Soviet republic of Moldavia that borders Romania, as saying Wednesday that about 30 miles of barbed wire had been removed. Soviet and Romanian officials also are moving to eliminate the border passes that previously were required, Tass said. ``From now on there is no need for special passes if residents of border villages enter the frontier zone for rest and recreation,'' Tass said. Crossing regulations have been simplified at seven border points, it said, without identifying them. The moves came after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze visited Bucharest on Jan. 6 and said that the two sides would work quickly to dismantle border restrictions. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warmly greeted the revolution in December that threw out hard-line Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Romanians and ethnic Moldavians speak nearly the same language and are members of the same ethnic group. But the border between them has been among the most closely guarded in the East Bloc. Soviets discouraged close border contacts after the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, in which Romania refused to take part. In the past several years, as Gorbachev has reformed the Soviet Union, Ceausescu restricted border contacts to keep Romanians from seeing how poorly they lived compared to others. Shevardnadze said he had agreed with Romania's new leaders to establish more liberal border crossing rules such as the Soviet Union has with Hungary and Poland. In the past, relatives have been allowed to make visits across the Romania-Soviet border only on special family occasions, such as weddings and funerals. A few cultural figures and scholars also have been allowed to make visits. The Tass report did not explain the new regulations. But it is likely that they will require a minimum of paperwork to allow people to cross the border.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh's `Irises' Reported Back on Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT style on van Gogh; ADDS date of painting in 3rd graf, `Bond bought ...'
DOC.TEXT: Vincent van Gogh's ``Irises,'' the world's most expensive painting, is reportedly back on the block after the businessman who bought it failed to pay off a loan from the auction house that sold it. Australian businessman Alan Bond, who purchased ``Irises'' in November 1987 for a record $53.9 million, has put it back on the market, The New York Times said today. Bond bought the 1889 masterpiece with the help of a $27 million loan from Sotheby's auction house, which handled the sale. The one-year loan has not been paid off and has been extended twice, the newspaper said. ``There are discussions going on regarding the sale of the painting. They are going on directly with Mr. Bond,'' said Michael Ainslie, president of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. ``We are having discussions with several parties,'' said Michael Cross, managing director of Dallhold Investment Ltd., a privately held company owned by Bond. ``We have received a great many approaches but nothing is conclusive at this stage.'' Ainslie also said Sotheby's will no longer extend loans to art buyers using the artworks they purchase as collateral. ``Irises'' was used as collateral on the loan that helped Bond buy the painting, an arrangement criticized by dealers and collectors for driving up art prices. The loan arrangement was disclosed by Cross in October. By that time, Sotheby's reportedly had moved the painting to a secret location. The disclosure of the loan and the fact that Bond didn't have ``Irises'' in his possession shocked the art community, the Times said. The report that the painting is for sale comes at a time when Bond's corporate empire has outstanding debts of more than $5 billion, the newspaper said. The sale of ``Irises'' for the record price was viewed at the time as a great boost to the financial well-being of the art market after the Wall Street collapse of Oct. 19, 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Student Sent to Jail in Woman's Death
DOC.TEXT: A college student who says he released the emergency brake on a pizza delivery car blocking a fraternity house driveway drew a year in jail for the death of a woman hit by the runaway vehicle. Brett B. Weinstein, a 21-year-old West Virginia University honor student from King of Prussia, Pa., was also fined $1,500 Wednesday by Circuit Judge Larry Starcher after a no-contest plea to involuntary manslaughter and battery. Jennifer Ann Wehner, 19, of Chappaqua, N.Y., a WVU freshman, was killed in April when the delivery car careened down a hill and struck her in front of a dormitory. Two other young women were injured. Weinstein said he had released the brake and put the gearshift in neutral to move the vehicle from the driveway. The judge said the WVU finance senior would be allowed to leave jail to attend class but must return shortly after his last class each day. Weinstein could become eligible for release after 10 months. Wehner's parents have filed a $10 million lawsuit against Weinstein, his parents and the pizza business.

DOC.HEAD: Government Promises Investigation Into Writer's Death
DOC.TEXT: A senior Politburo member has promised an investigation into the 1978 slaying of a prominent emigre writer who died after he was jabbed by a poison-tipped umbrella in London. Politburo member Alexander Lilov made the pledge after meeting Wednesday with Annabel Markov, the widow of writer Georgi Markov. Mrs. Markov said her husband's slaying was ``one of the darkest crimes of the Cold War'' and that she wants Communist authorities to take responsibility. Lilov is among the reformers who have assumed control since the Nov. 10 ouster of hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. Zhivkov, who once received Markov in his villas and hunting lodges, was in power when Markov was murdered nine years after the author defected while on a trip to Italy in 1969. There has long been speculation that the orders to kill Markov came from Sofia. Asked if Lilov said Bulgaria's former hard-line leaders were linked to her husband's death, Mrs. Markov replied: ``There was not a specific admission. But he said this had been a terrible time for Bulgaria, and things had happened that shouldn't have happened.'' The British native said she is not seeking any kind of retribution. ``I just want them to admit responsibility for what they've done.'' Mrs. Markov said she felt confident the government would investigate. Many hard-line Communists remain in power, but Bulgaria's new leaders have promised democratic reforms and are trying to cast off the country's Stalinist image. A special parliamentary commission already has said it has enough evidence to proceed with an investigation of Zhivkov on suspicion of diverting state funds into Swiss bank accounts. Bulgaria's ambassador in London said Tuesday that his country would finally investigate the death of Markov, one of Bulgaria's foremost authors before his murder in London on Sept. 29, 1978. British investigators concluded that Markov, who worked for the British Broadcasting Corp.'s Bulgarian service, was killed by poison injected through an umbrella tip as he waited for a bus on London's Westminster Bridge. Before he fell into a coma, Markov told friends he had been jabbed from behind. The author had made public comments highly critical of Zhivkov's rule before his death. Vladimir Kostov, an outspoken emigre in Paris, survived what he says was a similar attempt to kill him with a poison pellet. Lilov also pledged that Bulgaria for the first time will publish Markov's posthumously collected memoirs, ``The Truth That Killed,'' Mrs. Markov said. The book, already published in the United States and Britain, is a collection of essays that testify to the psychological and moral damage inflicted by Stalinism in Bulgaria. ``His memoirs are like a document of what 35 years of totalitarian rule did to the country,'' Mrs. Markov said.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Threatened Underlings With Death For Ignoring Orders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with report of Ceausescu bribe, official death toll. TRIMS from bottom. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu threatened army commanders at their final meeting with execution for ignoring orders to kill protesters, and a newspaper report today said that he offered more than $5 million to be freed when he was later captured by revolutionists. According to the minutes of the Dec. 17 meeting, the dictator berated his top men for shooting blanks at the crowds in the western city of Timisoara. ``They've got to kill the hooligans, not to beat them,'' the hard-line Communist leader said angrily. Ceausescu's wife, Elena, told the meeting the protesters should be hurled into the basement jails of the Securitate, the secret police, and never again ``see the light'' of day. A transcript of stenographers' notes from the meeting _ what turned out to be the Communist Party Politburo's last gathering _ was published Wednesday in the daily newspaper, Romania Libera. Ceausescu was overthrown on Dec. 22 when army troops and citizens rebelled against him, and he was executed along with his wife on Christmas Day. The official Rompres news agency today quoted Silviu Brucan, a senior member of the new government, as saying about 10,000 people died in revolutionary clashes in Timisoara, Bucharest, Sibiu, Brasov and other cities. Western diplomats in Bucharest, citing witnesses and other accounts, also said earlier that about 10,000 had been killed. According to the minutes, Defense Minister Vasile Milea, Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu and chief of the Securitate secret police Iulian Vlad first tried to reason with Ceausescu, then pledged to carry out his orders. Milea, originally reported to have committed suicide several days after the meeting, later was found to have been slain by Ceausescu henchmen. Postelnicu and Vlad are under arrest and awaiting trial, along with hundreds of other Ceausescu underlings. Crowds in Timisoara had broken into the local party headquarters on Dec. 16, and troops armed only with truncheons and blank ammunition had been unable _ or unwilling _ to stop them. Troops issued live ammunition later fired at the unarmed protesters, causing the outrage and revulsion of a nation that endured 24 years of Ceausescu's repression and harsh economic policy. According to the minutes, Ceausescu at times seemed to lose control of his emotions as he criticized the army commanders for not following his orders to fire on the crowds. ``I didn't think you would shoot with blanks, that is like a rain shower,'' Ceausescu said. ``Those who entered the party building should not leave the building alive.'' The notes showed that Milea, Postelnicu and Vlad became submissive when he accused them of treason and threatened to have them shot. ``I have told you that all have to be armed,'' Ceausescu shouted at Postelnicu. ``Who has given this order? When I understand that Securitate troops are going somewhere, it is clear to me that they are going armed. You send them to fight with fists, what kind of interior units are you?'' The 71-year-old dictator's fury appeared to peak when told by Milea that he had decided not to supply army units facing the Timisoara demonstrators with ammunition. ``Why didn't you give them ammunition? If you don't give them ammunition, you might as well keep them at home. What kind of defense minister are you, what kind of interior minister are you, Postelnicu? They received orders to fight and not to go on maneuvers.'' ``A few hooligans want to destroy socialism, and you make it child's play for them!'' Ceausescu shouted. ``You do not quiet an enemy by talking with him like a priest, but by burning him.'' Mrs. Ceausescu spoke little but expressed her contempt of the defiant Timisoara protesters. ``You should shoot them so they fall, and put them in (Securitate) basements,'' she said. ``Not even one should see the light (of day) again.'' As the revolution flickered fitfully in Timisoara, she and her husband alternately berated and threatened Milea, Postelnicu and Vlad to try to get their support. ``They are cowards,'' Mrs. Ceausescu said. ``They are more than cowards,'' Ceausescu said. ``As supreme commander, I consider that you have committed treason against the country's supreme interests, and against the people's interest and against the interests of socialism. ``Do you know what I'm going to do with you?'' he said. ``Send you to the firing squad!'' The historic record of the meeting vividly underlined the control exercised by the Ceausescus over the party, whose apparatus constructed a personality cult reminiscent of Josef Stalin. Few other of the 25 other leading functionaries present spoke as the Ceausescus vented their anger. When they did, it was submissive. After his later flight from the capital, Ceausescu promised one of the two uniformed policemen who captured him and his wife $5 million to release them, the daily Adevarul said. It quoted Col. Gen. Jean Moldoveanu, the deputy interior minister, as saying, ``At a certain time, Ceausescu promised the non-commissioned officer $5 million ... I repeat, $5 million,'' to let them escape. ``Seeing that the policeman remained unmoved, the tyrant raised the price, promising him more than $5 million,'' Moldoveanu reportedly said without specifying the sum.

DOC.HEAD: Woman: Raped and Entombed Overnight in a Hole
DOC.TEXT: Police charged a man with kidnapping and raping a young woman who said she was entombed overnight in a 9-foot-deep hole ventilated by a pipe. William R. Grau, a 48-year-old man neighbors describe as a loner, was arrested Wednesday and awaited a bail hearing today. The 19-year-old woman said Grau threw her into a hole he had dug that measured 4 feet wide and had a thick plastic glass cover, a ladder and a lightbulb strung on wire, according to sheriff's spokesman Jack Espinosa. ``You can only imagine what this must have looked like to this girl, this hole in the dark and fog,'' Espinosa said. ``It's like a ladder to your grave.'' She said she was abducted from her mobile home, sexually assaulted, bound hand and foot, gagged and buried in a nine-hour ordeal that began Tuesday night. She escaped when her captor pulled her out and dragged her toward a ditch on a swampy, wooded property in nearby Thonotosassa, authorities said. The woman found her way back home. She sought treatment for trauma, cuts and bruises.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Celebrated Giant Frogs Not Welcome in California
DOC.TEXT: An animal collector who wants to enter Goliath African frogs in Calaveras County's frog jump says California's import restrictions won't stop him from bringing in his 10 mighty leapers. State officials said Wednesday that Andy J. Koffman's 3-foot frogs would be unwelcome, a ruling likely to come as a relief to entrants in the contest inspired by the Mark Twain story ``The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County.'' The Goliath African frogs, which weigh up to 12 pounds, can clear 30 feet in a single bound, while the record leap in past Frog Jumping Jubilees is 21 feet, 5} inches _ in three hops. ``Under the Fish and Game code, those species are considered undesirable and prohibited from import,'' said Lenny Clavecilla, a spokesman for the California Fish and Game Department. Clavecilla said Koffman will need permits to bring the frogs into the state, ``and we wouldn't be inclined to issue them for that purpose.'' The frogs could loose in the wild and harm native wildlife, he said. But Koffman called the restrictions ``bureaucratic nonsense'' and he said he was determined to enter his frogs in the 62-year-old jubilee in May in Angels Camp, a community in the Sierra Nevada foothills 150 miles east of San Francisco. ``I've been a licensed importer in this country probably longer than they've been bureaucrats,'' he said. Jubilee officials, who are scheduled to consider the issue Friday, have expressed fears that the sharp-toothed frogs could leap off the stage and into someone's lap. Moreover, they believe the African frogs would be unfair competition for the domestic variety. The record jump was set by a normal-size frog named Rosie the Ribiter in 1986. Interim fair manager Diane Baumann said the state's position may make local action moot. ``It definitely takes us off the hook, but it sort of ruins the whole issue,'' she said. ``Let's face it, we're getting a lot of publicity out of this.''

DOC.HEAD: Singh Announces Concessions in Effort to Stop Sikh Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Singh announcing concessions to Sikhs. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh today announced major concessions intended to end Sikh separatism in Punjab state but told tens of thousands of Sikhs and Hindus he has no ``magic wand'' to bring peace to the region. Singh said Sikh deserters from the Indian army will be given employment in other government organizations and that the detentions of jailed Sikhs will be reviewed. These have been key demands in the Sikh movement. Hundreds of Sikh soldiers mutinied when the army attacked the Golden Temple, Sikhism's holiest shrine, in 1984. There were hundreds of deserters. The number of Sikh detainees is not known, but it is easily in the hundreds and possibly thousands. Singh spoke at a public rally in the Punjab city of Ludhiana that the government organized as part of its movement to restore peace in the state. ``When blood flows in Punjab, it is the country's heart that bleeds,'' Singh said. ``I have not come here with a magic wand. The solution is not in the corridors of New Delhi but in the wheatfields of Punjab.'' A resolution adopted at the end of the three-hour rally said: ``Violence and the use of coercive methods must be put (to) an end and security of life and property and respect for human rights for all must be exercised.'' The rebellion in the agriculturally rich state on India's border with Pakistan began in 1982, when Sikh militants accused the majority Hindu community of discrimination. ``The rally will mobilize people of Punjab to quash secessionist efforts,'' said Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral, a key figure in the government's moves to end the Sikh campaign, which has claimed thousands of lives and kept the state in turmoil. Gujral, who was elected to Parliament from Punjab, is a Hindu widely respected among Sikhs. Today's rally was held on the grounds of a college. People began streaming to the site an hour before the meeting began and continued to pour in hours after politicians started speaking. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, estimated the crowd at 100,000. Many came from villages around Ludhiana, a city of 800,000 known for its garment and bicycle factories. The Punjab state police chief, K.P.S. Gill, said: ``There is absolute tight security. We are prepared for anything. No problem.'' The ground was surrounded by about 5,000 policemen, many on horseback. The rally was Singh's second effort to bring peace to Punjab since he replaced Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister. Singh was sworn in as prime minister on Dec. 2 after Gandhi's Congress Party failed to win a majority in the Nov. 22-26 general elections. Singh had called a meeting of all political parties in New Delhi on Dec. 17 to discuss the Punjab problem. But the Akali Dal, a semi-religious Sikh party, did not attend, saying the effort was futile. A consensus statement issued by about 40 leaders at the meeting condemned ``terrorism'' in Punjab, but the Congress Party disassociated itself from the statement, saying the party was not consulted when the statement was drafted. The Akali Dal party, which the separatists tacitly support, and Gandhi's Congress Party refused to attend today's meeting. But Akali Dal leader Simranjit Singh Mann received Singh when he landed at an airfield near Ludhiana. ``It is courtesy to receive the prime minister when he comes to your house,'' said Mann, who spent five years in jail on charges of sedition and being involved in the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. Sikh bodyguards killed Mrs. Gandhi in retaliation for her decision that year to raid the Golden Temple, where militant Sikhs were holed up. More than 2,000 people, mostly Sikhs, died in the raid.

DOC.HEAD: Recall Drive Against Gay School Board Member Fails
DOC.TEXT: A recall drive against a gay school board member in this San Francisco suburb failed when organizers were unable to gather enough signatures to put the measure on the June ballot. But even as Robert Stipicevich congratulated residents for ``not succumbing to fear,'' his opponents said they would press on with an effort to defeat him in the November election. ``It's not a defeat, it's a minor setback,'' said Ron Smith, spokesman for the Fremont Family Alliance, which opposed what it called the board member's ``advocacy of a homosexual lifestyle.'' The group said it had failed to gather 12,219 signatures by Wednesday's deadline but declined to reveal how many were collected. The town has a population of more than 130,000. Stipicevich, 26, was one of the youngest elected officials in the state when he won a school board seat in 1985. He disclosed his homosexuality at a news conference in May, saying he was tired of others' whispering behind his back. Recall backers accused him of defrauding voters by not disclosing his homosexuality earlier, but Stipicevich maintained the recall campaign stemmed from misconceptions and hysteria. ``Fremont is not a blue-collar, backwater town,'' he said. ``It is a progressive community and this (the recall) was a growing pain. ... The only thing Family Alliance succeeded in doing was making my name a household word.'' Stipicevich said he has not decided whether to seek re-election.

DOC.HEAD: French Official Holds Talks with Romanian Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details of talks. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France today pledged help for this country's shattered economy during the first visit by a Western foreign minister since the overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The French official, who arrived Wednesday as a guest of Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac, said in an airport statement that he carried ``feelings of admiration for what the Romanian people have done, knowing how to free themselves of the dictatorship,'' the official Rompres news agency reported. ``France, which has been on Romania's side since the very first day in this time of trial, is still with her in everything we can do to be together,'' the Romanian agency quoted Dumas as saying. France and Romania have strong historical ties. Before World War II, many Romanians went to France to study, and French was the main foreign language spoken in the country. Rompres said that during today's talks with interim President Ion Iliescu, Dumas conveyed a message from President Francois Mitterrand pledging France's material and moral support for the ``consolidation of the conquests of the popular revolution and for political stability in Romania.'' Iliescu reportedly thanked France, but no details of any new aid for the ailing centralized economy were announced. Late last year, a bloody revolution by pro-democracy forces overthrew the 24-year rule of Ceausescu, the hard-line Communist leader. He and his wife Elena, his second in command, were executed on Christmas Day.

DOC.HEAD: Loser Challenges Gandhi's Election Victory
DOC.TEXT: The re-election of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi to Parliament has been challenged in court by the candidate he defeated in voting marred by violence and fraud charges, news reports said today. Rajmohan Gandhi, grandson of independence leader Mohandas K. Gandhi, filed a petition Wednesday in Lucknow saying the former prime minister's campaign workers resorted to terror, bribery and abuse of power during November's balloting, according to reports in The Statesman and other newspapers. ``My petition alleges that the election was conducted in defiance of all rules and regulations and of every democratic norm,'' The Statesman quoted the losing candidate as saying when he left the court building in Lucknow. The two Gandhis are not related. The challenger asked the High Court of the state of Uttar Pradesh to declare the poll invalid and hold new elections. No date was given for further court action. After an investigation of the Nov. 24 voting in the two candidates' Amethi constitutency, the Election Commission threw out thousands of ballots and ordered a partial repoll in the poor rural district 60 miles southeast of Lucknow. The revote was ordered after Rajmohan Gandhi and his Janata Dal Party complained of widespread voter fraud and intimidation by supporters of Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party. In the most dramatic confrontation, a local Janata Dal leader was seriously wounded when he was shot in the stomach during a dispute with Congress Party workers on election day. In the final vote count, Rajiv Gandhi won 270,471 votes to Rajmohan Gandhi's 69,099. Nationwide, the elections were the most violent in India's 42 years of independence. At least 140 people died across the country during the voting. The Congress Party lost control of the goverment, and V. P. Singh of the National Front alliance came to power as prime minister. Rajiv Gandhi was relegated to the role of opposition leader in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Indictates Opposition Could Join Gov't
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th pvs, `He also...' to UPDATE with police chief, former Politburo member ousted; picks up 6th pvs, `In his...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist Premier Hans Modrow today indicated that opposition groups could join his governing coalition, which has been shaken by threats of a walkout by three traditionally allied parties. But Modrow defended an unpopular plan to set up a successor to the hated secret police network before multiparty elections on May 6. The allied parties threatened to leave the coalition, and other pro-democracy opposition groups threatened to break off talks on the government's future after hearing that a new secret police organization would be formed. ``In the interests of our country's citizens, there cannot be a security vacuum,'' Modrow told Parliament. As a partial concession, Modrow offered to have Parliament supervise the planned new internal security agency and the dissolution of its predecessor, popularly known as ``Stasi.'' He also said the government would suspend a plan to give state support, such as pensions, to former secret police, a proposal that had provoked warning strikes from factory workers in recent days. Earlier today, Parliament ousted the head of the state security police, Lt. Gen. Wolfgang Schwanitz, and appointed a new chief prosecutor. It also voted out several old-guard Communists and other members of the 500-seat legislature, including Guenther Schabowski, a former Politburo member. In his nearly 90-minute address, Modrow told the opposition to make suggestions about how ``it would be prepared to participate directly and responsibly in the work of the government.'' Modrow did not say when or in exactly what form such participation could take place. In Bonn, the West German government welcomed Modrow's speech for ``beginnings that could lead further.'' But government spokesman Dieter Vogel said much depends on how much government access Modrow actually gives the reform groups. Modrow also called on the opposition to offer its ideas on new legislation, including a draft election law. That proposal, which would formally authorize the May 6 vote, has drawn fire from the reform groups and West Germany for containing a ban on all campaign aid from abroad. Opponents charge this would greatly help the Communists, who still control state media and essentials such as paper supplies and copying machines. Opposition groups planned to form a human chain around the Parliament building tonight to protest what they perceive as the coalition government's reluctance to make democratic reforms. Modrow rejected that charge and said the oppostion should not issue ultimatums. The opposition Social Democrats today demanded Modrow allow opposition leaders to join in talks with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Modrow rejected the opposition's questioning of his authority to rule. ``I cannot recall becoming premier through a coup,'' he said. Modrow reportedly was considering calling for a national referendum on his government before the election, but he did not mention that in his speech to Parliament. In reviewing his first eight weeks in office, Modrow said ``the aim is not to maintain the old structure'' of the hated secret police, which the government has promised to dismantle. Many East Germans appeared to be worried about the continued political turmoil in their nation and the Communist in turn are worrying about their chances in the May elections. The political infighting is the most serious setback since Modrow's caretakr government was seated in mid-November, compounding the problems of a sagging economy, a continuing exodus to the West and labor strikes. East Germany has seen major changes since the Oct. 18 ouster of hard-line leader Erich Honecker. But Communist control of the country remains strong, and many promises made by the new leaders still have not become law. Leading the list is the proposed law that will actually authorize the May 6 elections, the first free voting in the country's 40-year history. The Christian Democrats and the Liberal Democrats, two of the current coalition partners, said Wednesday that they would quit Modrow's Cabinet if the new law fails to meet their demands. Together, the Christian Democrats and Liberal Democrats have seven seats in the 28-member Cabinet. The National Democrats, another non-Communist party with two seats, have also threatened to desert Modrow. Party leaders on Wednesday also cited the re-establishment of the secret police as a reason to pull out.

DOC.HEAD: Man Slashes Painting With Knife In National Gallery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with suspect appearing in court; ADDS other estimates of value of painting, expectation painting can be restored, CORRECTS year painting was put on display. Pickup penultimate graf pvs, `In 1987...
DOC.TEXT: A man with a knife slashed a painting by the 16th century Italian artist Federico Baroccio at the National Gallery, officials said. He was ordered today to stand trial on charges of causing criminal damage. The state-funded gallery, home of some of the greatest art treasures in Britain, said in a statement that the painting _ ``The Madonna and Child with St. Joseph and the Infant Baptist'' _ was cut in nine places in Wednesday's attack. Guards wrestled the knife from the assailant, identified as Martin Came, 27. No hometown was provided. The National Gallery said its conservation and restoration department will take ``maybe more than a year'' to repair the painting, which measures 44 inches by 36 inches and is said to be worth at least $1.6 million. ``At the moment, we believe that complete restoration will be possible,'' said a gallery spokeswoman who refused to be identified. Came appeared at Bow Street Magistrates Court today on charges of causing criminal damage and was ordered to stand trial Feb. 1 pending medical reports from a western England hospital where he has undergone unspecified treatment. Baroccio, or Barocci as he is sometimes known, worked at the same time as Michelangelo. Baroccio spent most of his time in the Italian city of Urbino but the two men met in Rome in the 1550s and Michelangelo encouraged the younger artist with his work. The damaged painting had been on display since it was bequeathed to the gallery in 1831. Gallery experts refused to estimate its value. But a lesser known work by the same artist sold for $209,160 at Christie's auctioneers last year. Britain's domestic news agency, Press Association, said the painting, has been valued at $1.6-4.8 million. But art critic Brian Sewell said the painting could fetch as much as $25 million. Baroccio was ``monumentally influential in his time ... and none of his work that is really authentic has come on the market for donkey's years,'' he said. In 1987, a man with a shotgun blasted one of the gallery's greatest treasures, Leonardo da Vinci's drawing The Virgin and Child with St. Anne and St. John the Baptist, as it hung on show.
