The da Vinci drawing underwent an intricate 15-month restoration and is now back on show. The gunman, Robert Cambridge, age 38 at the time, was ordered to be held indefinitely at Broadmoor hospital for the criminally insane when he appeared at London's Old Bailey Central Criminal Court in June 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Saxophonist Georgie Auld Dies at Age 70
DOC.TEXT: Georgie Auld, a saxophonist who played with Benny Goodman and Artie Shaw and taught actor Robert De Niro how to hold the instrument for the movie ``New York, New York'' has died at age 70. Auld died at his home Monday of lung cancer. He was born John Altwerger in Toronto, Canada. A self-taught saxophonist who did not read music, he was still a teen-ager when he hooked up with Bunny Berigan in 1937. He joined with Shaw in 1938 and in 1940 joined Goodman's sextet, playing alongside jazz legends such as Cootie Williams, Charlie Christian and Count Basie. In the 1940s, he briefly led his own band, which featured soloists including Sarah Vaughan, Erroll Garner, Dizzy Gillespie and Billy Butterfield. Auld also appeared during the 1940s in a Broadway play about a musician and a dance-hall hostess, ``The Rat Race,'' playing a saxophonist. Nearly 30 years later, he helped De Niro portray a saxophonist in ``New York, New York.'' Auld was the principal soloist on the soundtrack and had a cameo in the 1977 picture as a bandleader. By 1975 he had recorded nearly 20 albums. Auld is survived by two brothers and a sister. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying Two U.S. Officials Reported Missing in Chile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with FDA confirmation, hometowns on victims, report on when U.S. was notified. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A police airplane carrying five people, including two officials of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, was reported missing on a flight from northern Chile to Santiago, authorities said today. Authorities said there was no indication of sabotage. No guerrillas are believed to operate in the areas the plane flew over. The American officials were identified as John Harty and Patrick Pouzar. The FDA officials arrived in Chile on Saturday to investigate security measures taken by Chilean authorities in handling fruit for export to the United States. Police said the two-engine Cessna 206 disappeared Wednesday after taking off at 5:20 p.m. from Copiapo, a city 500 miles to the north. The plane was due to land 9:10 p.m. at Tobalaba airport in Santiago. In Washington, FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said Harty, of Silver Spring, Md., is director of the agency's international affairs staff in the FDA's Office of Health Affairs in Rockville, Md. Nesbit said Pouzar is director of investigations in the FDA's Nashville, Tenn., district office and lives in Nashville. Nesbit said the two had visited several fruit-processing facilities in northern Chile. They left the United States on Friday and were expected back Monday, said Bill Oates, acting director of the Nashville office. The spokesman said the Chilean foreign minister informed the U.S. Embassy in Santiago at 11:30 p.m. Wednesday that the men's plane was two hours overdue. There has been no electronic communication with the plane since then, he said. The Chileans on board are Oscar Badilla, a government agricultural official; Sergio Lazcano, an executive of the Fruit Exporters Association; and an unidentified pilot, police officer German Fuentes said. Police said a wide search for the missing airplane was in progress this morning, involving police and air force planes. The FDA officials were in Chile to check security in the Chilean fruit exports process after two grapes laced with cyanide were found in Philadelphia last year. The finding prompted a temporary suspension of the sale of all Chilean fruits in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Go Ahead, Take Out 10 Books, Library Says
DOC.TEXT: Homewood Library is suggesting a limit on the number of books patrons check out _ at least 10. The library is about to move into a new building, and to help save on moving costs, officials are asking residents to check out as many of the library's 93,000 volumes as possible. ``They won't be due until after the new library opens Feb. 14. We want people to bring them back there,'' said administrative librarian Larry Gelfius. Ground was broken in 1988 on the $3 million library that will more than double the space of the current building, built in 1961. To assist the move, the library on Monday started checking out books for six weeks at a time, and townsfolk responded. About 700 books are checked out on an average day, but on Monday the number was nearly triple that. Nearly 12,000 of this Chicago suburb's 20,000 residents have library cards, Gelfius said. Debbie Moylan did her duty, checking out so many books for her three children that she need help getting them from the library basement. ``Right now, they're stacked up on the back porch,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Lifting of Martial Law in China
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 10 grafs new with Bush quotes; picks up 5th graf pvs, On Capitol Hill.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today praised the lifting of martial law in China as a ``very sound step'' and said he will be watching developments there closely. Bush's praise of the Chinese move this week contrasted with criticism from members of Congress who said they doubted Beijing is about to improve its record on human rights. ``I view the lifting of martial law as a very sound step. For those who are interested in the human rights and reform that was on the move, that we'd all like to see go forward, there's no way you can look at that but say it's very positive,'' Bush said. He reiterated that he is not interested in isolating China, adding, ``Of course we welcome the lifting of martial law as a good sign.'' A day earlier, U.S. officials had reacted cautiously to the Chinese move, saying they would reserve judgment until the announcement by Premier Li Peng was implemented. More upbeat, Vice President Dan Quayle called the announcement ``a positive step forward for human rights.'' The White House and State Department reflected a cautious U.S. policy stance by issuing identical statements saying ``we must assess the full scope of this action after observing its implementation.'' The Bush administration dropped its opposition to World Bank loans to China for aid for earthquakes and other unspecified calamities, but officials said the step was not related to the lifting of sanctions and that the United States would continue to oppose loans to China for projects. Bush today did not indicate whether he is considering further softening of sanctions he imposed on Beijing after China's violent crackdown on thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators last spring. ``We will continue to watch this situation very closely,'' he said. On Capitol Hill, Rep. William S. Broomfield of Michigan, the ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said China's announcement was ``more blue smoke and mirrors, and would not fool anybody in Congress into believing that the Chinese leadership was moderating its oppressive rule.'' Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., who sponsored legislation to permit Chinese students to remain in the United States after their visas expire, called the lifting of martial law an ``empty gesture.'' ``I am confident the Congress of the United State will see through this feeble attempt by Chinese leaders to mislead western governments,'' she said in a statement. ``Beijing can lift martial law because it does not need martial law to crush dissent.'' Pelosi said she would push for a congressional override of President Bush's veto of the bill to protect Chinese students even though he has promised to shield them through an executive order. Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California called the announcement ``a small, very small, step in the right direction ... insufficient justification to halt sanctions against China.'' House Democratic Leader Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri renewed criticism of Bush for sending two senior officials to Beijing for talks soon after Chinese troops massacred hundreds of students and other pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square in June. ``We shouldn't have been over there at the very time that Eastern Europe was breaking loose and people were taking courageous stands against despotic regimes to say to the Chinese all is forgiven for what you did,'' Gephardt said. ``While it may make sense to communicate with the Chinese government, I don't think you want to be clinking champagne glasses with them as you say all is forgiven, because I don't think all should be forgiven that quickly or that easily.'' Continuing U.S. opposition to loans for projects could derail a $700 million World Bank program for China. The sanction was imposed by Bush after the crackdown in Beijing. As for permitting humanitarian help, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said that decision was distinct from the announcement that martial law would be lifted after seven months. ``It is a coincidence that they dropped on the same day,'' she said. ``They are not linked.'' She described the U.S. action as a partial easing of Bush's sanction on loans. But Roman Popadiuk, the deputy White House spokesman, said: ``The sanctions remain in place. Period.'' The Bush administration has been under fire in Congress and elsewhere for what critics consider to be kid-glove treatment of Chinese leaders. The criticism intensified last month when it was disclosed that National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger made two trips to Beijing. Bush, at a news conference last week, again defended his policy. He said he did not think isolating the Chinese was the best way to promote human rights in the country.

DOC.HEAD: White House Rules Out Social Security Tax Cut
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will oppose any effort to change Social Security taxes, even a politically appealing one to lower them, President Bush's spokesman said today. ``Democrats seem to want to fool around with the Social Security system. We don't,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters. He was asked about a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back this year's Social Security tax installment and further cut the rate on Jan. 1, 1991. The Social Security payroll tax rate, including Medicare, went to 7.65 percent of income on Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, under a formula endorsed in 1983 by a reform commission headed by economist Alan Greenspan, who now is chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Moynihan was a member of the commission. ``Mr. Moynihan's got a lot of ideas and we'll let the Democrats have them,'' Fitzwater said. ``We don't anticipate any changes in Social Security.'' Moynihan has said he will introduce his proposal for lower Social Security taxes when Congress reconvenes on Jan. 23. He has called his proposal a $55 billion tax cut for working people, claiming that bulging Social Security trust funds warrant such a tax reduction. Contributions to the trust funds are counted as revenue in the federal budget, which has the effect of making the overall federal deficit appear smaller than it otherwise would be. Administration opposition to a Social Security tax cut comes despite Bush's frequently repeated ``no new taxes'' pledge. ``The Social Security system is sound. Let the Democrats fool with it, not us,'' Fitzwater said. However, White House chief of staff John Sununu said on CBS' ``Face the Nation'' last Sunday that the administration does plan to propose a change to Social Security financing that would require surpluses generated by the trust funds to be used to help retire the national debt after 1993. Currently, the trust funds are invested in Treasury securities. Fitzwater said today that the proposal disclosed by Sununu deals mostly with budget accounting, and not with the structure of the system. Social Security taxes jumped almost $320 this year for Americans earning $51,300 or more and by smaller amounts for those earning less. Employers match their workers' contributions.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Leak Forces Eastern Airliner to Land
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines plane flying from Philadelphia to Miami made an emergency landing at Washington National Airport today after suffering an apparent fuel leak, officials said. There were no injuries. Eastern Airlines spokesman Robin Matell said the pilot of the DC-9, which was carrying 36 passengers and a crew of five, declared an emergency and landed at National at 10:43 a.m. ``There was apparently a fuel leak and the pilot did declare an emergency,'' Matell said. ``It was classified as an emergency, but the landing itself was routine.'' The passengers on the aircraft were to be flown to Miami on another Eastern flight, Matell said. The incident is being investigated, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Urge End to State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Church leaders Thursday urged legislators not to extend Zimbabwe's 24-year-old state of emergency. The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace said in an open letter that the state's emergency powers, scheduled for renewal by the House of Assembly on Jan. 16, were used ``to harass and intimidate people.'' It cited the five-week detention last year of a labor leader for criticizing government actions, including the arrests of student protesters and the indefinite closure of Zimbabwe's only university. Sweeping emergency powers, which have been renewed by parliament every six months since independence in 1980, allow for detention without trial. The church leaders said they believed the state of emergency was no longer necessary and often led to ``inefficient and unreliable methods of investigation'' by security authorities. In July, the government said it needed wide-ranging emergency powers to deal with threats from neighboring South Africa and border incursions by rebels from Mozambique. The church leaders said, ``It has not been shown that the emergency powers improve police performance when it comes to dealing with spies and saboteurs.'' Existing security procedures and legislation were sufficient to safeguard the nation's interests, the commission said. Zimbabwe has been under a state of emergency since 1965 when it was introduced by the government of former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith to crack down on black nationalists.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Oldest Man Dies at Age 109
DOC.TEXT: Eiju Tsuru, said to be Japan's oldest man, died of heart failure Thursday at the age of 109 and 11 months. Tsuru died in the city of Saga on Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu. The Health and Welfare Ministry said Kiichi Fujiwara in Kanagawa prefecture, near Tokyo, now is Japan's oldest man, 109 years and one month. Japan's oldest woman is Mitsu Fujisawa, 113 years and nine months, the ministry said. Also on Thursday, Teiichi Igarashi, the oldest person ever to climb 12,395-foot Mount Fuji, died at the age of 103. Igarashi began climbing Fuji, Japan's highest mountain, in 1976, and made it an annual event. His last climb was in 1988 at age 101.

DOC.HEAD: French Actress-Director Juliette Berto Dead at 42
DOC.TEXT: Juliette Berto, the leading lady in Jean-Luc Godard's avant garde films ``Weekend'' and ``La Chinoise,'' has died of cancer at the age of 42. Miss Berto, who died Wednesday, symbolized the free-spirited intellectual-style actress for the generation that came of age in the 1968 student-led riots. Made famous by ``Weekend,'' Godard's 1966 classic about a group of people taking to the roads to escape Paris, Miss Berto eventually turned her back on the French star system that produced actresses Brigitte Bardot and Jean Seberg. She went on to a successful career directing movies, including ``Neige'' (``Snow''), a 1981 docudrama about drug trafficking in the seedy Pigalle district of Paris. She also starred in Joseph Losey's award-winning ``Monsieur Klein'' with Alain Delon in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Mysterious Panther Eludes Dragnet
DOC.TEXT: Demands for controls over ownership of exotic animals escalated Thursday after a mysterious black panther eluded a dragnet on the outskirts of Rome. Newspapers published grainy photos of a black animal running in a wooded area Wednesday in what they said was the eighth sighting of the panther since Dec. 27. Police and forest rangers equipped with nets went to the area on the northern edge of the capital but the panther escaped into the woods. No one has claimed ownership of the big cat. Environmental and animal rights groups called for laws that would require a census of lions, tigers, panthers and other exotic animals kept as pets and set up centers for such animals abandoned or mistreated by their owners.

DOC.HEAD: Father Accused in Death of Infant Thought Baby Hated Him
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of shaking his 3-month-old daughter to death believed she hated him, and wore a Jimmy Carter mask to keep her from crying every time he approached her, court records show. Gerald Migliaro, 34, was arrested this week on a charge of second-degree manslaughter in the Oct. 10 death of his daughter Anna. He is free on $5,000 bond. A state medical examiner determined the infant died of blood clots within the skull. Doctors also found signs the baby suffered at least one fractured rib four or five weeks before her death, police said. According to a police affidavit, a nurse at Yale-New Haven Hospital quoted Migliaro as saying his daughter hated him since the day he and his wife brought her home from the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: The Anything that Goes Turned Out to Be Audience Cars
DOC.TEXT: Three people attending a production of ``Anything Goes'' found out after the show that it was their cars that were gone. They told police they left their cars _ and their keys _ in the care of two men they thought were valets at a lot near the Taft Theater on Tuesday night. One man was wearing a uniform and badge, police said. Cindy Schweikert, 31, said the bogus valets collected a $3 parking fee and joked with Ms. Schweikert and her mother. ``Are you two sisters?'' one of them asked the mother of Ms. Schweikert. ``My mother tipped him $1.'' Police recovered one car. They're still on the lookout for Ms. Schweikert's 1987 Nissan Sentra and for a 1989 Plymouth Acclaim.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Scoop Up Thousands of Dollars Spilled from Purse
DOC.TEXT: Travelers along Highway 99 picked up some extra cash when a purse containing $10,000 fell off the roof of a moving car and fluttered along the freeway. Motorists screeched to a halt along the shoulder of the road and jumped out to scoop up the $20, $50 and $100 bills on Wednesday, said California Highway Patrol Officer Guillermo Godinez. The money belonged to a Keyes family who had withdrawn the cash from the bank to pay bills in Modesto, Godinez said. Octavio Sajuan put the money in his wife's purse which she placed on the car while strapping their child into a car seat outside the bank. The purse was left on top of the car when they drove away, Godinez said. ``The husband said he had been working seven days a week to try to catch up on bills,'' Godinez said. ``He was so upset he was crying. It's a very sad story.'' The couple was able to retrieve $6,000, Godinez said. Also lost was Mrs. Sajuan's wedding ring, which also was in the purse.

DOC.HEAD: Four Drug Dealers Executed
DOC.TEXT: Four men have been executed after being convicted of selling heroin and opium in southern China, a newspaper reported Thursday. The overseas edition of the People's Daily said a court in Kunming, the provincial capital of Yunnan, found the four guilty of earning thousands of dollars between 1985 and 1988 from selling drugs in Kunming and Canton. The court said the drugs were smuggled from abroad. The four appealed the verdict to higher courts but the death sentences were carried out Monday after the appeals were rejected, the newspaper said. Also on Monday, the Kunming Intermediate Court sentenced 82 people, including 44 for selling drugs, four prostitutes, four for selling obscene material, 26 swindlers, three gamblers and one person cheating people through use of superstition, the newspaper said. China is in the midst of a nationwide campaign against the ``six vices'': prostitution, pornography, gambling, drugs, the selling of women and children and fraud through superstition. China has a small but growing problem with drug abuse. Illegal drugs are found mostly in southern China, near the opium-growing areas of Burma, Laos and Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Blocks Special Judicial Elections In Texas
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court today blocked special judicial elections that a lower court had ordered in nine of Texas' largest counties as a way of remedying discrimination against black and Hispanic voters. A federal judge Jan. 2 had ordered the elections to take place in May under a system less likely to dilute minority voting power. But the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals today said the Legislature deserves a chance to come up with a new system first. ``Only if it becomes apparent that the state is unwilling to act with measured and appropriate speed in this regard should the courts intervene,'' the appeals court said. Gov. Bill Clements has already called the Legislature into session on Feb. 27 to consider judicial selection, along with school finance reforms. ``I applaud the decision of the 5th Circuit not to allow the wholesale disruption of our judiciary,'' he said. ``Our Legislature will now have the opportunity to resolve this crucial issue in a manner that is representative of the wishes of the people of our state and that enhances the participation of all Texans.'' U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton had ruled that the nine counties' method of electing state judges from each county as a whole violated the federal Voting Rights Act by diluting minority voting power. He ordered special elections held in those counties, with judges chosen from smaller, existing political districts. The ruling affected 115 state district court judgeships in Bexar, Dallas, Tarrant, Harris, Travis, Midland, Ector, Lubbock and Jefferson counties. In all, Texas has 375 state district judgeships. The counties were named in a lawsuit filed in 1988 by the League of United Latin American Citizens and other minority groups and individuals. In its opinion today, the appeals court said Bunton's ruling would mean sweeping changes in Texas' 113-year-old judicial system. And that job is more properly one for lawmakers, the court said. The court went on to say that the Legislature hasn't had ``a reasonable period within which to address the problem presented.''

DOC.HEAD: Court: State Official Should Have Dismissed Himself from Dorrian's Case
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court Thursday threw out a decision revoking the license of the New York City bar where ``preppie murderer'' Robert Chambers met Jennifer Levin before killing her in Central Park. The chairman of the State Liquor Authority should have have excused himself from a hearing involving alleged underaged drinking at Dorrian's Red Hand after he made public statements about the bar's guilt, a sharply-divided State Court of Appeals said. The court, by a 4-3 vote, sent the case back to the liquor authority and said Chairman Thomas Duffy should not be among those deciding the matter. Dorrian's had appealed a decision that it served underaged drinkers in November 1986 _ three months after Levin was strangled. The bar forfeited $1,000 bond and lost its liquor license for 10 days. Dorrian's lawyer said the bar didn't receive a fair hearing because Duffy had already pre-judged the case and because the bar was being made a scapegoat for the highly publicized slaying. In March 1988, Chambers pleaded guilty to manslaughter in Levin's death. He is serving five to 15 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Close in on Satellite They Plan to Retrieve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with 3rd engine-firing maneuver completed. PICKS UP 3rd graf, `Once the ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts mopped up water from a leaky dehumidifier today as they closed in on the floating science laboratory they plan to pluck from space on Friday with the shuttle's robot arm. Commander Dan Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee executed three engine-firing maneuvers today, putting Columbia on a near-collision course with the satellite they have been chasing since they were launched Tuesday onto a path 1,725 miles behind their quarry. Once the astronauts move in on the 11-ton target, they will fly in formation 35 feet away while mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar reaches out with Columbia's 50-foot mechanical arm to snare the 30-foot satellite, which is as large as a small school bus. If all goes well, she will make the catch at 9:48 a.m. Friday. The shuttle this morning was reported to be within 300 miles of the satellite, known as the Long Duration Exposure Facility. Brandenstein and mission specialist David Low interrupted their flight plans for more than two hours today to cope with the leak of about two gallons of water, shown on television as a slow bubbling of water beads. They shut off the faulty dehumidifier, shifted to a backup, and then went to work on the water with towels and a hand-held vacuum, using a flashlight to dry cables and other surfaces. Loose water, which forms beads and globules in weightlessness, can interfere with electronics. Looking at all the equipment that had to be moved to get at the water, Brandenstein remarked, ``It's kind of a mess right now. I'll get the plumber of the year award, but not the housekeeper of the year award.'' Scientists are eager to examine the satellite to learn how various systems and materials withstood the long stay in orbit, information that will help in designing the space station and other space vehicles. Atmospheric drag has been pulling the satellite closer to Earth. If Columbia does not retrieve it, trackers estimate the satellite will burn up in a plunge into Earth's atmosphere about March 9, its experiments lost forever. The shuttle, which is in a slightly lower orbit, takes less time to circle the globe and was catching up with the satellite at a rate today of about 38 miles for each 91-minute orbit of the Earth. Controllers, meanwhile, reported the $85 million Navy communications satellite launched by the astronauts Wednesday was functioning well. An onboard motor late Wednesday boosted it on another leg toward its permament working outpost 22,300 miles above the Pacific Ocean. As the gap between the shuttle and the wayward laboratory closed, hunter and hunted were traveling nearly 200 miles high at more than 17,400 mph. ``We're glad you're doing so well; the whole world's impressed,'' Mission Control told the astronauts as it wakened them today with its version of ``Banana Boat Song.'' The control center version substituted the name of astronaut Low for the words ``Day-O,'' and it included such phrases as, ``Come all you astronauts sleeping in the cabin, daylight comes and its time to get up.'' Mission Control explained the words were written by members of the team that trained Low for a space walk in case of an emergency on this flight. To pass the time during these training sessions, he often hummed the song. Low, replying in a calypso beat, said, ``Good morning, Houston, man. We be up.'' While the commander and pilot tended to flying Columbia, the three mission specialists, Dunbar, Low and Marsha Ivins, busied themselves with experiments. They melted crystals, photographed the Earth and took medical measurements of one another in tests to determine how well the human body adapts to space weightlessness. Columbia's 10-day mission, the second-longest in the 33 shuttle flights, is a stepping stone toward longer shuttle missions and to months-long rips aboard space station Freedom starting in the mid-1990s. After Dunbar grabs LDEF, she will hold it on the end of the robot arm for nearly four hours while Ivins makes a detailed photographic survey of all 57 experiments mounted on the exterior. The laboratory has been exposed to space for six years and there is concern some of the experiments might deteriorate when re-introduced to Earth's gravity after being eroded by atomic oxygen and bombarded by interplanetary debris.

DOC.HEAD: Self-Rule and Capitalism Won't Come Without Pain, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON AP) _ Now free to set their own course, the people of East Europe are seeking self-rule and free enterprise, but experts say fulfilling those yearnings won't necessarily come easily. Even if the desire to run one's own life _ and to make money _ is instinctive, they say, history shows that Eastern Europeans may have trouble setting up shop under the flags of democracy and capitalism. ``People want liberty, naturally, but the working out of institutions is a very complicated process,'' said Richard Pipes of Harvard University, an East European specialist who served with President Reagan's National Security Council. ``The Russians in 1917 were wild for liberty and democracy, but it collapsed in a matter of months because they didn't have the traditions, the institutions,'' he said in an interview. The same is true in trying to set up a capitalist system, said economist Murray Weidenbaum of Washington University in St. Louis, a former Reagan adviser who recently surveyed Poland's economy on a mission for President Bush. ``People have the entrepreneurial profit-seeking instinct, you don't have to teach it to them,'' he said, ``but when you're talking about the free enterprise system they have to learn business infrastructure, like cost accounting, contract law, preparation of financial statements _ that isn't instinctive.'' Paul A. Samuelson, Nobel Prize-winning economist from MIT, said he is not too sure that the people of Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania _ having ousted their Moscow-installed communist governments _ are aware of the pitfalls of the free enterprise system, if that is what they opt to install. ``It is not a system of profits, it is a system of profits and losses,'' he said. ``Bankruptcy is an important part of the capitalist system. If you don't want inequalities, unemployment, bankruptcies, then you want the good side of capitalism without the other side.'' Weidenbaum agreed. ``The Poles see the benefits of capitalism but don't see the costs,'' he said. ``I don't know if they realize that capitalism is not a profit system but a profit-or-loss system. In the best of times, thousands of companies go broke.'' Poland has already felt the pain of moving away from a state economy. On Jan. 1, taking the plunge, Poles saw bus fares and gasoline double and the price of electricity and heating gas increase fourfold. Robert Conquest, a specialist on the Soviet Union at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University, said he suspects East Europe's economic rebirth will be more troublesome than its political renewal. In politics, he said, ``they can go back to their old constitutions,'' but on the economic front ``they're stuck with these apparatuses of uselessness.'' In a system that guaranteed a job to everyone, he said, no one worked hard. Economist Paul Craig Roberts, who served in the Reagan administration, said he fears that Poland especially is ``so social democratic in its outlook'' that it may impose ``restrictions that make it difficult for individuals to suceed economically,'' such as high progressive tax rates and high death taxes. Capitalism is instinctive, he said _ ``it just grew up as a natural spontaneous development'' _ while ``communism and socialism began as ideologies that then seized political power and imposed themselves.'' Harvard government professor Harvey Mansfield Jr., author of a new study of power, ``Taming the Prince,'' said he worried that fascism could beckon if democracy founders in East Europe. That was the pattern of 1933, when Adolf Hitler took advanatage of discontent with unemployment and inflation in newly democratic Germany to seize power. But Conquest doubted that fascism holds much appeal or poses much of a threat in East Europe. ``I think the attraction of democratic liberty is very, very great,'' he said. ``They have a higher opinion of the West than the West does.'' Yet it took two tries to establish a workable democratic system in this country, even though the colonialists had experience in parliamentary rule in England, Pipes said. The first American constitution _ the Articles of Confederacy and Perpetual Union _ was recognized as a failure within nine years and replaced by the Constitution within 12. On the other hand, he said, East Europeans ``are so fed up with despotism of any kind, right or left, that you're going to se a tremendous desire for democracy and capitalism.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers March Across Tiananmen Square After Martial Law Lifted
LaserPhoto BEJ8
DOC.TEXT: China's army will maintain a strong presence ``to safeguard public security'' in the Beijing area following the lifting of martial law, the government's top spokesman said Thursday. Up to 1,000 troops marched across Tiananmen Square on Thursday morning, hours after seven months of martial law officially ended in the capital. ``I thought martial law was over,'' said one of the several thousand people on the 100-acre square as he watched the military procession. The government spokesman, Yuan Mu, told a news conference there was a ``small increase'' in troop levels in Beijing and its suburbs, but he gave no indication of how many soldiers would be stationed around the capital. Yuan said the military presence was necessary to ``safeguard public security and the peaceful work of the people.'' He said martial was ended because ``the task of martial law has been victoriously completed, the situation in Beijing and throughout the country is stable and the social order has returned to normal.'' President Bush on Thursday praised the lifting of martial law as a ``very sound step'' and a ``good sign.'' There was no suggestion from the Chinese government that it was responding to strong pressure from the West to lift martial law as a signal that it is easing its policy of harsh suppression of political dissent. Premier Li Peng on Wednesday night announced the end to martial law, imposed in May after pro-democracy crowds of up to 1 million people took over the streets of Beijing. Li stressed that decision to bring troops into Beijing in the June military crackdown had been ``timely, necessary and correct.'' Police replaced military sentries in the city at the end of October, and the lifting of martial law had no visible effect on the city except that Tiananmen Square, previously entered only by Chinese with proper documents, again became open to all citizens. About 150,000 troops entered Beijing to quell the pro-democracy unrest of last spring, and many are believed to remain unobtrusively behind the walled compounds of the city. Chinese sources said the military went on full alert in late December when the overthrow of the pro-China Nicolae Ceausescu regime in Romania raised fears of political unrest in Beijing. On Thursday, the troops, many shouting in cadence or singing military songs, marched across Tiananmen Square and entered a compound next to the Great Hall of the People in an obvious show of military force. Although tough anti-protest laws and surveillance of university campuses remain in place, many expressed relief that martial law was over. ``This is the way it should be,'' said a high school student about the opening of the square to the public again. But others, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said the end of martial law will have little meaning as long as political repression continues. ``The government draws a circle and you have to stand inside,'' said a Beijing teacher. ``It's like the Russian Gulag, only a different size,'' he said, adding that ``we haven't forgotten the students'' who stood up to the military. Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people were killed when troops stormed the city on June 3-4 to drive student demonstrators from the square. Since then thousands of political activists have been arrested, and many languish in jail without formal charges. Asked about students under detention, Yuan said only that judicial departments were still carrying out investigations. Gao Xin, one of four intellectuals who began a hunger strike for democracy just before military assault, has been freed after six months in jail, but Gao, who looked much thinner, said Thursday he could not talk about the experience. The government spokesman said China would take a ``prudent attitude'' toward providing the names of those killed in the crackdown because many relatives of the victims were ``not quite willing to have the names announced in the papers.'' Yuan said the situation in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa, also under martial law since the outbreak of pro-independence riots in March, was different from that of Beijing and he had no information on when martial law would end there. China's official newspapers said the nation cannot relax its vigilance against anti-socialist enemies. ``Lifting martial law doesn't mean all is well,'' said the Communist Party's People's Daily. It said the ``few people who adhere to bourgeois liberalization refuse to admit their defeat.'' The Liberation Army Daily said the army, ``the pillar of the people's democratic dictatorship in China, will not slacken its vigilance ideologically.''

DOC.HEAD: American Indian Center Offers Hot Line for Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A toll-free 24-hour hot line has started to help homeless people across the United States find shelters and other social service agencies. The Findlay Area Native American Indian Center set up the hot line, which opened Monday, said Michael Michaud, the group's spokesman. ``There are many people out there who are hungry, cold and living on the streets, with little hope that things will get better,'' he said Wednesday. ``We have information for every state in the union, for the shelters, soup kitchens, different social service agencies, to help people in need.'' The center, composed of a house, barn and craft shop on two acres in this northwestern Ohio city, was created to promote American Indian culture. But four months ago, Michael Adams, the center's owner who is a Cherokee Indian, and Michaud, an Abenaki Indian, decided to convert part of the complex to help the needy. Since October, the center has provided food and clothing and emergency shelter. It has helped about 500 people in the Findlay area. The center, which is supported by donations, also helps people find jobs and provides transportation to job interviews.
The hot line number is 1-800-526-5414.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The phone number for tourists interested in vacation information is being answered by people who aren't going anywhere. Working out of a cramped room at the Correctional Institution for Women in Raleigh, six inmates are taking 700 calls a day, a number that will grow in the next three months as people plan summer vacations and respond to state advertisements. The inmates, working for the highest prison wage of $1 a day, three weeks ago replaced the two to four state employees who used to answer the calls. The idea was to save the state $40,000 a year, but officials say the prisoners, with the help of 14 other inmates who stuff envelopes with brochures and maps, also are getting out more information than state employees did. Inmates and their overseer expressed satisfaction with the program in interviews with The Charlotte Observer. ``I never dreamed I'd be sitting in prison, talking to people all over the world,'' said Rochelle Daniels, 31, who is serving a 30-year sentence for murder. ``My travel experience is limited,'' Ms. Daniels admitted. She is able to tell callers about fishing at the Outer Banks, golfing in Pinehurst or driving the Blue Ridge Parkway because the women received six weeks of training, including lessons in geography and history.

The bill introduced into the General Assembly is only one sentence long and not particularly controversial, but it involves a lot of steps and circuitous action, not to mention toe-tapping. ``The square dance, part of recorded American history since 1651, is the official American folk dance of the state,'' Ohio law would declare, under a proposal Wednesday by state Sen. Cooper Snyder. Snyder said the measure was prompted by the selection of Cincinnati as the site of an international folk dance conference. ``It's a big deal. They're coming from all over the world to put on a contest as to who's best and make a world deal out of it. So this is simply in recognition of that and support. And, of course, it is a widely enjoyed recreation across the state of Ohio,'' he said. Ohio already has an official state seal, flag, bird, tree, flower, insect, song and fossil. Inclusion of the insect and fossil came as a result of bills suggested by children.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Rejects Allegations of Human Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Officials Thursday rejected an Amnesty International report charging the government has detained and tortured hundreds of political opponents, and they denied the kingdom holds political prisoners. A high-ranking government official said the report did not take into account that Saudi Arabia follows Islamic law. In a document released Thursday in London, the human rights group said more than 700 people were detained in Saudi Arabia without trial between 1983 and 1989, most of them Shiite Moslems. The torture methods it listed included beating on the soles of feet, sleep deprivation and being suspended by the wrists from a ceiling or high window. ``The report is baseless,'' the official said. ``The laws in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia are derived from Islamic Shari'a.'' The official refused to be identified, as do most senior officials when speaking to the press. Amnesty International conceded the kingdom is run by Islamic law but said it was enacted by royal decree or ministerial regulations, with no regular penal code. Under Shari'a, courts are made up of Moslem theologians, and murderers are beheaded while thieves have their hands cut and adulterers are stoned. Lawyers are not assigned automatically but the prisoner can request legal counsel or an attorney can volunteer to defend. There are lawyers versed in Islamic Shari'a but it is not a practice to automatically assign one to defendants. The official Saudi Press Agency quoted a government spokesman as saying there were no political prisoners in the kingdom, but there were cases being considered by the rules of Islamic Shari'a through ``judges highly versed in Shari'a.'' Islamic Shari'a, he said, ``does not differentiate between sects or races or creeds and does not extract confessions by force, pressure or terror or any style that contravenes the dignity of man as established by Islamic Shari'a and applied by the kingdom.'' He added: ``Amnesty International should differentiate between laws by which the kingdom abides in line with the rules and principles of Islamic Shari'a and the systems in other countries in light of laws laid down by human beings who err more often than not.'' Beheadings are common in Saudi Arabia on Fridays, the Moslem Sabbath. A prominent case of beheadings last year was that of 16 Moslem Shiites, mainly Kuwaitis, who were convicted in bombings during the pilgrimage to the Saudi cities of Mecca and Medina. The blasts killed one person.

DOC.HEAD: Singh Proposes Concessions to Calm Sikhs
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh offered key concessions to Sikh separatists Thursday, but he said he had no sure way to end the violence. Singh appeared at a rally of about 100,000 people in the Punjab city of Ludhiana as part of his 6-week-old government's campaign to restore peace in the state. Singh said Sikh deserters from the Indian army would be given government jobs. The deserters' rehabilitation has been a key demand of the Sikh community. The prime minister also said the cases of jailed Sikhs would be reviewed. Hundreds and perhaps thousands are in jail. Hundreds of Sikh soldiers mutinied in 1984 when the government ordered Indian army troops to attack the Golden Temple, the Sikh faith's holiest shrine, and expel armed Sikhs. More than 2,000 people, mostly Sikhs, were killed in the raid. Later that year, Sikh bodyguards killed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in revenge. The violence has continued, with at least 1,820 people killed in the Punjab state last year, mostly in hit-and-run attacks by the militants. ``When blood flows in Punjab, it is the country's heart that bleeds,'' said Singh, a Hindu. He added, however: ``I have not come here with a magic wand. The solution is not in the corridors of New Delhi but in the wheatfields of Punjab.'' A resolution adopted at the end of the rally said: ``Violence and the use of coercive methods must be put (to) an end, and security of life and property and respect for human rights for all must be exercised.'' Many listeners in the crowd seemed skeptical about prospects for an end to the violence. ``V.P. Singh's latest rally is just a ritual. The government itself knows nothing will be solved. Can anything be solved by such rallies?'' asked Bhinder Singh, a Sikh resident of Ludhiana. About 20 leaders of various political parties attended the meeting in the industrial town of about 800,000 people known for its clothing factories. An influential Sikh party of Punjab, the Akali Dal, and former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, the largest opposition group, stayed away. Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral, a Hindu who has been a key figure in the government's efforts to win over Sikhs, said the rally's aim was to ``mobilize support from the people of Punjab to quash secessionist efforts.'' The rebellion was launched in 1982 with militants claiming Sikhs suffer discrimination by Hindus. Sikhs form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people but have in a slight majority in Punjab. Hindus make up 82 percent of the national population. Thursday's rally was the second multiparty meeting on Punjab called by Singh since he took office Dec. 2, replacing Gandhi. Singh, who led the centrist National Front alliance, was named prime minister with support from communists and right-wing Hindu fundamentalists.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Greet Gorbachev With Demands for Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with 200,000 at rally, Sajudis leader saying Lithuania will decide its own fate, background. Pickup 13th, `As the..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VIL1,2; LON5
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today tried to persuade Lithuanians to halt their drive for independence, but tens of thousands of people rallied to show they are not willing to wait for freedom. Gorbachev did not attend the evening rally, but earlier he told several hundred Lithuanians they can have a say in their future, yet warned that pitting the Lithuanian leadership against the Kremlin could lead to tragedy. The comments were aimed at cooling pro-independence passions as Gorbachev embarked on a crucial mission to persuade Lithuanian Communists to reverse a decision to split from the federal Communist Party. ``We have been tied together for these 50 years, whether we like it or not,'' Gorbachev said, walking through a crowd of several hundred after laying a wreath at a monument to Lenin. ``And all the more so, we have not lived in a federation. We have lived in a unitary state with its own realities.'' One person called out to Gorbachev: ``People must decide their own fate!'' ``Nothing will be decided without you,'' Gorbachev responded as he slowly made his way back to his limousine. ``We will decide everything together.'' But he added: ``Remember, if someone succeeds in pitting us against each other in a clash, there will be a tragedy. We should not allow this.'' Gorbachev did not say what such a tragedy might be. But one of his closest political allies, fellow Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, was quoted Monday in an interview with Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow, as saying the Lithuanian Party's move might cause a ``domino effect,'' encouraging Communists in the country's other 14 republics to break off from Moscow. Soviet officials have given a virtual guarantee they will not use force to keep Lithuania and its 3.7 million residents in the Soviet Union. Josef Stalin absorbed Lithuania along with the two other Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, in 1940 under a secret agreement with Nazi Germany. ``We've come here to express our unity, in light of the East European changes, to announce that we will decide the problems of Lithuania ourselves,'' Vytautas Landsbergis, leader of the grassroots political organization Sajudis, told the crowd of at least 200,000 in Cathedral Square this evening. ``We demand freedom and independence,'' said the chief of Sajudis, a political movement pressing for Lithuanian independence. Harry Subacius, a Sajudis spokesman, said in a telephone interview to Moscow that the evening rally began with 15 minutes of silence. Many people held candles, red, green, and gold Lithuanian flags, and the red-and-white banner of neighboring Latvia, Subacius said. After 1 hour and 15 minutes, bells in the Roman Catholic Cathedral and elsewhere began ringing through the city of 544,000. Landsbergis referred to Gorbachev as ``head of a great neighbor state,'' emphasizing the view that Lithuania is an independent land. As the rally was going on, Gorbachev was meeting elsewhere with Communist Party members, according to an unofficial schedule. As never before in his nearly five years in power, Gorbachev put his personal prestige on the line in coming to Lithuania, exposing himself to a population that openly disagrees with him. At times, he adopted a pleading tone as he spoke to the people earlier in the day. The Soviet leader said the rights of all minorities in the Soviet Union _ whether they be Lithuanians or small non-Lithuanian ethnic groups in the republic _ must be respected, or it could endanger the unity of the country's more than 100 ethnic groups. ``If even the slightest suppression occurs, or misunderstanding, somewhere in Estonia or Moldavia, it spills over into the rest of the country,'' he said. Several thousand people gathered around the square as Gorbachev placed the wreath, and several hundred of them broke through police cordons to surround Gorbachev afterward. The crowd was calm and curious. Gorbachev, who has bitterly criticized the decision of the 200,000-member Lithuanian Communist Party to split from the national party, was straightforward and friendly. The people who gathered apparently were passers-by attracted by the heavy security around the Lenin memorial. It was not announced in advance that Gorbachev would visit the memorial. The Sajudis group said they planned the evening rally to show Gorbachev they cannot be dissuaded. Invited by a member of the crowd to attend, Gorbachev replied, ``For me, the meeting already is going on.'' He then drove away to an equipment factory for a meeting with workers. During his three-day visit to Lithuania, Gorbachev plans to meet with collective farmers, members of ethnic minorities, intellectuals and Communists. Although Gorbachev has granted Lithuanians and their neighbors in Estonia and Latvia a large measure of economic and political power, he has consistently criticized Lithuanian Communist leaders for pressing for complete independence. Last month, he convened an emergency session of the national party Central Committee to discuss the issue. Landsbergis said his countrymen are not trying to hurt Gorbachev's political and economic reforms but are showing other republics ``how certain problems can be solved in a peaceful, diplomatic manner.'' ``It's not destabilization. It's de-Stalinization,'' he told a news conference Wednesday, referring to the rigid, centrally controlled political and economic systems that Stalin devised. In the past two years, Sajudis-backed candidates have defeated hard-line Communists in local and national elections and helped the republic win a measure of economic independence from Moscow. Gorbachev, for his part, is treating the Communist Party split as a critical setback in his reform program. The Soviet leader sent a crew of top-level national party officials headed by Kremlin ideology chief Vadim A. Medvedev to lobby Lithuanian party members in preparation for his visit. Gorbachev last visited one of the Baltic republics in February 1987, when he traveled to Riga, the capital of Latvia. Lithuanian activists said he had not been in their republic in a decade.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Offers Pentagon Management Reform Update
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs with Cheney quotes after 6th graf, `So every'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, faced with budget-cutting pressures, said today that his package of Pentagon management reforms will save $39 billion and trim 42,000 weapons-buying jobs over the next five years. Offering a six-month update on his proposals to trim the Defense Department's massive purchasing bureaucracy, Cheney said in a statement that he was aiming for major changes in the way the Pentagon is run and in the way its purchasing system works. Weapons purchases have accounted for more than $60 billion of the department's $305 billion budget and involves some 580,000 civilian and uniformed personnel. President Bush asked Cheney to undertake the effort over the summer as part of a major review spurred by the weapons-procurement scandals that rocked the defense establishment. ``The changes in the nature of the threat around the world, and the realities of the budget, mean that our defense budgets are going to be leaner in the years ahead,'' Cheney's statement said. ``So every dollar that we can cut out of the cost of running the Pentagon is a dollar we don't have to cut from force structure, readiness or the quality of life for our men and women in uniform.'' ``Real changes are being made ... that we believe will improve Pentagon management and help make it possible for us to buy what we need at lower cost, in less time and with greater assurance of quality,'' Cheney told reporters. He had few details to offer, however, saying he was constrained because disclosing precise plans must await the release of Bush's fiscal 1991 budget later this month. Asked about the possibility of additional base closings, Cheney said ``extensive'' closures were planned to aid his overall cost-cutting effort. When asked to define ``extensive,'' he quipped, ``More than two.'' Although reports had circulated recently that Cheney's reforms would include doing away with the duplicative purchasing systems entrenched in the separate military services, the Pentagon announcement said the savings would be achieved primarily through: _Streamlining each service's purchasing system. _Reducing the use of consultants and outside advisers. _Creating a full-time acquisition corps in each service that would report to a ``streamlined chain of command'' to top civilian department officials. _Eliminating unnecessary paperwork. ``The management improvements will generate $2.3 billion in savings for FY (fiscal year) '91 and an estimated $39 billion through FY '95,'' the statement said. ``The improvements make it possible to trim the logistics and management workforce of 580,000 civilians and military personnel and by as many as 8,000 civilians and 8,000 military personnel in FY'91 and by 18,000 civilian and 24,000 military personnel by the end of FY '95.'' When Cheney first undertook the study, some members of Congress complained that the effort wasn't deep enough to radically reform the system. Meanwhile, Defense Department sources said Cheney has ordered other reviews of strategic policies and major aircraft programs to help plan long-range spending as the department faces near-certain budget cuts, sources said Wednesday. Cheney, seeking advice on the Pentagon's long-term strategy and budgets, directed Paul Wolfowitz, the undersecretary of defense for policy, to reassess the overall defense strategy. He asked John Betti, the undersecretary of defense for acquisition, to review the Pentagon's most expensive aircraft projects, the sources said. ``In part, it's because of what's happening in Eastern Europe,'' said one Pentagon official, who spoke on condition he not be identified by name. ``It really puts on paper what people were asked to do months ago,'' said a military source, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. The first official said although such studies are usually done continuously at the Pentagon, but the events in Eastern Europe and the prospect of declines in the military's projected budget increases added impetus to Cheney's request. Much of the military's planning and budgets is focused on fighting a U.S.-Soviet war, primarily in Europe with NATO and Warsaw Pact troops, and airlifting U.S. troops overseas for protracted battles. President Bush's 1991 budget, to be delivered to Congress later this month, is expected to include some weapons cutbacks and call for a 2 percent real drop in Pentagon spending. But because of the complex Pentagon budget-building process, it is not expected to reflect a major adjustment in the U.S. military response to the sweeping changes in the Soviet Union and Europe, the source said. So the studies, expected to be sent to Cheney by March, will be used as officials begin deliberations for the fiscal 1992 budget cycle and for long-range planning, the official added. The military source said Cheney's memorandum, dated mid-December, says the review ``should begin from basic principles.'' The source said the memo does not specifically mention which aircraft are to be studied, but that it is clear the secretary is interested reviewing requirements for the top four billion-dollar programs _ the B-2 stealth bomber, the C-17 transport plane and the Air Force and Navy advanced fighter jets still under development.

DOC.HEAD: Orr Aides Say They Misstated Her Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: An aide to Gov. Kay Orr says he mistakenly reported she wants to require an anti-drug pledge from students at Nebraska's public colleges and suspend students for any drug-related offense. Gary Rex, director of the Policy Research Office, took the blame Wednesday for what he and administration spokesman Doug Parrott said was a misunderstanding of what Mrs. Orr wanted in the measure. The proposal, sharply criticized by some lawmakers, newspapers and others, first was described earlier this week as requiring that students at public colleges lose any state aid and be suspended for any first-offense involving drugs. It also required a pre-admission pledge to stay drug free. In the wake of the criticism, the administration said that the written materials that explained the plan were wrong and that Rex, a lawyer who holds three supervisory roles in the administration, misunderstood Mrs. Orr. Rex said Wednesday the governor wants a bill that would suspend a student and revoke financial aid only after a second drug-related offense. A first offense would simply require the student to take a rehabilitation course, he said. ``And it wasn't supposed to be a pledge or some sort of loyalty oath or promise to stay drug-free,'' Rex said. ``It would simply be a written acknowledgment that a student would face certain penalties and requirements if they had a drug offense. ... The governor was aghast at the talk of `loyalty oaths' that was going around.'' Some legislators charged that Rex is too smart to have misunderstood the governor and that the Republican governor had backed down under criticism. Sen. Ernie Chambers, an independent, said Rex was ``obviously taking the heat for the governor.'' ``All this shows is that she will do any sort of thing and sacrifice anyone to avoid the political embarrassment she so richly deserves,'' he said. Administration spokesmen previously acknowledged that, under Mrs. Orr's proposal, a student convicted of a drug infraction could be suspended from school while someone convicted of violent crimes wouldn't face such a penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Group Formed to Help Poland
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday praised the efforts of a newly formed group that announced it was sending 50 tons of infant formula and medical supplies to hard-pressed Poland. Bush met at the White House with leaders of the group, a coalition of business, labor, civic and academic leaders banded together as the Emergency Committee for Aid to Poland. ``This is an effort to provide an outlet for the business community, for individuals to provide support, much needed support to Poland right now,'' Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said after the meeting. She said the shipment of 50 tons of supplies was ``the first of many shipments that will be made.'' ``This is going to be a very difficult winter for the Polish people,'' she added. ``There will be a lot of hardship, a lot of deprivation and they're very much in need of medical supplies, food, infant formula. The hardship will be particularly difficult for the elderly, for youngsters for the poor.'' Poland is going through wrenching economic times as it moves from a controlled economic system toward a free-market.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Cleanup, Suggests Aerosol Product Bans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to ADD overall level of pollution; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Henderson noted ...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge who ordered a reduction of air pollution caused by such items as deodorants and hair spray says some of the products may have to be banned. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson on Wednesday ordered a reduction of four tons a day of air pollution from household products in the San Francisco Bay area by 1993. The pollution level was an estimated 45.3 tons a day in 1987. Henderson noted that a plan approved in 1982 by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency had required such a reduction by 1987. Rejecting proposals by local and state smog agencies to delay compliance until 1997 or 1999, Henderson said the Bay Area Air Quality Management District has been guilty of an ``appalling failure to take any significant action.'' Wednesday's ruling applies to emissions from ``consumer solvents'' such as air fresheners, deodorants, disinfectants, aerosol paints, household cleaners and hair spray. Henderson left many of the details up to state and local agencies. But he said banning local sale of certain products would work, especially deodorants, air fresheners and household pesticides that have non-aerosol equivalents. Henderson said he would issue timetables shortly for reducing emissions from farm pesticides and lawn mowers, leaf-blowers and power tools. Larry Chaset, a lawyer for the Bay Area Air Quality Management District, said Henderson's schedule ``sounds impractical on the face of it,'' although ``we think we could probably get a good chunk of the reductions by 1994.'' He said the agency hasn't decided whether to appeal the order. ``The agencies have known since 1982 that they were supposed to adopt a consumer solvent rule,'' said William Curtiss, lawyer for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. ``They have done nothing but think about it.'' ``The court, I think, is sending a pretty strong message that more of the same is not going to be regarded as adequate compliance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Aide Says He Erred in Anti-Drug Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Kay Orr's administration says a proposal that would suspend students at public colleges for drug-related offenses was submitted in an erroneous form that made it harsher than the governor wanted. The proposal, sharply criticized by some lawmakers and others, originally carried a written explanation saying students would lose state aid and be suspended for any first-offense involving drugs, including misdemeanors. It also involved a pre-admission pledge to stay drug free. Gary Rex, director of the Policy Research Office, said Wednesday that he had misunderstood the governor's wishes. A first offense would require the student to take a rehabilitation course, he said. A second drug offense would involve a suspension and re-admission only after a second course, he said. ``And it wasn't supposed to be a pledge or some sort of loyalty oath or promise to stay drug-free,'' Rex said. ``It would simply be a written acknowledgment that a student would face certain penalties and requirements if they had a drug offense. ... The governor was aghast at the talk of `loyalty oaths' that was going around.'' State Sen. Tim Hall, an Omaha Democrat, said he doesn't believe in fighting drug use by taking education away, and ``the new version is still ridiculous. ... What you have here is the governor trying to get off the hook. I'm skeptical about the whole thing.'' Administration spokesmen previously acknowledged that under the Republican governor's proposal a student convicted of a drug infraction could be suspended while someone convicted of violent crimes wouldn't automatically face such a penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Portugese Prime Minister Confer on Angola
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new with Bush, Cavaco Silva quotes; picks up 5th graf pvs, A senior.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today told Portuguese Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva that the United States appreciates his country's efforts to help end the fighting in Angola and get peace talks resumed. ``When peace and stability come to that region, as certainly we hope they will, Portugal will have an important role in the reconstruction process,'' Bush told Cavaco Silva in a farewell statement after talks in the Oval Office and a luncheon. The prime minister said he briefed Bush on his talks with the leaders of the Angolan and Mozambique governments. Cavaco Silva said he had ``expressed the hope that if all interested parties show a positive attitude, it will be possible to put an end to the conflict that exacts such a heavy toll on the peoples in those two African countries. Bush called Portugal ``a close and enduring ally'' and said their talks had been productive. The prime minister said he wanted a ``broader and deeper relationship'' with the United States. The impasse in talks between the Soviet-backed government supported by Portugal and the UNITA rebels armed by the United States had been expected to be a significant part of discussions between Bush and Cavaco Silva. A senior Portuguese diplomat flew to Angola last week for discussions with the president of the former Portuguese colony, Eduardo Jose dos Santos, in advance of Cavaco Silva's Washington trip. The Portuguese leader, who arrived in Washington on Wednesday, is bringing Bush ``lots of information'' about the situation there and Angola's views, said an aide to the prime minister. A truce between the Angolan government and UNITA broke down last summer and efforts since then to hold peace talks have failed, despite intense U.S. lobbying. On Tuesday, the State Department chastised the Soviet Union for supporting a Angolan government offensive against UNITA that began Dec. 23. ``We welcome an active Portuguese involvement'' in bringing the two sides together, said a senior administration official who briefed reporters about Cavaco Silva's visit. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Despite differences over U.S. support for UNITA, the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, led by Jonas Savimbi, the official stressed both countries are now eager to seek peace in the African nation. Cavaco Silva's aide, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the prime minister also hoped to reassure Bush that the economic integration of the 12-nation European Economic Community by 1992 will not exclude American products and services. Cavaco Silva's visit is meant to highlight the rapid growth of U.S. investment in Portugal, which doubled to more than $1 billion from 1988 to 1989, the American official said. An agreement on investment is to be signed Thursday. Also on the agenda was a preliminary discussion on renewing the U.S. rights for use of Portugal's Lajes air force base in the Azores Islands. The eight-year agreement expires next year and the official predicted prospects for renewal are ``pretty good.'' Lajes is a strategic refueling depot for U.S. military aircraft and is also used to track Soviet submarine activity in the Atlantic. Bush and Cavaco Silva were also to focus on the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in light of the changes in Eastern Europe and Soviet disarmament proposals. Portugal is an active member of the 16-nation Atlantic alliance. Cavaco Silva was to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney later in the day. On the agenda was a U.S. program to modernize the Portuguese armed forces. The U.S. official said some of the modernization will be funded by the annual military aid appropriated by Congress for Portugal. The assistance for this year is $100 million and will probably decline slightly next year in light of budget constraints, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Hall to Celebrate 100th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Carnegie Hall will resound with music both morning and night on the 100th anniversary of its first concert, with one top name in classical music after another promising to perform. Organizers announced plans Wednesday for a season of special concerts to mark the passage of a century since the May 5, 1891, opening concert at the hall. They will culminate in an all-day gala on that concert's 100th anniversary. Violinist Isaac Stern, who is also Carnegie Hall president, said the hall's 1990-91 season will be ``probably the most extraordinary season that any hall has ever had.'' On May 5, 1991, the day will begin with a morning concert of nine choruses led by Robert Shaw. A concert by the New York Philharmonic will begin at 4 p.m. After a break for dinner, the concert will resume. Among artists already booked are Leonard Bernstein, Zubin Mehta, Placido Domingo, the Empire Brass Quintet, Marilyn Horne, Yo-Yo Ma, Jessye Norman, Leontyne Price, Mstislav Rostropovich, Rudolf Serkin, Pinchas Zukerman and Stern. Judith Arron, executive director of the hall, said the budget for next season has been increased to $13.2 million from $7.5 million to bring in a large number of leading musicians. The centennial season will begin with a free concert in Central Park on Aug. 20, a salute to Carnegie by the New York Philharmonic conducted by Mehta, with Stern as violin soloist. Opening night in the hall itself will be Sept. 26 and will feature Andre Previn conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic with violinist Itzhak Perlman as soloist. The nine days leding up to the May 5 gala will include concerts featuring Van Cliburn as piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic; the Boston Symphony conducted by Seiji Ozara with Rostropovich as cello soloist; soprano Kathleen Battle in her Carnegie Hall recital debut; a jazz concert organized by Wynton Marsalis, and a folk music concert organized by Pete Seeger. Mrs. Arron said the hall is commissioning new works from 14 composers to premiere at the hall during the season, calling it ``the most ambitious commissioning project ever undertaken by a presenting institution in this country.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Tapes of Father Charged in Childrens' Drowning Released
DOC.TEXT: A man told police he wanted to frighten his wife by speeding their station wagon with his four children toward the Detroit River, but then couldn't slam on the breaks. ``I just wanted to give, um, just scare my wife enough to slam on the brakes, come to a skidding halt and get her all upset so she'd forget about the bed for a couple of days,'' Lawrence DeLisle said in videotaped police interrogations released Wednesday. ``Just let me be. I couldn't stop accelerating. I didn't.'' The family earlier had priced a $500 bed for one of the children. DeLisle faces trial Jan. 30 on four counts of murder and one count of attempting to murder his wife, Suzanne, who survived the Aug. 3 river plunge. On the interrogation tapes, DeLisle said he loves his wife and children. ``I didn't want to hurt my babies. I didn't even realize they were in the car. My mind went blank.'' The tapes have been barred from use at DeLisle's trial by a judge who agreed that DeLisle's statements were coerced. The Michigan Supreme Court ruled Friday that the tapes be released. DeLisle, 30, and his wife maintain the car plunge was an accident, caused when a leg cramp forced DeLisle to jam his foot against the gas pedal and sent the car through a barrier rail and into the river. DeLisle's attorney, Frank Eaman, said the tapes contain clear evidence of pressure from police. ``He gives rambling answers about his feelings, which can have multiple interpretations,'' Eaman said. ``He never says he drove his car into the river intentionally to get rid of his burdens.'' Police, however, have said the tapes reveal a man who lost his ability to lie and confessed to purposely drowning his four children _ Bryan, 8, Melissa, 4, Kathryn, 2, and Emily, 8 months. Police have said DeLisle's $13,000 in debts and troubles with supporting his family on a $31,000 salary as manager of an auto service store might have been a motive for the drownings. DeLisle told interrogaters he was thinking of no longer having to pay bills as the car hurtled toward the river. But DeLisle also denied wanting his family dead.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Chief Tied to Louisiana Money Case Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comment from board chairman; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `We viewed ...'; SUBS 11th graf pvs, `It's no ...' to RESTORE newspaper's hometown.
DOC.TEXT: The man chosen to enforce Chicago's ethics laws resigned today, one day after officials learned he had been implicated in alleged campaign fund-raising violations in Louisiana, the city Board of Ethics said. Gary M. O'Neill, who started work as executive director of the Board of Ethics on Dec. 12, has ``a cloud over his head, and therefore he can't act as ethics director,'' said Albert Hofeld, chairman of the board. O'Neill was expected to release a statement later in the day. O'Neill, who helped Louisiana's Commissioner of Insurance Doug Green finance his successful 1987 campaign, was a defendant in a lawsuit by the Louisiana Board of Ethics for Elected Officials. The lawsuit accused Green of attempting to conceal the source of $2.2 million in contributions to his 1987 campaign. The lawsuit was thrown out of court last year when the Louisiana ethics board's enforcement provisions were declared unconstitutional by a state judge. A rehearing of the issue is pending before the Louisiana Supreme Court. Word of those allegations came as a surprise Wednesday to Chicago officials. The board had hired O'Neill, a lawyer, last month after a three-month search that involved 200 applicants. ``I am unaware of these allegations, but most assuredly they will be looked into,'' Hofeld said Wednesday. ``We viewed him as the best candidate and we were impressed with his credentials and with his abilities, and we will examine whatever charges are brought to our attention.'' The agency enforces the city's ethics and campaign disclosure ordinances. ``Obviously the Board of Ethics has egg all over their face because they're supposed to make the appropriate checks'' before hiring someone, said J. Terrence Bruner, executive director of the Better Government Association, a watchdog group. ``It's no secret, of course _ I was involved in Doug Green's campaign,'' O'Neill was quoted as saying in Wednesday's Morning Advocate of Baton Rouge, La. ``I think we did it in compliance with law.'' Authorities also subpoenaed O'Neill in June to testify before a grand jury that is investigating possible criminal wrongdoing surrounding the collapse of an insurance agency that was regulated by Green's office. Louisiana investigators said the subpoena was never delivered because O'Neill could not be found, the State-Times of Baton Rouge reported. ``I haven't been in hiding,'' O'Neill told the Advocate. ``I haven't been running. My leaving was happenstance. It was not calculated.''

DOC.HEAD: L-Tryptophan Investigation: So Far, `Nothing Obvious'
DOC.TEXT: Federal scientists are not sure, despite two months of investigation, why more than 1,000 people have gotten sick after taking the health food supplement L-tryptophan. The protein component widely taken as a nutritional supplement was linked in November to a rare, painful blood disorder known as eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, which suddenly started mushrooming in New Mexico. Within weeks of those reports, cases were spotted in 49 states, all but Alaska. As of Tuesday, 1,046 had been reported to the Centers for Disease Control. One fatality has been confirmed, and at least six more deaths are believed linked to L-tryptophan. The disorder is marked by an abnormally high number of white blood cells called eosinophils and causes severe muscle pain, or myalgia. Scientists at the CDC and the Food and Drug Administration quickly began trying to determine if the illnesses were being caused by L-tryptophan itself, or by some contaminant that got into batches of the product. They're still trying. ``We, together with the FDA, have done all the obvious things,'' said Dr. Ed Kilbourne, chief of the Health Studies Branch of the CDC's Environmental Hazards Division. ``That includes evaluating the relationship of specific samples to cases, and looking at the relevant lab analysis for major contaminants. ``And they don't show anything obvious.'' The FDA also acted to get the product, sold in several preparations under numerous brand names, off the shelves of health food stores and drug stores. People have taken L-tryptophan for years, but the problem apparently started just last year. Cases don't point to any particular manufacturer, brand or lot number. ``The epidemiology suggests it's a contaminant,'' Kilbourne said. ``A relatively large number of cases seemed to mushroom this past summer, and that suggests that something happened.'' So far, investigators haven't found any signs of contamination. ``But negative lab results or not, there's got to be something there,'' Kilbourne said. This is not a simple contamination investigation case, like trying to find poison in a capsule where it isn't supposed to be, because researchers don't know what they are looking for yet, Kilbourne said. ``This is just a thorny scientific problem,'' he said. Researchers with the Atlanta-based CDC are retracing their steps to see if they missed something small. ``Maybe the odd chromatographic peak that didn't seem significant before,'' Kilbourne said. ``We're re-evaluating all those things.'' ``We're just looking for anything identified as a potential contaminant,'' said Chris Lecos, an FDA spokesman in Washington. ``The answer lies somewhere in the laboratory, I suspect.'' The FDA issued a recall request for L-tryptophan Nov. 17 and expanded it Nov. 21 to block importation of the product. ``For the most part, it appears to us that most of the manufacturers and distributors and retail stores have complied with the recall request,'' Lecos said. ``We do know that some retail operations and a few manufacturers are not heeding the recall request,'' he said, adding that the FDA is contemplating seizure actions against seven companies although no action has been taken yet.

DOC.HEAD: A List of 32nd Annual Grammy Nominees
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of nominees for the 32nd annual Grammy Awards announced Thursday. 1.
