RECORD OF THE YEAR: ``The End of the Innocence,'' Don Henley; ``The Living Years,'' Mike and the Mechanics; ``She Drives Me Crazy,'' Fine Young Cannibals; ``We Didn't Start the Fire,'' Billy Joel; ``Wind Beneath My Wings,'' Bette Midler. 2. DOC.HEAD: Union, Management Meet in Bid to Resolve Violent Strike
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested several striking rail workers Thursday, and union leaders and management met in a bid to resolve a violent 10-week-old walkout. Both police and union officials confirmed the arrests in Pretoria of members of the South African Railways and Harbor Workers Union. Neither side had figures on exactly how many men were taken into custody. About 25,000 rail workers, all black, have been striking the state-owned South Africa Transport Services since November. They are demanding their minimum monthly wage be increased from $225 to $560. Workers also are seeking official recognition of their union. The company has fired 22,000 strikers, but says it will rehire half of those dismissed. It has refused to offer a wage increase. More than 20 people have died in strike-related violence, including seven in a clash Tuesday. The union and management met Thursday in Johannesburg and planned additional talks Friday. Management spokesman Leon Els said the negotiations were ``back on line,'' while the union's General Secretary Martin Sebakwane said the meeting was ``unsensational.'' Transport Services officials met separately with members of the anti-apartheid Mass Democratic Movement, which included union leaders and clergymen. In other developments Thursday: _ A mob stabbed a bus conductor near Durban, then set the vehicle afire and trapped him inside, where he burned to death, Transport Services officials said. The driver of the bus was stabbed eight times and hospitalized, the officials added. Officials said it was not clear whether the attack was connected to the strike. _ Police used tear gas to disperse hundreds of angry blacks protesting the prosposed demolition of their squatter community. Five homes were destroyed at the Tokoza shantytown east of Johannesburg, but authorities halted the operation when the crowd gathered. No injuries or arrests were reported. The government has declared the 3,000 squatter shacks illegal and seeks to move residents 20 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say Record Number of People Killed in Medellin
DOC.TEXT: A record 4,015 murders were committed in the cocaine capital of Medellin in 1989, authorities said Thursday. Colombia's efforts to fight the traffickers gained a boost with the Defense Ministry reporting delivery of seven more U.S. helicopters, part of a $60 million aid package. So far, 19 helicopters have been delivered. The city morgue in Medellin said murders increased last year to 4,015 from 3,299 in 1988, a rise of 22 percent. Gunfire caused 3,546 of the deaths, said Cesar Augusto Giraldo, the head of the morgue. He said he does not break down the deaths according to types of violence and could not say how many were drug-related. Government officials launched a campaign to annihilate the cocaine traffickers in August after they were blamed for killing a presidential candidate. Traffickers retaliated with a wave of bombings and other attacks. More than 200 nationwide bombings blamed on drug traffickers have killed at least 199 people and injured more than 1,200 since August. The deaths include 107 people killed Nov. 27 when a bomb believed planted by drug terrorists brought down a Colombian jetliner. Medellin, a city of 2 million people, is headquarters of the Medellin Cartel, which controls much of the billions of dollars in cocaine smuggled into the United States each year. Last year's violence also included a war between rival drug groups, vigilante killings of people suspected of theft, and fighting by street gangs bent on control of crime in poor areas. In addition, right-wing death squads and leftist guerrillas have been active in the city. Twenty prostitutes were killed recently in Medellin and their bodies thrown from speeding cars. Police say they don't know why they were killed. Since Sunday, a nationwide wave of violence in areas contested by right-wing death squads and leftist guerrillas has claimed 39 lives, the national police and the Defense Ministry said Thursday. The dead included 18 guerrillas and four soldiers slain in a battle in the northern state of Cesar. The dead also included seven peasants who were apparently massacred by a right-wing death squad in northern Colombia. In Medellin, a bomb tossed by one of two rival gangs in a prison killed one prisoner and wounded 35 others Wednesday, prison authorities there said in a news release Thursday. In addition, six kidnappings since Sunday include a federal congressman and a former mayor, the national police said. The congressman, Mario Silgado Romero, was pulled from his car Wednesday in the northwern city of Sincelejo, the police said. The kidnappers apparently belong to the leftist People's Liberation Army, a guerrilla group, the police said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The audience was kind when actress Lily Tomlin cut short her one-woman show. After just 30 minutes Tuesday night, Ms. Tomlin gave a lengthy apology to a near-capacity crowd. ``I just cannot serve the play,'' she said, explaining she had an extremely dry mouth because of an anti-flu medication. She asked the audience what she should do and was greeted with shouts of ``Dn't push yourself!'' and ``We love you anyway.'' Audience members were offered a refund or tickets to another performance of Ms. Tomlin's ``The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.'' Ms. Tomlin told the crowd she felt particularly bad ``because you all got dressed up and flossed your teeth and everything.''

A robber who punched a convenience store manager didn't realize the 72-year-old man standing by the newspaper stand was a former light heavyweight champion. Former boxer Billy Conn jumped into the struggle and tried to break up the robbery, but the crook got away Wednesday with about $80 from the store, police said. Conn and the robber ended up on the floor and the thief got away after dumping the newspaper rack on the boxer's legs, said Conn's wife, Mary Louise, who ran out of the store to summon help. ``My instinct was to get help. Billy's instinct was to fight,'' she said. Conn declined to talk about the incident. As a boxer, he won 63, lost 11 and fought one draw from 1935 to 1948. He held the light heavyweight title from July 1938 to May 1941 an was elected to the Boxing Hall of Fame in 1965.

Spotting Miss America during her Missouri Capitol homecoming was easy _ just look for her official escort. A dozen state troopers, deputy sheriffs, and Capitol Complex police, many in dress uniforms, walked Debbye Turner through visits with the governor, both chambers of the Legislature, and individual officeholders Wednesday. Miss Turner, an Arkansas native who is the first Missouri resident to wear the Miss America crown, also addressed the House and Senate after talking to 400 children in the Rotunda. Miss Turner explained how others told her she could never be Miss America because she was black, too short and because her talent _ marimba playing _ was too oddball for pageants. ``If this marimba-playing, five-foot-seven minority can be be Miss America, then you can do anything,'' she said.

Stephanie Smith Roos got a shot at fame 19 years ago singing ``It's the real thing'' in a Coca-Cola commercial, and now she gets to do it all over again. Roos, a Gary native, was living with her parents in Rome when she appeared in the classic 1971 commercial in which 40 young people on a hillside sang ``I'd like to teach the world to sing.'' Roos was the freckled, round-faced woman with straight blonde hair whose line closed the spot. Her hair is wavier now, her face thinner and the freckles are gone, but she'll reprise the role Jan. 28 in a new Coke commercial to appear during the Super Bowl. The new spot also features two of her four children _ Matthew, 12, and Elicia, 10 _ with her on that same hilltop in Sacrofano, Italy. ``The call from Coke in August came out of the blue,'' said Roos, 39. Coke, in rounding up the original cast, had nothing more to go on than photos from the first commercial and names discovered in a closet at an advertising agency. Pinkerton detectives tracked down 25 of the original 40 cast members in a few months.

DOC.HEAD: Iowans Not Laughing at Yeutter Jokes
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's remarks about Iowa's drought were meant as a joke, but his Iowa counterpart isn't amused. ``Secretary Yeutter unfortunately has chosen to make Iowa the butt of his jokes,'' Iowa Agriculture Secretary Dale Cochran said Thursday. ``The 60 percent of Iowans who earn their living directly or indirectly from agriculture aren't laughing.'' Yeutter made the remarks Wednesday at a Republican fund-raiser in Topeka, Kan., attended by Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan. ``Iowans define drought a little differently than we do in Kansas and Nebraska,'' said Yeutter, who grew up in Nebraska. ``It really has to be dry to have a drought here. In Iowa, as Bob put it, it's a question of whether it rained yesterday or not. If it didn't rain yesterday, they're having a drought.'' Yeutter visited Iowa on May 30 to tour areas suffering from the state's lingering drought. Southern Iowa, where Yeutter visited, received its only measurable rainfall of the month the night before he arrived, Cochran said. ``Each time as we came into land ... water was standing everywhere,'' Yeutter said of the trip. ``They were having a little hard time ... persuading me that they had a huge drought problem. But they kept saying, well, but it's the subsoil moisture, you know. It may well be wet on top, but it's really dry down below. They got a huge digger and they dug down about eight feet and they never did find any dry dirt.'' Cochran said 1989 was the seventh-driest year in Iowa in 117 years of record keeping in the state. He said 1988 and 1989 ``have gone down as the driest two-year period ever in Iowa.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Federal Judge Blocks Portions of Pa. Abortion Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today blocked sections of Pennsylvania's new abortion law from taking effect Tuesday. The law contains the toughest abortion restrictions in the nation. U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett III issued an injunction against requirements that women notify their husbands and wait 24 hours before an abortion. The judge left intact sections banning abortions after the 24th week of pregnancy and abortions to select the sex of the child, said Robert Gentzel, spokesman for state Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. The American Civil Liberties Union, the Women's Law Project and Planned Parenthood said the order was a victory in their first round against the new law. ``For the moment, in Pennsylvania, abortion remains safe and legal, but we have to fight to keep it this way,'' Kathryn Kolbert, an ACLU attorney, said in a statement. In passing the law last fall, Pennsylvania became the first state to take advantage of a U.S. Supreme Court ruling in July allowing states to put more curbs on abortion. Huyett, in blocking some of the new sections, actually amended an injunction first issued in 1988 against an earlier version of Pennsylvania's abortion law. Planned Parenthood and some abortion clinics had challenged the earlier law in court and amended their lawsuit after passage of the new, tougher law. The injunction remains in effect while the lawsuit is decided. Gov. Robert P. Casey today said he believes the entire law will pass constitutional muster. Anti-abortion leaders have said the law could present the U.S. Supreme Court with an avenue to reconsider the Roe vs. Wade decision, which established abortion as a constitutional right in 1973. The author of the law, Rep. Stephen Freind, said it placed pro-choice groups in a dilemma. If the law went unchallenged, the provisions would go into effect; if they challenged it, the case might lead the high court to further erode abortion protections, he said. ``We're in a no-loss situation. They're are in a no-win situation,'' said Freind, a Republican from suburban Philadelphia and the Legislature's leading abortion foe.

DOC.HEAD: Chicken Plucker's Feathers Ruffled by City Ordinances
DOC.TEXT: How many chickens would a chicken plucker pluck if a chicken plucker had a place to sell them in Bismarck? At least 500 more a week, says an owner of the state's only poultry plant. Mike Schmidt of S&S Poultry says Bismarck ordinances are keeping his chickens out of supermarkets and limiting the work of his plucking machine, which can pluck about 60 pounds of chickens in 30 seconds. ``Bismarck is the only city in North Dakota we cannot run our chickens in,'' Schmidt said. He plans to ask the City Commission on Tuesday to change its meat inspection laws. But city officials are resisting, saying the laws protect consumers. City Sanitation Coordinator Mel Fischer said Bismarck's ordinance requires all meat to be inspected and stamped with a retail code. Schmidt's poultry processing plant is federally inspected, but it lacks an on-site inspector and facilities for such an inspector. The inspector would be an employee of the federal Department of Agriculture, but Schmidt would have to provide an office and restroom and pay overtime wages for inspections. ``We have plans for doing it in the future, but right now money is tight,'' Schmidt said. Ironically, Schmidt started his business in Mott in western North Dakota nearly three years ago with his brother and brother-in-law after their wives saw a television news report about the unclean processing of chickens. They were shocked at the high incidence of salmonella bacteria contamination and the sloppy manner in which chickens were cleaned and cooled. S&S works to avoid those problems, Schmidt said. One Bismarck grocer is interested in selling 500 chickens a week, he said. The company sells to 30 stores in the state.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Ugandans on Border Flee Civil War in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Ugandans have fled a northern border town, fearing the spread of fighting from Sudan's civil war, officials said Thursday. Loic Flachet, a Kampala representative of the French relief group Doctors Without Borders, said 11 French volunteers were among those who took flight from the town of Moyo. Brig. Moses Ali, Uganda's minister for culture who represents the Moyo district in Parliament, confirmed the exodus but was unable to say how many of the estimated 40,000 residents of Moyo took part. The town is about 280 miles from Kampala and six miles from the Sudan border. The Guide newspaper reported in Kampala that the civilians began fleeing in the middle of last week when they heard gunfire near the town. The number increased after two military aircraft flew over Moyo on Saturday. Flachet said the relief team safely fled Dec. 5 to Adjumani, 27 miles to the south, and would remain there until the situation in Moyo returned to normal. They had been treating Ugandans for sleeping sickness, a disease transmitted by tsetse flies. The Guide newspaper said residents were afraid of a repeat of a bombing in Moyo by Sudanese aircraft three months ago that killed six civilians. A spokesman at army headquarters in Kampala said neither the southern Sudan rebels nor Sudan government troops had entered Ugandan territory. ``The situation is normal as far as the international border is concerned,'' the officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Fighting between Sudanese troops and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army has flared in recent months after a de facto cease-fire to permit a U.N.-sponsored emergency foodlift to southern Sudan. On Monday, the rebels claimed its fighters had captured a garrison town of Kajo-Kaji 18 miles north of Moyo. The rebels often seek sanctuary in northern Uganda, raising tension on the border. On Dec. 29, a Sudanese army armored vehicle and six truckloads of soldiers crossed six miles inside Uganda in the Moyo area. Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni and a six-member Sudanese delegation agreed Tuesday that the countries should each establish units to monitor security violations along the common border. The Sudanese rebels took up arms in 1983 against the Moslem-dominated Khartoum government to press for increased autonomy for the predominantly animist and Christian south.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Favor Limit for Congressional Members
DOC.TEXT: More than two-thirds of Americans surveyed said they favor a consitutional limitation on the number of years a person can serve in Congress, according to a Gallup survey released Thursday. The poll, conducted for the National Federation of Independent Business, found 70 percent of respondents favored in general a limitation on House and Senate members, while 28 percent opposed and 2 percent had no opinion. Asked if they would support establishing a 12-year limit on service in the House and Senate, 58 percent said yes and 40 percent opposed. The National Federation of Independent Businesses, an association of small business owners, also had the Gallup Organization Inc. put the questions to members of Congresss. It reported surveying 158 of the 435 House members, and finding 73 percent opposed and 23 percent favored a 12-year limitation. It surveyed 21 of 100 senators and found 52 percent favored a limitation and 48 percent opposed _ but the Gallup Organization said it surveyed too few for the results to be considered a reliable reflection of Senate opinion. The poll found 62 percent of total respondents favored establishing a mandatory retirement age for members of Congress, while 37 percent opposed. Nine out of 10 House and Senate members surveyed opposed an age limit. George Gallup, who presented the results at a news conference, said the findings were consistent with 50 years of surveying of attitudes about Congress by his organization. The survey of 750 people was conducted nationally by telephone in December and January and had a stated margin of error of plus or minus 4 to 5 percentage points, according to the business group. There was no margin listed for the survey of members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Government Cuts Homeless Aid From Counties in 30 States
DOC.TEXT: Some 126 counties that got aid for the homeless last year through a program created by Congress have been dropped for 1990. They include 20 with double-digit unemployment and one with a poverty rate of 42.7 percent. Advocates for the homeless, as well as local officials in the 30 states hit by the cutback, are protesting. But program administrators say they are merely fulfilling a mandate to target the aid to the nation's worst-off areas. Congress didn't cut funds for the $124.9 million Emergency Food and Shelter National Board Program. The 126 jurisdictions lost out when they fell below eligibility levels for local poverty, unemployment or the size of the overall labor force. Some may still get limited grants from a separate fund set aside for underfunded areas. Twenty-eight new counties became eligible this year. The rejected counties are as large as Oklahoma's Tulsa County, including the city of Tulsa, and as small as Madison Parish, La. Madison has unemployment and poverty rates of 16 percent and 42.7 percent respectively. But the parish, which got $22,000 in 1989, lost its eligibility because it had fewer than the required total of 1,000 people unemployed, according to the program's figures. Told the list said there were 883 jobless people in Madison, parish administrative assistant Geneva Jones said, ``I know it's more than that.'' But whatever the exact figure, she said the loss of money would hurt the elderly in her area. ``Most of them are on fixed incomes and by the time they pay their utilities, they don't have enough for adequate food,'' she said in a telephone interview. The United Way was no happier in the urban county of Tulsa, where officials complained to federal administrators in a Nov. 30 letter: ``While on the face of it, this (denial) would seem to be a positive reflection of an improving local economy, nothing could be further from the truth.'' Program staff director Wylie B. Cooper said in an interview, ``Communities change in what's happening. Last year, Texas was incredibly hard hit, and this year it is beginning to recover. That happens all over the country because the money is designated for the most critical need areas.'' But Jim Cieslar of Tulsa's United Way said there have been new oil company layoffs in his area. The national program's Cooper said that the system was designed ``to supplement and extend'' efforts on behalf of the homeless and that the government cannot guarantee funding to individual counties beyond one year. ``The flip side of predictability is being unable to respond to change,'' Cooper said. But Rep. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa., said, ``You don't suddenly become a non-needy area. There ought to be a way to come down slowly.'' Grant money may be used to buy and distribute food, run homeless shelters, assist with mortgages or help the poor pay energy bills. Counties don't apply for grants. Rather, they are told if the formula qualifies them for money, and then must come up with a spending plan. This year, 882 counties automatically qualified for aid compared with 980 in 1989, said program aide Sharon Bailey. The National Alliance To End Homelessness, a private research and assistance group, estimates as many as 2 million people are homeless for at least a portion of the year, and says the number seems to be growing. ``To learn at this time, just as winter weather is beginning to grip our area, that we will not have the resources to meet the needs presented to us by these very vulnerable individuals and families is disappointing, to say the least,'' Theresa Zogby, supervisor of Catholic Social Services of Hazleton, Pa., said in a letter last month to Kanjorski. Her county, Luzerne, received about $230,000 last year but nothing this year. Despite a poverty rate above the 11 percent in the guidelines, Luzerne was declared ineligible because the labor force in Wilkes-Barre, its largest city, did not exceed 25,000. Cooper said the rule would be reversed if the national board determines at its Jan. 19 meeting that it is unfairly preventing needy counties from obtaining funding. Madison, Luzerne and the other counties and parishes may still get aid from set-aside funds, although probably not as much as last year. Those funds, representing 15 percent of total program expenditures, are administered by state boards trying to cushion the blow for communities whose eligibility has expired. Cooper said the set-aside money is considered an important backstop. Ohio had the most dropped counties with 15. There were 13 in Illinois, 11 in Texas and nine in North Carolina. The dropped counties or parishes with double-digit unemployment rates, the program said, were Edgar, Fayette, Union, Wayne and White in Illinois; Grayson, Johnson and Letcher, Lincoln and Montgomery in Kentucky; Madison, Plaquemines and Union in Louisiana; Washington in Missouri; Cibola and San Miguel in New Mexico; Adams and Pike in Ohio, and Lincoln and Upshur in West Virginia. The food and shelter program is governed by a national board composed of representatives of the United Way of America, Catholic Charities USA, the American Red Cross and other charitable organizations. The program has generated praise from communities for bypassing state bureaucracies and providing money directly to agencies that serve the homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Of Infanticide Suspect Says She Was Unaware of Pregnancy
DOC.TEXT: The mother of an 18-year-old woman charged with killing her newborn said she saw her daughter hours before she gave birth and never suspected the teen-ager was pregnant. ``She's quiet,'' Darlene Broadwater said. ``She kept everything to herself. All she had to do was open her mouth and say, `Mom, do you want a baby?' I'd have taken it. I'd have fed it. I'd have given it a home.'' Tammy Lynn Sanner of Meyersdale was arrested Monday and charged with criminal homicide. She was being held without bond. Her baby, born the day before Christmas, was found Saturday in a grocery bag in an alley. An umbilical cord was wrapped around her neck. Coroner Wilber Miller said the infant had been strangled. Some of Miss Sanner's relatives suspected she was pregnant but hadn't said anything. They said she not lived with her mother since she was 5. They said Miss Sanner had not confided in any relative since the November 1988 death of the woman who raised her, Salome Sanner, her grandmother. ``In Tammy's mind, Tammy had nobody,'' said an aunt, Hilda Sanner, also of Meyersdale. Miss Sanner had lived with another aunt, Bertha Lynn Sanner, in recent months. Mrs. Broadwater, who lives in Avilton, Md., said she visited her daughter the day before the birth. Her husband and Miss Sanner's stepfather, Gerald Broadwater, also was present during the half-hour visit. Broadwater said the young woman looked unhealthy and ``her stomach was bigger than what it generally used to be.'' He thought she was pregnant, but said nothing. Hilda Sanner said she began to suspect Miss Sanner was pregnant in October. ``But I didn't want her to think I was nosing into her business,'' she said. Miss Sanner's relatives believe she did not have the will to intentionally kill an infant. ``Tammy didn't think on an 18-year-old basis,'' Hilda Sanner said. ``She has a childlike way of looking at things,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Reveals 207 Killed in September Accident on Danube
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: The interim government said Thursday that 207 Romanians were killed in September when a passenger ship sank after colliding with a Bulgarian tugboat on the Danube river. Deputy Foreign Minister Romulus Neagu, who revealed the death toll, said the accident was under investigation, the Rompres news agency reported. The accident occured Sept. 10, upstream of the city port of Galati, 125 miles northeast of Bucharest. The Romanian media, at the time tightly controlled by the authoritarian government of Nicolae Ceausescu, gave few details of the accident. The Romanian vessel sank ``in conditions of poor visibility,'' the state news agency reported at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Engine Fall Firmly Blamed on Ice from Lavatory
DOC.TEXT: Ice from a leaky lavatory caused a rear jet engine to shear off a Northwest Airlines airliner over northern Florida last week, federal investigators have determined. Blue fluid from the forward lavatory leaked outside, froze because of the low temperature at 35,000 feet, broke off and slammed into the compressor blades of the right rear engine on the three-engine Boeing 727, National Transportation Safety Board investigator Andrew Alston said Wednesday. The ice broke eight blades in the engine's low-pressure compressor and the damage multiplied through other blades until vibration made the three bolts holding the engine to the plane's tail section break off, as they are designed to do to prevent damage to the fuselage, Altson said. Airline and government officials had speculated that was the cause. Pilots safely landed the plane, which carried 145 passengers and crew, at Tampa International Airport on Jan. 4 about 90 minutes after it had taken off from Miami bound for Minneapolis. The 3,500-pound Pratt & Whitney engine was found the next day on a cattle ranch in rural Madison County near the Florida-Georgia border. The NTSB has not ordered any safety inspections, but is informing all airlines about the cause of the accident, Alston said. Airlines do not use anti-freeze in their lavatories because it is toxic, said Jorge Prellezo, regional director of the NTSB in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Helmsleys' Ex-Manager Gets Minimal State Sentence In Plea Deal
DOC.TEXT: Frank Turco, a former executive in the Helmsley real estate empire, was sentenced Thursday on state conspiracy and fraud charges to eight months in prison, concurrent with a two-year federal term he received last month. The sentence was part of a plea bargain, according to Turco lawyer William Brodsky, who called it ``the best deal he could have gotten.'' Turco pleaded guilty Oct. 27 to four counts of a 188-count indictment. He admitted he falsified business records so that $3 million spent on Harry and Leona Helmsley's Greenwich, Conn., mansion would appear as business expenses for their hotels and other properties. Turco, 46, now living near Tampa, Fla., was convicted in August with Mrs. Helmsley and Joseph V. Licari, 53, another Helmsley executive, on federal charges of evading $1.2 million in taxes. On Dec. 12, Mrs. Helmsley was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.2 million. Licari got 2{ years in prison and a $75,000 fine. Turco got a $50,000 fine and the two-year sentence, which he will serve at the minimum-security federal prison at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, Brodsky said. Mrs. Helmsley, 69, is free pending appeal and still faces state charges. Harry Helmsley, 80, was found incompetent to stand trial in federal court. A hearing on his application to be excused from state trial on similar grounds is set for Feb. 8.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Lifting of Matial Law in China
With AM-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday welcomed the lifting of martial law in China as a ``very positive'' move, despite congressional criticism that it was a meaningless gesture by Beijing. Bush took the opposite view of those saying the Chinese showed no indication they were improving their stance on human rights and reforms. ``I view the lifting of martial law as a very sound step,'' the president told reporters during an Oval Office photo session. ``For those who are interested in the human rights and reform that was on the move that we'd all like to see go forward, there's no way you can look at that but say it's very positive.'' ``Of course we welcome the lifting of martial law as a good sign,'' he said. Critics took a different view of China's announcement it would lift the martial law put into place last spring during a brutal crackdown on thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators. On Capitol Hill, some have derided the lifting of martial law as smoke-and-mirrors and an empty gesture, noting that China still retains tough anti-protest laws and surveillance of university campuses as well as a strong presence by its army in the streets of Beijing. In addition, China did not include the Tibetan capital of Lhasa in its lifting of martial law. Beijing said the situation was different in Lhasa, where Buddhist monks have suffered repression for demonstrating for religious freedoms and independence. Tibet has been under martial law since the outbreak of pro-independence riots in March. Bush on Thursday did not indicate whether he considered the move enough of a step to spur further lifting of the sanctions he imposed in June when the Chinese government mowed down demonstrators with tanks, killing hundreds, perhaps thousands in the streets. ``We will continue to watch this situation very closely,'' he said. On Wednesday the administration announced that it would review on a case-by-case basis World Bank loans to China for humanitarian causes, but would continue to oppose loans to China for projects. That marked a shift from the initial position on sanctions, which made no mention of evaluating humanitarian loans. The State Department has said the partial easing of the sanctions was unrelated to China's lifting of martial law. Among $780 million worth of pending World Bank loans to China is a $25 million loan for earthquake relief. Bank spokesman Peter Riddleberger said Thursday the bank board had no discussions scheduled on the loan. Bush has come under fire for what critics say was his failure to come down hard on China, the country where he served as U.S. representative in the mid-1970s. Although he announced in June he was banning high-level contacts with Beijing as part of the sanctions, Bush secretly dispatched National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to Beijing twice in subsequent months to explore the possibilities of renewing relations.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Stuart Family Lawyer Says Only Matthew Knew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Until Jan. 1, the only member of the family of Charles Stuart who knew of his plot to kill his pregnant wife was the youngest brother who linked him to the crime, an attorney said Thursday. ``They knew nothing, they did nothing, they saw nothing, they touched nothing,'' attorney Richard Clayman said of other family members at a news conference attended by Stuart's siblings Michael, Mark, Shelley and Neysa. Only Matthew Stuart, who turned his brother in, did not attend. ``The appearance that has evolved in my judgment is that there was some kind of conspiracy. That is not true, and these people want you, and the DiMaiti family, and eveyrone else to know that is so,'' said Clayman, who represents Michael Stuart but spoke on behalf of the family. Clayman said his client would tell a grand jury anything they want to know, ``I am comfortable that there is no violation of law ... that his hands are legally clean.'' He also said the Stuart family wanted people to know ``they loved Carol Stuart'' and that their family and her parents, Eveylyn and Giusto DiMaiti, had suffered greatly. He said that on looking back Michael Stuart had a ``disjointed, vague conversation'' with Charles Stuart but that it had no significance at the time. ``In retrospect, after examining all the data there an argument can be made ... that it had some significance,'' he said. Since the case began unraveling last week, the street outside the Stuart family home in Revere has been the daily assembly point for neighbors and about a dozen reporters and photographers. Stuart told police after the Oct. 23 shooting that he and his wife, Carol, were attacked by a mugger as they left a birthing class at a city hospital. But in a stunning turnaround last week, his brother, Matthew, implicated him in the death, saying he met Charles Stuart at the crime scene and retrieved Mrs. Stuart's handbag, which contained personal items, and the gun. Matthew Stuart, who has said he did not realize a shooting had occurred when he took the items, told his lawyer he had shared his suspicions about his brother with family and friends. A transcript of a telephone conversation between Michael and a sister, Shelley Yandoli, recorded on firehouse communications equipment, revealed that the parents and another sister, Neysa Porter, did not know of Stuart's plot until the family assembled Jan. 2 to discuss it with the parents. Meanwhile, divers searched the Pines River again Thursday for clues in the plot, which may have evolved from little more than Stuart's feeling that his wife and baby would hinder his dreams of being a big-time restaurateur. Police divers recovered the handbag shortly after Stuart committed suicide Jan. 4 by jumping from the Tobin Bridge into Boston Harbor, and Tuesday they found a snub-nosed .38-caliber revolver believed used in the crime. Prosecutors have refused to say whether anyone might be charged in the crime, saying the investigation is continuing. A grand jury is to convene Friday on the case. Authorities have investigated whether Stuart might have plotted the murder so he could collect money from insurance policies on his wife. Stuart received $82,000 from one policy due his wife from her job as a tax attorney. He had taken out at least one other policy on her, for $100,000, that was being processed when he committed suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Black Firefighters Want 15-Month-Old Promotion Freeze Continued
DOC.TEXT: The 15-month freeze on promotions in the Dallas Fire Department should be continued at least until a discrimination lawsuit against the department goes to trial, an attorney for black firefighters told a federal appeals court Thursday. ``Right now the system isn't even fair among blacks. Black firefighters who are getting through may not be the ones who would if the system was fair,'' attorney Roger Albright told a three-judge panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Craig Hopkins argued for the city of Dallas that the 220-member Black Fire Fighters Association of Dallas has not proved that its members would suffer irreparable harm without a freeze on promotions. In addition, he said, the case shouldn't even be before the 5th Circuit yet because the black firefighters haven't exhausted their civil service appeals. The judges did not indicate when they would rule. The department's freeze on promotions began in October 1988, a month after the black firefighters sued the department alleging racial discrimination. The city has since enacted a new affirmative action plan for the department, but the black firefighters say it doesn't go far enough. During the promotion freeze, the city has filled the need for supervisors by temporarily promoting lower-level workers. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Porter rejected the black group's request for an order continuing the freeze on promotions pending the trial, but both sides agreed to continue the freeze while the black group appealed to the 5th Circuit, Albright said. Porter is in ill health, attorneys told the judges, and they don't know when the discrimination case may go to trial. Hal Gillespie, attorney for the predominantly white Dallas firefighters group, who joined the city in arguing that the freeze should be discontinued, said people who already qualified for promotion are losing out because the promotion lists have expired. When the lawsuit was filed, Albright said after the hearing, blacks made up 35 percent of the city's population but 17 percent of the 1,700 people in the fire department. Out of 367 drivers _ the first level up from fire and rescue workers _ 17 percent were black. Five of 121 lieutenants, or rougly 4 percent, were black, as were six of 182 captains, or 3 percent, and one of 22 battalion chiefs, or 4{ percent. Blacks contend that a major reason for the disparity is that promotion exams ask for knowledge beyond what is useful for each level. The exam for driver, for instance, includes questions about building codes and construction, said Albright. ``Our point of view is that the exams test for things that a firefighter ought to know at any level,'' Hopkins said after the hearing. During the hearing, Senior Judge John R. Brown asked Hopkins if Dallas hadn't contradicted its legal stand by adopting an affirmative action plan calling for blacks to get 25 percent of all fire department promotions. The plan approved by the City Council expands the pool of eligible minorities for promotion by putting less emphasis on seniority and test scores and more on affirmative action. The council also agreed to spend more than $400,000 to re-evaluate hiring and promotion tests. ``This is not the first affirmative action plan. It's a modification and continuation of previous efforts ...,'' Hopkins responded. ``It is not an admission of wrongdoing, but that there can always be improvements.''

DOC.HEAD: Council OKs Plan to Kidnap Ugly Ducks
DOC.TEXT: After a two-year dispute over pesky ducks, the city has committed itself to helping residents who want to drive them from an exclusive beach community. City Commissioners voted 4-1 Monday to let residents in the Woodlands area capture ducks on their property, call the city and have the ducks picked up and released unharmed in a rural area. When asked Wednesday about what the program would cost taxpayers, City Manager Max Royle said, ``Twenty bucks a duck.'' Commissioner Paul Von Ins had introduced a petition with 39 signatures asking the commission to come up with a way to enforce a decision made in June to drive the Muscovy ducks out of the neighborhood. Mayor Pete Dobson cast the dissenting vote, saying pro-duck forces had not been given the opportunity to respond to the petition. The dispute began in January 1988 when the commission voted to reduce the duck population from 150 to 20 after some residents complained that the ugly, mottled birds defecated on their lawns, mated in public and acted aggressively toward other animals. Others felt the ducks predated homeowners in the area, and had every right to stay. Gradually the population was reduced to six or seven as a special duck committee approved the snatching of duck eggs to keep them from hatching, and even arranged for the removal of some of the adults. Von Ins said, however, that the population could rebound.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors in Utility Case Treated to Tour of Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who heard a long court battle between Houston Power & Lighting and the city of Austin have been invited on an expense-paid trip to see the nuclear power plant that was the focus of last summer's trial. The jury had ruled that the utility didn't have to pay the city damages. Some Austin officials questioned the plan's propriety. The utility confirmed that about a month ago it had invited the Dallas jurors and retired appellate court Judge Clarence Guittard, who presided over the four-month trial, to visit the South Texas Nuclear Project plant at HL&P expense, the Houston Chronicle reported Thursday. ``This is a bunch of people who spent an inordinate amount of time studying the plant and never got a chance to see it,'' said HL&P spokesman Graham Painter. The jurors decided in July that although HL&P denied information to one of its partners in the STNP _ the city of Austin _ Austin deserved no damage payments. Austin had sought $419 million and is appealing the jury's decision. The trial was held in Dallas after a judge decided a fair trial could not be held in Austin. Painter said the company decided that jurors should stay overnight in Houston because of the time it takes to get from Dallas to the plant site at Bay City, 90 miles southwest of Houston. He said HL&P has reserved 19 rooms in the Westin Oaks at the Galleria, where single rooms run $150 a night during the week and half that on weekends. ``We're awfully proud of our plant, and we'd like to show it off,'' Painter said. Besides, he said, ``They are the only people in Texas who are certain never to serve on an STP jury again, so there's no reason they shouldn't go on a plant tour.'' Juror Kathy LaMarr agreed: ``I want to see what it was we were talking about all that time.'' But some Austin officials are outraged. ``It's highly unprofessional and very questionable. Until the people of Texas realize that this sort of shenanigans cost the people hundreds of millions of dollars, it won't stop,'' said Austin City Councilman George Humphrey. ``When you have a jury that rules the defendant is guilty and awards no damages and a short time later, they're offered free air fare, free lodging, free meals and first-class treatment, it can't help but cast a doubt,'' Humphrey said. ``I've never heard of this happening in civil litigation. I think it's fundamentally unethical, but so what else is new?'' said Councilman Smoot Carl-Mitchell. Austin claimed in the trial that HL&P withheld information from its partners that would have lead the city to move to cancel construction of the plant before its cost ballooned from $900 million to almost $6 billion, not counting interest costs on construction that lasted 17 years. During the trial, specialists in engineering, accounting and law were called on and jurors were shown a million-dollar scale model of the nuclear power plant.

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Defends Plan for Security Agency; Widespread Protests
With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Communist Premier Hans Modrow on Thursday defended his plan for a new internal security force and tried to quell growing dissent by indicating the opposition could have a part in his government. Thousands of people formed a human chain around Parliament after Modrow's speech to legislators, and a non-Communist partner in the coalition government repeated threats to quit the Cabinet. An independent trade union movement threatened to call a nationwide strike Jan. 25 if Modrow fails to prove the state secret police force has been dissolved. In a nearly 90-minute speech before the national Parliament, Modrow defended his authority and appealed for national unity to fight the economic and political problems threatening his shaky government, which came to power after the fall pro-democracy movement. ``I cannot recall becoming premier through a coup,'' he said. Modrow did not rule out the resignation of his transitional government for ``compelling reasons'' but said he expected it to last until nationwide elections planned May 6. During the meeting, Parliament dismissed state security chief Lt. Gen. Wolfgang Schwanitz, whose agency the government promised last month to dissolve. The hated secret police, popularly known as ``Stasi,'' used repressive measures to help ensure 40 years of Communist control. Government officials say about 26,000 of the 85,000 state security employees have been taken off the payroll. Opposition groups want guarantees the force will be disarmed and assurances former agents will not have a part in a new agency. ``The aim is not to maintain the old structure'' of state security, Modrow said. But he told Parliament ``there cannot be a security vacuum,'' and cited violence by neo-Nazi groups as well as ``terrorism, drugs and ecological crime.'' Modrow urged the opposition to make suggestions about how it would be prepared to ``participate directly and responsibly in the work of the government with competent personalities.'' However, Modrow did not say when or in what form such participation could take place. He offered to have Parliament supervise the new security agency and dissolution of its predecessor. Within hours, the Liberal Democrats, a non-Communist partner in the government, repeated their threat to leave. ``There can be no compromise with us'' on the secret police issue, said party spokesman Werner Fahlenkamp. Two other non-Communist parties in government have threatened to quit over the issue. Several thousand opposition supporters chanting and holding candles formed a human chain around the Parliament building. Demonstrators lowered several East German flags from their poles and ripped out the Communist symbol from the centers. Representatives of the ``Initiative For Labor Union Reform,'' which claims 70,000 members, called for Modrow's resignation and the freezing of Communist Party assets. They threatened to call a nationwide warning strike Jan. 25, to demonstrate their strength, if they are not convinced the security agency has been dissolved. Earlier, East Berlin construction workers staged such a strike, which lasted one hour, and marched through the city center. The ADN news agency said 2,000 workers at a farm equipment factory in Erfurt also staged a strike Thursday. Modrow, responding to the warning strikes, announced the government would suspend a plan for state aid to internal security employees who lost their jobs. For the first time, opposition members sat as observers in Thursday's Parliament session. Modrow's speech was broadcast live on East German and West German TV. News reports had said Modrow was considering calling for a national referendum to gauge the public support for his government before May, but he made no mention of this. Several old guard Communists in the 500-seat Parliament lost their seats to younger deputies Thursday. Those ousted included Guenther Schabowski, a former Politburo member and close associate of disgraced former leader Erich Honecker. At the start of the session, Parliament speaker Guenther Maleuda confirmed a West German report that Johanna Toepfer, once the No. 2 official in the government-run labor union federation FDGB, committed suicide Sunday. Ms. Toepfer was forced to resign in November during the pro-democracy movement that drove out hard-line Communist leaders and cleared the way for scheduling of free elections May 6. Maleuda gave no details of the suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians, Hezbollah Clash as PLO Seeks to Quell Militia Fighting
DOC.TEXT: The PLO on Thursday accused fighters of a pro-Iranian militia of killing a Palestinian guerrilla and wounding three others deployed to quell battles between Shiite Moslem militias in south Lebanon. The fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, issued a statement in Beirut denying the PLO charge and said its fighters ``did not fire a single shot on Palestinian positions.'' But a Sunni Moslem cleric, Sheik Maher Hammoud, who maintains close ties with Hezbollah, said fundamentalist fighters fired at the Palestinians on the strategic Hamade hill, which overlooks the forward lines of Hezbollah and its rival militia, the Syrian-backed Amal. The militias have been fighting intermittently since May 1987 for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites. The latest battles have been waged on the fringes of PLO strongholds, in south Lebanon's Iqlim al-Tuffah, or apple province. About 700 members of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement were deployed last week to try to disengage the warring factions, and no major clashes have occurred since Monday between the militias. The PLO claimed Hezbollah gunners opened fire on a PLO disengagement force Wednesday, killing one guerrilla and wounding three. The commander of the Fatah force, identified only as Col. Abu Fadi, said the guerrillas ``will be forced to return fire to defend ourselves'' if Hezbollah fires on them again. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said Hezbollah believes the PLO intervention has helped Amal and stopped Hezbollah from taking the entire region. Police could not confirm the Palestinian casualties. They said the bodies of two slain Hezbollah fighters were found early Thursday in Iqlim al-Tuffah. The police spokesman said the two men were apparently slaughtered by Amal militiamen after being taken captive. Police said one Hezbollah gunman was also killed and two Amal militiamen were wounded in a brief shootout in the village of Arki, six miles southwest from the main area of fighting. The casualties, excluding the Palestinians, upped the overall toll to 97 dead and 277 wounded since the current round of clashes broke out Dec. 23. Fatah's political chief in the southern city of Sidon, Zeid Wehbe, refused a Hezbollah appeal for the withdrawal of Arafat's men from Iqlim al-Tuffah. ``We are not an occupying force to be asked to withdraw,'' Wehbe said in a statement published in several Beirut newspapers. ``We are a disengagement force. When fighting is over and its consequences are solved, we will return to our previous bases,'' he was quoted as saying by the independent An-Nahar daily. Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mohammad Ali Besharati, who is in Beirut trying to enforce a cease-fire, has warned of the dangers of the Palestinians' expansion in Iqlim al-Tuffah and called on them to withdraw promptly to their nearby refugee camps. But sources from both Shiite factions spoke of a deadlock. In public statements, Amal chieftain Nabih Berri insists on an unconditional withdrawal of Hezbollah from all territories it conquered during the latest round of fighting. Hezbollah has offered a gradual withdrawal, coinciding with negotiations on finding a way for both militias to exist in the region. There was sporadic sniper fire interspersed with blasts from rocket-propelled grenades Thursday, but no casualties were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Crop Estimated to Fall 24 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Orange production is expected to drop 24 percent this season to fewer than 158 million boxes, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The new estimate, based on Jan. 1 conditions and reflecting the severe freeze damage in Florida and Texas over the holiday season, was 19 percent below the Dec. 1 estimate. Overall citrus production, including oranges and grapefruit, is expected to decline 25 percent from the 1988-89 season to 9.63 million tons, the report said. The January estimate is down 18 percent from December. ``This significant reduction is due mostly to the severe freezing temperatures in the Florida and Texas citrus belts,'' the report said. ``Fruit droppage is increasing in all areas of Florida. Texas fresh market citrus harvest has ended.'' The report added that it is ``too early to determine if there is significant wood damaage or tree loss'' in either Florida or Texas. Florida's orange harvest was estimated at 92 million boxes, down from 146.6 million last season and 130 million forecast in December. The Texas crop was estimated at 1.25 million boxes, down from 1.85 million last year and 1.95 forecast in December. Total grapefruit output was forecast at 45.6 million boxes, down 30 percent from last season and 16 percent below the December forecast. Florida grapefruit production was indicated at 38 million boxes, down from 54.75 million last season and 44 million last month. The Texas crop, forecast at 2 million boxes, compared with 4.8 million last year and 4.4 million estimated in December.

DOC.HEAD: Grammy Nominees Include the Peculiar
With AM-Grammys
DOC.TEXT: Grammy Award nominees included sibling rivalries and a husband-wife duo, nods to a former Miss America and a jailed soul singer. Also among the 388 nominations announced Thursday were three motion picture stars and a newspaper columnist. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences will announce the winners Feb. 21. Janet Jackson and her brother, Michael Jackson, were competing against each other in the best music video category. Rosanne Cash, Johnny's daughter, and husband Rodney Crowell each got nominations. Gilda Radner, Roy Orbison, Keith Whitley and Hank Williams Sr. were the posthumous nominees. The late Nat ``King'' Cole will get a special lifetime achievement award. Three members of a disbanded group, the Beatles, will also be factors in this year's Grammys. Paul McCartney gets a lifetime achievement award, while George Harrison was nominated as a member of the Traveling Wilburys and Ringo Starr was nominated with Buck Owens for the single ``Act Naturally.'' Vanessa Williams, a former Miss America, was nominated for rhythm and blues performance for ``Dreamin''' and jailed singer James Brown shared a best R&B duo nomination with Aretha Franklin. The movie ``The Last Temptation of Christ,'' ridiculed as sacrilege by some fundamentalist Christians, got a nomination for Peter Gabriel's album background score. The Bulgarian State Female Vocal Choir got a nomination for best traditional folk recording. They were up against Masters of Traditional Missouri Fiddling, among others. Actress Kelly McGillis, who starred in ``Top Gun,'' ``Witness'' and ``The Accused,'' got a best children's recording Grammy nomination for her reading on the album ``Thumbelina.'' Jason Robards and Sir John Gielgud were other actor nominees this year. Humorist-columnist Erma Bombeck showed up the comedy recording and spoken word categories.

DOC.HEAD: Beneficiary of Babe Ruth's Legendary Home Run Dead at 74
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Johnny reportedly...', to CORRECT father's title to vice president sted president. Essex Fells is cq in 5th graf. A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: When Johnny Sylvester's father wanted a second opinion about his sick boy, he consulted Babe Ruth. The baseball legend's treatment was unorthodox _ a 1926 World Series home run. John Dale Sylvester, 74, died Monday. But Ruth's purported promise and delivery of a home run lives on, memorialized in newspapers, biographies and on film, though wildly distorted. ``So many things about Babe Ruth have become like Greek mythology,'' baseball historian Don Honig said after hearing of Sylvester's death. Sylvester died at a hospital on New York's Long Island. No cause of death was given. According to news reports from the time, Sylvester was kicked in the head by a horse, suffering a life-threatening injury which left the 11-year-old boy bedridden in Essex Fells, N.J. Johnny reportedly told his father, Manhattan bank vice president Horace Sylvester, ``Gee, I wish I could see Babe Ruth wallop a homer before I die.'' The elder Sylvester contacted Ruth's team, the New York Yankees, in St. Louis via telegram, recounting his son's request. Autographed balls from the Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals were sent to the lad; Ruth wrote on one ball, ``I'll hit a home run for you in Wednesday's game.'' The Sultan of Swat then hit three homers in the Yankees' 10-5 fourth game victory over the Cardinals. Johnny's doctors reported the boy had bounced back remarkably from his illness, and a legend was born. Sylvester quickly became America's most famous invalid. ``That and the called home run _ those two specific incidents are probably the best known Ruth stories,'' said Robert Creamer, author of the biography ``Babe.'' ``The incident is sort of characteristic of Ruth. He had a great sort of ingenious quality about him,'' said Creamer. ``He'd do things like this, sometimes with great publicity, sometimes with no publicity.'' When William Bendix portrayed ``The Bambino'' on film, the story had Ruth bedside with a dying boy when the home run was promised. It was far from accurate, but as Creamer noted, ``That was a pretty bad movie.'' One week later, Ruth visited the lad. Johnny, well aware that Ruth had been caught stealing for the final out in the Yankees series loss, told the Babe, ``I'm sorry the Yanks lost.'' Sylvester went on to attend Princeton University, serve in World War II, and become president of packing machinery business. His son, John Jr., said his dad remained a Yankees fan until the end. Slyvester is also survived by a sister and a brother. The whole Johnny Sylvester story apparently had little effect on the Babe. According to Creamer's biography, Ruth was sitting around with a couple of baseball writers during spring training in 1927 when Sylvester's uncle approached the Babe and thanked him profusely. ``How is Johnny?'' Ruth asked. The uncle assured the Babe that Johnny was doing OK and walked away. Ruth, who was notoriously bad with names and referred to most everyone as ``kid,'' turned to the reporters and asked, ``Now who the hell is Johnny Sylvester?''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Pushing for Alternative-Fuel Cars
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration renewed its push Thursday to require the sale of hundreds of thousands of alternative-fuel automobiles by the late 1990s in urban areas having the worst air pollution problems. William Rosenberg, associate administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told a Senate hearing that clean air legislation must ``break the monopoly'' that exists for conventional gasoline and give motorists an opportunity to use less polluting fuels. The phase-in of up to 1 million vehicles powered by fuels other than gasoline had been proposed by President Bush last summer as part of his clean air package, but the provision was cut from legislation under consideration in the House and never included in a Senate version. Administration officials and environmentalists hope to reinstate the alternative fuel provision into clean air legislation that is moving toward floor consideration in both the House and Senate. The automakers have opposed any federal requirement for alternative fuel vehicles, arguing that they fear consumers will not want them, and were successful in getting the provisons knocked out of a House clean air bill earlier this year. If Congress were to require such cars, it also should require incentives to stimulate consumer demand for them and ease stringent tailpipe emission controls required in the proposed legislation beginning after the year 2003, said Donald Buist of the Ford Motor Co. But leading Democrats in the Senate have said they are not prepared to trade a clean fuel car program for the more stringent pollution control standards that would apply to all new vehicles across the country under legislation advancing in the Senate. Rosenberg said the use of alternative fuel cars is ``a vital and integral part'' of any effort to clean up the worst urban smog that plagues nine specific urban areas. Among the fuels to be considered is methanol, ethanol, natural gas, and propane, he said. In urban areas with the worst pollution, the only other way to meet federal air quality at the turn of the century will be to dramaticaly restrict automobile use, an option he said is not considered appropriate. Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, the committee's ranking Republican, said he plans to offer an amendment to the Senate air pollution control bill that would require automakers to begin making 150,000 alternative fuel vehicles available in California within four years and phase similar cars in eight other urban areas beginning in 1997. Under the Chafee proposal nearly a third of the cars sold in the nine cities would be powered by fuel or a blend other than gasoline by 1999. ``Just cleaning up the tailpipe (emissions) on cars hasn't been enough to assure healthy air quality,'' said Chafee, who compared the problem to a treadmill on which tighter pollution controls on individual gasoline powered cars are often offset by the increased number of cars on the road. According to the EPA, the cities where air quality is so poor that alternative fuel cars would be required are Los Angeles, where local officials already are developing similar requirements, Houston, New York, Milwaukee, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Hartford, San Diego and Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Portuguese Prime Minister Discuss Angola
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Portugal's prime minister, Anibal Cavaco Silva, discussed prospects Thursday for ending the fighting in Angola but ``didn't agree on absolutely every point,'' an administration official said. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz refused repeatedly to say where the president and prime minister differed on developments in the former Portuguese colony, located along the southwest coast of Africa. ``They basically traded analyses,'' Seitz said. ``Didn't agree on absolutely every point but did agree that the goal of national reconciliation (in Angola) is what the purpose of the process is, and both sides agreed that every effort ought to be made to bring about that reconciliation.'' Cavaco Silva, on an official working visit, talked with Bush for 2{ hours in the Oval Office and during a luncheon. A key issue was the impasse in talks in Angola between the Soviet-backed government supported by Portugal and the UNITA rebels armed by the United States. A truce between the government and the rebels broke down last summer, and the Angolan government unleashed a new offensive against UNITA on Dec. 23. ``There was a lot of discussion as to why the cease-fire broke down,'' Seitz reported after the talks. ``There are some different interpretations as to how we have arrived at this particular point.'' Publicly, Bush and Cavaco Silva glossed over any differences. Bush called the prime minister a good friend and said that U.S.-Portuguese relations ``are stronger than ever.'' In his only comments on Angola, Bush said Portugal had historic ties to the southern African region. He said, ``We value the perspective and support'' that Portugal has given to efforts by Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, to mediate an end to the conflict. ``When peace and stability come to that region, as certainly we hope they will, Portugal will have an important role in the reconstruction process,'' Bush said. Cavaco Silva said he briefed Bush on consultations with the Angolan and Mozambique governments ``and expressed the hope that if all interested parties show a positive attitude, it will be possible to put an end to the conflict that exacts such a heavy toll on the peoples of those two African countries.'' On another subject, Cavaco Silva assured Bush that that Portugal ``is in favor of a continued commitment and presence of the United States in Europe, which is a key factor for Europe's own security.'' Bush called Portugal ``an inspiration and an example to Eastern Europe countries, as they emerge from the darkness of political and economic authoritarianism. The Portuguese experience has demonstrated that peaceful, democratic change and progress are possible.'' U.S. investment in Portugal has doubled to more than $1 billion from 1988 to 1989.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 Condemn Abuses in Albania; Report: State of Emergency Imposed
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 people rallied Thursday in Athens to protest Albania's treatment of ethnic Greeks, and a newspaper reported that the hard-line Communist leadership of Albania imposed a state of emergency on a northern city. The report of unrest in Shkoder, Albania's second largest city, could not be confirmed. An Albanian diplomat in Vienna called the report by the Yugoslav daily Politika an ``absurdity'' that is part of ``an angry smear campaign'' against his country, the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe. Black-robed bishops and Albanian emigres led the Athens rally, which coinciding with the anniversary of the founding of the Communist state in Albania in 1946. ``I am warning the Tirana (Albanian) regime that the policy it has followed up to now will lead to international isolation and certain collapse,'' said Archbishop Serapheim, primate of the Orthodox church in Greece. ``In all of Eastern Europe ... the systems of atheism and suppression of the people are falling,'' Serapheim said. ``Only the Albanian regime remains uncompromising and continues with its vicious policies.'' In Belgrade, the state-run Politika daily said the state of emergency was imposed to quell popular unrest in Shkoder. The Yugoslav report said ``a group of young people tried to organize demonstrations passing leaflets'' late last year in Shkoder, 60 miles northwest of Albania's capital of Tirana. Five people were sentenced to death and executed, it claimed. The Belgrade newspaper did not give the source of its information, say when the state of emergency was introduced or give any other details on the reported order. Albania is closed to most foreigners, and it was impossible to verify the claims in the newspaper report. Albania has resisted the democratic reforms sweeping the rest of the region. It has sharply restricted travel, and its secret police monitor contacts with foreigners. Relations have been strained between Greece and its northern neighbor since 1916, when the province of Northern Epirus was incorporated in Albania. The church claims the Greek minority in Albania makes up about 400,000 of the country's 3 million people. They say the ethnic Greeks are not allowed to move freely, to practice religion and to study Greek in school. Albania contends the Greek minority does not exceed 60,000. The Greek church claimed in December that four ethnic Greek Albanians were tortured and killed last year after failing to escape to Greece. The Greek Foreign Ministry has questioned the validity of an Albanian videotape purporting to show three of the four brothers celebrating the New Year, after the Greek charge d'affaires in Tirana was prohibited from visiting the brothers. Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras drew a protest from Tirana last month when he said Greeks should be free to celebrate Christmas in Albania. An Albanian newspaper, Zeri I Popullit, on Wednesday accused emigres of trying to foment unrest in the isolated Balkan nation, saying they wanted to restore the pre-World War II monarchy.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Tanker Plane Explodes on Ground, Two Escape Unharmed
DOC.TEXT: A military tanker caught fire and exploded on the ground Thursday, and two Guardsmen doing maintenance on board escaped unharmed, authorities said. The Air National Guard KC-135 tanker, used to fuel other aircraft in flight, had been grounded because of fuel storage problems on other KC-135s, Lt. Col. Joseph Riley said. Two of the tankers exploded last year, and a third crashed on takeoff, killing a total of 25 people. The Guard plane was parked near a runway at Pease Air Force Base, which President Bush uses when he travels to his Kennebunkport, Maine, vacation home. Guardsmen were working on one of the plane's many fuel cells _ rubber storage bladders _ when one caught fire about 10:30 a.m., Riley said. He said one of the Guardsmen ran to summon help and the other followed after briefly trying to extinguish the fire, which began toward the back of the plane. Riley said the plane exploded shortly afterward and burned for about a half-hour. Fire trucks surrounded the plane and firefighters continued spraying it with chemicals 90 minutes after the accident. One base firefighter suffered a dislocated shoulder when the plane exploded. Two holes were visible from above, one near the cockpit and the other near the tail. Riley said the plane, which cost about $12 million, was severely damaged and possibly a total loss. Riley said the four-engine plane, which holds 31,000 gallons of fuel, had no fuel on board. He said the cause of the fire and explosion was under investigation. An Air Force KC-135 tanker exploded over Canada on Oct. 4, killing all four crew members. An Alaska National Guard KC-135 exploded and burned Sept. 20 at Eielson Air Force Base, killing two people. On Jan. 31, all 19 people aboard a KC-135 died when it crashed on takeoff from Dyess Air Force Base in Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois House Urges Hearings on Museum Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois House asked state officials not to close a museum exhibit featuring the skeletons of 234 prehistoric American Indians without holding public hearings. Officials of the Dickson Mounds Museum near Lewistown announced last week that the exhibit would close to the public Feb. 1, to avoid offending Indians. ``No one had any idea the decision was coming,'' said state Rep. Tom Homer, sponsored the resolution approved Wednesday by voice vote. ``We never even heard there was any opposition to the exhibit.'' Although the resolution is not binding, Homer said it should influence Gov. James R. Thompson and officials from the State Department of Energy and Natural Resources to reconsider. David Fields, a spokesman for Thompson, said Thompson still concurs with the decision to close the display of excavated bones while leaving open the nearby interpretive center, Fields said. Karen Witter, director of the state energy and natural resources department, which oversees the museum, said Wednesday she still stands by the closure decision. ``We'll have to look into the resolution's details to decide how we'll respond,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Returning Exiles Vow to Help Romania
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Romanian exiles who returned to Britain after bringing food and medical supplies to their homeland pledged Thursday to help Romania consolidate the gains of its revolution. ``It is unbelievable that I am alive to see what has happened. Now I am looking forward to doing whatever little part I can play in making sure Romania is going to be and remain a free and democratic country,'' said former folk dancer George Tecucianu. Asked if he wanted to return to Romania to live, Tecucianu said: ``My heart tells me `yes.''' The exiles spoke after flying food and medicine to Romania on Wednesday and returning here early Thursday. Each of the 100 passengers on the British Island Airways charter brought 55 pounds of food and medical supplies. The flight was organized by a London-based group, the Relief Fund for Romania. Among those on the plane was Prince Paul, 41-year-old nephew of Romania's deposed King Michael. While most passengers returned, the prince stayed in Romania. The prince, who has a British passport, told reporters: ``The (new) Romanian government has promised itself to be a democratic government. It is time to visit as so many people have suffered, and I want to see what I can do to help.'' Among the passengers now living in Britain after fleeing Nicolae Ceausescu's Communist dictatorship was London University physics lecturer George Ross. He told reporters, ``We found out how we could help from London, particularly by offering academic scholarships.'' He said he left Romania in 1963 because of his political views and that it was his first visit home since then. Another passenger was actress Magdalena Buznea. She said she left Romania in 1969 after she was harassed by the Securitate secret police. ``I left because I couldn't stand it any longer,'' she said. She met her brother in Bucharest on Wednesday. ``Everyone in Romania is happy. They are all deliriously happy. They are happy that man (Ceausescu) is not there any more,'' she said. Another passenger was a British father from Essex county in eastern England. He visited an orphanage in Romania in the hopes of finding a child to adopt. Television reports in the West last week showed overcrowded Romanian orphanages and blamed Ceausescu's strictly enforced policies against abortion and birth control. In Playa de Aro, Spain, tourism officials said Thursday they would sponsor Mediterranean holidays for a group of orphans from Timisoara, where the Romanian uprising began last month. Ricardo Lopez, tourism chief of the seaside town near Barcelona, told the Europa Press news agency the children would spend April 17-28 in local hotels and homes ``so they could spend a few nice days after the horrors they lived through.'' In another development, Yugoslav police reported Thursday that 80 Romanians had illegaly crossed the border into neighboring Yugoslavia since the start of the Dec. 15 revolt and 208 had returned since the downfall of Ceausescu's regime. Yugoslav authorities quoted in the Tanjug state news agency denied reports in the Romanian press saying about 60 Romanians who escaped across the border belonged to the secret police. Those forces waged last-ditch battles against revolutionary fighters.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Pop and Rock Performers Claim Key Music Industry Award Nominations
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Don Henley's socially conscious ``The End of Innocence'' album was nominated for four plum Grammy Awards on Thursday and a host of other aging pop music legends grabbed most of the other key nominations. Henley's album earned nominations for album of the year and best male rock performance. The title track was put in competition for record and song of the year. The latter is a songwriting nomination shared with Bruce Hornsby. The 32nd annual Grammy Awards will be presented Feb. 21 and broadcast live on CBS-TV. A scattering of newer faces won prime nominations, but many went to such veterans as Bette Midler, Bonnie Raitt, Tom Petty, Billy Joel and Linda Ronstadt. Even the Rolling Stones got a nomination, for group rock performance on their ``Mixed Emotions'' single. Miss Midler was caught by surprise when her ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' single from the movie ``Beaches'' earned record, song and female pop performance nominations. ``To tell you the truth, I haven't been paying a lot of attention _ I have a lot of things going on, with the baby and everything else,'' Ms. Midler said by telephone from her home here as 3-year-old Sophie cried. The late Roy Orbison was nominated for pop vocal performance for the single ``You Got It,'' and twice with pals Petty, George Harrison, Jeff Lynne and Bob Dylan for their ``Traveling Wilburys'' collaboration. The nomination list for male rock performance typified the aging face of the awards: Henley, Petty, Neil Young, Lou Reed and Joe Cocker. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominations at a news conference with hosts singer Olivia Newton-John and producer Quincy Jones. The announcements experienced delays when a Grammy placard on the podium kept falling off. There were 388 nominees representing 113 record companies. Neneh Cherry, Indigo Girls, Milli Vanilli, Soul II Soul and Tone Loc were nominated as best new artists of 1989. The ``Batman'' movie soundtrack produced seven nominations, including four for rock star Prince. He was listed for producer of the year, male pop vocal performance, male Rhythm & Blues performance for the single ``Batdance,'' and for ``Partyman'' as best song written for a movie. The rock band Fine Young Cannibals, featuring the sensuous vocals of actor Roland Gift, was nominated for best album for ``The Raw & The Cooked'' and for best record and pop group for the single ``She Drives Me Crazy.'' Miss Ronstadt's work drew multiple nominations: song of the year and duo pop performance for ``Don't Know Much,'' and female pop vocal for the album ``Cry Like a Rainstorm-Howl Like the Wind.'' Joel's decades-summing single ``We Didn't Start the Fire'' was tabbed for best record, song and pop male vocalist. Petty was nominated for his ``Full Moon Fever'' album and the single ``Free Fallin''' was given the nod for male rock performance. Miss Raitt was nominated for her album ``Nick of Time'' and for female pop vocalist for the title track and female rock vocal performance for the album. Irish rockers U-2 earned a scattering of nominations, including rock group performance for the LP ``Rattle and Hum,'' and in the same category was picked for the single ``When Love Comes to Town'' with B.B. King. U-2 and lead singer Bono were also nominated for best song written for a motion picture for ``Angel of Harlem,'' from the movie ``Rattle and Hum.'' Mike and The Mechanics were nominated for best record and song for the single ``The Living Years'' as well as pop group performance and short form music video. ``The Living Years'' is a personal story about the singer's relationship with his father. ``I think it's one of those songs that sort of reaches anybody,'' said Mike Rutherford from his cottage in the English countryside. In the rhythm and blues category, best vocal performance nominations went to Janet Jackson, Aretha Franklin, Natalie Cole, Anita Baker and Vanessa Williams. Miss Franklin was also nominated twice in the R&B duo performance category for singles with James Brown and Whitney Houston. Janet Jackson's ``Miss You Much'' also drew a songwriters nomination. Her ``Rhythm Nation'' track from the album of the same name was up for an instrumental arrangment Grammy and for best long-form music video _ pitting her against brother Michael's ``Moonwalker'' video. Bobby Brown, Al Jarreau, Luther Vandross and Smokey Robinson were R&B male vocal nominees. In the country category, nominees included k.d. lang, Emmylou Harris, Rosanne Cash, Dolly Parton, Kathy Mattea, Rodney Crowell, Randy Travis, Clint Black and Lyle Lovett and the late Keith Whitley. Heavy metal was a new category, drawing nominations for the groups Dokken, Queensryche, Metallica, Faith No More and Soundgarden.

DOC.HEAD: Two Years Later, `Irises' is Wilted
DOC.TEXT: The sale of Vincent van Gogh's ``Irises'' for a record $53.9 million two years ago was considered a loud vote of confidence in an art market still under the cloud of Wall Street's Black Monday. But two years later the world's most expensive painting is sitting in a vault, and the ``Irises'' deal is looking wilted. It turns out that Sotheby's lent Australian tycoon Alan Bond $27 million to buy the 1889 painting; that as collateral Bond posted the picture he was going to buy; that Bond has not paid off the loan; that Sotheby's, not Bond, now has the painting; that Bond, reportedly $5 billion in debt, apparently wants to sell the painting, or at least his share of it. And Sotheby's said Thursday it was abandoning the loan policy that produced the whole fiasco and, critics complained, inflated art prices in general.
