In an interview, Michael Ainslie, head of Sotheby's, said buyers will no longer be allowed to use art objects they intend to purchase to secure loans from the auction house. Since a painting is worth what someone is willing to pay for it, and since what someone is willing to pay often depends on how much that someone can borrow, auctioneer's loans have the potential to stoke the art market. An auction house could use such loans to increase bidding and hike prices _ and the value of its own 10 percent commission. If the borrower-bidder defaults, notes Time magazine art critic Robert Hughes, the auctioneer takes back the picture, writes off the loan and resells the work at its new, possibly inflated, price. Since auction houses usually charge several points over the prime lending rate, some critics have described them as a lender of last resort. Christie's, Sotheby's rival, does not lend money to buyers. Ainslie said Sotheby's made such loans rarely and carefully, and that their discontinuation would have no impact on art prices. ``It was merely a financial service to our clients,'' he said. ``But our foremost concern is our credibility, so we're making this change largely to correct the misperception that something was wrong.'' Angelo Aponte, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, agreed: ``I don't think it's going to reduce prices, but Sotheby's had to do it to protect its own credibility. That's the biggest thing an auction house has going for it.'' Ainslie said Sotheby's had extended such loans only six times on objects that sold for more than $1 million. But one was ``Irises,'' whose sale, according to art dealer Richard L. Feigen, ``had a real impact on the art market.'' ``Assume that Bond could not have bid without Sotheby's financing,'' he said. ``Where would the bidding have stopped?'' If it stopped short of $40 million, would anyone have paid $47.9 million for ``Yo Picasso'' last May? Would Walter Annenberg have paid $40.7 million for the same artist's ``Au Lapin Agile'' in November? Ainslie's response: Bond probably would have bought the painting without the Sotheby's loan. At the time of the sale, he was no credit risk. Ainslie's assessment was supported by Thomas Hoving, former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and editor of Connoisseur magazine, who blamed critics and art dealers for the controversy. Dealers, he said, dislike auction houses for luring away their business; critics, he said, were trying to make something of nothing. ``Sotheby's just said, `Let's cut our losses. Who needs this?''' he said. ``It's a peripheral issue.'' And what of ``Irises'' _ the painting? Sotheby's took it back after Bond was forced to extend his loan, but Ainslie wouldn't say where it is ``because of security considerations.'' It is widely thought to be in a vault in Switzerland. And what is ``Irises'' now worth? About what Bond bid for it in 1987, said Ainslie; $30 million to $40 million, according to skeptical dealers. ``We are having discussions with several parties,'' said Michael Cross, a Bond associate. ``We have received a great many approaches, but nothing is conclusive at this stage.''

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Supporters Occupy Lebanese Embassy
With AM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of supporters of Lebanese military leader Gen. Michel Aoun occupied Lebanon's embassy in France on Thursday and threatened to remain there for days. Ambassador Fouad Turk negotiated with the protesters in hopes he could peacefully persuade them to leave. He said there had been no incidents and that he had not asked French police to evict them. The demonstrators occupied the chancellory and prevented embassy staff from entering the building. The protesters said they were opposed to an announcement by Lebanese Prime Minister Salim Hoss to transfer several Lebanese diplomats in the United States and Europe to other posts. Aoun, a Maronite Christian who controls remnants of Lebanon's army, is opposed to Hoss and President Elias Hrawi, whom he views as appointees of Syria. Syria maintains about 40,000 troops in Lebanon support Moslem militias opposed to Aoun.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Troop Withdrawal Plans Coming Soon
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday he intends to bring home within weeks the thousands of U.S. troops sent to Panama to oust former Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and will announce withdrawal plans in the next few days. ``We are going to be moving fairly rapidly to bring the troops home over the course of the next several weeks,'' Cheney said, adding that ``a residual force'' would remain. ``I think we'll go back to the level that was there'' prior to the invasion, he told reporters during a Pentagon briefing. Before the Dec. 20 invasion, about 13,000 U.S. troops were stationed in Panama, and Cheney emphasized that he expects to keep that number in the country. About 7,000 troops were airlifted to Panama on the first day of the operation, with the total number swelling to around 25,000, Pentagon officials have said. In recent weeks, that number has varied as some troops have begun to withdraw and other specialized units were rotated into the country. The secretary he and the top military leadership were ``wrestling with'' ideas in order to produce ``the exact time frame'' for withdrawing the additional forces and that he was hopeful such details could be released ``within the next day or two.'' On Friday, 2,000 paratroopers who took part in Operation Just Cause are scheduled to make a mass parachute drop on their return to Fort Bragg, N.C., homebase of the 82nd Airborne Division. On another issue, Cheney said that he approved the use of the F-117 Stealth jet fighter in the Panamanian operation, but that he objected to initial proposals for extensive use of the super-secret aircraft. ``When the planning was done ... there was more extensive use proposed for the F-117. I questioned specifically why we wanted to use that particular system, and why on those particular targets. They went back to the drawing boards and came back with a scaled-back plan in terms of the number of targets affected,'' Cheney said. Although officials have refused to disclose the exact number of planes used on the mission, they have said that two planes bombed the Rio Hato airfield near some infantry barracks in order to disorient those troops and make the U.S. paratroopers' arrival easier. ``We wanted pinpoint accuracy. We were trying to save lives, stun and disorient the forces at Rio Hato so our own Rangers could go in. We used the 117 and it worked. They dropped with pinpoint accuracy,'' Cheney said. The secretary, asked about his plans for base closures, said that he expected them to be ``extensive,'' but when asked to define the term, he quipped, ``more than two.'' Congress has agreed to the closures of 86 bases, and the secretary was asked whether additional closures were contemplated. ``There will ... be additional base closures. But the exact process in which we will undertake that, I'm not prepared to say,'' Cheney said. The secretary's spokesman, Pete Williams, said later Cheney ``has not signed off on the final list'' of bases, and that he expected ``some base closings'' to be included in the fiscal 1991 budget, due to be sent to Congress later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Boost Winter Wheat Plantings for 1990 Harvest
DOC.TEXT: Farmers planted nearly 57 million acres of winter wheat last fall for harvest in 1990, a 3 percent increase from 1989 and the most in five years, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The increase, however, was much less than the 6 percent to 8 percent that some analysts had been predicting and raised prospects of continued tight U.S. supplies and strong prices. ``This would be the largest wheat area since the 1985 crop'' when plantings totaled 57.8 million acres, said the department's Agricultural Statistics board. A major concern is that despite the increase in plantings last fall, crop conditions have been far from ideal so far this winter. ``Lack of moisture stressed winter wheat in the central and southern Great Plains during December,'' the report said. ``In mid-to-late December, cold weather stressed winter wheat in the southern Great Plains, Delta and Southeast.'' Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the following year. It accounts for about three-fourths of the total U.S. wheat output. Last year's winter wheat production declined because of lingering drought in some major production areas, but total wheat output increased because of a boost in spring-planted areas. Meanwhile, U.S. wheat stockpiles have continued to shrink, thus keeping market prices at high levels. To help replenish dwindling reserves, the department is requiring farmers to idle only 5 percent of their wheat base acres this year, compared with a 10 percent set-aside in 1989 and 27.5 percent previously. In another option intended to boost production, wheat farmers are permitted to plant up to 10 percent more acreage than otherwise would be permitted under the 1990 program. As originally announced last May 31, farmers were to plant no more than 95 percent of their wheat land. But the option announced on Sept. 13 lets them plant up to 105 percent, or 10 percent more than otherwise would be permitted under the basic program. Economist John Schnittker, a Washington-based consultant, said that larger plantings would have provided a better cushion for possible yield losses later in the season. For example, he said, if plantings had been boosted 6 percent to 8 percent as many had expected, that would have helped offset any major impact from reduced yields caused by poor growing conditions. But with only a 3 percent increase in 1990 plantings, that cushion is thinner and ``leaves very little margin for reduced yields,'' Schnittker said in a telephone interview. ``We're at greater risk than expected.'' The report showed that wheat farmers in Kansas, traditionally the biggest producer, kept plantings at last year's level _ 12.4 million acres. Increases were reported in Missouri and Montana, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Washington. But Nebraska farmers reduced winter wheat plantings by 2 percent, and Texas producers cut theirs by 3 percent. In a supply-and-demand analysis, officials said the U.S. total wheat stockpile on June 1, the beginning of the 1990-91 wheat marketing year, could be reduced to 468 million bushels from 702 million last June 1 and 1.26 billion bushels two years ago. However, the new June 1 forecast was up 25 million bushels from indications in December. No projections were included for 1990-91. Export demand has been fed by U.S. price subsidies for a number of countries, including the Soviet Union and China. Even so, total wheat exports in 1989-90 are expected to drop to around 1.275 billion bushels, down from 1.419 billion last season. Domestic requirements are slightly more than 1 billion bushels for 1989-90, the report said. The analysis said average market prices may average in the range of $3.80 to $3.90 per bushel over the 12-month marketing year, five to 10 cents less than the December projection. Wheat prices averaged $3.72 in 1988-89 and $2.57 in 1987-88. Another report showed the Dec. 1 inventory of all U.S. wheat at 1.42 billion bushels, down 17 percent from a year earlier. Farm holdings at 582 million bushels, were down 6 percent from Dec. 1, 1988, while off-farm stocks at 836 million were down 24 percent. The Dec. 1 corn stockpile was estimated at 7.08 billion bushels, virtually the same as a year earlier. Farm inventories were reported at 4.7 billion bushels, up 10 percent, while off-farm holdings dropped 15 percent to 2.38 billion bushels. Soybean stocks were reported at 1.61 billion bushels, up 18 percent from a year earlier. Farm inventories, at 793 million bushels, were up 22 percent, and off-farm stocks rose 14 percent to 817 million. A review of 1989 crop production relatively minor adjustments in USDA's previously announced harvest figures. The 1989 wheat crop was reported at 2.04 billion bushels, up 12 percent from 1988; corn, 7.53 billion bushels, up 53 percent; sorghum, 618 million bushels, up 7 percent; oats, 371 million bushels, up 72 percent; barley, 403 million bushels, up 39 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Cloud of Fear Caused By Misting Machines In Wake Of Legionnaires' Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: Supermarkets around the nation Thursday shut down mist machines designed to keep fruits and vegetables looking fresh after one such device was linked to a Legionnaires' disease outbreak that killed two people. ``We made the decision that if anything can happen because of this type of machine we wouldn't take the chance, we'd discontinue using them,'' said Mickey Clerc, spokesman for the Jacksonville, Fla.-based Winn-Dixie Grocery Chain. Late last year, about 70 people in Bogalusa, a town in southeast Louisiana, developed symptoms of Legionnaire's disease. Thirty cases were confirmed in the laboratory and two of the victims died. Researchers announced Tuesday that they had traced the Legionella bacteria to the one-quart water reservoir of the mist machine at a Winn-Dixie supermarket, said Dr. Louise McFarland, state epidemiologist. ``That doesn't mean grocers and hospitals should shut down their misting machines. All we're asking them to do ... is to contact the manufacturer or us and make sure they are using the machine properly,'' said Gwen Bach-Stewart, a spokeswomen for the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals. Misting vegetables is not the problem, she said. ``You can't get Legionnaires' disease from eating vegetables that have been misted. You have to breath the Legionella bacteria in to contract the disease. In Bogalusa, the bacteria was airborne in a very fine mist that could be inhaled,'' said Bach-Stewart. Hospitals use a variety of humidifiers and respiratory therapy machines which produce a fine spray, said Dr. Thomas Farley, a state epidemiologist. He said precautionary letters were sent to the hospitals. At least four national supermarket chains _ Winn-Dixie, Safeway, A&P and Kroger _ switched off their vegetable-freshening mist machines, however. ``We have never recommended the removal of the machines,'' Farley said. ``The mist machine in this outbreak was a type that has a reservoir in it. That is, a place where water was sitting continuously. The bacteria was found in the reservoir. We feel that was where it was multiplying. ``The other factor was the very fine mist this system produces which allowed it to be breathed by people in the area,'' Farley said. ``There were probably other factors present that we don't know about, but we feel that those two things were part of it. Most of the misters used in stores don't have reservoirs and produce heavier water drops that can't be breathed,'' he said. Winn-Dixie, which operates 1,228 stores in 13 states, began removing the misting machines from the 97 stores that had them in November, when state health officials went to check the devices as a possible source, Clerc said. ``We had the same type of service in all our stores. We're not experts in the area and we saw no reason to take a chance with the health of our employees or customers,'' Clerc said. Clerc said Winn-Dixie in future would spray produce by hand and will not reinstall the machines. Most stores like Safeway, which has 1,200 stores mostly in the western United States and Canada, were turning off the systems and cleaning them, said John J. Hayman Jr., president of KES Irrigation Systems Inc., of Marietta, Ga. Hayman supplies misters to about 7,000 U.S. and Canadian supermarkets. He said his company is the largest of its kind, has been in business five years, employs 25 people and does $4 million worth of business annually. ``They're telling us that they are shutting them down until the public is educated to the difference in a `fogger' like the one in the Louisiana store and a misting system. A misting system, which is what I manufacture, does not use a reservoir. It draws its water directly from the city water system and produces a spray, not a fog,'' Hayman said. Cincinnati-based Kroger, the nation's second-largest chain with more than 1,200 stores in 20 mostly Midwestern and Southern states, said it has stopped using the sprayers in its produce departments. It said most of its stores use automatic spray or mist systems, but its stores in the Cincinnati and Dayton, Ohio, areas use hoses. Montvale, N.J.-based A&P, with 1,250 stores in 26 states and Canada, originally said it would continue using its misters because they didn't have water reservoirs like the one in Bogalusa. A&P spokesman Michael Roarke said Thursday that the company had decided temporarily to shut down its misters, used in about 200 outlets, because of customer concern. In hospitals, concern about Legionnaires' disease prompted precautions in the use of misting systems years ago, officials said. ``We've always been aware of the potential for increased bacteria growth,'' said Frederick A. Kron, an epidemiologist at Baptist Southern Hospital. ``We use only sterile water in any system that produces mist.'' Legionnaires' disease was first identified in 1976 after an outbreak at an American Legion convention in Philadelphia killed 34 people. It is caused by bacteria that often thrive in cool, standing water found in such places as water towers or air conditioning ducts. The germ usually enters the lungs through water droplets.

DOC.HEAD: Blustery, Cold Weather In North-Central States
DOC.TEXT: Strong northwesterly wind blasted across the north-central part of the nation Thursday, dropping temperatures and kicking up blizzard conditions. The wind, associated with an intense low pressure system over Lake Superior, ushered in much colder air with afternoon temperatures 20 to 40 degrees lower than at the same time Wednesday, when temperatures hit record highs. High wind warnings were posted over Iowa, eastern North Dakota, central and eastern South Dakota, and east-central and northeastern Nebraska. A gale warning was issued for Lake Huron. Wind gusted to 75 mph at Yankton, S.D.; 72 mph at Fort Dodge, Iowa; 63 mph at Ord, Neb.; 62 mph at Rice Lake, Wis.; 58 mph at O'Neill, Neb.; and 54 mph at Grand Rapids, Mich., and Moline, Ill., the National Weather Service said. Snow and blowing snow was prevalent in the upper Mississippi Valley and the upper Great Lakes region, and blizzard conditions were reported in northwestern Minnesota during the morning. Blowing dust sharply reduced visibility over parts of eastern North Dakota, eastern South Dakota, western Minnesota and northern Iowa. Elsewhere, rain and snow showers were reported from the upper Ohio Valley to western New England. In the West, a warm front produced showers over the northern Pacific Coast. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 5 degrees at Caribou, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Friction Arises Over Secrecy Issues
DOC.TEXT: A Justice Department team overseeing the safety of classified documents for the trial of Manuel Noriega has warned attorneys they may have to pass a security check and cautioned them about disclosing classified documents. Pressure to maintain secrecy in the case prompted a closed-door meeting Thursday of he judge, an angry defense attorney and the security team. The indictment issued in February 1988 accused Noriega of protecting cocaine shipments heading north and coca processing chemicals and drug money headed south. Classified documents figure in the case because the deposed Panamanian dictator assisted the CIA from the 1970s until 1985. ``It is pretty odd that they're both (prosecutors and security team) from the Department of Justice and yet these people (security team) claim that they're neutral,'' said Steven Kreisberg, who represents co-defendant William Saldarriaga, an accused Colombian cocaine trafficker. ``When they all work in the same department, I question that.'' A February 1988 indictment charges Noriega with taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombian cocaine dealers to turn his nation into a way station for smugglers. Michael O'Kane, attorney for codefendant Daniel Miranda, who is accused of flying drug money from Florida to Panama, said U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen was misapplying security guidelines and contended he was threatened in the name of security. Lehtinen spokeswoman Diane Cossin responded: ``Defense counsel should abide by ethical standards and not try this case in the news media or comment on any discussions with the U.S. attorney's office.'' O'Kane asked the government in a motion Monday to examine intelligence information collected at a U.S. military telecommunications listening post dubbed ``The Tunnel'' in Panama City. He attached a map copied from the Panama City telephone book to specify its location, and that raised security concerns. After the filing, O'Kane said he was contacted by a member of the security team and then by a prosecutor in Lehtinen's office ``who tells me they are very upset in Washington with what I've been filing and if I don't get on board it will be bad for my client and bad for me personally.'' O'Kane met Thursday with U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler and Justice Department officials to discuss security issues, and the judge laughed when O'Kane explained the source of the map. Another security provision ``is that no classified information be discussed even over the telephone because of the danger of interception of these transmissions, by the Russians or whoever,'' said Kreisberg. In cases with more than one defendant, attorneys normally share copies of pleadings, but that procedure may be restricted in this case, he said. ``I would hate to think there's things going on with other defendants that I don't know about,'' Kreisberg said. Noriega's arrival in Miami on Jan. 4 to face the drug indictment has fueled speculation that co-defendants may pursue plea bargains to avoid sitting through a barrage of allegations aimed largely at Noriega. ``There's always discussion, you know, but what the government has offered in my view is nothing,'' said Kreisberg, whose client faces two counts in the 12-count indictment. ``They offered, `If you plead guilty to one count, they'll dismiss the other counts.' I'm not really interested because my client's not guilty.'' Samuel Burstyn, who represents former Noriega intelligence chief Luis del Cid, said, ``The thought of going to trial in a joint trial with Mr. Noriega with the prospects of that being a real dog-and-pony show are not very appealing to us, so to a certain extent we are motivated to forego a lengthy and difficult trial.'' Del Cid faces up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted of racketeering and drug trafficking charges. Burstyn called discussions of a possible plea ``very preliminary.'' Burstyn and Kreisberg are seeking separate trials for their clients, but no timetable for a decision has been set.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Blocks Special Elections
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Thursday blocked a plan for nonpartisan special elections of state district judges, despite a finding that the regularly scheduled elections discriminate against minority voters. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the Legislature deserves more time to consider changes in the current, countywide, at-large election system. Last year, U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland ruled that the at-large system diluted the strength of black and Hispanic voters and violated the U.S. Voting Rights Act. The lawsuit was filed in 1988 by the League of United Latin American Citizens and other minority groups.Jose Garcia de Lara, LULAC's national president, said he didn't believe the Legislature or the governor could solve the problem in a special session. ``We've been waiting a hundred years for this and we're at the point where we want the changes done immediately,'' de Lara said, but added, ``We are very optimistic. This is not a point of despair or devastation (but) we feel we have taken a couple of steps backward on the issue.'' Following the appeals court decision, state officials said they will prepare for regular at-large elections of 115 state district judges in nine counties. ``This (decision) gives the people and their elected representatives an opportunity for a full and thorough debate on how judges should be selected,'' said Chief Justice Tom Phillips of the Texas Supreme Court. ``I hope the Legislature will move quickly in the next special session to give the people an opportunity to implement a system which is fair to all Texans,'' Phillips added. Gov. Bill Clements has called the Legislature into a special session Feb. 27 to consider judicial selection and public school finance. The appeals court stopped special, nonpartisan elections in May that had been ordered by Bunton for nine of the state's largest counties: Bexar, Dallas, Tarrant, Harris, Travis, Midland, Ector, Lubbock and Jefferson. A few hours after the 5th Circuit Court ruled Thursday, Bunton issued an apparently contradictory order rescheduling the nonpartisan special elections for November. Bunton said he believed the appeals court did not have jurisdiction in the case until he himself had ruled on a previous motion by the state. However, state officials said they believed the appeals court decision outweighed Bunton's latest order and the state would proceed with the regular March 13 primary elections. ``Since the 5th Circuit Court has ruled, I would think that would be the prevailing order at this time,'' said Steve Hall, spokesman for Attorney General Jim Mattox. ``The elections are going to take place, the primaries, as originally scheduled. The district judges in those nine counties will be running in the primaries as they normally would have,'' said Secretary of State George Bayoud. Praising the appeals court judges, Clements said, ``I applaud the decision of the 5th Circuit not to allow the wholesale disruption of our judiciary.'' In a two-page opinion, the appeals court said that overhauling the Texas judicial system is a job for the Legislature. ``That holding (by Bunton), if sustained on appeal, will require an organic and wholesale review and reconstitution of the Texas judicial election system, a task which should be addressed and carried out by the state's elected representatives, rather than by the federal courts,'' the ruling said. ``Only if it becomes apparent that the state is unwilling to act with measured and appropriate speed in this regard should the courts intervene.'' The appeals judges went on to say that the Legislature, thus far, hasn't been given ``a reasonable period within which to address the problem presented.''

DOC.HEAD: Berkeley Programmer Says Worm Hid Itself From Victims
DOC.TEXT: The ``worm'' program that paralyzed a nationwide computer network in November 1988 was designed so its victims wouldn't know how they were being attacked, a computer expert testified Thursday. Robert T. Morris' rogue program used several methods to worm its way into the Internet network, said Keith Bostic, a program analyst at the University of California at Berkeley. ``It was designed to break into as many computer systems as quickly as possible and escape detection as it was doing so,'' Bostic said on the second day of testimony in Morris' computer tampering trial in U.S. District Court. Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., is charged under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act with ``hacking'' into a federal computer network. If convicted, he faces as many as five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Prosecutors allege he devised and unleashed a program that replicated wildly, immobilizing an estimated 6,000 computers linked to Internet, including those at NASA and several Air Force installations and universities. Defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni has said that Morris created the worm as a computer security experiment, but that he made a programming mistake that let the worm go berserk. Guidoboni said during opening statements that once Morris learned of the problems his program was causing, he tried to stop it, and when that failed, he tried to alert network users. But Bostic testified that no one in Berkeley's computer science research group received any warning about the worm from Morris. Four top computer programmers worked 16 hours to crack the worm's defenses, he said. According to Bostic, the worm entered the school's computer system by using two defects in the software used by the system and by solving passwords, either through a list built into the worm or by checking possible guesses against the computer's own internal dictionary. The worm also took advantage of the computers' ``trust'' for one another on the same system, a process by which a second computer will allow access to the system after seeing that an account already has been authorized by another computer on that system, Bostic said. The rogue program hid itself in four ways, he told jurors. It traveled via binary code, rather than a more easily read source code, and those parts of the program that could be read by a literate user were encrypted to further mask what the worm was doing, Bostic said. Morris' program also was set up so that it provided phony identification names when Berkeley's scientists were trying to trace it. The worm created more deception by periodically changing the program identification number attached to it by the Berkeley computer system, he testified. Bostic said the ``quick and powerful attack'' by the worm left no computer on the university system untouched. ``It would break into as many machines as it could, even machines it could not run on. It was completely indiscriminate,'' Bostic said.

DOC.HEAD: Latin America's First Reactor Resumes Service After 17 Months
DOC.TEXT: Atucha 1, Latin America's first nuclear reactor, was resumed operations this week after 17 months of repairs, the president of the National Atomic Energy Commission said Thursday. ``This is a great triumph for us,'' Manuel Mondino said in a telephone interview. ``We worked very hard on this. The task was unprecedented.'' In August 1988, a fuel rod in the 340-megawatt reactor ruptured, shutting down the plant in Zarate, 60 miles northwest of this capital. Mondino said scientists at first didn't know how to fix Atucha because they had to remove one damaged tube and check 252 others in a reactor that was not designed to be opened. Technicians explored the tubes with miniature TV cameras and used robotic arms to remove the damaged tube along with bits of metal before the reactor, which began producing electricity in 1974, could become operational. The reactor uses natural uranium, which Argentina has in abundance, and heavy water; most reactors use enriched uranium and boiling water. Also, its 5-yard fuel rods are longer than those used elsewhere. Mondino, appointed by President Carlos Menem last July, said he is convinced that ``what damaged the channel won't happen again.'' Nevertheless, he said the reactor will operate at 50 percent capacity for several months. The plant is part of a national energy grid that includes hydroelectric dams, coal- and oil-fired power plants and the Embalse nuclear plant.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Critical Of Formation Of New Security Force
DOC.TEXT: A decision by the East German Communist Party to set up a new internal security force drew a stiff rebuke Thursday from the State Department. ``Non-Communist political groups struggling to organize for the promised free elections May 6 are understandably concerned that such a force could be used for political intimidation,'' the department said in a statement. In the past, the hated secret police, popularly known as ``Stasi,'' used repressive measures to help ensure 40 years of Communist control. East German government officials say about 26,000 of the 85,000 state security employees have been taken off the payroll. But opposition groups want guarantees the force will be disarmed and assurances former agents will not have a part in a new agency. In a speech to the national parliamen, Prime Minister Hans Modrow, who has U.S. support, said ``the aim is not to maintain the old structure'' of state security. But, he said, ``there cannot be a security vacuum.'' Modrow cited violence by neo-Nazi groups as well as ``terrorism, drugs and ecological crime.'' Still, the State Department was sharply critical of the development. It said the East German Communist Party was struggling to prove its credibility with the East German people. ``Re-establishing a police force such as the one which existed in the past could only put that credbility into further doubt,'' the statement said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III went to Potsdam last month to meet with Modrow and, separately, with a group of Lutheran ministers, several of whom had opposed the old regime. He signaled his support for Modrow, who is considered by the State Department a reliable force for moderation in East Germany. At the same time, though, U.S. officials are concerned about indications a mood of retribution is prevalent among East Germans who felt the sting of the ousted regime. Political divisions and shortages of food and fuel also contribute to unease within the Bush administration about Modrow's chances of maintaining control until the promised elections in May. An independent trade union movement threatened on Thursday to call a nationwide strike Jan. 25 over the security force issue.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Handed Up Against Shawcross for Ninth Victim
DOC.TEXT: Accused serial killer Arthur J. Shawcross was charged Thursday with a ninth murder in a string of slayings of prostitutes and other young women in and around Rochester. A Wayne County grand jury charged Shawcross with murder in the death of 29-year-old Elizabeth A. Gibson of Rochester. The body of Gibson, described by authorities as a prostitute, was found Nov. 27 in a wooded area in Wayne County, just east of Rochester where most of the killings took place. Shawcross, paroled in 1987 after serving 15 years in prison for the murder of an 8-year-old girl, was charged last week with slaying eight other women over the past two years in Monroe County, the county in which Rochester is located. A Monroe grand jury is to consider evidence in two other slayings next week. Shawcross was bought in manacles to the Lyons courthouse from Rochester for the arraignment in the Wayne County case. He answered ``Yes, sir,'' in a low voice when Judge Carmen Parenti asked if he needed a lawyer appointed for him. Public Defender Ronald Valentine did not enter a plea for Shawcross, but Parenti entered a plea of innocent on his behalf. Parenti granted a prosecution request to deny bail to Shawcross, and returned him to custody in Rochester, where he is being held without bail on the Monroe County charges. ``I do feel there is a high risk that the defendant would flee this jurisdiction,'' Parenti said. If convicted of the second-degree murder charge, Shawcross faces a minimum sentence of 15 years to life in prison. The 44-year-old parolee was arrested Jan. 4 after state police spotted him lingering near the frozen body of one of his alleged victims. Shawcross reportedly confessed to killing 11 women and told police where to find two bodies. He served 15 years in prison after admitting in 1972 that he raped and strangled of 8-year-old Karen Ann Hill in Watertown. He also allegedly told police of a second killing, of a 10-year-old boy.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Iraq Applaud Soviet Mediation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th pvs `We welcome' to UPDATE with State Department comment. Picks up 8th, `Thursday's welcome...'
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet proposal to mediate stalled peace talks between Iran and Iraq made headway Thursday when officials of the two nations expressed support for Moscow's offer. A senior Iranian Foreign Ministry official said Iran will look positively at the Soviet proposal, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Deputy Foreign Minister Mahmoud Vaezi returned to Tehran late Wednesday after talks in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, the news agency said. In Moscow, a Soviet official said Wednesday that Tehran had agreed to restart the talks with Soviet mediation. The chief of the United Nations had been leading the talks. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry in Baghdad also issued a statement Thursday welcoming the Soviet role. ``The Soviet Union proposed such a meeting last year, and Iraq informed Moscow it approved the meeting last August,'' said the statement, carried by the Iraqi news agency monitored in Nicosia. ``We welcome such a meeting if it will be comprehensive in order to achieve it aims,'' it said. In Washington, the State Department stressed that the Soviet proposal was meant ``to supplement the efforts of the U.N. Secretary General ... not to supplant them.'' Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler also urged both Iran and Iraq to immediately exchange the 100,000 prisoners they are holding from the war years. Thursday's statements came a day after Kamal Kharrazi, the Iranian ambassador to the United Nations, rejected a new Iraqi proposal to revive the talks. The Iranian said negotiations could continue only on the basis of an earlier peace plan, Tehran radio reported. Kharrazi said Baghdad's ``proposal is nothing new and does not change anything. ... It is another stage of Iraqi obstructionism in the peace process.'' He added that ``if Iraq does not have any ill intentions in introducing this proposal, it should accept the U.N. resolution and take positive steps in its implementation.'' The eight-year Iran-Iraq war halted on Aug. 20, 1988, after Tehran accepted U.N. resolution 598. The document calls for troop withdrawal to prewar borders, exchange of prisoners and negotiations towards a lasting peace. But the negotiations, which started five days after the cease-fire, have stalled. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq last month proposed new direct talks to revive the talks, exchange of prisoners, opening of air links and exchange of visits by Iranians and Iraqis. Tehran, which opposes direct talks, called the proposal a ``deception'' and said it fell short by failing to call for a troop withdrawal. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Wednesday that Iran had agreed to restart the talks, but that Moscow _ rather than the U.N. secretary-general _ would mediate. In Moscow, Gerasimov said Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran sent a message to Moscow saying Tehran was willing to resume the talks with Soviet mediation. The Iranian news agency said Thursday that Velayati's message stressed that Iran would consider any Soviet proposal ``containing a systematic and clearly defined formula for the implementation of U.N. resolution 598.'' Gerasimov said Baghdad already had agreed to talks with Soviet mediation.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Bomber Reportedly Believed to Be Elderly White Man
DOC.TEXT: The mail bomber responsible for the deaths of a federal judge and civil rights attorney may have been an elderly white man who is religious or has legal experience, according to a reported FBI profile. Nancy Conn, a victims' rights advocate in Alabama, quoted unidentified FBI agents as saying they believe the bombing suspect is old because he used 3-cent stamps that are no longer sold as postage on packages, the Birmingham Post-Herald reported Thursday. According to the report, the bomber also used an old-fashioned method to wrap the mail-bomb packages _ brown butcher's paper and baker's string. ``The agent said they believed he must have had those stamps for a long time,'' said Mrs. Conn, who works in the Alabama attorney general's Office of Victim's Assistance. U.S. Postal Service officials said Thrsday a 3-cent stamp issued in 1986 is still being sold and was widely used in 1988 as a supplemental stamp when first-class letters went from 22 cents to 25 cents. But an older 3-cent stamp reportedly used by the bomber was the going rate for first-class letters during two periods, 1917-1919 and 1932-1958, before those 3-cent issues ceased being sold, said postal service spokesman Art Shealy of Washington, D.C. The Birmingham Post-Herald said FBI sources confirmed a profile of the bomber. However, FBI spokesman Tom Moore refused Thursday to confirm that the profile was that described by Mrs. Conn. Moore refused to confirm Mrs. Conn's account of her interview with the FBI. ``We didn't say what kind of stamps were on the packages,'' Moore said. The FBI interviewed Mrs. Conn because they believe the bomber could be a victim of a crime committed by a black or is close to someone who is a victim. ``This person is angry at the justice system and we deal with a lot of victims who are angry,'' Mrs. Conn said. ``Some are radical racists. I've heard people make very bad, slanderous remarks.'' The bomber used the word ``shall'' several times in his letter and other stilted terminology, leading investigators to believe he is religious or has knowledge of legal terms, Mrs. Conn said. ``Shall'' is used frequently in scripture and legal books. Mrs. Conn gave the FBI the name of a crime victim who has called her office and complained about what he says is a justice system that discriminates against whites. That man is white and the person who committed the crime against him is black, she said. It was not known if the FBI has interviewed the man. Miriam Shehane, who started the group VOCAL (Victims of Crime and Leniency) with Mrs. Conn, was also interviewed by the FBI. She could not be reached for comment. U.S. District Judge Robert Vance, who served on the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, was killed Dec. 16 when a mail bomb exploded at his home in Mountain Brook, a Birmingham suburb. Two days later, civil rights attorney Robert Robinson, a black alderman in Savannah, Ga., was killed after a similiar package blew up in his face. Other mail bombs were safely removed from the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. FBI agents from Washington, D.C., have joined investigators from Birmingham, Atlanta and Jacksonville on the case. ``We are making steady progress,'' said Moore. In a letter to an Atlanta television station, a group called ``Americans For a Competent Federal Judicial System'' claimed responsibility for the bombings. The letter said the group was seeking vengeance for court decisions in favor of school desegregation and the 1988 rape and murder of Julie Love, a native of Mountain Brook, who was white. Two black men in Atlanta were charged in the crime.

DOC.HEAD: Sims Described as `Cold Blooded Killer' and `Victim'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with afternoon testimony.
DOC.TEXT: A woman implicated in the deaths of her two baby daughters three years apart is a ``cold-blooded murderer'' who concocted a ``fairy tale'' about how both infants were abducted, a prosecutor said Thursday. But the defense attorney for Paula Marie Sims, 30, of Alton in southern Illinois, called his client an innocent victim of a ``terrible tragedy.'' Mrs. Sims is charged with two counts of first-degree murder in the death of 6-week-old daughter Heather Lee, whose body was found in a trash barrel in May. If convicted she faces the death penalty. She also faces trial later in Jersey County on charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in the death of another daughter, Loralei Marie, in June 1986. No one has been charged with slaying Loralei. In his opening statement, Assistant Madison County State's Attorney Donald Weber said the infants' deaths were not coincidental. He scoffed at statements made by Mrs. Sims and her husband, Robert, to police that in both cases a masked gunman had entered their home and kidnapped their child. Sims, 37, was at work on both occasions and has not been charged in either death. He has custody of the couple's young son, Randy. Mrs. Sims ``told police a fairy tale about a roving Rumplestiltskin who showed up on her door step and snatched her baby,'' Weber said. ``The truth is that Paula and Robert Sims just don't like little girls,'' he added. ``Their impossible and preposterous story can lead to only one conclusion _ the baby's caretaker, their mother, is a ruthless and cold-blooded murderer.'' Defense attorney Donald Groshong countered that there ``is absolutely no evidence'' to link Mrs. Sims to Heather Lee's murder and that the real killer is still at large. He said his client was not smart enough to plan the crime and leave no evidence. ``Paula Sims did not kill those children,'' Groshong told the jury. ``It's a terrible tragedy what happened to those two children. Paula Sims is a victim, too. ``The evidence will show that Paula Sims is a good mother,'' he said. After opening statements, Jeff Reed of Florissant, Mo., testified that he discussed children with Mrs. Sims when they worked together at a grocery store in 1983. ``She said, `God no, I don't want to have children. Especially not a little girl. They are too much trouble,''' Reed said. ``I thought it was kind of strange.'' Another witness, Julie Fry of Jerseyville, said she shared a hospital room with Mrs. Sims in 1986 when Loralei was born. ``She woke me up because she was crying,'' Mrs. Fry testified. ``She was on the phone and she said `I'm sorry we had a little girl.' I thought she was talking to her husband. She said she wanted a boy _ that they wanted a boy.'' Mrs. Sims faces two counts of first-degree murder _ to allow prosecutors to propose different theories in Heather's death _ as well as two counts of obstructing justice by lying to police and one count of concealing the homicide.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Astronauts Prepare For Satellite Rendezvous and Rescue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Three more ..., with 2 grafs to CORRECT number of maneuvers planned to eight, sted three; UPDATE with flight director's comments.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1,3
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia gained on its quarry Thursday in its orbital pursuit of an 11-ton satellite that the astronauts hope to capture and save from burning up in the atmosphere. Commander Dan Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee fired the shuttle's orbital engines three times Thursday to put the shuttle on a near-collision course with the satellite they have been catching up with since liftoff Tuesday. As the astronauts ended their workday Thursday afternoon, Columbia was 218 miles from its target and closing at a speed of about 24 miles per 91-minute orbit. ``Tomorrow's a big day, so get a good night's sleep tonight,'' said Jim Voss, the shuttle communicator at Mission Control. ``We had an excellent day and we're looking forward to tomorrow,'' replied mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar. When the shuttle was launched, it entered orbit 1,725 miles behind its quarry, but it has flown in a lower orbit than LDEF so it could circle the Earth faster and catch up with the satellite. Eight more maneuvers were planned for early Friday before Brandenstein would assume manual control of the shuttle for the final approach to the Long Duration Exposure Facility, which is the size of a small school bus. ``The orbiter continues to perform very well, orbiter and crew,'' flight director Bill Reeves said during a press briefing late Thursday afternoon. ``Everything is go for the rendezvous tomorrow.'' Flight director Al Pennington said Thursday that when the shuttle is about 400 feet away from LDEF, the crew ``will get a good look at the sides of it. At that point in time, he (Brandestein) will have a good visual image of what he's going in for.'' Once within range of the target, the plan was for the shuttle to fly in formation 35 feet from LDEF while Dunbar uses the orbiter's 50-foot robot arm to reach out and grab the satellite, expected at 9:48 a.m. EST Friday. After snaring the satellite, she will turn the arm slowly for four hours so LDEF can be photographed before it is tucked into the shuttle's cargo bay for the trip home. Mission specialist Marsha Ivins was in charge of the photography. The satellite has been in orbit for nearly six years, but it is being slowed by atmospheric drag and tugged down by Earth's gravity. If the astronauts don't retrieve it, it is expected to plunge to Earth on March 9 and burn up in the atmosphere. Scientists hope LDEF is returned intact so they can see what has happened to its experiments after the long exposure to space. Early Thursday, Brandenstein and mission specialist David Low interrupted their flight plans for about three hours to mop up about two gallons of water that leaked from a faulty dehumidifier. The spill was shown on television as a slow bubbling of water beads floating in the air. When Brandenstein looked at all the equipment that had to be moved to get at the water, he remarked: ``It's kind of a mess right now. I'll get the plumber of the year award, but not the housekeeper of the year award.'' Mission Control awakened the five astronauts Thursday with its own version of the ``Banana Boat Song.'' The name of astronaut Low was substituted for the words ``Day-O,'' and it included such phrases as, ``Come all you astronauts sleeping in the cabin, daylight comes and its time to get up.'' Mission Control said the words were written by members of the team that trained Low for a space walk in case of an emergency on this flight. To pass the time during these training sessions, he often hummed the melody. ``Good morning, Houston, man. We be up,'' Low replied in a calypso beat. In addition, controllers reported Thursday that the $85 million Navy communications satellite launched by the astronauts Wednesday was functioning well. Columbia's 10-day mission is the second-longest in the 33 shuttle flights, is a stepping stone toward longer shuttle missions and to months-long trips aboard space station Freedom starting in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Praises Baker, But Israel Considers Other Options
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 5th graf, `Israel has ... Israel seeks U.S. clarifications. Picks up 6th, `The delay ...; 7 grafs SUB for grafs 12-15, UPDATING with Rabin goes to U.S., Labor threatens to quit coalition. Picks up 16th, `In the ...
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, seeking to ease friction over stalled peace efforts, on Thursday urged U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to keep trying to arrange Israeli-Palestinian talks. But the Israeli daily Haaretz reported Shamir and Foreign Minister Moshe Arens were studying alternatives to the U.S.-supported plan for Israeli-Palestinian talks in Egypt. Haaretz said the two leaders were looking into resuming efforts toward a direct dialogue with Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip without help from Egypt. Egypt openly consults with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. Egypt offered to help arrange preliminary Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo after Israel's earlier efforts at a direct dialogue failed. Israel has hesitated to accept the U.S.-backed plan unless it has firm assurances from Baker about the composition of the Palestinian delegation and the agenda. Shamir's top aide Yossi Ben-Aharon told Israel Television that Israel would seek further clarifications after receiving a draft letter of assurances from Baker. ``There is still a difference between what we see as a proper response and what the Americans gave us,'' TV quoted Ben-Aharon as saying. The delay has led to warnings this week from Baker and other officials that the United States may abandon its Middle East efforts. Shamir told visiting U.S. congressmen that Israel hoped Baker would persevere. ``Facing us is a difficult and complicated process and, in order to advance it, we need a lot of patience,'' Shamir said, according to his office. The prime minister also said ``we rely on the efforts of the United States'' for success in the Israeli peace initiative. Israel's plan calls for elections in the occupied lands to select Palestinians for negotiations on limited autonomy with Israel. The Foreign Ministry said Arens spoke with Baker by telephone Wednesday and that they discussed ``ways of advancing the peace process.'' Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin left Thursday for the United States, where he is to meet next week with Baker. Also Thursday, Finance Minister Shimon Peres, head of the center-left Labor Party, criticized Shamir for delays in accepting the U.S.-backed initiative. ``We can start peace talks,'' Peres told a forum of manufacturers. ``We, in my opinion, are unnecessarily delaying a decision.'' In a separate speech, Peres warned his party will leave Israel's coalition government ``if it will be decided to go against the peace process or if there will be no peace process.'' The Labor Party favors striking a compromise with Baker over two issues that have held up Israeli acceptance of his plan. But Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, wants U.S. assurances that Palestinians who live outside the occupied territories will be excluded. Likud holds that involving outsiders is tantamount to negotiating with the PLO. Shamir also wants the Americans to limit the discussion in Cairo to Israel's election plan. In the occupied territories, Israeli soldiers shot and wounded 14 Palestinians during stone-throwing clashes Thursday, Arab hospital officials reported. The army confirmed one wounded. In Hebron, masked Palestinian activists stabbed and injured Jamila Ramadan, a 32-year-old principal of a girls' school. Arab reporters and Israel radio said she was suspected of assisting Israeli authorities and committing ``moral offenses.'' Palestinians have killed at least 168 of their Arab brethren as suspected collaborators with Israel during the 25-month-old uprising against Israeli rule. Since the uprising began, 646 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire in the uprising, and 43 Israelis have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Wall Guard Dogs Will Be Donated To West Germany
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: German shepherds that used to guard the Berlin Wall will be put up for adoption in West Germany, the national Animal Protection Union said Thursday. The organization said East German authorities have promised to reveal the 150 locations where the dogs are held this weekend, and will start turning them over free of charge to West German animal protection societies at the end of January. The West German union said the accord was reached in talks with East German defense ministry and trade officials in East Berlin on Thursday. The union said it had offered to find ``responsible'' West Germans owners for any of the so-called ``wall dogs'' that fail to find homes in East Germany. The objective was to ensure the dogs are not ``put to sleep or acquired by souvenir hunters as a live memento of the wall,'' a union statement said. The organization did not say how many ``wall dogs'' there are. The wall was heavily guarded until Communist authorities opened East Germany's western border on Nov. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Stuart Family Lawyer Says Only Matthew and Michael Knew Until Recently
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 15th, `A grand ..., to ADD lawyer's comments on moral dilemma; picks up 16th graf: `Matthew's attorney ...; SUBS 24th graf, `As investigators ..., with 4 grafs to UPDATE with statement from fur store co-worker. Picks up 25th graf, `One emerging...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX12
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart tried to draw two brothers into his plot to kill his pregnant wife, but other family members did not know of Stuart's involvement until days before he committed suicide, an attorney said Thursday. Family attorney Richard Clayman revealed that Michael Stuart had been approached by Charles ``weeks before'' the Oct. 23 crime, but did not realize the significance of the overture and refused to get involved in ``any crazy thing.'' Three days after the shooting, another brother, Matthew, who disposed of a pistol suspected to be the murder weapon and other evidence, told Michael of Charles' role in the crime. The brothers did not share their knowledge with the rest of the family until shortly before Charles Stuart's Jan. 4 suicide. Charles Stuart told police after the shooting that he and his wife, Carol, 30, were attacked by a mugger as they left a birthing class at a city hospital. Stuart was seriously wounded but recovered. Their son, born premature by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Charles Stuart, 30, became a suspect in the case Jan. 3 when Matthew implicated him in his wife's killing. He jumped off a bridge into Boston Harbor before police could arrest him. Clayman held a news conference Thursday and was joined by Michael and a third brother, Mark Stuart, and their two sisters, Shelley Yandoli and Neysa Porter. Matthew Stuart did not attend. None of the siblings made any comment during the session. ``The appearance that has evolved in my judgment is that some type of conspiratorial scenario existed by and between all of these family members sitting around talking about keeping something hidden. That is not true,'' said Clayman, who represents Michael Stuart but spoke on behalf of the family. Clayman was asked if Charles Stuart ever asked Michael for assistance in killing his wife. ``There may have been an early, disjointed, vague conversation by and between Charles Stuart and my client, Michael Stuart, weeks before Oct. 23 ... which at that time had no significance to Mike,'' Clayman said. ``In retrospect, after examining all the data there, an argument can be made ... that it had some significance,'' he said. Clayman, who declined to elaborate on the discussion, said Michael Stuart's response was, ``a definitive `I don't know exactly what you're talking about, but I'm not getting involved in any crazy thing you're talking about.''' Of the other family members, he said: ``They knew nothing, they did nothing, they saw nothing, they touched nothing.'' Clayman said Matthew had told Michael of Charles' involvement within three days of the crime. He said his client would tell the grand jury anything it wants to know. ``I am comfortable that there is no violation of law ... that his hands are legally clean.'' A grand jury is to convene Friday and hear testimony on the case. Asked about the moral dilemma Michael Stuart faced, Clayman told reporters they had all the relevant facts to ``come to a moral judgment yourself.'' Matthew's attorney, John Perenyi, was in conference and not available for comment, his office said Thursday afternoon. Clayman also said the Stuart family wanted people to know ``they loved Carol Stuart'' and that their family and her parents, Eveylyn and Giusto DiMaiti, had suffered greatly. ``The agony they have experienced over the last week ... has been horrible,'' he said. According to Matthew Stuart's attorney, Matthew met Charles at the crime scene and retrieved Mrs. Stuart's handbag, which contained personal items and a gun. Matthew Stuart, who has said he did not realize any shooting had occurred when he took the items, told his lawyer he had shared his suspicions about his brother with family and friends. Matthew Stuart said he threw the handbag and gun into the the Pines River in suburban Revere. Police divers recovered the handbag and a snub-nosed .38-caliber revolver believed used in the killing. Divers searched the Pines River again Thursday for further clues. The search continues for a gold watch and a ruby ring _ among items that Stuart reportedly said were stolen when he and his wife were shot. Prosecutors have refused to say whether anyone might be charged in the crime, saying the investigation is continuing. As investigators search for a motive, they have dismissed reports that drug use was involved. And interest in Stuart's connection with a 22-year-old woman who worked at a Boston fur store with him has diminished. In a statement released by her attorney Thursday, the woman said: ``I was never romantically involved with Charles Stuart.'' She said she knew him as a friend and ``felt nothing but sympathy for Mr. Stuart'' after his wife's death. She said Stuart had asked her to call and visit him in the hospital. ``I told him that I felt it was inappropriate for me to visit because this was a time for family, but I agreed to telephone him,'' she said. One emerging theory is that Stuart wanted to leave the fur store, where he was a manager, and open his own restaurant, but he felt his wife and a baby would be a hindrance. Mrs. Stuart, an attorney, reportedly knew of the restaurant plans, and literature on starting a restaurant was found in the couple's Reading home. Authorities have investigated whether Stuart might have plotted the killing to collect on insurance policies on his wife. He received $82,000 from one policy due his wife from her job as a tax attorney. He had taken out at least one other policy on her, for $100,000, that was being processed when he committed suicide.

DOC.HEAD: 19 Rescued from Cargo Ship in Mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: A British tanker rescued all 19 people from a Bermuda cargo ship drifting in heavy seas and high winds Thursday in the mid-Atlantic, the Royal Air Force said. The 7,000-ton Irving Forest, carrying wood pulp in containers on its deck, sent out a Mayday signal when it developed ballast problems, began to list heavily and lost engine power, the RAF and Falmouth Coast Guard said. An RAF Nimrod jet from Kinloss, Scotland, and a U.S. Air Force Orion stationed in the Azores Islands responded to the call for assistance, an RAF spokesman said. The Nimrod dropped dinghies at the scene, 300 miles north of the Azores and 1,000 miles southwest of England. The tanker Nestor, bound for New York, approached to try to take the 18 men and one woman crew on board. The Nestor picked up two men and the woman, but it was about two hours before the remainder were found and taken aboard, the Coast Guard said. ``We were concerned for some time that the other crew members might be in the water. There was some doubt about whether they had made it into the rafts,'' said Peter Baker of the Falmouth Coast Guard in southwest England. The Nestor had all the crew _ Britons, Filipinos and Canadians _ safely aboard and was headed for New York, the RAF spokesman said. The Irving Forest, registered in Bermuda and owned by Kent Lines Ltd., based at Hamilton, Bermuda, was left adrift.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Charged With Racketeering Violations
DOC.TEXT: Three lawyers from a personal-injury firm were indicted Thursday on federal racketeering charges for allegedly fabricating evidence and paying for false testimony. The 23-count indictment charges that lawyers and several other employees of the Morris J. Eisen law firm engaged in a pattern of mail fraud, bribery of witnesses and court workers, and falsification of evidence since 1981. In one instance, a man who testified as an eyewitness in two separate car-accident cases in 1984 saw neither of them and was in prison on forgery charges when one of the accidents happened, said Andrew J. Maloney, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York. ``I haven't seen the extent of this kind of shenanigans by lawyers in my career,'' said Maloney. The Eisen firm until recently was one of the largest personal-injury firms in the nation. In 1986, the firm grossed some $20 million in contingency fees and employed more than 40 lawyers, Maloney said. The indictment names Morris J. Eisen, 58; Joseph P. Napoli, 48; and Harold M. Fishman, 50. Four private investigators and the firm's former office manager were also charged. If convicted, the defendants could face up to 20 years in prison and fines of as much as double the proceeds of each criminal activity on each count, Maloney said. James La Rossa, the attorney for Eisen, called the indictment a vendetta and said it was false and unfair. ``Eisen is a thorn in the side of the insurance companies out to protect their profits and a medical bureaucracy seeking to avoid the awesome responsibility for ruined and broken lives,'' La Rossa said. ``Let there be no mistake about what this indictment is, a clear and brazen effort to cripple the advocates of the men, women and children who have been crippled and maimed.'' The ivestigation involved 19 personal-injury lawsuits, seven against the city. The awards in those lawsuits amount to as much as $9 million and the firm's contingency fees were about one-third of that amount, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Waters Easing in Northwest, Cleanup Begins
DOC.TEXT: Flood waters receded Thursday in parts of the Northwest, and thousands of people began returning home to contend with the damage caused by rain-swollen rivers. Three people were killed in Washington state and millions of dollars of property damage occurred when rivers ran over their banks after four days of heavy rains. The rains slackened Wednesday and flood warnings remained Thursday on just three rivers: the Chehalis, White and Snohomish. Oregon also sustained millions of dollars in damage and weather contributed to the deaths of three people. Residents along the northern Oregon coast were cleaning up damage from high winds and heavy rains. Rain was forecast for Thursday night, but not as heavy as the earlier storms, the National Weather Service said. However, officials warned that high tides along the Washington coast could exacerbate flooding at Grays Harbor and on the lower Chehalis. The Chehalis had the worst flooding, along with a tributary, the Skookumchuck, flooding scores of homes and much of the business district in Centralia, 80 miles south of Seattle. An estimated 3,000 of Lewis County's 57,000 residents were forced to leave their homes. High water also closed Interstate 5 at Chehalis, 4 miles to the south, Wednesday morning. State officials said the water was receding on the freeway, but the main route between Portland, Ore., and Seattle remained closed. The Chehalis' flood surge Thursday soaked the small towns of Oakville and Porter, about 20 miles southwest of Olympia and was expected to reach Aberdeen and Grays Harbor on the Pacific coast Friday. Kate Heimbach, Washington's emergency management director, said losses easily will be several million dollars in each county. Oregon Gov. Neil Goldschmidt planned to tour his state's northern coast Friday. He declared a state of emergency in the two affected counties Tuesday. Many of the 37 evacuees in Oregon's Clatsop and Tillamook counties began heading home Thursday. Two men drowned in separate accidents in the Centralia area, authorities said, while a third man drowned in Fife, east of Tacoma. In Oregon, two people were killed in separate weather-related car accidents and an 11-year-old girl was killed by a falling tree.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Fugitive Found In Switzerland
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive who failed to appear for his 1987 sentencing for a $1.3 million tax-shelter fraud case in Los Angeles was arrested by police in Switzerland, the U.S. Marshals Service said Thursday. Gerald L. Rogers, 54, was arrested by police in Zurich, said spokesman Bill Dempsey. Rogers, who had been previously spotted in Britain, Portugual and France, had been a fugitive since July 1987, Dempsey said. The investigation produced sightings of Rogers aboard his 101-foot yacht named ``Laissez-Faire'' and worth $2 million, Dempsey said. Rogers, who jumped $500,000 bond, was to be sentenced in federal court in Los Angeles for mail fraud and causing the filing of false tax returns in connection with the tax-shelter scheme, Dempsey said. He faced 101 years imprisonment for bilking investors out of $1.3 million in the scheme, Dempsey said. Rogers also faces racketeering, conspiracy, securities fraud and mail fraud charges in Denver stemming from a tax-shelter scheme involving gold mines in Colorado, Dempsey said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Says Social Security Tax Rollback a Democratic Ploy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS ``$55 million'' to ``$55 billion'' in 13th graf: ``The Heritage,''
DOC.TEXT: increases

The Bush administration found itself arguing against a politically appealing tax cut Thursday as it denounced a proposed rollback of Social Security payroll taxes as a Democratic ploy to ``fiddle around'' with the nation's retirement system. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the administration opposes a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to repeal this year's Social Security tax hike and to further cut the rate next Jan. 1. ``Mr. Moynihan's got a lot of ideas, and we'll let the Democrats have those ideas,'' Fitzwater said. Bush's ``no-new-taxes'' philosophy does not apply to the Social Security tax increases, which were scheduled to take place anyway, administration officials said. Moynihan's plan, which is fast gaining support from business and conservative groups, would cancel the Jan. 1 increase that raised the Social Security tax rate to 7.65 percent from 7.51 percent. The tax covers both retirement and Medicare programs. Moynihan's proposal would then lower the rate even further, to 6.55 percent, on Jan. 1, 1991. ``We don't anticipate any changes in Social Security. Democrats seem to want to fiddle around with the Social Security system; we do not,'' Fitzwater said. Moynihan aide Ed Lopez, who said Bush seems to be putting himself at dds with many conservatives, asked: ``So the president doesn't like our tax cut?'' ``We expected it would have bipartisan support. But it's a bit surprising the extent to which the right wing has climbed all over it,'' Lopez said. He said Moynihan, who has called the legislation a ``$55 billion tax cut for working people,'' planned to introduce the rollback measure on Jan. 23, the day Congress returns from its winter recess. Kay O'Beirne, deputy director of the conservative Heritage Foundation, said the administration is finding itself ``in a position of opposing a tax break that Americans deserve.'' ``That will be a problem for them,'' she said, suggesting widespread support for the proposed tax cut might force the administration into a position of having to ``argue that Americans aren't overtaxed.'' The Heritage Foundation, which usually finds itself on opposite sides from Moynihan, put out an analysis of the legislation on Thursday entitled ``Three Cheers for Moynihan's $55 Billion Tax Cut.'' ``It hasn't happened too often in the past. But here he is, championing a proposal we've been advocating for years,'' said Ms. O'Beirne. ``We welcome his leadership.'' The increases in Social Security taxes were enacted in 1983 under a formula for shoring up the system produced by a blue-ribbon commission headed by Alan Greenspan to overhaul the social security financing. Greenspan was a private economist at the time. He is now chairman of the Federal Reserve. Moynihan, who is chairman of the Senate Finance subcommittee on Social Security, was a member of the Greenspan commission. ``The Social Security system is sound. Let the Democrats fool with it, not us,'' Fitzwater said. He said the administration favored keeping the ``commitment to America'' he said was made by the Greenspan commission. ``We're not changing Social Security,'' he added. However, White House staff chief John Sununu said on ``Face the Nation'' last Sunday that the administration did plan to propose a change to Social Security financing that would require surpluses generated by the Social Security trust funds to be used to help retire the national debt after 1993. Currently, the trust funds are invested in Treasury securities. The surplus in the trust funds is currently about $65 billion, and since these funds are figured in the federal budget, they tend to mask the real extent of the federal budget deficit. However, Fitzwater said that these changes dealt mostly with bookkeeping methods. ``I don't know about the budget stuff. I just know we aren't changing Social Security.'' Social Security taxes jumped almost $320 this year for Americans earning $51,300 or more, in part because the wage limit on which the tax is levied was raised from $48,000. At $48,000 and below, the increase is 0.14 percent of wages _ $67 for someone earning $48,000; $42 for someone earning $30,000, $28 for someone earning $20,000, and so forth. Don Levins, director of federal budget policy for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said the Moynihan proposal, which would cut the tax rate paid by both employees and employers, was ``a positive first step'' toward strengthening the Social Security system. ``How can you go against such a good idea? It's a populist idea. And it will do a lot of good for economic growth,'' Levins said. He said that, while the chamber had some concerns about paying for such a tax cut, the administration and ``Republicans in general'' would be ``missing a golden opportunity'' by not backing such a payroll tax rollback. Bush addresses a Chamber of Commerce audience on Friday in Cincinnati, but aides said it was unlikely he would have much to say about Social Security financing.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying U.S. Officials Disappears in Chile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with search suspended until Friday, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said Thursday night a daylong search found no trace of a police plane carrying five people, including two Americans from the Food and Drug Administration, that disappeared on a domestic flight. Search officials said 21 aircraft scoured a 500-mile-long stretch of terrain north of Santiago, spending much of their time over the Atacama Desert, one of the driest sites on Earth. Land patrols were also sent out. Col. Luis Godoy, head of the national police aviation branch, said the air search was suspended after 8:30 p.m. but will resume at daylight Friday. Police said the twin-engine Cessna 206 disappeared Wednesday after taking off at 5:10 p.m. from Copiapo for the four-hour flight south to Santiago. Godoy said, ``The search centers near Copiapo, because the last radio contact with the missing plane occurred only 15 minutes after it left that city. But we are covering the entire route it was scheduled to follow.'' Authorities said no sign of sabotage emerged, and no guerrillas are believed to operate in the region, which is in a 125-mile section of land sandwiched between the Pacific and the Andes mountains. The Americans aboard were identified as John Harty Jr., of Silver Spring, Md., and Patrick Pouzar of Nashville, Tenn., FDA officials who arrived in Chile last Saturday to investigate Chilean security measures in harvesting, packing and transport of Chilean fruit to be exported to the United States. They had gone to Copiapo to visit the area's vineyards. The Chileans on the plane were Oscar Badilla, a government agricultural official; Sergio Lazcano, an excecutive of the Chilean Fruit Exporters Association, and the pilot, Police Lt. German Fuentes. American and Chilean authorities agreed on such security checks after two Chilean grapes laced with cyanide were found in Philadelphia, prompting a temporary suspension of the sale of all Chilean fruits in the United States. No victims were reported. Weather conditions in the area Thursday were described as ``excellent all day long,'' by a police officer helping to coordinate the search operation. He identified himself only as Lt. Carreno. Godoy said the Cessna carried a device that ``would send a strong radio alarm signal in case of a crash, but we have not monitored such a signal so far.'' In Washington, FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit identified Harty as director of the agency's international affairs staff in the FDA's Office of Health Affairs in Rockville, Md., and Pouzar as director of investigations in the FDA's Nashville district office. Nesbit said the two visited fruit-processing facilities in northern Chile. They were expected home Monday, said Bill Oates, acting director of the Nashville office. Nesbit said the foreign minister informed the U.S. Embassy in Santiago late Wednesday that the plane was overdue.

DOC.HEAD: French Aid Agency Says Shortages Plague Cambodia Relief Efforts
DOC.TEXT: Shortages of water and medical supplies continue to hamper relief missions to wartorn regions of Cambodia, the French aid agency Doctors Without Borders said Thursday. Fighting between rebels and government troops has left ``numerous'' casualties in the western provinces and near the capital Phnom Penh, the organization said in a statement based on reports from its medical teams inside Cambodia. A surgeon, anesthetist and logistics expert have been helping treat the wounded at an emergency hospital at Kompong Thom in central Cambodia since Dec. 15, the agency said. Their work has been slowed by primitive medical conditions and shortages of water, drugs, medical equipment and personnel, the statement said. Most of the wounded suffered injuries from bullets, rockets and mines, the agency said. Medecins Sans Frontieres, or Doctors Without Borders, hopes to dispatch fresh teams, especially to Kompong Cham in the east, the statement said. Rebels opposed to the Vietnamese-supported regime of President Hun Sen have stepped up their guerrilla campaign against the government since Vietnam said it had withdrawn its troops last fall. The rebels include the 40,000-strong Khmer Rouge, who killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians during the Pol Pot reign of terror from April 1975 to December 1978, when a Vietnamese invasion drove them from power. Two smaller rebels groups loyal to former ruler Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann, a former prime minister, are allied with the Khmer Rouge to topple Hun Sen, whom they view as a Vietnamese puppet. Most of the fighting has taken place in the western provinces near the border with Thailand. The rebels receive support from refugee camps along the border. The agency said its teams have also witnessed troubles in Kompong Cham and Kompong Thom as well as Kompong Speu, 31 miles southwest of the capital. The statement came as the Khmer Rouge claimed Thursday to have smashed strategic government positions after shelling the country's second-largest city in Battambang on Jan. 5 and 6 and ``liberated'' 38 villages and four communes in western Cambodia. The report could not be verified and previous claims by the Communist rebels have proved to be exaggerated. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council are scheduled to meet Monday and Tuesday in Paris to follow up last summer's international conference on Cambodia, which adjourned without reaching agreement on a peace plan. Australia has proposed replacing the government with a United Nations interim administration until free elections can be held. The plan would require backing from all five permanent members of the security council _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China.

DOC.HEAD: First Multiparty Elections in April
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's ruling Communist Party is preparing to give up its monopoly on power and allow the first multiparty elections in 45 years in April, a leading Communist said Thursday. Stefan Korosec, secretary of the policy-setting Central Committee, told a news conference that the Communist Party will take part in the legislative elections in Yugoslavia's six republics ``just as another party (would) with its new program.'' Elections in the republics, which delegate deputies to the national legislature, are scheduled for April. The new program, which Korosec said ``departs from the model of authoritarian'' Communism, still has to be adopted at an extraordinary Communist Party congress scheduled to start Jan. 20 in Belgrade, he said. The document appears to be Yugoslavia's reply to the wave of democratic reforms currently sweeping Eastern Europe. Yugoslavia had a multiparty system before World War II, but the Western-style democracy was abolished when the Communists came to power in 1945.
