Korosec also presented to reporters a final draft of a declaration to be approved by the congress in which the party pledges to relinquish its monopoly on power. It also calls for ``free, direct and secret'' multiparty elections. The draft declaration also says that Yugoslav Communists ``advocate full participation (of Yugoslavia) in European integration processes (including) its Membership in the European Community, the Council of Europe, the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and other similar organizations and institutions.'' Korosec said leaders in all of Yugoslavia's divergent Communist republics support the declaration ``in principle.'' However, he also indicated the document could spark fierce debate between hardliners and more liberal communists. Yugoslav Communists were the first to break with the monolithic Soviet-led Communist bloc in 1948, but Yugoslavia, faced with its worst economic and political crisis ever, has been slower in adopting the Western-style reforms that have gripped other East European countries. ``The declaration represents the real divorce of the party from the state and the constitution of the party as a non-monopolistic organization,'' Korosec said. He did not elaborate on what if any legal guarantees would be taken that the party was giving up its leading role. In Hungary, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, articles in the constitution guaranteeing the leading role of the party have been scrapped. In Bulgaria, similar steps have been promised. Yugoslavia is currently reworking the Constitution and if the document is adopted in its current form at next week's congress, it is likely that the Constitutional reference to the party's leading role will be scrapped. Korosec said he thinks ``the Communists cannot lose next April's elections'' but if they do, they might form a coalition with other leftist parties such as the Socialist Alliance, which is now a communist-led mass organization but plans to constitute itself as an independent party. Even though Yugoslavia has not formally adopted a law allowing independent political groups and parties to form, numerous political parties have sprung up all over the country over the past few months. Some of the parties have clear nationalist programs that has sparked fears this could lead to open clashes between the republics that could seriously threaten the unity of this Balkan country.

DOC.HEAD: State Agency: Immigration Reform Led to Widespread Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: The 1986 federal immigration amnesty law led to widespread discrimination against hundreds of thousands of U.S.-born and foreign-looking persons seeking work, a state report concluded. The state Fair Employment and Housing Commission report released Thursday also accuses the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service of enforcing the law poorly, the Los Angeles Times reported. ``I predicted that would happen,'' said Rep. Edward Roybal (D-Los Angeles), who voted against the law, ``but no one at the time seemed to pay attention.'' The seven-member commission said the law, which orders that those hiring undocumented workers be prosecuted, led many employers to turn away job applicants even though many had proof of U.S. residency, the report said. It also recommended the INS suspend enforcement of employer sanctions, which include fines up to $10,000 for those who knowingly hire undocumented aliens. The non-binding recommendations are the first by a public agency in the western United States on the controversial 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, under which more than 3 million immigrants applied for amnesty. More than half of those immigrants live in California. A New York state agency issued a similar report in late 1988. The report comes as the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, is preparing a final report on the law's effects. If the GAO agrees discrimination has occurred, the act requires Congress to consider changes. The state commission oversees enforcement of California laws prohibiting housing and employment discrimination. INS officials defended their performance, pointing out the agency spent millions of dollars and thousands of hours to educate employers how the new laws affected. ``The INS has done an excellent job of implementing this law,'' agency spokesman Virginia Kice said. ``I don't think anyone can classify employer sanctions or IRCA as a failure.'' The commission's findings were based on testimony delivered at public hearings last year in Oakland, Fresno and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Chile Disbands Its Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: The military junta on Thursday dissolved the feared secret police of President Augusto Pinochet, which has been accused of widespread human rights abuses. Adm. Jose Merino, president of the junta, said it passed a law under which agents of the clandestine police force will be sent back to the armed forces branches from which they were assigned. The junta is made up of the commanders of the navy, air force and national police and a reprsentative of the army appointed by Gen. Pinochet, president and army commander. It acts as legislature for his 16-year-old administration. The text of Thursday's law dissolving the secret police, formally called National Information Central, was not made public. Merino said secret police files ``will remain in the hands of the same people who have them now.'' Rights groups have asked that the files be given to the Supreme Court, saying the documents may be essential if the truth is to be discovered in cases of serious rights violations in recent years. Secret police directors all have been army generals. Most of the force's officers came from the armed forces. A recent report by an opposition magazine reckoned the number of agents at 8,000 military men and 4,000 civilians. The goverment gives no figure. The agency was created in 1977 to replace another secret police force, the National Intelligence Directorate, after that force was linked to the assassination of prominent dissidents abroad. Among the deaths was that of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier in Washington in 1976. The 74-year-old Pinochet, who seized power in a violent coup in 1973, will hand over the presidency on March 11 to an elected civilian successor, Patricio Aylwin. But Pinochet says he will remain as commander of the 60,000-member army, as permitted by the 1980 constitution crafted by his military regime.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Erupts; Ash Suspected But Not Confirmed
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano rumbled through another eruption Thursday, ejecting a plume that rose more than five miles into the sky, the Alaska Volcano Observatory said. There was no confirmation of ash in the plume, but it probably contained some, observatory geologist Steve Brantley said. Wind reports indicated any ash carried from the volcano area would miss Anchorage, Brantley said, and no ash was expected to reach the Kenai Peninsula, hit by gritty fallout after Redoubt rocked through an eruption Monday. Monday's blowup was the volcano's biggest since it emerged from a quarter-century of slumber in mid-December. Redoubt, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, was cloaked in clouds Thursday. Brantley said scientists had virtually no warning of the eruption, which occurred at about 2 p.m. ADT. ``Since the volcano became active, some of the larger explosive events have been preceded by a systematic increase in the number of earthquakes.'' The lack of warning is tied to destruction of Redoubt's lava dome on Jan. 2, he said. ``We don't have the capability of predicting when these events will occur or how large they will be,'' Brantley said. He said scientists are equipped to gauge the strength of eruptions and transmit information to the Federal Aviation Administration and other agencies. The FAA alerted pilots that volcanic ash was possible in the Redoubt area Thursday. Ash can shut down jet engines, as it did last month when a Boeing 747 operated by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines flew through fallout from Redoubt. The plane lost power to all four engines and landed in Anchorage after they were restarted. Brantley said the volcano also went through a small explosion Thursday morning. ``After these two events, the volcano seems to be relatively quiet,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Our Gang' Actor Robert Winckler Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: Robert Winckler, an entertainment lawyer whose Hollywood career began as a child actor on the ``Our Gang'' film comedies, has died of stomach cancer, his son said. He was 62. Winckler died Dec. 28 at his home in Woodland Hills, the Los Angeles Daily News reported Thursday. Winckler's acting career began at age 9 at Hal Roach Studios, after Charlie Chaplin's former wife, Mildred, provided him with a letter of introduction. By the late 1930s, he had appeared as the bully in at least eight Little Rascals features. He also was cast in numerous films, appearing in ``Boys Town,'' ``Knute Rockne _ All American,'' ``Blue Montana Skies,'' and ``Stagecoach.'' Winckler graduated from the Southwestern University School of Law in 1953, and subsequently represented stars such as George ``Spanky'' McFarland and Billy Barty. Recently, Winckler had been representing Adam West, the former television star of ``Batman,'' in a lawsuit against several advertising agencies over the alleged imitation of West's Batman in a television commercial. West is seeking $900,000 in damages over a commercial for Zayre Stores. The case was taken over by other attorneys and will go to trial Monday, said Winckler's son, Bill Winckler. In addition to his son, Winckler is survived by his wife of 27 years, Betty, and daughter Patricia Winckler, all of Woodland Hills.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Kicks Out Radio Prague Report for `Distorting' Reality
DOC.TEXT: Cuba has told the Havana correspondent for Radio Prague to leave, accusing him of ``distorting the reality of Cuba,'' the official Cuban news agency said Thursday. Prensa Latina said Czech reporter Michal Cermak was told of the decision by the International Press Center early Thursday. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, did not say when Cermak was to leave Havana. The head of the press center, Hector Argiles, told Prensa Latina that Cermak was asked to leave after a broadcast ``about current conditions'' in Cuba. The Prensa Latina dispatch did not elaborate on the offending broadcast but said Argiles compared it to reports in the ``Western media that constantly try to damage the prestige of the Cuban Revolution.'' ``Foreign journalists here can count on complete support and facilities to carry out their professional missions, but those who deliberately distort the reality of Cuba can't stay in the country,'' Argiles said, according to Prensa Latina. With the crumbling of communism in Eastern European nations like Czechoslovakia, Cuban President Fidel Castro is becoming more and more isolated as one of the last of the hard-liners.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Independence is Possible But Warns Lithuanians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD details, background. Picks up 8th pvs, `You must...' Minor editing thereafter to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XVIL1,2; VIL20
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told independence-seeking Lithuanians Thursday that a faceoff with Moscow could lead to tragedy, but he also said a law is being prepared that would permit the republic to secede from the Soviet Union. It was not clear from the Soviet president's comments how free Lithuania would be under the framework he envisions. About 300,000 Lithuanians jammed central Vilnius late Thursday in a candlelight demonstration for freedom at the conclusion of the first day of Gorbachev's three-day visit. ``We have been tied together for these 50 years, whether we like it or not,'' Gorbachev told a crowd after placing a wreath at a monument to Vladimir Lenin. But he also told a meeting of Lithuanian intellectuals that ``I am for self-determination all the way to secession,'' according to Lithuanian TV correspondent Eduardas Potesinskas. Lithuanians say they want to restore the independence they had between the world wars. Soviet dictator Josef Stalin absorbed Lithuania along with the two other Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, in 1940 under a secret agreement with Nazi Germany. Lithuania, the southernmost of the Baltics, is about 600 miles west of Moscow. Gorbachev reiterated his opposition to the independence drive, which he has said could cause a breakup of the Soviet Union, but said he would not stand in the way of the Lithuanian people's will. He said he had ordered that a law be written and published establishing a mechanism for secession from the Soviet Union, a right guaranteed by the country's 1977 Constitution but not recognized to date. He did not spell out how the machinery for secession worked. In an interview with Britain's Independent Television News, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov confirmed Moscow was preparing the law. ``You must think about the interests of the other party too, so there must be mechanism for divorce, so to say,'' the spokesman said from Vilnius, Lithuania's capital. The ITN reporter asked if the draft law meant a law of total independence. ``We have an article in the Constitution. According to this article, every republic has the right to secession, to go away. The right is there,'' he said. Although he has granted Lithuanians and their neighbors in Latvia and Estonia a large measure of economic and political power, Gorbachev has consistently and sharply criticized Lithuanian Communist Party leaders for pressing for complete independence. He convened an emergency session of the national party's Central Committee last month to discuss the issue. By going to Vilnius, Gorbachev put his personal prestige on the line as never before in nearly five years in power, appearing in a republic that openly disagrees with him and is unlikely to be moved by his appeals. Gorbachev is in Lithuania to try to reverse the Lithuanian party's break with the national party, decided in December. Gorbachev waded into a crowd of several hundred people after the visit to the Lenin monument, and he talked for nearly an hour. One man called out: ``People must decide their own fate!'' ``Nothing will be decided without you,'' Gorbachev replied. ``We will decide everything together.'' However, he added the following warning: ``Remember, if someone succeeds in pitting us against each other in a clash, there will be a tragedy. We should not allow this.'' Gorbachev was not explicit about what such a tragedy might be, but one of his closest allies, fellow Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, was quoted Monday as saying the Lithuanian party's move might cause a ``domino effect,'' encouraging Communists in the other 14 republics to break from Moscow. Soviet officials have given a virtual guarantee they will not use force to keep Lithuania and its 3.7 million residents in the Soviet Union. Gerasimov told the BBC last week the Kremlin has ``only one tool'' for preventing a breakup. ``It is dialogue, dialogue and dialogue,'' said Gerasimov. ``The only way is political means. We have no other choice.'' Gorbachev also spoke of possible national repercussions when he told the Vilnius crowd the rights of all minorities in the Soviet Union must be respected or the nation of more than 100 ethnic groups may unravel. ``If even the slightest suppression occurs, or misunderstanding, somewhere in Estonia or Moldavia, it spills over into the rest of the country,'' he said. As Gorbachev met with Communist Party members in another part of Vilnius, an estimated 300,000 pro-independence demonstrators rallied in the shadow of a cathedral once closed by atheist Soviet authorities. The strains of violins and patriotic hymns filled the air along with the smell of burning candles carried by demonstrators. The crowd hushed briefly in commemoration for the tens of thousands of Lithuanians who suffered in the Soviet takeover, then again broke out in song. ``We've come here to express our unity, in light of the East European changes, to announce that we will decide the problems of Lithuania ourselves,'' Vytautas Landsbergis, head of the grass-roots political movement Sajudis, told the crowd. Landsbergis, who is also a member of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, spoke of the Soviet Union like a foreign country. ``What was stolen must be returned,'' he told the rally. ``The time has come for intergovernmental negotiations between Lithuania and the Soviet Union.'' The square was a mass of color at the twilight rally, with the red, yellow and green of hundreds of flags of a free Lithuania joined by flags symbolizing independent Estonia, Latvia, Georgia, Armenia, Moldavia and the Ukraine. It was a reminder that Moscow faces calls for independence not just from Lithuania but the other non-Russian republics as well. There were signs of local defiance toward centralized Soviet rule elsewhere Thursday. In Armenia, the legislature amended the republic's Constitution to give itself an effective veto over national laws it sees as conflicting with Armenia's interests, said Yerevan activist Rafael Popoyan. In Latvia, lawmakers followed the lead of their Lithuanian colleagues and amended the Constitution to create a multiparty system, the evening TV news program ``Vremya'' reported. The amendments end the Communist Party's constitutional guarantee on political power and allow Latvians to form rival parties ``that do not advocate overthrowing the existing state system or other anti-constitutional goals,'' according to ``Vremya.'' Gorbachev is also pressing for creation of a Soviet ``federation'' whose constituent republics would have more rights. He blames many of the country's ills on the strongly centralized Moscow-based bureaucracy.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LIMA
300 Shining Path Guerrillas Attack Army Jungle Patrol in Peru
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with rebel raid on army patrol, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Shining Path guerrillas attacked an army patrol in their jungle camp in the coca-rich Upper Huallaga Valley, killing at least six soldiers, police said Thursday. The 14 other soldiers in the patrol were missing, and police think they fled into the jungle when their ammunition ran out. Army helicopters failed to find them. In Lima, the capital, police said earlier Thursday that from witness' descriptions, they identified one of the guerrillas involved in the assassination of former Defense Minister Enrique Lopez as Gregorio Olivos, a former university student with purported links to the Shining Path. Lopez, the most prominent figure to be killed in 10 years of guerrilla violence in Peru, was attacked in his car on Tuesday by at least three men with sub-machine guns as he arrived at his office in the Lima suburb of San Isidro. Another rebel group, the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, claimed responsibility Thursday, but a government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the claim ``looks pretty thin. The attack ... has the Shining Path written all over it.'' On Wednesday evening, according to a police report, rebels attacked the army patrol's camp in New San Martin area, 110 miles south of Tarapoto. The battle lasted until Thursday morning, when the soldiers apparently ran out of ammunition and the survivors fled, police said. An army helicopter recovered the soldiers' bodies Thursday but found no survivors. Nor did other helicopters dispatched to the attack site. Police in Tarapoto, 435 miles north of Lima, told The Associated Press that peasants living nearby informed them that the guerrillas came to the area a few days before. The attackers had automatic weapons, grenades and dynamite. They took the weapons and uniforms of the dead soldiers. The Upper Huallaga Valley is the source of most of Peru's coca. The Shining Path operates there in an alliance with drug traffickers, allowing them to do business with peasant coca-growers in exchange for part of their profits. The traffickers buy coca leaves, make them into paste and ship the paste in small planes north to Colombia, where it is refined into cocaine. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in political violence since the Mao-inspired Shining Path launched its armed insurgency in 1980. A congressional commission said in Lima it will meet Friday to hear testimony from the ministers of interior and defense on why bodyguards were not accompanying Lopez when he was killed. President Alan Garcia criticized the military on the day of the shooting for not providing full-time protection for the retired general. An article published Thursday in the newspaper Cambio, considered an outlet of the Tupac Amaru movement, said Lopez was shot by their guerrillas in response to the government's ``politics of annihilation (and) extrajudicial executions of guerrillas and civilians.'' Police say it was the Shining Path. They continued stopping cars and checking people's documents Thursday in a search for suspects. A government spokesman said more than 15,000 people without identification had been detained since Tuesday, but most were released after proving their identity.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Charged in AIDS-related Case Dies
DOC.TEXT: A woman believed to be the first prostitute in the United States to be charged with attempted manslaughter in an AIDS-related case has died. Elizabeth Kaye Sherouse, 26, died Tuesday at her mother's home, said Mitch Gazil, cremation director of Beacon Cremation Service of Central Florida. The exact cause of death was not available. The state spent more than a year trying to send her to prison on dozens of charges, including attempted manslaughter for planning to have sex with two clients while knowing she carried the fatal virus. The two men used condoms and have tested negative for the virus. Last June, circuit judge Michael Cycmanick in Orlando said her infection with AIDS was ample punishment for breaking the law as a prostitute. She could have been sentenced to up to four years and 120 days in prison. ``There is no question that punishment in this case is what you have sustained and are enduring because of your conduct,'' Cycmanick told the 88-pound woman, already feeble from AIDS-related infections. He sentenced her to four years' probation on six remaining misdemeanor prostitution charges. Ms. Sherouse, a cocaine addict with a seventh-grade education, had spent most of her time since then at home with her mother. ``Thank you, Jesus,'' Ms. Sherouse said after the judge's decision. Her doctor had preregistered her with the medical examiner, indicating that those close to her expected several days before her death Tuesday that she would die, Gazil said. Family members declined comment.

DOC.HEAD: Hackers Charged with Selling Computer Codes to Soviets on Trial
DOC.TEXT: Three West Germans ``hackers'' went on trial Thursday charged with selling Western military computer passwords and codes to the Soviets. Dirk Brzesinski, Peter Carl and Markus Hess were arrested last March after an investigation by U.S. and West German officials revealed they had obtained information giving them access to key military and research computers in the United States, Western Europe and Japan. A fourth man, 30-year-old Karl Koch, who was also arrested in the case, committed suicide in May. Brzesinski, 30, a computer specialist, told the court that Koch had come up with the idea of selling the information. ``We decided in 1986 to sell the information to the Soviets for 1 million marks ($605,000) to help them even out the technical know-how advantage of the West,'' Brzesinski said. Carl, 35, said he was responsible for contacting the Soviet trade mission in East Berlin, where he dealt with a contact identified only as ``Serge.'' Carl said he did not want to reveal anything more about the Soviets in court for fear of reprisals. Court records show Carl made at least 25 contacts with the Soviets and received a total of 90,000 marks ($54,500) for the information. According to Brzesinski, Koch before his death claimed he had managed to gain access to the U.S. Defense Department general databank known as Optimus. After the arrests last year, U.S. and West German news media reported that other computers the hackers entered included a NASA and a ``Star Wars'' research computer, as well as computers linked to nuclear weapons and energy research in Los Alamos, N.M., and the Fermi Laboratory in Illinois. However, U.S. officials said last year that although the hackers obtained sensitive codes and passwords to enter the computers, they were stopped short of obtaining any highly classified information. Investigators have said that codes and passwords from computers in Japan, Britain, France, Italy, Switzerland and West Germany were also obtained and sold to the Soviets. A verdict in the trial, scheduled to be completed in 12 sessions, is expected Feb. 8. The men face up to 15 years in prison each if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: French Travelers Warned of Terrorist Threats in India
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry on Thursday warned travel agents planning tourist packages to India to be on guard against possible terrorist attacks against French citizens. The warning comes a day after an Air India jumbo jet bound from Paris to New Delhi made an unscheduled stop in Karachi, Pakistan, after a bomb threat. No bomb was found and the 284 passengers continued their journey safely. The Foreign Ministry warning was relayed to the National Union of Tourist Agents by the Tourism Ministry. It follows a threat telephoned Monday to the French news agency Agence France-Presse in New Delhi. The caller threatened to kill French citizens in India and elsewhere unless France frees Anis Naccache, a Lebanese Moslem convicted of trying to assassinate Iran's former prime minister, Shahpour Bakhtiar, in Paris in 1980. Naccache began a hunger strike Sept. 8 and his lawyer says he could die any time. The caller claimed to represent Shiite Moslems in Kashmir, where Islamic militants are conducting a violent campaign for secession from predominantly Hindu India. He said he represented a group called Harakat Jihad-e-Islami, or the Islamic Holy War Organization. The French Embassy in New Delhi asked Indian authorities to take extra measures to protect French nationals in the country.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Halts Contacts With Baltic Nationalists
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Secretariat has discontinued informal contacts with nationalist leaders of the three Soviet Baltic republics but U.N. officials said Thursday no pressure came from the Soviet Union. Francois Giuliani, spokesman for the secretary-general, said in a briefing Thursday the contacts were strictly ``informational'' between the nationalist groups of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and Assistant Secretary-General James O.C. Jonah. He said they went on for several months and were initiated by the groups. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar had not been a party and had not been informed until recently, he added. In answer to a question, Giuliani said Soviet officials had not sought to intervene or block contacts. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev currently is visiting Lithuania trying to diffuse separatist sentiment there. U.N. officials said Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky contacted Jonah's office about the discussions, but lodged no protest with the secretary-general. The Soviet Mission's press officer was not available for comment, although a message was left with his office by telephone. The U.N. Charter bars the world organization from interfering in members' domestic affairs. Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, once independent, were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 and never have acquiesced to Soviet domination. Baltic nationalism has been fanned by democratic upheavals in Eastern Europe and by policies of openness and reform under Gorbachev. The Soviet Constitution provides the right of secession to its republics but Gorbachev opposes any breakup of the Soviet Union. Baltic groups in New York expressed regret over the U.N. decision. ``We are sorry to see that these informal, informational contacts have been discontinued because of Soviet sensitivity,'' said Ginte Damusis of the Lithuanian Information Center. ``It is scandalous to see the United Nations officials running scared of Moscow.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Objects to Use of Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-five drug defendants refusing to plead guilty in District of Columbia courts were retaliated against by prosecutors who moved the cases into federal court, said a judge who dismissed the indictment against one of them Thursday. The federal court cases carried stiffer penalties. In dismissing an indictment against Vernon Holland of Washington, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene said the defendant had been deprived of his rights to due process of law and to a speedy trial. Holland was charged in the federal court with possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine after he refused to plead to a lesser crime, attempted possession of cocaine, in a local court where he might have escaped a jail sentence. The federal charge carries a five-year minimum prison term on conviction. Holland's was one of 55 drug cases the U.S. attorney's office moved from D.C. Superior Court to U.S. District Court, where the defendants were indicted by federal grand juries. The transfers, prosecutors said, followed an April 1989 initiative against violent crime and drug abuse in the District of Columbia announced by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and federal anti-drug czar William Bennett. The U.S. attorney's office in the District of Columbia is unique in the country in prosecuting crime in both the federal and the local courts. Greene served as chief judge of the Superior Court for seven years before being elevated to the federal bench by President Carter in 1978. In two days of hearings last week before Greene, prosecutors denied that the defendants' refusal to plead guilty played any role in the transfers. But Greene concluded that the case files of the transfers proved otherwise. ``In case after case, the particular defendant whose case was transferred had declined to plead guilty in Superior Court prior to his indictment in this Court,'' said the judge. ``Indeed, in several instances, the relationship between the refusal to enter a guilty plea and indictment in federal court was explicitly spelled out.'' ``It is the Court's conclusion that, like a number of the other defendants, Holland has been deprived of his rights under the Due Process Clause and under the Speedy Trial Act, and the charges against him will therefore be dismissed,'' said Greene. In a typical transfer case, said the judge, a decision was made in May or June of 1989 to seek an indictment in federal court, even though an indictment for the same conduct was pending in Superior Court. Despite the decision to transfer, the new federal indictment was deliberately not obtained until the fall of 1989. That was ``just about the time the Superior Court case was called for trial and could no longer be postponed,'' said Greene. The U.S. attorney's office said the transfers were made solely on the basis of the provable facts in each case. The status of the other 54 cases could not immediately be determined.

DOC.HEAD: Post Reporters, Editors Who Quit Planning New Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: More than 25 reporters and editors who resigned from The Jerusalem Post because of a dispute with the publisher are trying to put together financing for a new English-language daily, a spokesman said Thursday. ``We are engaged in intensive efforts to set up an alternative English-language daily that would be what we consider to be the old Jerusalem Post,'' said Menachem Shalev, a former Post diplomatic correspondent. ``We are in touch with both foreign and Israeli investors but haven't concluded anything yet,'' he added. He declined to say who the potential investors are and said ``millions of dollars'' would be needed for the venture. The 58-year-old newspaper, which began in pre-state Israel as The Palestine Post, has extensively covered the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and is widely read by journalists and diplomats here and abroad. On Wednesday, the staff remaining at the Post announced they were dropping a labor dispute after publisher Yehuda Levy pledged to protect jurnalistic freedom and not impose a political slant. Problems began after Levy, a career army officer, was appointed president and publisher last July by the Canadian newspaper chain Hollinger Inc., which purchased controlling interest in the Post in April. The paper announced Tuesday that Hollinger Inc. had purchased the remaining shares, giving it ``complete control.'' The staff charged that Levy was interfering in the editorial freedom of the paper and said they feared he would steer its traditional liberal policy to the extreme right. In a letter that led to settlement of the labor dispute, Levy pledged that ``The Jerusalem Post will be a free and independent newspaper and will not reflect a single political orthodox position.'' He also promised ``a continuing effort to give the readers accurate news reporting and a wide spectrum of opinion and commentary'' and said ``the editor and sub-editors will not be instructed to slant articles politically.'' Levy said he had asked six of the reporters and editors who submitted resignations to withdraw them. It was unclear if any will do so. Shalev said some journalists who quit have been approached by other Israeli newspapers. But he said the group's first choice was to start a new paper. ``We hope to provide an alternative,'' he said. ``Frankly, we don't believe in Levy's promises.''

DOC.HEAD: Community, Wracked by Slayings, Tries to Begin Healing Process
DOC.TEXT: About 150 people packed a school's music room Thursday night to try to cope with their grief and bafflement over the slayings of a family of five here, reportedly as a cult sacrifice. ``In the last day and a half, I've seen a real positive shift, increasingly toward acceptance and moving on,'' said the Rev. Dale Luffman, pastor of the church where the victims once worshiped. ``We have become more sensitive to how our fellow community members feel, more sensitive to value people more than things,'' Luffman said at the Kirtland High School forum organized by the clergy and community mental health leaders. Kay Plona, the mother of a classmate of one of the victims, said she attended the two-hour session to try to understand the tragedy. ``People are really defensive. Kirtland is a tighly knit community,'' said Mrs. Plona, whose son attended kindergarten with Karen Avery, who was 7 when she was killed. Mrs. Plona said her 8-year-old son was having trouble handling the death of his former classmate. ``I remember the night he came home. He showed me Karen's picture in the yearbook and then he slammed it shut and said he didn't want to open it again.'' Last week authorities, acting on a tip, dug up the bodies of Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their daughters, Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen. A service in remembrance of the Averys was held Wednesday night at the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Kirtland. The Averys, who moved to Kirtland about three years ago from the Independence, Mo. area, attended services here a few times, said Luffman, church pastor. Later, however, they joined a Kirtland cult led by a former lay preacher with the Reorganized Church. Thirteen members of the cult, including the leader, Jeffrey Lundgren, 39, have been charged with crimes including aggravated murder, kidnapping, and conspiracy in the shootings. Lake County Prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette has said the Averys may have been killed as a sacrifice that would cleanse cult members' souls and allow them to travel to the wilderness. Others have suggested that the slayings may have been prompted by disputes over money or sex, or fear that the Averys would leave the sect.

DOC.HEAD: Earth's Home Galaxy Has Football-Shaped Core, Experts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``In other,'' with new ``attractor'' observations
DOC.TEXT: The Milky Way Galaxy, home of the sun and the Earth, has a core shaped like a football instead of the perfectly spherical center many astronomers have long believed, according to a new study. Astronomers at the University of Maryland and Princeton University announced Thursday the discovery of evidence that the spiral arms of the Milky Way actually rotate around an oval center, causing the sun to follow an elliptical path in its 200 million-year orbit of the galaxy center. Leo Blitz of the University of Maryland said that the discovery shows that the Milky Way is a so-called barred spiral galaxy. This means that the spiral arms, composed of stars, gas and other matter, flare out from a so-called bar structure of stars and gas at the center. In a normal spiral galaxy, the arms curve out like spokes from the very center. ``It has been something of a holy grail for astronomers to determine if the Milky Way is a barred spiral or a normal spiral galaxy,'' said Blitz. ``This study shows it is barred.'' The Milky Way galaxy is disk-shaped with a large bulge in the middle. Seen from above, arms flare out like curved spokes, creating a spiral appearance. The galaxy has a diameter of about 100,000 light years and a thickness, seen from the edge, of about 4,000 light years. A light year is the distance light will travel in a year, about 6 trillion miles. In other galactic news, two other astronomers said Thursday they have confirmed that the Milky Way and about 100 other galaxies are being pulled toward a powerful gravitational source called ``the great attractor'' over a region of space 100 million light years wide. The new findings, expanding on preliminary 1987 observations, show galaxies on both sides of the ``attractor'' are swerving toward it in addition to their normal motion away from each other, said Alan Dressler of the Carnegia Instititon of Washington and Sandra Faber of the University of California at Santa Cruz. The sun and its solar system, which includes the Earth, are located in one spoke, about midway out from the galaxy center. That spoke, along with the four other arms of the Milky Way, rotate about the galaxy core. Though the rotation rate of the arm at the sun's location is about 600,000 miles an hour, the galaxy is so large that it takes about 200 million years to complete one rotation, or orbit. Because the sun is away from the middle of the galaxy _ about 25,000 light years from the center _ the galaxy is seen edge-on from the Earth. This means that stars, clouds and dust obscures the view of most of the Milky Way. And this has blocked astronomers from being able to determine the shape of the galaxy center directly. Blitz and David Spergel of Princeton overcame this problem by examining the movement of hydrogen gas clouds in the outer regions of the Milky Way, an area called the galactic halo that surrounds the Milky Way like a globe. Spergel said the hydrogen movement was first studied about 15 years ago, but the motions were never well understood. He said the new study, developed with the help of a computer, showed that movement of the clouds, caused by gravitational influences, could be explained only if there is an ellipsoidal center to the galaxy. ``The center is like a football,'' said Blitz. ``There is absolutely no question about the data on this.'' Since, according to the study, the sun and its solar system move about the galaxy in an ellipse instead of a circle, the sun's distance from the galactic center will change regularly over time. Right now, Blitz and Spergel said the sun is about halfway between its closest approach to the center and the farthest point of its orbit. The sun will reach its outermost point from the galactic center in 25 million years. That is about 1,500 light years farther away than the point of closest approach to the center. ``It's not something we have to worry about,'' said Blitz. A paper on the study was given Thursday at the 175th national meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Transplant Surgeon Says Jarvik Works, Might Defy FDA On Banned Use
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to clarify that Copeland is leading transplant surgeon. SUBS last graf to CORRECT to 159 bridge-to-transplants, sted 155.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Artificial Heart
DOC.TEXT: A leading transplant surgeon said Thursday he might be forced to implant a Jarvik artificial heart if the need arose, despite the FDA's decision to withdraw approval of the device. Jack Copeland, head of the transplant and artificial heart program at the University of Arizona, said there is no scientific basis for the decision earlier this week by the Food and Drug Administration to withdraw approval. The Jarvik heart, named after its inventor, Dr. Robert Jarvik of Utah, gained household recognition after it was implanted in Barney Clark on Dec. 2, 1982. He lived 112 days, his new heart tethered to a bulky external power system, before he succumbed to multiple organ failure. Jarvik, in a statement issued in New York, referred to the Jarvik-7 as ``the Sputnik of medical science in artificial heart development'' and said he ``was disappointed to see this chapter close.'' He said he had ``favored continued research'' but added that he has been working to develop the Jarvik 2000, an egg-sized miniature rotary blood pump to be permanently implanted within a patient's natural heart. The FDA notified Symbion Inc. of Tempe, the only company that has manufactured the Jarvik device, that it was withdrawing approval for human use of the artificial heart, both as a permanent implant and as a temporary bridge to transplantation, and of its acute ventricular assist device. The FDA said that during two inspections of the Tempe, Ariz.-based company last year, it had found ``some serious deficiencies'' in manufacturing quality control, monitoring of research sites, servicing of equipment, training of personnel and reporting of adverse patient reactions to the FDA. Copeland acknowledged that ``the heyday of the Jarvik-7 has passed.'' But he said it still has specific use, and he thinks the immediate effect of the withdrawal of the Symbion devices will be ``to deprive potentially hundreds of critically ill patients of a chance for life.'' Copeland said the FDA action means that for now, his staff faces the option either of not implanting a Symbion artificial heart in a critically ill patient as a bridge to transplant, ``or what would appear to be taking a decision that is not approved by the FDA and putting a device in anyway. ``And I think our decision right now would be to go ahead and use the devices,'' he said. ``We're confident, we have good data, good statistics, we're happy with the way the devices have worked, we think they can save lives.'' Copeland stirred controversy once before, using a different artificial heart without approval to keep a patient alive for 11 hours while he awaited a transplant. Dr. William C. DeVries of Louisville, Ky., who implanted the heart in Clark and three other permanent recipients, all of whom have died, said he had not yet been notified by Symbion or the FDA. He said he would not comment until he had received official notice of the recall. In Jasper, Ind., Margaret Schroeder, the widow of artificial heart recipient William Schroeder, said the heart gave her husband another 620 days of life that he otherwise wouldn't have had. ``I'm sure that he would have even died the next day, when he got the heart on the 25th of November, if they hadn't got him on that Jarvik heart,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``And at that time, I think that's the only thing that was available.'' Copeland said he would be willing to testify before the FDA to defend the efficacy of the Jarvik and other devices. He said the Jarvik-7 is the best device available for people weighing more than 180 pounds with double-sided heart failure. The greater loss, he said, is the Symbion biventricular pumps. Copeland's team has implanted Jarvik-7s in seven patients, including two in Bernadette Chayrez, with six going on to transplant and four of them surviving. Five patients received left ventricular assist devices and nine biventricular devices, with four, who went on to transplant, surviving, he said. In all, there have been 159 bridge-to-transplants with Jarvik-7 hearts since 1985 and 116 biventricular implants since 1986, said Lane Castleton, chief financial officer for Symbion.

Drink for drink, women get drunker than men. Now scientists believe they know why: Men have more stomach for booze. A study published today found that men typically make higher amounts of a substance that breaks down alcohol in the stomach before it reaches the bloodstream. As a result, men feel fewer effects of alcohol, even when men and women the same size drink the same amount. ``I am convinced that there are sex differences in handling alcohol,'' commented Dr. Judith Gavaler of the University of Pittsburgh. ``This is a very important study for all of us doing research in alcohol. This will change the way we approach this subject.'' Researchers said the study also underscores concerns about drinking during pregnancy, provides an explanation on the effects of drinking on an empty stomach and could be used to help set safe drinking levels for men and women.

China's announced lifting of martial law is receiving muted praise from the Bush administration, while members of Congress express doubt that Beijing is about to improve its record on human rights. Moving cautiously, U.S. officials said Wednesday that they would reserve judgment until the announcement by Premier Li Peng was implemented. More upbeat, Vice President Dan Quayle called the announcement ``a positive step forward for human rights.'' But the White House and State Department reflected a cautious U.S. policy stance by issuing identical statements saying ``we must assess the full scope of this action after observing its implementation.'' The Bush administration dropped its opposition to World Bank loans to China for earthquakes and other unspecified calamities, but officials said the step was not related to the lifting of sanctions and that the United States would continue to oppose loans to China for projects.

Neighbors and strangers jammed a memorial service for a family of five who authorities say were shot and buried under a barn by a religious cult, possibly as a sacrifice. As about 250 people filled the small brick church Wednesday night to pay respects to the Avery family, authorities in Southern California said they arrested the last two members of the cult, ending a nationwide manhunt for 13 people accused in the slayings. Law officers stopped a pickup truck about 60 miles northeast of San Diego and arrested Daniel David Kraft and Kathryn Johnson, said agent James Stathes of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in California. In Kirtland, five pink candles burned at the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints for 49-year-old Dennis Avery; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters: Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7.

Astronomers at the U.S. Naval Observatory are narrowing their solar system search for a 10th planet, a mysterious, phantom giant that has long captured the speculation and interest of stargazers. Speculation about the existence of another planet evolved because something, perhaps a massive object orbiting the sun on the outer edge of the solar system, is giving a gravitational nudge that disrupts the predicted orbits of Uranus and Neptune, said astronomer R.S. Harrington. ``We are still incapable of predicting the location of Uranus,'' Harrington said Wednesday. ``It's clear something is wrong in the outer solar system.'' Astronomers have theorized since the beginning of the century that some additional planets existed beyond the orbits of Neptune. The theory sprang from observations that Uranus failed to orbit the sun with the majestic and mathematical symmetry experts expected.

DOC.HEAD: School's Out for Graffiti Students in Sweden
DOC.TEXT: City authorities didn't call on the police to take care of Stockholm's graffiti problem. They sent teen-age graffiti artists to school where they lived out their aggression, believed to be the underlying reason people spray a wall. Not only was there a sharp decline in graffiti, said teacher Lee Spangberg, but a lot of artistic talent was found among those who had been merely defacing walls. Money ran out and the school has closed. But social workers involved in the project believe it was a good example of the way social offenders should be handled _ with guidance and rehabilitation, not punishment. Spangberg, 18, admits to having scrawled on some walls before he became a teacher at the school when it opened last March. He has a business card that says, ``You Say It, I'll Spray It.'' The project was set up in an empty high school in central Stockholm. ``As soon as we opened up, everybody knew about it,'' Spangberg said. Spray-can wielders from 8 to 25 years old came in four weekdays after school for a few hours of ``living out their aggressions,'' he said. ``We didn't exactly stand at the blackboard and tell them how to sit down and the rest,'' he said. ``You would just throw down the spray cans on the floor and there'd be an explosion of activity. ``It was not the kind of school where guys came along with spray cans in their attache cases. The vandals came here.'' ``The ones who came to us had a pain in their souls,'' said fellow teacher Sven-Arne Hokenstrom. Social officials claimed graffiti lessened by more than half while the school operated. The national government awarded it a medal in October for reducing vandalism. Then the project's $27,500 fund ran out and the group lost the lease on the school building Nov. 1. ``Now they're all out there again on the street,'' Spangberg said. Of 150 pupils, about a dozen had serious artistic ambitions and came for advice, Spangberg said. But youth centers seeking to decorate their walls with controlled graffiti began to call the school to hire young artists. Some people wanted their motorbikes or boats decorated. Some pupils found they could get painting jobs that paid as much as $320. Inger Wissen, a social worker who thought up the project and headed it, said the idea of a graffiti school was born in 1987, when a wave of vandalism led to public calls for tougher police action aginst the young. ``According to insurance company statistics, scribblings went down by between 50 and 70 percent'' after the school opened, Wissen said. She added that she hoped authorities would grant the project more money so it could reopen. Ragnar Backman, who heads Stockholm's Department for the Removal of Scribbling, said graffiti lessened considerably last summer. He said the city spent $406,000 to wash away names, political slogans and drawings in 1989. Backman roams the city in a small van equipped with chemical cleansers. He said he feels no regret in removing graffiti; ``most of it is simply messy.'' In April, the graffiti students showed off their skill at an exibition in a Stockholm gallery. In August, 50 spray-can artists went to a youth fair at Strangnas, outside Stockholm, where they painted for spectators. ``Police guarded them,'' Spangberg said. Now, the doors and windows of the graffiti school are bolted and barred. The building is deserted, its outside walls covered in graffiti left over from eight months of classes. ``What the authorities didn't count on was that the guys would spray not only every single wall inside the school, but also everything outside it,'' Spangberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Thais No Longer Turn Noses up at Milk and Cheese
DOC.TEXT: Not long ago many Thais thought milk made them sick and cheese was smelly stuff, but a younger generation is gulping down milk and devouring cheese-topped pizzas all across Bangkok. ``I think the nutritional qualities of milk are well-understood here,'' said Mauri Uotila, of the Bangkok office of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. ``People here see tall European and American people drinking a lot of milk. I think, like all parents, they want taller children with stronger bones.'' In keeping with an Asia-wide trend, consumption of milk in Thailand has gone up 56 percent from 1986 to 1988, and cheese imports have more than doubled over the past three years. It's quite a nutritional shift for a country where milk was once thought fit only for infants and young children. But Thailand's milk consumption, averaging 9.4 quarts a year per person, is still the lowest in Southeast Asia. Japanese average an annual 75.5 quarts while Americans down 132 quarts, according to Att Senasarn, general manager for Nestle Products Inc. in Thailand. The penetration of Western ways is also cited as a factor; thousands of Thais return from studies in the United States with a taste for milk shakes, pizzas and yogurt. Although the Thai dairy industry has been growing rapidly, it still produces only a third of the 500,000 tons of milk consumed yearly. The rest is imported. Hard to find less than a decade ago, fresh milk now takes its place next to soft drinks at streetside stands in Bangkok. And grocery stores are stocked with a bright array of more than a dozen different brands and types of sweetened, flavored, plain and lowfat milk. Nestle's Senasarn said that 85 percent of all milk consumed in Thailand is sweetened or flavored. ``The big problem in marketing is with taste. I think the so-called lactose intolerance problem has more to do with the question of taste,'' he said. It has been claimed that the greatest obstruction in promoting milk drinking in Thailand and other parts of Asia has been the prevalence of lactose intolerance among many Asians. ``Many people here say they can't drink milk, but actually in many cases its because they don't like it rather than because it gives them stomach trouble,'' he said. Uotila said that if a person stops drinking milk over a long enough period of time, the enzyme in the body necessary to digest lactose in the milk disappears and the person could encounter stomach problems including diarrhea from drinking milk. He said there are no statistics available on lactose intolerance in Asia, so it is difficult to know the extent of the problem. About six years ago, the government began promoting milk, and slogans _ ``Have you drunk your milk today?'' _ appeared on billboards, television, and radio all over the country. ``The program was not so popular,'' said Dr. Sirikul Isanurug of the Ministry of Health. ``People thought milk was not for adults. This was the old concept still in mind. The government was trying to get all parts of society to drink milk but it's not part of Thai culture.'' However unpopular the campaign may have been, awareness and acceptance of milk increased considerably, according to Eric Simon, director of Foremost Friesland Dairies, one of the leading dairy companies in the country. The major milk campaign has let up in recent years, and efforts are now being channeled into making milk available in schools, said Jiradej Sakulneya at the state-run Dairy Farming Promotion Organization. ``We are aiming milk promotion at the younger generation, particularly those in schools because they are the most affected by malnutrition and are the easiest to convert,'' he said. ``The older generation is pretty useless because they are not used to it and have problems with their stomachs.''

DOC.HEAD: Buffalo Makes Startling Recovery After Brush With Extinction
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There's more capitalism than altruism these days behind the resurgence of the once nearly extinct buffalo _ the shaggy animals are easier to raise, fetch more per pound and are lower in fat and cholesterol than beef. The buffalo, which once roamed the Great Plains like a moving black robe, was hunted for meat and hides in such great numbers that historians say by 1889 fewer than 600 remained. Since 1970, the number of buffalo has doubled in this country to about 60,000, according to the American Bison Association. About 400 stockmen, ranchers like Brian Ward of Center, have gone into the buffalo because of a beef market made unstable by American eating habits. Ward runs 1,700 head on his 100,000-acre spread in southern Colorado's San Luis Valley and sells about 100,000 pounds of boneless meat a year. ``We get long winters in this valley,'' he said. ``The buffalo hide's thicker (than cattle), they got a lot more hair and they eat and tend to be more like wild animals _ store fat in the fall and their metabolism slows down in the winter, so they require less feed. ``There are some exciting times. We drive them about 35 miles to pasture and back every year cross country. We used to use horses but we use motorcycles now. The buffalo don't charge the cycles as bad as they do horses.'' The price of good buffalo breeding stock has doubled in the past five years to about $1,500 for a young breed cow, twice what a comparable beef cow brings, according to the Denver-based ABA. But buffalo meat also brings twice the price of beef, and it's lean meat. A 3-ounce serving has 93 calories, compared to 183 for beef; 43 milligrams of cholesterol, compared to 55 for beef; and 1.8 grams of fat. compared to 8.7 for beef, the association says. A buffalo cow can bear calves for 30 years or more, while a cow is usually sent to slaughter after about 10. Stockmen can also sell skulls for $100 or so, uncured robes for $6 to $12 a square foot, and mountable heads for $400 on up. The symbol of the American West is an imposing animal. It has a black-brown, shaggy head and cape and short curved black horns. A mature bull stands more than 6 feet tall at its hump and weighs 2,000 pounds. A century ago, the buffalo was nearly exterminated as the railroads pushed westward. The slaughter was triggered by demand for meat to feed the rail crews and the crowded East, a new tanning method that let the spongy hides be used as leather, and political expediency _ to destroy the Plains Indians' food supply. Historian Francis Haines said ``the rush of new hunters to the Kansas plains resembled the stampede to a new gold strike. ... In the spring of 1872 ... the constant booming of the big guns sounded more like a battle than a hunt.'' In 1872, Col. Richard Irving Dodge wrote there was ``apparently no limit to the number of buffaloes.'' A year later, he found ``myriads of carcasses, The air was foul with a sickening stench and the vast plain, which only 12 short months before teemed with animal life, was a dead, solitary putrid plain.'' Historians estimate 6.3 million buffalo were killed in seven years. The Plains Indians, whose society depended on the buffalo for food, shelter and clothing, either starved or surrendered. Their lives were so miserable the ``Ghost Dance'' cult sprang up, preaching that whites would be buried and the buffalo would return. The Army's massacre of 200 Sioux at Wounded Knee at the end of 1890 ended the ``Ghost Dance'' movement. It wasn't until the early 20th century that buffalo preservation became a concern. The newly created American Bison Society and President Teddy Roosevelt were able to convince Congress to set up preserves in Oklahoma and Montana in 1907. By then there were several hundred buffalo in private herds. ``It was the ranchers who really took it upon themselves to save the bison,'' said Duane Lammers, president of the ABA. ``Some of those early people who wanted to save the buffaloes had Indian heritage, some had Indian wives. It was very important to them to save the bison. ... ``I think, too, it was just out of genuine care for them.'' Buffalo stockmen warn that the bison remains a wild animal, extremely powerful and territorial. There is an old saying that you can push a buffalo anywhere it wants to go. Another is never turn your back on a buffalo. But the advantages are apparent as well. ``They are easier to take care of,'' said Lammers, who runs about 1,000 head on his Triple Seven ranch in South Dakota. ``Beef producers are living with their cow herds during the calving season. That first spring when we didn't have cattle we went through calving here with free time. It was like a couple of weeks off,'' he said. ``If a storm comes up, I'm not losing sleep over my cattle. With my buffalo, I can just sleep through the night.''

DOC.HEAD: Life After `Chicken Soup' for Lynn Redgrave
DOC.TEXT: Last summer, Lynn Redgrave filmed an ABC spoof of juries, ``Jury Duty: The Comedy.'' Almost everyone in the cast was in an ABC series then, she says, and she was about to be. ``Unfortunately,'' she mused this week, ``mine is demised, as I'm sure you're only too aware.'' Indeed. ``Chicken Soup,'' wherein she played an Irish widow to Jackie Mason's Yiddish-accented former pajama salesman, went poof, amid much publicity, on Nov. 7. It was a quick yank for a new series of great expectations but declining ratings. Redgrave, of the English acting dynasty, has been an actress since 1962. She has seen works in which she was involved go poof before. But it was a new experience to have it happen just before a run-through of a new episode. The actress, whose ``Jury Duty'' finally is airing this Sunday, still recalls that dark day in a Hollywood studio, when a ``Chicken Soup'' run-through was halted by the arrival of executive producers Bernie Orenstein and Saul Turteltaub. Orenstein had a toddy in hand, she says, ``and I thought, `This is not a good sign. These are very professional writers, producers, they don't drink during the working day ... something's wrong with this picture.' ``And indeed it was.'' Redgrave's disposition tends to be sunny side up. She does not live on Rue Regret. The acting profession has been very, very good to her, starting in the '60s with her London stage debut in ``A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and first film hit, ``Georgy Girl.'' Still, she wishes the lords of ABC had let ``Soup'' brew a bit longer, as future plots called for more of a love-hate relationship between her and Mason: ``I'd become somewhat becalmed in the early shows, a loving, always-supporting person, which does not for comedy make. But we were heading more into Laurel and Hardy, a bit of `Here's another fine mess you've got me into.' ``It would have been fun. It's just a shame that nobody saw fit to see it through a bit further.'' But ``next'' is the slogan of the acting profession. So, after ``Soup'' shut down, Redgrave and her husband-manager John Clark, who've lived for 10 years in Los Angeles, adjourned to New York, where they keep an apartment. They took a breather from the TV ramble by returning to the stage, where their respective careers began. They guest-acted for a December week on Broadway in A.R. Gurney's ``Love Letters,'' a play about the friendship and romance of a couple from childhood to adulthood, all told through letters and other correspondence. The two hadn't acted together since meeting in the late '60s in a British television drama, she said, but ``Love Letters'' was such great fun they plan to do it again for two weeks in San Francisco, starting Jan. 23. While here, Redgrave also teamed up with her older, equally famous sister, Vanessa, and Sigourney Weaver, in a just-for-kicks staged reading of the final scene from Chekhov's ``The Three Sisters.'' That was fun, too, she says. ``I'm hoping we can do the whole play soon, perhaps first in England, then New York. I hope we can do it before we get too old and have to call it `The Three Grandmothers.' '' Television again someday? ``Oh, I'd love to,'' Redgrave says. ``These things (series) come and go. But you never know. Each season comes along, and what a crap shoot it is.''

Elsewhere in television... CABLE SALUTES CABLE _ This Sunday, the ever-growing cable industry is holding its 11th annual ACE Awards show _ the equivalent of over-the-air TV's Emmys. Cable's big show, in Los Angeles, starts at 8 p.m. EST. Unlike the Emmys, shown only on one network each year, Sunday's festivities will be simultaneously shown on 12 cable networks. They include Ted Turner's TBS Superstation and TNT network; NBC-owned CNBC; The Discovery Channel, and even SportsChannel America. GOOD START FOR ``GOOD MORNING'' _ ABC's ``Good Morning America'' narrowly edged NBC's ``Today'' in ratings for the New Year's first week. ABC's show averaged a 4.0 rating for the week of Jan. 1-5. ``Today,'' on its first week without Jane Pauley, had a 3.8. ``CBS This Morning'' remained a distant third with a 2.4 average. Each rating point represents 921,000 homes. Ratings for this week _ the first week of co-hosting by Pauley's successor, Deborah Norville _ aren't due until next Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: BOSTON: Boston Harbor.
DOC.TEXT: Even in death, Stuart continued to fool people. The first word of his suicide prompted sympathy and sorrow from the DiMaitis, who were expecting him that night for dinner. Mrs. DiMaiti had even checked what foods Chuck could easily digest because of his stomach wounds and resultant colostomy. ``We were grieving for Chuck because we thought he killed himself through grief,'' said Carl DiMaiti. ``He couldn't go on without Carol and Christopher. My God, he's thrown himself off the bridge in the ultimate act of love. Then, to find out from the police that he was a prime suspect, it was more than you can take.'' The DiMaitis were devastated. Giusto, 64, who had open heart surgery a few years ago, was rushed to a hospital, gasping for breath with his blood pressure rising. His wife could not stop crying. Carol was their only daughter. Her father had paid her way through law school by laboring as a pizza dough maker. Many others touched earlier by the attack on the Stuarts, such as the emergency medical crews and McLaughlin, the dispatcher, felt revulsion at the revelations. ``It's a pretty remarkable turn of events, very bizarre and twisted, a horrific ending to the real tragedy,'' McLaughlin said. ``Anyone familiar with the case would have ... an empty feeling about it, especially the people involved in the mission, police and nurses.'' Others felt fury and anger. Stuart's original story about a black assailant touched off a vast manhunt. Police fanned out through the Mission Hill neighborhood, frisking black men. State politicians called for the reinstatement of the death penalty. ``When I ordered an aggressive police response ... I wanted to send a strong signal ... to show the city's outrage,'' Mayor Raymond Flynn said. Three weeks after the murder, William Bennett, a 39-year-old paroled convict with a long record of violence, including the shooting of a police officer, was arrested and held on a warrant for a motor vehicle violation. Bennett became the prime suspect in the Stuart case after grand jury witnesses said he had boasted of committing the crime. Stuart's suicide cleared Bennett, but black leaders were furious. They asserted that Bennett had been railroaded, that his and other blacks' constitutional rights had been violated. They accused law officers of being all too willing to narrow their investigation to the black community. Paul Leary, first assistant district attorney of Suffolk County, retorted that black neighborhood residents themselves had led police to Bennett as the No. 1 suspect. ``Folks, Charles Stuart took us all in,'' said Flynn.

DOC.HEAD: Suburban Man's Murder Plot Inflames Wounds in Boston's Black Community
With BC-Stuart-Death and Decei
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart's cold-hearted scheme to kill his pregnant wife didn't just dupe the police and a sympathetic nation. By setting the crime in a racially mixed neighborhood and concocting a black assailant, he also ignited a tinderbox of resentment and smoldering anger among Boston blacks. Leaders of the black community say racial stereotypes helped Stuart elude suspicion until he killed himself, 2{ months after claiming a black mugger shot him and his wife. ``Stuart used the idea of a black man doing violence to a white woman because it was probably the most reasonable thing he could say to cover up his wrongdoings,'' said Paul Parks, a veteran activist and former state secretary of education. Police and city officials have been shaken by the force of the outcry, but they repeatedly note that they had no reason to doubt Stuart's claim until his brother turned him in Jan. 3. When Stuart's suicide cleared William Bennett _ never charged but frequently named in police leaks to reporters _ an angry community erupted and Bennett, a man with a history of violence and arrests, became an odd cause celebre. ``It was not just Bennett,'' said City Councilor Charles Yancey. ``It was the sense that the entire community of color was somehow being blamed for this awful killing.'' Community and church leaders held news conferences, blasting police, city officials and the news media. Some called on the mayor and police commissioner to resign. ``What there has been is a release of feelings from this community,'' said Georgette Watson, founder of Drop-A-Dime drug tip hotline. ``There is the release of the hurt that we've been holding inside and the shame that's been felt over this particular crime.'' Blacks say black victims never get the kind of attention paid the Stuarts. They assert that the police squads who flooded the Mission Hill area, where the shootings were alleged to have taken place, ran roughshod over residents in their hunt for clues. ``The police went wild. It was like wartime,'' said Martha Knight, an organizer at the Mission Main Task Force, who said her 25-year-old son was among the many residents stopped by police. ``Before he knew it, he was surrounded,'' she said. ``The cops told him to go into the hallway and drop his pants, then his underwear ... ``You couldn't send a kid to the corner store because before they got back they'd been searched and questioned at least once. And you can't tell me everybody they stopped and searched fit the description.'' Most of Boston's blacks live mainly in the Roxbury, Mattapan and Dorchester neighborhoods. Few are seen amid the everyday bustle in the financial, tourist, capitol and shopping sections of the city, whose population of 562,994 includes 126,229 blacks and 36,068 Hispanics. It is a minority community still scarred by the violence of forced busing, and more recently by redlining and police stops of suspected gang members on the street. ``Charles Stuart touched the sore that was left by racial wounds in this city,'' said the Rev. Bruce Wall, who counsels gang members. ``If you listened to the radio talk shows the day after the killing,'' Wall said, ``you heard the white community ... calling black people animals and saying blacks should go back to Africa.'' But Wall was also distressed by the attention accorded the claims of some black leaders that the police had conspired to railroad a black man and to conceal the real crime. ``For my elected officials and for ministers to stand up and vent rage ... that is not the scene that we want people to see of this community,'' said Wall. ``It bothered me and a lot of people that we couldn't come together and make one statement with a united voice.'' Mayor Raymond Flynn, whose tenure has been noted for efforts to establish urban harmony, has tried to emphasize that much of the impact of the Stuart case comes from extreme circumstances. Almost forgotten in the uproar of the last 10 days is how the widely publicized transcript of Stuart's dramatic pleas for help over his car phone riveted the public's attention in October. Without that recording of a 911 operator's desperate efforts to help Stuart, the story might have faded away as just another urban crime tragedy. Said Edith Flynn, a professor of criminology at Northeastern University, ``What I think has happened has been a collision of longstanding prejudices with a very bizarre case.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Jan. 14

DOC.HEAD: Animal Acupuncture: Needling Horses Back to Health
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The patient quivered as William McCormick applied pressure to pinpoint the source of back pain. Then he inserted a needle. No problem this time, though sometimes the patients try to bite _ or kick. McCormick, one of about 125 U.S. veterinarians certified to practice acupuncture, says the therapy used by the Chinese on humans and animals for 3,500 years is an effective alternative to Western medicine. ``The potential is vast. I feel each time I do it I'm touching on new ground.'' Acupuncture, whether in humans or animals, consists of stimulating precise points on the surface of the body. Traditionally, the stimulus is insertion of extremely fine needles; more recently, ultrasound and lasers also are used. In traditional Chinese thought, each human or animal is born with a fixed amount of energy, called ``chi.'' Energy imbalance, from external or internal causes, is thought to be the underlying reason for disease. By treating certain reflex points, the acupuncturist helps the body balance its own vital energies. Laboratory studies have found that this balancing occurs primarily through the nervous system, although physiological mechanisms such as hormones also are involved, the International Veterinary Acupuncture Society says. Balancing can adjust blood flow, nerve and muscle tone, hormone levels or organ function. Dr. Meredith L. Snader of Chester Springs, Pa., executive secretary of the society, uses acupuncture exclusively in her practice. ``People are looking to alternative methods of treatment rather than going to drugs,'' Ms. Snader said. ``The public is demanding that vets change, instead of pumping animals full of medication.'' The American Veterinary Medical Association endorsed acupuncture in 1988 as valid treatment, but it hasn't been totally accepted by veterinarians. ``Some think it is pretty strange and others accept it quite readily,'' said McCormick. Ms. Snader said her colleagues were skeptical when she started using acupuncture eight years ago. ``It didn't bother me. I said, `Just give me a chance.' Now most of them are very willing. Now they refer clients to me.'' Acupuncture makes up a major part of McCormick's practice in Virginia's horse country, where many owners and trainers insist on it. ``My clients have come to expect expertise from me on that _ mostly because the horses have done well,'' he said. ``At its best, it's effective 80 percent of the time.'' Acupuncture started out as a small part of Ms. Snader's practice, but ``the demand became so great that I had to give up my traditional practice because I did not have time to do it.'' While McCormick and Ms. Snader deal primarily with horses, acupuncture can be used on any animal. ``The Chinese use it on chickens, pigs, camels, water buffaloes,'' said McCormick. ``You could use it on snakes for that matter.'' Kitty Beveridge, who trains show horses at her Wind in the Willows farm near Middleburg, swears by the technique. As McCormick applied needles to a horse, she described the ``dramatic turnaround'' of a 3-year-old thoroughbred treated for pain in its back and legs. ``He became much more relaxed through work and didn't try to hurry.'' At Wind in the Willows, McCormick treated three horses Ms. Beveridge planned to take to Florida for winter shows. He worked quickly, inserting needles into the horses' backs, haunches and legs as she held their halters. A chestnut roan swung its head in a half-hearted attempt to nip McCormick, an expert on such equine disrespect after having horses kick him in the face and lie down on him. The worst he's suffered is a broken tooth. ``Working back on this end, a kick could kill you,'' McCormick said as he inserted needles in an animal's hindquarters. He administered a mild sedative to two of the horses at Wind in the Willows to cut down on rambunctious behavior as he made his way under and around them. He said the needles themselves cause little pain and rarely require anesthesia. While needles are the preferred implement, portable, battery-operated lasers sometimes are used on sensitive reflex points because they are less intrusive than needles. Ultrasound machines provide deep heat and are useful for such diseases as arthritis. In addition to chronic pain, acupuncture is used to treat a wide variety of animal ailments, including reproductive, urinary tract and abdominal problems, though McCormick said it's not effective for such problems as broken limbs or acute bacterial infections that require antibiotics. He recalled the case of an expensive race horse with an abdominal problem. The owner spent $5,000 for surgery and $5,000 for treatment of colitis, but the horse kept having pain. When he was called in he performed a $150 acupuncture treatment, and the animal didn't have the problem again. Ms. Snader said acupuncture usually produces a positive response within minutes. ``Usually at the end of my treatment I see a reasonable improvement,'' she said. ``Over the next several days I see changes in gait.'' Although animal acupuncture was brought to the United States in the early 1970s when President Richard M. Nixon re-established ties with China, it isn't taught in veterinary schools, said Dr. Kent Roberts, an associate professor at the Virginia-Maryland Regional College of Veterinary Medicine. To receive certification, veterinarians must take a 120-hour course offered by the acupuncture society. Acceptance would become more widespread if it was included in veterinary education, Roberts said, but he sees little chance of that happening because ``we're pretty well pushed to get everything into a 4-year curriculum.'' Still, he believes acupuncture is a legitimate therapy. ``It certainly has stood the test of time. It must have some validity.''
