DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Discover New Tomb in Pyramids' Shadow
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A tomb built 4,300 years ago for a palace official and his two wives has been found in the shadow of the Giza Pyramids, the first unknown tomb discovered on the plateau since the mid-1950s. ``This is the first time we've seen such a tomb,'' said Zahi Hawass, director general of the pyramids area. ``We can find no parallel to this tomb during the Old Kingdom.'' Giza inspector Mahmoud Hassan Afife found the new tomb in October when he chanced upon the edge of a limestone wall. ``We looked at the old records to see what early excavators had recorded in this spot. There was nothing.'' Hieroglyphics revealed the tomb owner's name, that he was a ``purification priest'' who handled religious rituals, and that he was a palace official. Hawass dates it to the end of the Fifth Dynasty, about 200 years after the death in 2528 B.C. of Pharaoh Cheops, builder of the Great Pyramid. Built of limestone blocks, the 26-foot by 66-foot oblong tomb, called a mastaba, stands over a shaft 23 feet deep that was sealed with mud bricks after bodies were lowered into it. The mastaba had no inner chambers. On one side, ancient artists carved two false doors with the owner's name, Per-N-Ankh. The doors face a courtyard with six limestone columns describing him and his wives Mitrt Nefer and N-Hwy. The winter archaeology season was a month old when Afife found the tomb, and vigorous excavation has continued since. On a recent morning, a sandstorm so engulfed the dig that workers used rubber buckets to shield their heads from the sand. Debris cascaded onto the tomb's base faster than diggers could dig. Suddenly, from deep in a shaft, a workman yelled, ``gumgumah,'' Arabic for ``skull.'' As a man above slowly turned a pulley, a reddish-gold skull creaked its way up the pit. It appears to be a female's, in excellent condition. Such a find testifies to the site's value. Nearby pits have yielded piles of pottery shards, bones and wooden pieces that officials said might be part of a bed or other funerary furniture to accompany the dead into the afterlife. In an adjacent tomb were two limestone statues of wives of pharaonic officials. Hawass said he knew valuable leftovers would emerge from re-excavation of the vast Western Cemetery, begun in the fifth year of Cheops' reign. Officials and their families used the cemetery over the centuries, building limestone and mud-brick tombs along avenues of various sizes. ``Some Egyptologists thought the area wouldn't give anything else, but they're wrong. Early excavators were in a hurry, Indiana Jones-style. Some even used dynamite,'' he said. ``This tomb lies at the edge of the cemetery. Earlier this century archaeologists dumped their dirt onto these hills without checking to see if anything interesting lay underneath. ``Chances are even more tombs still lie just over there.'' Excavating leftovers is ``never a waste of time, never busywork,'' said Amal Samuel, Giza's chief inspector, who estimates that as many as 4,000 tombs and pits exist in the area known as the Western Cemetery. ``When people dug in the past they only searched for treasure. Today, we're looking for history. We never think if we'll find something or not.'' Last spring archaeologists clearing another part of the cemetery found the well-preserved, gypsum-masked head of a female mummy from about the same period, her faint smile reminiscent of the Mona Lisa's. Giza Plateau has two great cemeteries: the Eastern, between the Great Pyramid and the Sphinx, and the Western, wedged between the pyramids of Cheops and Chephren. Generally, queens and royal offspring are buried in the Eastern Cemetery, officials and their families in the Western. The cemeteries of mastabas were arranged in parallel rows several feet apart, with ownership planned carefully. Everybody wanted to be buried in the pyramids area, seeking special benefits in life after death. Over the years, as demand increased, the symmetry went askew. Small tombs of officials and priests were placed among the once neat rows until the area was honeycombed. ``We have to think of these cemeteries as a community that surrounded the king with the same feeling as when he was alive,'' said Hawass. ``At the top of his pyramid is the pharaoh, the head of his country. Around him lay those who would have been near him, his family and officials. ... Those closest are in the Eastern cemetery, just like in a palace.''

DOC.HEAD: Twists to Natural Process Solve Wastewater Problems
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nature's way of recycling water gets some wet and wild twists in machines Bill Williamson builds to clean up hazardous wastes for industries ranging from nuclear power to perfume. ``There's a whole new science that we've got to learn,'' said Williamson, 74, who's been experimenting with evaporation and condensation since World War II, when he developed machines that distilled sea water aboard warships. Williamson, a mechanical engineer, turned his attention to fighting pollution 14 years ago when he and his sons, Bruce and Rod, founded the small but fast-growing Licon Inc. in Pensacola. ``We are doing some weird things. Some smart physical chemists, when they see what we are doing, they just throw up their hands,'' he said. Licon produces evaporators that clean up wastewater and let industries concentrate and reuse toxic metals and chemicals that once went down the drain into the environment. Some plants that use the machines don't even have sewers. The evaporators, with a patented heat exchanger, operate at relatively low temperatures, high efficiency and low cost, said Rod Williamson. They can treat wastewater for 1 or 2 cents a gallon compared to as much as 12 cents for other machines and up to $2 for disposal in a hazardous waste dump, he said. One is being tested at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant; NuPac Services plans to use it to decontaminate 2.3 million gallons of water irradiated in the 1979 accident that shut down the Harrisburg, Pa., plant. Licon evaporators, which cost $14,000 to $250,000, are in use in the United States, Canada and Europe. Most are in metal plating plants, although one is cleaning up shampoo wastes at an Alberto Culver plant in Puerto Rico. Customers can be found in nearly any industry that produces liquid hazardous waste, but there are limits, Rod Williamson said. Some industries, including paper mills and chemical factories, produce too much wastewater to be efficiently treated with evaporators now being produced, he said. Bill Williamson, who holds 30 patents, said the key to the machines is low air pressure. When boiled, even freshwater leaves a scale, although the residue is much worse with saltwater or wastewater and would quickly foul and corrode a conventional evaporator. He said he discovered that heating water in a whole or partial vacuum, thereby lowering its boiling point, would reduce the scale and permit recovering specific salts for reuse. The machines also reuse heat the way a heat pump improves a home heating and air conditioning system. Williamson began working on desalinization while employed by Maxim Silencer Corp., which specialized in equipment to muffle diesel engines. It was asked to develop a way to purify saltwater aboard Coast Guard cutters so that they could escort convoys in World War II. The cutters were too small to carry enough fuel and water to cross the ocean, but could make the trip if water storage areas were used instead for fuel oil, he said. The company rented a beachfront house at Clinton, Conn., to test the machine. Its resemblance to a moonshiner's still prompted neighbors to call the police. At first, officers who raided the place didn't believe the machine was producing nothing stronger than water but, ``They looked at it and tasted it and said `OK,''' Williamson said. He later worked on similar equipment for nuclear submarines and in 1970 helped set up a desalting test station near the Panhandle resort town of Destin for Mechanical Equipment Co. of New Orleans. Williamson and his sons then formed Licon, short for ``liquid conditioning'' or ``liquid concentration,'' and built its first evaporator in his garage out of pipe fittings and other parts they bought or made.

DOC.HEAD: Comet Austin May Put on a Big Show, But Astronomers Hedge Bets
DOC.TEXT: Recently discovered Comet Austin may put on a big show in the eastern sky at dawn in late April and early May, delighting sky watchers who needed binoculars to get a decent peek at Halley's Comet. Comet West in 1976 was the last time a comet provided spectacular view for naked-eye observers, and ``It's high time we had another one!'' said Leif Robinson, editor of Sky & Telescope magazine. But the magazine's editors, wary because of past comet predictions gone awry, also warned that Comet Austin ``could turn out to be just another run-of-the-mill faint comet undergoing a temporary brightening.'' For the rest of the winter, Comet Austin will be barely above the western horizon after sunset, likely visible only to careful observers with binoculars or telescopes and charts telling them exactly where to look. In early April, it will pass 32 million miles from the sun, which will vaporize large comet ice to create a tail of gas and dust millions of miles long, Sky & Telescope said. The best viewing will be in late April and the first week of May, when the comet, speeding toward Earth, should shine in the eastern sky at the first light of dawn with its tail pointing upward. ``If it becomes as bright as hoped, you'll be able to just step outdoors and see Comet Austin hanging among stars at the first beginnings of daybreak,'' at least in areas away from city lights, the editors said. Comet Austin was discovered Dec. 6, when it was 230 million miles from the sun, by amateur astronomer Rodney R.D. Austin of New Plymouth, New Zealand.
DOC.HEAD: Scientists Figure Out the Shape of Eros: Rounded Trapezoid
DOC.TEXT: NASA scientists used radar to figure out the shape of Eros, an asteroid named after the Greek god of love. But it's not a very sexy hunk of rock. Eros is a ``rounded trapezoid'' _ in other words, it looks roughly like a baking potato. Steven Ostro and colleagues at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory used a new approach to studying radar waves that were bounced off Eros in January 1975. They learned that Eros is nearly 22 miles long, 9 wide and 8 thick. It rotates on its short axis, so it appears to tumble end-over-end every five hours and 16 minutes, laboratory spokesman Jim Doyle said. Ostro recently outlined his findings during a meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco. His paper was titled ``The Shape of Eros.'' Eros was discovered in 1898. It's orbit crosses Mars' orbit. Eros made its closest approach to Earth this century in January 1975 when it was 14 million miles away. A few months later, it was observed using radar at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goldstone, Calif., facility.

DOC.HEAD: Targeting Fats Likely to Help Weight Loss
DOC.TEXT: By now, the resolutions of even the most resolute New Year's dieters may be wearing thin _ especially if the dieter is not. Americans seem forever to be dieting and falling for the latest ``miracle'' way to a thinner body. But experts insist it is only through a permanent change in behavior that any weight loss plan can be effective. Specialists lately are focusing on two factors: exercise and dietary fat. ``Overall if there's anything people agree with among nutritionists, it's that you should cut back on dietary fats,'' said Dr. Helene Swenerton of the cooperative extension nutrition office at the University of California, Davis. Ron and Nancy Goor and Katherine Boyd, authors of ``The Choose to Lose Diet'' (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95), advise, ``Don't focus on total calories ... or sugar ... or starch. Focus on fat.'' Eat pasta and potatoes, they say. ``Carbohydrates are the good guys.'' Because fat is often a big component of food that's not real nutritious anyway, and because it's more calorie-dense, it's a good target for dieters. ``Fats are twice as concentrated as carbohydrates or proteins,'' said Jayne Newmark, a dietician at the Arizona Heart Institute and a spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association. One gram of protein or carbohydrate has four calories; one gram of fat has at least nine. ``The Choose to Lose Diet'' works on the principle of a fat ``budget.'' The dieter determines, based on height, desired weight and frame size, how many fat calories can be consumed daily. Then, as long as the dieter stays within the budget, all foods are OK. ``You need to eat some fat,'' Newmark said. ``But it is easy to get too much, because it tastes good.'' In children, especially, fats should not be drastically reduced, because they are needed for proper growth and development. ``The way to make it easier is to do small simple changes, one at a time,'' she said. For example, switch from a high-fat to a low-fat cheese or limit the amount of cheese eaten. ``I'd rather someone follow 50 percent of what I say forever, than 100 percent for a while.'' Still, dieting is dieting and means cutting down, though very-low-calorie, unsupervised diets are considered dangerous by many physicians. ``Choose to Lose,'' which includes calorie and fat tables and recipes, recommends no fewer than 1,000 calories a day, and no more than 20 percent of the calories as fat. A typical American diet is 35 percent to 40 percent fat. The authors list foods with high fat concentrations and those without, lists that could surprise some people. They include fast foods and frozen ``diet'' dinners that get as many as half their calories from fats. Microwave popcorn, for example, has 99 to 214 fat calories per ounce; popcorn popped at home in oil has 138; air-popped popcorn has no fat calories. The Goors say the impetus for their new book came from an earlier book on lowering cholesterol; people who cut back on saturated fats to reduce cholesterol found they also lost weight. Although all fats have the same caloric content, experts say saturated fats, such as butter, contribute to other health problems as well. They recommend olive and other vegetable oils. But while people can take some action, ``with respect to weight control, we don't have the answers,'' Swenerton said, noting that 98 of 100 people regain weight they lose and that many people are misled by diet promises. ``One kind of misinformation is that obesity is just from eating too much,'' she said. ``That's only part of the whole picture,'' which also includes exercise, psychology and genetics.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 15

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Shareholder Solicitation Firm Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Donald C. Carter, who founded a company that solicits proxies in takeover battles and has advised takeover artists, resigned his administrative post Wednesday at the Carter Organization. Carter said he stepped aside as the firm's chief executive but will retain his chairman's post. He also resigned from the six-member board of VPI Group, the British-based public relations agency that bought the Carter Organization in 1987. Donald Carter has been under investigation for several months by New York state officials on allegations that he overbilled clients and underpaid taxes, The New York Times reported in its Thursday editions. Carter, 41, has declined to discuss the investigation. He told the Times his resignation was unrelated. Carter turned over his executive duties to Art Ross, the company's president and chief operating officer, and Dennis Mensch, its executive vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia-Pacific Chairman Accused of Giving False Testimony
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. has accused Georgia-Pacific Corp. Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. of providing untruthful testimony in the paper companies' merger fight, according to documents unsealed Wednesday. Great Northern charged that Hahn falsely said under oath that his company had no plans to sell mills in Millinocket and East Millinocket during the time it was asking bankers to finance the attempted takeover of Great Northern. At the time, Georgia-Pacific actually told Citibank it would sell the Maine assets but did not want to go on record saying so, the documents indicate. The latest charges to surface in Georgia-Pacific's $3.8 billion attempt to acquire Great Northern were unsealed late Wednesday by U.S. District Judge Gene Carter, after Citibank said it would not oject. Citibank had been approached by Georgia-Pacific to be the lead lender in the deal, but Bank of America ultimately was chosen, the court documents say. Georgia-Pacific immediately responded with a statement that repeated its assertion that there is no plan to sell the Maine mills and lashed out at Great Northern's ``scurrilous and false charges.'' Great Northern's filing came as part of its attempt to persuade the judge to block Georgia-Pacific's merger attempt as well as Georgia-Pacific's attempt to oust Great Northern's directors in a proxy fight. The filing says that, although Georgia-Pacific told Citibank it wanted to sell the Maine assets, Hahn told lawyers in a sworn deposition last week in New York such sales had been ruled out ``before the first approach through lending institutions for financing of the offer.'' In its motion for a preliminary injunction, Great Northern says Georgia-Pacific broke securities laws by attempting to cover up its plans to sell the Maine properties. But Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific called Great Northern's accusations ``unconscionable and intolerable.'' ``For the umpteenth time, we have no asset sale plans and no undisclosed intentions relating to the acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa,'' Hahn said in the statement, adding that he cannot ``control what interpretations others may make of our discussions.'' Great Northern says Georgia-Pacific has tried to conceal its alleged plans to sell the Maine assets in order to make the merger more politically palatable in Maine. Great Northern also is challenging the merger on antitrust grounds, as is the Maine attorney general.

American Telephone & Telegraph Co. sued rival MCI Communications Corp. for allegedly stealing thousands of its long-distance customers with deceptive telemarketing practices. The suit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Newark, N.J., said MCI and its telemarketing agent, Pioneer Teletechnologies of Sergeant Bluff, Iowa, sometimes lied to AT&T customers or switched customers' long-distance phone services without their consent _ a claim MCI strongly denied. AT&T's suit asks that MCI stop the alleged practices and seeks an unspecified amount of damages.

Regulators penalized two directors of the failed Silverado, Banking Savings and Loan Association in Denver, which once listed President Bush's son Neil as a director. The directors _ Richard K. Vandapool and Robert M. Lewis _ agreed Wednesday to an order prohibiting them from working at any federally insured financial institution without prior approval from regulators. The order covers commercial banks, savings institutions and credit unions. No action was announced against Neil Bush, who served on Silverado's board from 1985 until August 1988.

Federal securities regulators charged a Minneapolis lawyer with making $4.35 million in illegal profits by trading on inside information about Grand Metropolitan PLC's bid for Pillsbury Co. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday accused James H. O'Hagan of engaging in the insider trading to repay $1 million he allegedly diverted from client accounts. But O'Hagan's lawyer, while admitting O'Hagan borrowed money from client accounts, denied his client engaged in insider trading to pay it back.

Texas Air Corp. Chairman Frank Lorenzo expressed regret about the Eastern Airlines strike, but he insisted he was optimistic about the rebuilding carrier. ``While the airline that's out there today is not as big as the airline it was before, I believe very strongly and I believe you will, too, when you see it that a lot of quality has been substituted for quantity,'' Lorenzo told an overflow Rotary Club luncheon crowd of 250 people Wednesday. Lorenzo walked through a gauntlet of chanting, protesting Machinists, whose strike is in its 11th month, and police stood guard for the speech.

Campeau Corp. said it was sending payments on schedule to numerous merchandise suppliers, apparently passing the first of two key tests facing the troubled retailing company. Carol Sanger, spokeswoman at Campeau's corporate communications office in Cincinnati, said Wednesday that most of the bills, which total about $100 million, were for women's apparel. A more crucial test will come Monday when Campeau's two big retailing chains, Allied Department Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., must assure banks they are solvent. Otherwise, $2.34 billion in loans could be declared in default.

Vice President Dan Quayle told Japan's top trade official that easing repression in China depends on close coordination among the United States, Japan and other countries, officials said. During Wednesday's 30-minute meeting, Hikaru Matsunaga, minister of international trade and industry, also reaffirmed Japan's intention to become an ``import superpower'' and described to Quayle a program to stimulate imports with tax breaks, tariff reductions and overseas missions, officials said.

The Supreme Court limited the ability of multinational corporations to challenge state taxes in federal court in a case involving two foreign-based companies that challenged California law. The justices ruled Wednesday that a law generally barring federal courts from handling lawsuits that attack a state tax applies to foreign-based multinational businesses. The Supreme Court's unanimous decision means that two foreign-based corporations will have to turn to California courts to challenge that state's business tax.

The paperwork generated by the takeover battle between paper giants Georgia-Pacific Corp. and Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. has become so immense that a judge has stepped in to free up the court clerk's copy machine. ``Counsel on all sides of this case have, by virtue of their written submissions, given ample evidence of their devotion to the mercantile interests of the paper industry,'' U.S. District Judge Gene Carter said during a December hearing. Carter issued an order, filed Tuesday and made available Wednesday, that the clerk's office begin sending everything involved in the companies' five lawsuits to a nearby copy shop so the store can make copies for sale to the public.

Philip R. Lochner Jr., deputy general counsel of Time Warner Inc., was nominated by President Bush to fill a vacancy on the five-member Securities and Exchange Commission. Wednesday's nomination to a post on the federal agency that regulates the nation's stock and bonds markets is subject to confirmation by the Senate. ``Phil Lochner has an excellent resume. He appears to have the potential to make an outstanding SEC commissioner,'' said Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, which will question the nominee at a confirmation hearing.

Stock prices recorded their second straight loss Wednesday as hopes for an early-1990 rally dimmed on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 15.36 to 2,750.64. The dollar was mostly firmer while gold rose sharply. Bonds were unchanged to slightly higher. Precious metal and energy futures soared, grains and soybeans were lower and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Yields on 7-Year Notes at Lowest Level Since July
DOC.TEXT: Yields on seven-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level since last July. The average yield was 8.02 percent, down from 8.08 percent at the last auction on Oct. 11. It was the lowest rate since seven-year notes averaged 7.89 percent on July 12, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,989.40. A total of $7.59 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $22 billion.

DOC.HEAD: New York Attorney General To Sue Unless Exxon Admits Liability
DOC.TEXT: The New York attorney general says he will sue Exxon Corp. for an oil spill off Staten Island unless the company admits its liability and agrees to pay for damages within 48 hours. ``It is imperative that Exxon immediately accept its liability not only to clean up its spill, but also to fully compensate the state financially for the damage to New York state's natural resources,'' Attorney General Robert Abrams said in a letter sent Wednesday to Exxon President Lee R. Raymond. Abrams called on Exxon to pay for an immediate study ``to assess the damage to natural resources caused by the spill and to determine the best ways to restore our natural resources.'' Abrams said the study should be done under the supervision of the state. More than 560,000 gallons of home heating oil leaked from an Exxon pipeline into the Arthur Kill waterway off Staten Island on Jan. 2. Abrams said the oil has contaminated ``critical waterfowl feeding and wetland areas of the environmentally sensitive Pralls Island bird sanctuary.'' Exxon has also been criticized for the handling of the spill of 11 million gallons of oil from the Exxon Valdez tanker last March 24 along 1,000 miles of Alaska coastline. It was the worst oil spill in U.S. history. On Wednesday, Exxon said it had created a senior management position to handle safety and environmental issues. Edwin J. Hess, an executive formerly in charge of marketing, refining and planning for international operations at the nation's largest oil company, has been named to the new position of vice president, environment and safety. Hess will report to Raymond. Since the Alaska spill, Exxon shareholders have called on the company to show greater environmental accountability. The company subsequently named an environmentalist to the board of directors and created a special committee to review environmental issues. Abrams accused Exxon of creating a ``mini-Alaska'' in the Arthur Kill. He said the damage was ``compounded by Exxon's apparent failure to notify New York state and city environmental officials of the spill immediately upon its discovery.'' On Tuesday, Exxon said a company refinery operator twice restarted the flow of oil through the leaking pipeline after automatic safety systems stopped the flow. Exxon also told New York and New Jersey environmental officials that a system to detect leaks in the pipeline had been faltering at least once or twice a week for a year. More than 200 birds have been found dead since the leak was detected. A spokesman for Abrams, Leslie Gersing, said the attorney general would file a lawsuit if Exxon had not met his conditions by late Friday. A spokesman for Exxon, Bill Smith, said the company did not receive the letter until after business hours and had no immediate comment.

DOC.HEAD: Siemens Agrees To Acquire Majority Stake in Financially Troubled Nixdorf
DOC.TEXT: Siemens AG, the giant electronics company, will acquire a majority stake in Nixdorf Computer AG, a financially troubled West German data and information-systems maker, officials said. The two companies plan to merge their computer operations after the transaction, according to a brief announcement from Nixdorf on Wednesday. The announcement gave few details of the transaction or the intended plans of the two companies. Earlier Wednesday, sources at Munich-based Siemens said their company had acquired 51 percent of Nixdorf for an unspecified price. Siemens also officially confirmed the Nixdorf pact. Meanwhile, the West German Federal Cartel Office said it had been informed of the intention of the two companies, but that a formal application for approval had not yet been submitted. The cartel office must rule on the agreement and is empowered to reject it if it finds antitrust concerns. The companies said Siemens acquired the common stock from the Nixdorf family, which in effect controls all the voting common shares. There are about 5.6 million common shares outstanding. Nixdorf's 5.6 million non-voting preferred stock shares are listed on West German exchanges. Up to now, the Nixdorf family had been reluctant to part with their full control of the company despite deep financial problems. There had not been any hint of the negotiations with Siemens, which in the past stated publicly its interest in taking a stake in Nixdorf. It was not immediately clear what, if any, measures Siemens will take to help Nixdorf recover from ongoing financial losses that the West German news magazine Der Spiegel recently reported as totaling $560 million last year. Nixdorf has not confirmed that figure. In its press statement Wednesday, Nixdorf said it will continue to push through its previously announced broad corporate overhaul aimed at improving profitability by cutting costs, beefing up productivity and redirecting strategic priorities. The company plans to pull out of loss-producing business areas such as the manufacture of various types of computer hardware. A Nixdorf spokesman said his company's exchange-listed preferred shares will not be affected by the Siemens agreement and that this stock will remain in public hands and traded on exchanges. Meanwhile, Nixdorf said the contemplated business arrangement with Siemens is predicated on the idea that both companies' data and information systems businesses would together form a powerful market force. ``The corporate focus of both companies lies in these areas, though up to now in different market segments and geographic regions,'' Nixdorf said. Under the agreement, Siemens would merge its data and information systems operations with those of Nixdorf, which would then become a majority-owned affiliate of Siemens. Final details of the transaction and the merging of the business lines remain to be worked out, the companies said.

DOC.HEAD: MCI, AT&T Announce Cheaper Rates to Europe, Pacific, Canada
With PM-AT&T Suit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. has announced cut-rate calling plans to Western Europe, the Pacific and Canada. The plans _ Call Europe, Call Pacific and Call Canada _ will provide flat, per-minute rates during weekdays and all weekend for a $3 monthly fee, MCI said Wednesday. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. responded to MCI's plan with a belated announcement of its own international calling program, AT&T Reach Out World. AT&T said it the plan has been in effect since July but not announced formally. Under MCI's Call Europe plan, callers will be charged 59 cents per minute to call any of 23 Western European nations on weekdays from 3 p.m. to 8 a.m., and all weekend. In the Call Pacific plan, calls may be made to Australia, New Zealand and eight Asian nations for 79 cents per minute from 10 p.m. to 2 p.m. the following day, and all weekend. Call Canada is priced at 19 cents per minute from 5 p.m. to 8 a.m. weekdays and all weekend. The plans are expected to be available Jan. 15, said Wayne Gattinella, MCI's vice president for consumer marketing. Gattinella said a 10-minute call at 8 p.m. to the United Kingdom would cost $5.90 under the new plan, compared with current MCI prices ranging from $8 to $8.50 for the same 10-minute call. An evening 10-minute call to France now costs between $7.75 and $8.25, Gattinella said. On Saturday morning, it now costs about $8.50. AT&T's plan also provides discounts calling to 25 nations for an additional fee of $3 a month. Reach Out World customers also receive a 5 percent discount on direct-dialed interstate calls within the United States, the company said. AT&T has offered discounts for calling to Canada for three years, and to the United Kingdom and the Philippines for the past two years. AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said AT&T had planned to tie a formal announcement of its international calling plan with a national advertising campaign due to begin today. MCI estimated that residential international calling represents a $5 billion market and is growing 25 percent annually. It estimated that 10 percent of U.S. consumers make monthly overseas calls, with an average duration of 10 minutes. Both MCI and AT&T said they planned to add additional countries to their plans this year.

DOC.HEAD: House Members Consider Abolishing New Office To Regulate Thrifts
With PM-S&L Bailout, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of the House Banking Committee are considering abolishing the new office Congress established last August to regulate thrift institutions during the 1989 savings and loan crisis. Rep. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., said Wednesday he will introduce a bill when Congress reconvenes to eliminate the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision and turn its authority over to two bank regulators, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board. A similar approach has been advocated by Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa, the second ranking Republican on the banking committee. Schumer said M. Danny Wall's resignation as the thrift office's top official ``presents us with a tremendous opportunity to straighten out a regulatory system that most agree has been jerry-built.'' Wall, after being harshly questioned by the House panel in six weeks of hearings last fall over his regulation of the now collapsed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., announced in December he would step down from the job as soon as President Bush finds a replacement. The new thrift office in the Treasury Department was established as part of a $160 billion taxpayer bailout of S&L lossses to replace the Federal Home Loan Bank Board as the industry's chief regulator. A former banking aide to Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, and one-time staff chief of the Senate Banking Committee, Wall had chaired the bank board for slightly more than a year prior to its abolition. While effectively making S&Ls come into compliance with federal banking rules, Schumer complained that last year's bailout law also allowed them to retain their own separate regulator, ``leaving open the potential for the same abuses that scarred the industy and depositors in the past.'' ``Since the two agencies promulgate regulations that are required by law to have the same practical effect, it is clear that only one body is necessary,'' he said of the thrift and comptroller's offices. Schumer said his bill would gradually merge the thrift office into the Comptroller of the Currency's agency to coincide with the scheduled phase-out in 1994 of the Resolution Trust Corp., another new agency established in the bailout law. The trust corporation's primary function is disposing of up to $400 billion in real estate and other property collateralizng soured loans by failed thrifts that have been or will be taken over by the government.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Suing MCI Over Marketing Practices
DOC.TEXT: The long-running feud between American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and upstart MCI Communications Corp. continues to escalate with new charges of deceptive telemarketing practices being lodged. AT&T sued MCI and its telemarketing agent, Pioneer Teletechnologies of Sergeant Bluff, Iowa, on Wednesday, claiming they stolesome of its long-distance customers by using false or misleading information or by switching services without customers' consent. MCI strongly denied the allegations. The suit, which was filed in U.S. District Court in Newark, N.J., is the latest salvo in a battle that began in the 1970s when MCI successfully broke AT&T's long-distance monopoly. AT&T still remains the nation's largest long-distance carrier, with about 68 percent of the market, followed by MCI, with about 12 percent, and US Sprint Communications Co., with 8 percent. Last October, MCI sued AT&T for allegedly engaging in deceptive advertising by claiming AT&T's service was superior or that MCI had misrepresented its services or rates. AT&T countersued, questioning claims made in MCI ads. In the latest court action, which seeks an unspecified amount of damages, AT&T claims it suffered losses in the ``tens of millions of dollars'' by MCI's alleged deceptive telemarketing practices. AT&T also petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to amend its rules so that telephone customers would have to provide written permission before switching long-distance carriers. Current rules allow customers to authorize a change verbally. ``We believe our proposal to the FCC will curtail the numerous instances of unauthorized switching _ or `slamming' as it's known in the industry _ that consumers have endured,'' Merrill Tutton, AT&T's vice president for consumer services, told a news conference in New York on Wednesday. ``I think there are probably an awful lot of people there who this has happened to, but they haven't gone to the trouble to complain.'' AT&T claimed that the ``many thousands of complaints'' it did receive from consumers about MCI _ particularly from elderly people who might suffer from hearing problems or Hispanics who faced language barriers _ prompted it to seek legal action against MCI. ``I'm talking about ... a 90-year-old woman in New Jersey who gets a call asking her if she'd like to sign up with MCI ... (and) couldn't hear the representative clearly, so she asked that they send her information by mail,'' Tutton said. ``Instead, she gets a letter from MCI and learns she's been switched without her approval.'' Tutton claimed other customers said MCI erroneously told them, for example, that they needed to switch services because AT&T and MCI were merging or that AT&T was going out of business. When asked, Tutton said AT&T could not provide specific numbers of people who complained and did not have permission to release names of the complainers. He said preliminary studies showed that from February to November of last year, 10 percent to 15 percent of the AT&T customers switching to other long-distance carriers had been unaware of the change. John Houser, a spokesman for Washington-based MCI, said the company ``categorically denies that we have been misleading customers.'' MCI said AT&T is acting out of frustration at MCI's success in attracting new business since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984. ``MCI has been winning customers in the marketplace at a rate of over 100,000 a week based on value and superlative customer service,'' the company said in a statement. ``This is just another example of AT&T preaching competition on one hand and whining when competition takes hold in the marketplace.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC: Lawyer Made $4.35 Million in Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: A suspended Minneapolis lawyer denies charges that he illegally traded on inside information to pay back more than $1 million he allegedly diverted from clients' accounts. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint against James H. O'Hagan on Wednesday, charging he made $4.35 million in illegal profits by trading on inside information about Grand Metropolitan PLC's bid for Pillsbury Co. The SEC also alleged O'Hagan engaged in insider trading to repay money taken from client trust accounts. In Minneapolis, O'Hagan attorney William Mauzy said his client denied trading on inside information but concededed he ``borrowed'' money from clients' accounts. Mauzy said O'Hagan has been charged with theft by the Hennepin County, Minn., prosecutor, but asserted, ``He really didn't have to make a score in Pillsbury to repay the accounts.'' Mauzy said O'Hagan was a ``sophisticated and heavy investor in the stock market'' who accumulated a total of $5 million in his accounts before he began trading Pillsbury securities. O'Hagan also maintains he bought Pillsbury shares on the recommendation of brokers, who have filed affidavits with the SEC to that effect. On Dec. 5, 1989, O'Hagan was temporarily suspended from practicing law by the Minnesota Supreme Court. The SEC complaint, filed in federal court in Minneapolis, accuses O'Hagan of trading Pillsbury securities in 1988 using misappropriated confidential information about Grand Met's pending hostile tender offer. O'Hagan at the time was a partner in the law firm Dorsey & Whitney, which was local counsel for Grand Met, a British food and beverage producer, in the bid for Pillsbury. Grand Met acquired Minneapolis-based Pillsbury in January 1989. O'Hagan left Dorsey & Whitney late last February, said Robert Struyk, chairman of the Minneapolis firm. Struyk said O'Hagan, who specialized in securities, commodities and medical malpractice litigation, had been with the firm since 1963 or 1964. He said Dorsey & Whitney was not involved in the case and had cooperated with the SEC. The complaint alleges that O'Hagan learned of the pending Grand Met offer in July 1988 after speaking with another Dorsey & Whitney partner. According to the complaint, between late July and Sept. 21, 1988, O'Hagan bought Pillsbury stock and call options. On Oct. 4, 1988, Grand Met announced its cash tender offer for Pillsbury at $60 per share, driving up the stock's price by $20. From Oct. 5 to Oct. 17, O'Hagan sold his Pillsbury stock and options, allegedly netting $4.35 million in profits. Mauzy said in a statement that when O'Hagan learned in September 1988 that Dorsey & Whitney had been approached to act as counsel to Grand Met, he immediately cancelled outstanding orders to purchase options to buy Pillsbury shares. The SEC complaint alleges that O'Hagan needed the trading profits to repay about $1 million he had secretly diverted from a client of his law firm, Northrup King Co. The complaint also alleged O'Hagan diverted funds from at least two other clients, which were not identified. Asked if it was unusual for an SEC complaint to go into such detail about the alleged motive for a violation, Harry J. Weiss, an SEC attorney who worked on the case, said: ``Keep in mind this case is not settled. The complaint contains all evidence that the commission thinks is relevent.'' The complaint seeks a court order requiring O'Hagan to return the profits from his alleged illegal deal plus fines equal to his profits.

DOC.HEAD: Payment Deadline Passes; Doubts Persist About Campeau's Financial State
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp. has saved face by paying certain bills on time but the larger question of whether the troubled company and its U.S. retailers can achieve a financial turnaround remains unresovled. Campeau said Wednesday it was sending payments on schedule to numerous merchandise suppliers. In addition, the company's restructuring committee announced the appointment of a new executive to direct the financial revival at Campeau's U.S. holdings, including Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. Campeau also owns shopping malls and other commercial real estate in the United States. There has been widespread speculation in the retail trade that Campeau might seek shelter for its U.S. retailers in bankruptcy court, which would allow its stores to remain open while they work out their financial dilemmas. By paying money owed to vendors, the Canadian retail and real estate company signaled its interest in maintaining good relations with manufacturers that do business with its nearly 260 U.S. department stores. Carol Sanger, spokeswoman at Campeau's corporate communications office in Cincinnati, said most of the bills, which total about $100 million, were for women's apparel. ``The fact that these bills are being paid ... as they are due reinforces the company's desire to deal with its vendors in as close to a normal course of business relationship as possible and it also reinforces the value we place on our relationships with vendors,'' Ms. Sanger said. She said the Campeau board, which met Monday and Tuesday, met again Wednesday at the company's Toronto headquarters. The meeting was adjourned by afternoon and was scheduled to reconvene this morning. After adjourning, the board issued an announcement on the appointment of Chance Bahadur to the post of executive vice president and chief financial officer of Campeau Corp. (U.S.) Inc. He will assume his new duties immediately. Bahadur is joining Campeau from Marriott Corp., where he has been senior vice president of finance and treasurer since October 1988. The board also said it accepted the resignation of Russell S. Davis as executive vice president and chief financial officer of Campeau, Federated and Allied. Davis, who joined Federated in 1984, had been promoted to executive vice president and CFO of Federated and Allied in May 1988 and added those titles at Campeau in April 1989. Board members said they understook Davis' ``desire to relinquish a range of responsibilities ... that has become increasingly demanding and unrelenting in recent months.'' The bills due Wednesday were for goods shipped during the peak shopping weeks ahead of Christmas. Companies that regularly deal with the Campeau stores have said bills from last autumn were paid promptly. But when news of the depth of Campeau's financial difficulties unfolded late last year, many suppliers suspended further merchandise shipments and said they would decide whether to resume after Jan. 10, when new bills came due. A number of manufacturers of women's sportswear and other apparel said they had been notified their bills were being processed and had no reason to doubt it. The Wednesday deadline had been viewed as an important symbolic date by the retail trade. Even merchants who weren't owed anything were watching for what Campeau would do so they could decide whether to take the risk of doing future business with its stores. Spring merchandise typically is shipped starting at the end of this month. Janet Mangano, director of research at the investment firm Josephthal & Co. Inc., said it is still unclear whether Campeau will be able to pull out of its problems. She said meeting current bills from suppliers didn't mean Campeau would be able to cover debt obligations coming due in the near future. A more crucial test for Campeau will come Monday. Allied and Federated must assure Citibank and other members of a group that lent them $2.34 billion that they are solvent. The loan could be declared in default if they cannot give the assurance. Disclosures about Campeau's financial predicament surfaced in September. The Canadian property company Olympia & York Developments Ltd. provided a $250 million cash infusion and Campeau said it would restructure its far-flung operations and attempt to reorganize its finances. Campeau's precarious condition was caused chiefly by the heavy debt burden it built up when it bought Federated in 1988 for $6.6 billion and Allied two years earlier for $3.4 billion. Part of the restructuring plan already mapped out involves selling Federated's Bloomingdale's department store chain, considered one of Campeau's most valuable possessions. Federated's other chains include Abraham and Straus, Burdines, Lazarus and Rich's. Allied operates the Bon Marche, Jordan Marsh, Maas Brothers and Stern's chains.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Time Warner Deputy General Counsel to SEC
DOC.TEXT: On the same day that he went from being general counsel at the former Time Inc. to deputy general counsel at the newly merged Time Warner Inc., Philip R. Lochner Jr., was was nominated by President Bush for a spot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wednesday's nomination to a post on the federal agency that regulates the nation's stock and bonds markets is subject to confirmation by the Senate. ``Phil Lochner has an excellent resume. He appears to have the potential to make an outstanding SEC commissioner,'' said Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, which will question the nominee at a confirmation hearing. ``However, the committee will have to examine his background and qualifications carefully during the confirmation process,'' Riegle, D-Mich., said in a statement. ``Clearly, the position of SEC commissioner, at this time, is among the most important in government.'' Lochner had been general counsel of Time Inc., which renamed itself Time Warner Inc. last year and officially merged Wednesday with Warner Communications Inc., resulting in the change in his title to deputy general counsel. Reached at Time Warner's New York office, Lochner declined to comment on the SEC nomination. ``I just spent the better part of a year working with him on the Time Warner deal,'' said Samuel Butler, presiding partner of the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, where Lochner worked from 1973 to 1978. ``I think it's an excellent nomination,'' said Butler, who was Lochner's boss for a year in the 1970s. ``He had a lot of securities experience when he was here, generally,'' said Butler, adding ``He brings an an excellent business-legal perspective to the SEC which it hasn't had for a long time.'' If confirmed by the Senate, Lochner would serve out the remaining 17 months of the term of former SEC Chairman David S. Ruder, who stepped down last year and was succeeded by Bush aide Richard C. Breeden. Breeden, who was at Cravath, Swaine & Moore during part of the time Lochner was there, hailed the nomination. ``His background as a lawyer with extensive experience in securities and general corporate law and as a former law professor and associate dean make him uniquely qualified to serve on the commission,'' Breeden said in a statement. Time Warner said in a statement issued at its New York headquarters: ``Time Warner has a tradition of encouraging public service and we are very proud of Phil's nomination.'' Lochner, of Greenwich, Conn., was general counsel and secretary for Time Inc. and Time Warner starting in September 1988. He was among the supporters of Time management's decision to reject a bid from Paramount Communications Inc. last year and go ahead with the $14 billion Warner merger. But like several officials at Time and Warner, he found he was one of two employees with the same job title at the merged company, although a Time Warner spokesman denied that Lochner's post had become redundant. A 1964 graduate of Yale University, Lochner joined Time Inc. as an associate general counsel in 1978. He obtained his law degree from Yale in 1967 and a doctorate in political science from Stanford in 1971. Before going to work at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, Lochner served as an associate dean and assistant law professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo from 1971 to 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Offered Tour of Nuclear Plant at Utility's Expense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf pvs, `The jurors ...' to ADD why trial was in Dallas.
DOC.TEXT: Dallas jurors who gave Houston Lighting & Power Co. a favorable verdict in a $419 million lawsuit will be flown to Houston at the utility's expense for a tour of its nuclear plant and a stay at a luxury hotel. The utility confirmed it invited the jurors about a month ago to come to Houston at HL&P's expense, the Houston Chronicle reported today. Spokesman Graham Painter said that because the jurors' role in the case is over, there is nothing improper about HL&P Chairman Don Jordan's playing host and showing off the plant. He did not know how many jurors would take up the offer, nor would he estimate the cost of the air fare and overnight accommodations during the trip this weekend. The jurors decided in July that the utility's partner in the South Texas Nuclear Project, the city of Austin, deserved no damages for HL&P's withholding information that would have allowed the city to anticipate huge cost overruns. The trial was held in Dallas after a judge determined that a fair trial could not be held in Austin. City officials in Austin said the invitation to jurors and the judge was just the latest impropriety in the utility's push for the plant, whose cost ballooned from $900 million to almost $6 billion. ``It's highly unprofessional and very questionable. Until the people of Texas realize that this sort of shenanigans cost the people hundreds of millions of dollars, it won't stop,'' said City Councilman George Humphrey. ``When you have a jury that rules the defendant is guilty and awards no damages and a short time later, they're offered free air fare, free lodging, free meals and first-class treatment, it can't help but cast a doubt.'' ``I've never heard of this happening in civil litigation. I think it's fundamentally unethical, but so what else is new?'' said Councilman Smoot Carl-Mitchell. Clarence Guittard, a retired appeals court judge who presided over the four-month trial, decided not to join the plant tour. He gave no reason, the newspaper reported. Painter said public tours of the plant in Bay City, 90 miles from Houston, usually include lunch and that the utility decided jurors should stay overnight in Houston because of the time it takes to get from Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Introduces 1.5-Liter Sporty Liftback
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Co. Thursday unveiled the NX Coupe, a sporty two-door liftback with a 1.5-liter engine and digital instrument panel. The 13.5-foot-long car has a 140-horsepower, four-cylinder engine and ``large, easy-to-read digital instruments that project an entirely new feeling.'' ``A sporty interior has been created through the use of a three-spoke steering wheel and sports seats,'' a Nissan release said. In Japan, the NX Coupe will cost 1.14 million to 1.96 million yen, between $7,860 and $13,500. Exports, primarily to North America, are to begin in May, but Nissan said it has not yet decided on export prices. Nissan also unveiled a revamped Sunny, known as the Sentra in North America. The new version of Nissan's mainstay four-door sedan discontinues the garnish used around the ceiling in the previous model and brings the instrument cluster 2.75 inches closer to the driver. The Sentra has engine options similar to the NX Coupe, along with a 1.8-liter version. It will cost between 845,000 and 2.11 million yen in Japan and also will be exported, mainly to North America, starting in May.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Chairman Expresses Strike Regrets
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo says Eastern Airlines' rebuilding program is a case of smaller is better, but that he needlessly provoked ``a united opposition'' from the carrier's three unions. In a rare Miami appearance since all three of Eastern's unions went on strike last March 4, Lorenzo told a Downtown Rotary Club luncheon crowd Wednesday he should have been ``more sensitive to the realities the union leaders were dealing with.'' Lorenzo's remark echoed earlier statements of Eastern officials that management had underestimated the resolve of the carrier's pilots. The pilots and Eastern's flight attendants walked off the job in sympathy when the airline's machinists went out on strike. The pilots and flight attendants only returned to work in late November. ``The last year has been a very difficult one,'' Lorenzo told his audience. ``There have been mistakes, and there have been a lot of things I know all parties would like to change. ``If you look at the last nine months as a battle,'' he said, ``it is a battle no one has won, with the possible tiny exception of consumers.'' Arriving for the luncheon, Lorenzo, whose Texas Air bought Eastern four years ago, walked through rows of striking Machinists chanting ``choke, Frank, choke'' and warned Rotarians to ``secure your wallets.'' Police officers stood guard for the speech. Inside, Lorenzo told the Rotarians Eastern losses for the eight years before he took over the carrier amounted to $1 billion. He said major changes were needed, but that union leaders were reluctant to face the needed changes. Thousands of dedicated employees, he said, are out of work because ``they got caught in a system that was no fault of their own.'' Cutting wages and employees was hard ``from a human point of view,'' but there was no choice, he said. But Lorenzo said Eastern's rebuilding was succeeding since seeking Chapter 11 protection from creditors shortly after the strike began. ``While the airline that's out there today is not as big as the airline it was before, I believe very strongly and I believe you will, too, when you see it that a lot of quality has been substituted for quantity.'' Lorenzo said there has been a strong response to Eastern's newly announced discount fares, starting at $69, and the airline has been getting good consumer response to its service overall. ``We face the '90s with great optimism,'' he said. But Frank Ortis, the Machinists union Local 702 president, said afterward that Lorenzo ``is in big trouble'' as he tries to bring Eastern out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Eastern is plagued by cancellations and ``their load factors have been disastrous,'' said Ortis, who was not allowed to attend the speech. ``It's time for Frank Lorenzo to come to his senses and sell the airline so we can save it.'' Ortis said 96 percent of the Machinists are still out on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Grocery Chains Turn Off Mist Machines Afer Legionnaires' Finding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with fourth chain shutting down misters. PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Researchers traced ...'; SUBS penultimate graf with 2 grafs to add detail on shift in A&P position.
DOC.TEXT: At least four major supermarket chains switched off vegetable-freshening mist machines like the one implicated in a deadly outbreak of Legionnaires' disease. The manufacturer said the device wasn't to blame. Winn-Dixie, Safeway, A&P and Kroger said their stores stopped using the machines as a precaution after learning that one at Winn-Dixie's Bogalusa store had been blamed for November's outbreak, which killed two people and infected dozens. Researchers traced the bacteria to the one-quart water reservoir of the mist machine at the supermarket, one of three in this southeast Louisiana town of about 16,000 people, said Dr. Louise McFarland, state epidemiologist. ``This is the first time a community outbreak of Legionnaires' disease has been traced to a mist machine of any type,'' she said. ``I don't think anyone would ever have suspected it.'' The machine fell under suspicion after the store was implicated in interviews with the 70 people who fell ill and about 150 who didn't. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta was examining the device to determine what role its design may have played in harboring the bacteria, which cause flu-like symptoms, officials said. Other supermarkets use mist machines, but it was not known if they were made by the same company, L.W. Beal of Portland, Maine, said Dr. Thomas Farley, an epidemiologist with the state Department of Health and Hospitals. Beal said his company supplies the sprayers to most major grocery chains and has had no other problem with other systems. ``The Legionnaires' virus is in the water in that area,'' Beal said. ``You'll find it in any kind of machine that uses water and is not properly cleaned. ``If a machine is properly cleaned you won't have a problem. If you have an ice cream machine and you don't clean it properly, you can't blame an outbreak of salmonella on the manufacturer of the machine.'' Health authorities long ago learned that the Legionnaires' bacteria thrive in standing water, but Farley said researchers learned important lessons from the Bogalusa investigation. ``We now know more about where the bacteria can hide and what can cause an outbreak,'' he said. ``That's important to Louisiana and the nation.'' The machine was installed more than a year before the outbreak, said Lewis Libby, vice president of Jacksonville, Fla.-based Winn-Dixie. Winn-Dixie had been using the Bogalusa-type mist machine in 97 of its 1,250 stores in 13 Sun Belt states, Libby said. The machines were removed, and those stores are spraying tap water from hoses to keep produce fresh. All misting machines at Safeway's 1,200 stores, mostly in the western United States and Canada, have been turned off and were being cleaned, said Bob Bradford, a spokesman for the Oakland, Calif.-based company. ``We have two types. We are not sure if we have the one involved,'' he said. ``We just thought it would be best to turn them off until further notice.'' Cincinnati-based Kroger, the nation's second-largest chain with more than 1,200 stores in 20 mostly Midwestern and Southern states, said it has stopped using the spayers in its produce departments. It said most of its stores use automatic spray or mist systems, but that stores in the Cincinnati and Dayton, Ohio, areas use hoses. Montvale, N.J.-based A&P originally said it would not stop using its misters because they do not have reservoirs to hold the water like the one in Bogalusa. But spokesman Michael Roarke said today that the company had decided to shut down its misters temporarily because of customer concern. He said A&P has 1,250 stores in 26 states and Canada and uses the misters in about 200 outlets. Legionnaires' disease, first identified in 1976 after an outbreak at an American Legion convention in Philadelphia killed 34 people, is caused by bacteria that often thrive in cool, standing water found in such places as water towers or air conditioning ducts. The germ usually enters the lungs through water droplets.

DOC.HEAD: Sanctions Still Possible Against Bush Son
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs pvs grafs 2-5, The Office, with regulators meeting with Neil Bush. Picks up pvs graf 6, The office.
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan regulators who penalized two directors of a bankrupt Colorado savings institution are leaving open the possibility of sanctions against other former officers, including President Bush's son. Enforcement officials from the Office of Thrift Supervision met Monday with Bush's son, Neil, who served on the board of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association from 1985 until August 1988, thrift office spokesman William Fulwider said today. ``He's been here ... as have other associates of Silverado,'' Fulwider said. The Houston Post said in today's editions that Bush met with thrift office enforcement director Rosemary Stewart for four hours. The thrift office said Wednesday that two directors of Silverado have agreed to an order prohibiting them from working at any federally insured financial institution without prior approval from regulators. The order covers commercial banks, savings institutions and credit unions. Richard K. Vandapool, formerly vice chairman and chief operating office of the thrift, and Robert M. Lewis, formerly vice chairman and chief financial officer, agreed to the penalty without admitting or denying the allegations against them. No action was announced against Neil Bush. However, the thrift office said it was still investigating the S&L, was ``considering what action should be taken against any other former Silverado directors and senior management'' and ``anticipates the initiation of other prohibition actions in the near future.'' The office said in a statement that examiners had expressed ``grave concerns'' about the soundness of Silverado before closing it in December 1988. ``The regulators were particularly concerned about what they believed to be excessive concentration in commercial loans in a depressed market, an unusually large number of problem transactions with related parties such as shareholders, officers and directors, and inefficiencies in assessing the credit worthiness of borrowers,'' the thrift office said. Lewis' lawyer, Michael Bender, said his client denied any wrongdoing but agreed to the penalty because ``he just doesn't have the money to fight the feds.'' Liz Kearney, an attorney for Vandapool, had no comment. Another agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., is reviewing Silverado to determine whether to file a civil suit to recover some of the institution's losses from officers and directors. James Moroney, a former examiner at the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, has alleged in interviews that regulators did not crack down on Silverado because of its political ties, including the presence of Neil Bush on the S&L's board. Neil Bush, however, has denied attempting to influence regulators and has said he is cooperating with investigators. Regulators sold Silverado to a Ford Motor Co. subsidiary, First Nationwide Bank of San Francisco, which renamed it Mile High Federal Savings and Loan Association.

DOC.HEAD: Grains Mixed, Soybeans Higher in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain futures opened mixed, and soybean futures were higher this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat prices were boosted by the purchase overnight of 100-thousand metric tons of wheat by the Soviet Union. The Soviets are in the market today for an additional 500-thousand metric tons of winter or spring wheat. Continued good growing weather in South America is expected to weigh on soybean futures, as will slack demand for soy and Malaysian palm oil. Analysts say corn futures are expected to remain steady today. Overall, trading is expected to be subdued in anticipation of the release this afternoon of several U.S. Department of Agriculture crop reports. Analysts say the Agriculture Department is expected to announce that farmers planted more acres of winter wheat last fall than they did a year earlier. The department also is expected to increase slightly its estimate of the size of last fall's corn and soybean harvest. In early trading, wheat was unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.06{ a bushel; corn was } cent lower to a \ cent higher with March at $2.38 a bushel; oats were } cent lower to a { cent higher with March at $1.44{ a bushel; soybeans were a { cent to 2 cents higher with January at $5.69\ a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle prices were lifted by followthrough buying from Wednesday's strong close and the belief cash prices will rise. Pork futures prices rose despite steady to lower cash prices. Live cattle were .17 cent to .40 cent higher with February at 77.40 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .37 cent higher with January at 84.35 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent lower to .33 cent higher with February at 51.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .37 cent to .73 cent higher with February at 56.47 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed and pork futures were higher in Wednesday trading.

DOC.HEAD: J.P. Morgan Reports $1.3 Billion Loss for '89
DOC.TEXT: J.P. Morgan & Co. reported a 40 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings Thursday and a $1.3 billion loss for the year, a decline that reflected a major increase in the bank's reserves for problem debt. The 1989 loss, which translates to a loss of $7.04 a share, compares with earnings of $1 billion or $5.38 a share a year earlier. For the final quarter of 1989, the nation's third-largest bank reported earnings of $154 million or 81 cents a share, vs. earnings of $258 million or $1.38 a share in the year-earlier period. Morgan joined a long list of major U.S. banks that moved to bolster their reserves when it announced in late September it was adding $2 billion to provisions for potentially bad loans to Third World countries. Loan-loss reserves totaled $2.05 billion for the full year, while Morgan had $3.6 billion in total outstanding debt to restructuring countries. The bank noted that at the end of 1989, 64 percent of its total loans to restructuring countries were protected by reserves. In the previous year, Morgan had set aside $200 million to cover potentially bad loans. Net interest income totaled $275 million for the final quarter, down 54 percent from $603 million in the last quarter of 1988. For the full year, net interest income was $1.1 billion, down 39 percent from $1.8 billion in 1988. Morgan said interest income lagged throughout the year because flat yield curves in major markets prevented the bank from taking advantage of favorable interest rates. Noninterest income rose 18 percent in the fourth quarter to $444 million from $377 million a year earlier. For the full year, noninterest revenue totaled $1.74 billion, up 12 percent from $1.56 billion 1988, partly reflecting gains from the sale of securities and higher trading revenues. Noninterest expenses totaled $535 million in the final quarter and $1.9 billion for the full year, up 5 percent and 7 percent respectively, from $511 million for the year-ago final quarter and $1.8 billion for 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Says Texan Businessman's Takeover Bid Doubtful, Embarrassing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to update with Canadian brewer considering bid for Bond's Australian brewing interests, ADD comment from Reynolds; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Lucas also ...
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. cast doubt today on an obscure Texas businessman's questionable takeover proposal, and a Canadian brewer said it might offer $1.6 billion for part of the troubled conglomerate. Peter Lucas, spokesman for the Australian group of companies controlled by millionaire industrialist Alan Bond, said Bond Corp. has not been able to obtain information about a proposed $197 million cash offer by Jeff Reynolds. Meanwhile, John Labatt Ltd., a Canadian brewer, said the company is considering making a bid for Bond Corp.'s Australian brewing operations. Edward Stewart, spokesman for the Toronto-based company, said Bond approached Labatt about buying the brewing businesses about a month ago. ``On the basis of the preliminary look we had at the most recent profit figures provided to us, we believe the offer might be in the range of 1.6 billion to 2 billion Australian dollars,'' Stewart said. An Australian dollar is worth about 79 cents, making an offer potentially worth up to $1.6 billion. Stewart cautioned though, that no firm offer would be made for ``several weeks at best.'' Lucas said the lack of information from Reynolds had convinced Bond Corp. officials that he could not proceed with his planned takeover. ``In the absence of any such information having been made available so far, despite repeated requests, we are taking the view at this time that he does not have that capacity,'' said a statement from Bond Corp. headquarters in Perth, Western Australia. Lucas said Bond Corp. had written Reynolds asking him to provide information confirming his financial intentions with regard to purchasing the company. ``It was made very clear to Mr. Reynolds and his associates right from the very beginning that there would be no discussions until Bond Corp. was satisfied that Mr. Reynolds and-or his companies have the financial capacity to undertake a transaction of the size and nature he proposes,'' Lucas said. Reynolds, reached early today at his mother's home in Houston at first declined comment, then threatened to press on with a hostile bid if Bond Corp. does not work with him. ``Either they're with me or they're against me, and if they're against me they better look out,'' Reynolds told the Associated Press. He also reasserted that he has the $197 million, but said he was trying to put together refinancing for Bond's huge debt. Lucas also said Reynolds' public comments were causing Bond Corp. ``considerable embarrassment.'' Reynolds, 28, said in a news release last week that he was negotiating with Bond Corp., whose Australian brewing assets were recently placed in receivership by an Australian supreme court. However, little is known about Reynolds or his companies, which U.S. officials said Monday did not appear to be publicly traded as he contends. Reynolds says he heads a firm called Weatherby Investments Inc. He has said he planned to visit Australia to talk with Bond and was prepared to take out citizenship to seal a deal, thereby overcoming any obstacles over foreign investment in Australian media. ``There is certainly an air of scepticism about the fellow and I've got to tell you we share that scepticism,'' Lucas said told a television station here. He said Reynolds first contacted Bond about 10 weeks ago through an intermediary, and that Bond Corp. had responded asking for more details. Bond Corp. was founded by Alan Bond, a former America's Cup yachting winner and multimillionaire entrepreneur whose holdings include brewing, natural resources, property and media. He also owns the G. Heileman Brewing Co. in Wisconsin. Bond's empire is saddled with debts of nearly $6 billion and the group of companies is involved in several court actions. Bond has appealed the supreme court action placing his Australian brewing assets in receivership.

For release Monday Jan. 15
DOC.HEAD: Roundup Time at the M-K Means Herding Squirmy Critters
LaserPhoto PA1 of Jan. 9
DOC.TEXT: Ranch foreman Bryant Copeland, eyes shaded from the Florida Panhandle sun by a cowboy hat, grinned and gazed at the new stock grazing on the 12,000-acre spread. He wasn't looking at cows. ``Crawfish are easier to round up than cattle are,'' he said in his Arkansas drawl. ``Harder to brand, but easier to round up.'' He was kidding about the branding but not the roundups at M-K ranches, where millions of squirmy crawfish, resembling tiny lobsters, feed in outdoor ponds. They're herded with 40 flat-bottom boats built in Louisiana bayou country where crawfish are a staple of the Cajun diet. Until five years ago Copeland never had eaten crawfish. Now he supervises one of the nation's largest crawfish-raising operations. Each year, M-K Ranches produce from 850,000 to a million pounds of crawfish, also are known as crayfish or ``mud bugs.'' The operation has 12 full-time employees but it grows to more than 100 during harvesting from mid-Janary through June. It isn't just a ``crawfish plantation,'' said J.T. Murff Jr., who owns M-K Ranches in partnership with his father. Softshell crab, freshwater shrimp, fingerling catfish and tilapia, an African perch, also are raised in a temperature-controlled production building although crawfish in the 19 ponds outside are the main product. The Murffs, who had been in the cotton business in Memphis, Tenn., bought the property almost 18 years ago. The land was cleared of pine trees and up to 7,000 head of cattle roamed until 1979. ``The cattle market at the time made it where that didn't look economical,'' Murff said in a telephone interview from his Memphis office. Some cattle remained, but most of the land was switched to crops: corn, soybeans, rice, wheat, milo and sunflowers. Copeland, an expert in rice growing and watering, was brought in. By 1984 rice was the main crop. Water to flood the rice ponds was diverted from the nearby Brothers River. The federal government then removed price supports that had kept rice at about $7 a bushel. Rice prices dropped in half in 1985, and it no longer was profitable, Murff said. Meanwhile, Cajun cuisine had become a national rage. ``A lot of people were eating crawfish and Cajun cooking and creole cooking,'' Copeland said. ``We had the water and we had the ground so we put in 2,500 acres of crawfish ponds.'' Crawfish were especially attractive because they could be raised with relatively little modification to the shallow rice ponds, Murff said. They feed on decaying hay and rice, both grown on the ranch. Until this year, processing had been farmed out to seafood plants in Panama City and Port St. Joe, but M-K is building its own on-site plant. It is scheduled for completion later this month. The crawfish, caught in traps, are sold live or preboiled and seasoned in frozen blocks of 5 to 25 pounds under the brand name Crawfish 1 in 29 states. Up to 15 percent of the catch goes to Europe where it is prepared in a dill sauce rather than hot Cajun spices, Murff said. A few months ago, M-K donated 1,000 pounds of crawfish to Californians made homeless and hungry by the earthquake that shook the San Francisco area. Tail meat also is sold at a higher price, but the most profitable product is softshell crawfish. It is a gourmet item that goes for $7.50 to $9 a pound wholesale compared to a range of 60 cents to $1.25 for hardshell crawfish. ``Softshell tastes real good and besides that you get to eat the whole crawfish,'' Copeland said. For the softshell process, immature crawfish are sorted into hundreds of shallow holding trays in the production building. They remain there until they shed their shells which happens about once every two weeks. As soon as a crawfish molts, it is plucked from the holding tray, put in cold water and then frozen before its new shell can harden. The same process is used with crabs. ``The trouble is everyone knows what a softshell crab is, but very few know what a softshell crawfish is,'' Murff said. He is trying to spread the word through advertising directed toward distributors and with displays at trade shows. The Cajun craze has done more for blackened fish, chicken and meat than for traditional Louisiana-style boiled crawfish, Murff said. While crawfish have covered the overhead, M-K hasn't yet turned a profit. ``We couldn't create the high-value niche we thought we could,'' Murff said. He remains committed to aquaculture but believes diversification into species with larger and established markets will be the answer. He has ordered some ponds converted to raise fresh water shimp and new ponds dug for catfish. The switch to aquaculture meant some retraining for ranchhands, but Copeland said his lifestyle remains little changed. ``Farming is farming,'' he said. ``It's 24 hours a day, seven days a week.''
