DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Modestly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with close
DOC.TEXT: Shares closed modestly higher on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, shaking off worries over British inflation with active blue-chip buying. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished 5.3 points, or 0.2 percent, higher at 2,417.9. Volume came to 578.8 million shares, up from 449.3 million shares Wednesday. Dealers attributed Thursday's modest recovery to at program trading in oil and gas stocks. The program helped spark a flurry of buying in a range of blue chip stocks, dealers said. The action also helped mute early concerns over wage inflation in Britain exerting further pressure on interest rates, fueled by Ford Motor Co.'s 10.2 percent wage increase offer to British unions late Wednesday. The unions rejected offer, dampening hopes that Britain's high interest rates could be eased by spring, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary Warns Wheat Growers of Budget Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told wheat growers Thursday that developing countries can be good customers and that U.S. exporters should take advantage of sweeping reforms in eastern Europe. He also told the National Association of Wheat Growers that as the 1990 Farm Bill is debated it will face tight budget restrictions, and farmers must choose where federal dollars will be spent. ``I see the developing countries as among your best customers in the coming years,'' Yeutter told about 700 people at the association convention. Wheat growers should continue to watch developments in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, where economic changes are taking place and countries are getting more involved in world trade, Yeutter said. But he said those nations must first control their debt, which has been a barrier to exports. Other export obstacles have been ``non-tariff barriers'' that U.S. negotiators currently are trying to eliminate, Yeutter said, referring to talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as GATT. ``Everybody has a gimmick to keep a competitive product out,'' he said, citing barriers such as quotas, import licensing and minimum import prices. Yeutter said he favors converting those provisions to tariffs. Yeutter also said he favors continuing to use the Export Enhancement Program to counteract European Economic Community export subsidies until international negotiations are concluded. Yeutter refused to disclose details of his agency's Farm Bill proposals until President Bush releases his budget plan. But he said the Agriculture Department will not be spared the budget ax. Yeutter said the agriculture industry must decide among such areas as research, deficiency payments and crop insurance in spending federal money.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Stronger in Europe, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose against most major currencies in Europe Thursday and gold prices advanced. The dollar rose because of a perception that the West German mark had become overvalued after rising sharply against the U.S. currency in recent weeks, foreign exchange dealers said. The mark had been boosted by expectations that the liberal revolution shattering Communist control of Eastern Europe would invigorate the West German economy. Dealers said they expect the dollar to trade in a narrow range around 1.70 marks. Central banks are likely to intervene to sell dollars if the U.S. currency rises toward 1.73 marks, a level it last reached on Dec. 20. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6575 late Thursday from $1.6625 late Wednesday. Other rates for the dollar in Europe compared with Wednesday's late rates: 1.6800 marks, up from 1.6795; 1.5210 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7325 French francs, up from 5.7145; 1.9021 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8815; and 1,258.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.00. The U.S. currency fell to 1.1575 Canadian dollars from 1.1585. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar slipped to 145.27 Japanese yen from 145.30. The dollar edged slightly lower in London later to close at 145.25 yen. Gold dealers said strong buying from Switzerland early in the day boosted the bullion price. Gold rose to a late bid price of $412.25 a troy ounce in London, up from $408.55 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a late bid price of $412.75 from $409.25. In Hong Kong earlier, gold rose to $411.75 an ounce from $405.65. Silver rose four cents in London to a late bid price of $5.34 an ounce.

DOC.TEXT: Grain futures prices fell and soybeans rose Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Volume was held down in anticipation of several U.S. Department of Agriculture crop reports. Soybean futures were buoyed by a slight rebound in cash prices after farmer selling slowed from the pace set earlier in the week. Soybean prices also were supported by expectations of increased export sales. Buying by a number of commerical houses also strengthened soybean futures. Wheat futures continued to show weakness due to the lack of export business. DOC.HEAD: Canadian Brewer Ponders Bid for Australian Breweries of Struggling Bond
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figures are U.S. unless otherwise noted. Stands for AM-Bond listed on Business News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian brewer said Thursday it was considering making a bid for the Australian brewing operations of Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., the Australian conglomerate staggering under nearly $6 billion in debt. Bond Corp., controlled by millionaire industrialist Alan Bond, approached John Labatt Ltd. about buying the brewing businesses and Labatt has studied the possibility for about a month, said Edward Stewart, Labatt vice-president of corporate affairs. ``On the basis of the preliminary look we had at the most recent profit figures provided to us, we believe the offer might be in the range of 1.6 billion to 2 billion Australian dollars,'' Stewart said in a telephone interview from Toronto. Based on the present exchange rate of about 79 cents per Australian dollar, an offer could be worth up to $1.6 billion. Stewart said it would be at least several weeks and perhaps months before Labatt makes any offer, adding that Labatt is not interested in acquiring Bond Corp.'s U.S. brewing unit, G. Heileman Brewing Co. The Australian beer operations, Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd., were forced into receivership last month by a syndicate of Australian and international banks, which contend Bond violated provisions of a $690 million loan agreement. Bond is seeking to overturn the receivership. Bond Brewing also is under threat of legal action from a group of investors holding $510 million in U.S. securities, who this week rejected a plea from Bond to delay $32 million in overdue interest payments. John Labatt is Canada's biggest brewer and a leading beer exporter to the United States. The company also markets dairy products, grain products, packaged and frozen foods and owns 45 percent of the Toronto Blue Jays professional baseball team. Separately Thursday, a little-known Texas entrepreneur seeking control of Bond Corp. for $197 million reacted angrily when told that Bond had stated he did not appear to have the capacity to actually undertake the deal. Jeff Reynolds, 28, claims he has $197 million lined up and is negotiating for financing to service Bond's immense debt. He has declined to provide any details or identify his source of funds, but Bond Corp. had said it was willing to listen to him. On Thursday, however, Bond released a statement from its headquarters in Perth, Western Australia, saying it had been unable to obtain information about the proposed cash offer. Bond said Reynolds' bid was doubtful and causing the company ``considerable embarrassment.'' ``It was made very clear to Mr. Reynolds and his associates right from the very beginning that there would be no discussions until Bond Corp. was satisfied that Mr. Reynolds and-or his companies have the financial capacity to undertake a transaction of the size and nature he proposes,'' Bond Corp. spokesman Peter Lucas said. ``In the absence of any such information having been made available so far, despite repeated requests, we are taking the view at this time that he does not have that capacity,'' Bond's statement read. Read the statement during a telephone call to his mother's home in Houston, where he has been living since fall, Reynolds first declined comment. Then he said he would consider a hostile bid. ``Either they're with me or they're against me, and if they're against me they better look out,'' he said. Reynolds' Weatherby Investments Inc., the Nevada company through which he is trying to gain control of Bond Corp., is no longer chartered as a corporation in that state, according to documents provided to The Associated Press on Wednesday. Reynolds is not named in the incorporation documents, although his father, Dallas businessman L. George Reynolds, was listed as president of Weatherby in 1986, when the last filing was made. Weatherby lost its charter in 1987 after failing to file its annual list of officers and the charter never has been reinstated, according to the Nevada secretary of state's office.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson Names New President; Implements ESOP
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, With more... to CORRECT number of outstanding common shares and ESOP's percentage of total. Picks up 8th graf, ESOPs sometimes...
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp. named a new president Thursday and announced the start of an employee stock ownership plan. Stephen E. Watson, who has been chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Department Store Co., will replace Bruce G. Allbright as president of the parent corporation when Allbright retires at the end of January, the nation's fifth largest retailer announced. Watson, 45, has been the top executive at the Minneapolis-based department store company for the past five years. As president of the parent corporation, he will be responsible for financial, legal, personnel, public relations and audit functions under Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Kenneth A. Macke. Watson's successor at the department store company will be named later this month, Macke said. The stock ownership plan, authorized by the board of directors in July, will supplement an existing retirement and savings plan. Dayton Hudson said its ESOP will be funded with $379 million of newly authorized preferred stock that can be converted into 4.38 million shares of common stock. To fund the stock purchase, the ESOP will borrow $379 million with a 15-year loan from the corporation. Dayton Hudson has about 71.2 million shares of common stock outstanding. When all of the ESOP shares are added, the ESOP would account for about 5.8 percent of the total shares. ESOPs sometimes are used as anti-takeover devices by putting more stock in friendly hands, but company spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said ``that's not what drove the decision to have an ESOP. The primary motivator is to improve the benefit program for our employees.'' Dayton Hudson became the target of a hostile takeover attempt in 1987, when the Haft family of Washington, D.C., acquired 4.6 million shares. The company sought help from the Minnesota Legislature in fending off the hostile bid. The Legislature then passed a corporate anti-takeover bill in a one-day special session June 25 of that year. The takeover threat ended when the stock market collapsed in October 1987. Soon after the Hafts announced they were selling their Dayton Hudson stock, the company announced a program to buy back 15 million shares of its stock to put more of the shares in friendly hands. In July, when the ESOP was authorized, the board of directors also approved the repurchase of up to 7 million additional shares of its common stock. In a separate development Wednesday, the company's board of directors increased the regular quarterly stock dividend by 18 percent, from 28 cents to 33 cents per share. Dayton Hudson had 1988 annual revenue of $12.2 billion. The corporation has about 140,000 employees in its Target, Mervyn's and Dayton Hudson Department Store Co. divisions and operates 659 stores in 33 states. About 70,000 employees would be eligible to participate in the ESOP, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Receives Engine Order from Ansett
DOC.TEXT: Ansett World Aviation Services of Australia has ordered $110 million worth of jet engines from Pratt & Whitney to power as many as 12 Airbus aircraft, Pratt & Whitney said Thursday. Ansett ordered PW4000 engines for six A300-600R Airbus twinjets, a total of 14 engines including spares, and took options on 12 more engines to power another six planes, said Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies Corp. If Ansett chooses to order all 26 engines, the value of the orders would be $225 million, Pratt & Whitney said. Pratt & Whitney claims its PW400 is the most fuel-efficient, high thrust engine ever developed.

DOC.HEAD: Personal Computer Retailer To Cut More Than 200 Jobs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to delete incomplete reference; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Businessland Inc., a personal computer retailer, announced plans Thursday to cut about 200 jobs in a restructuring. Businessland said it would make a one-time staff reduction of 5 percent to 7 percent of its 3,900 worldwide workforce, meaning a loss of from 195 to 273 jobs. The company said the cuts were due to recent acquisitions and streamlining through a multimillion-dollar investment in automating information systems and field distribution. Businessland, which resells personal computers and workstations to a mostly corporate market, did not indicate where the jobs would be eliminated. The San Jose-based company, which reported soft sales in its first quarter ended last Sept. 30, said the restructuring is targeted to take advantage of cost savings from new management information systems and ongoing consolidation of distribution operations. Businessland, founded in 1982, reported sales last year of $1.2 billion. The company said sales growth remains strong, with revenue estimated at more than $370 million for the second quarter ended Dec. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $6.82 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 483 money market mutual funds surged by $6.82 billion in the latest week to an all-time high of $375.23 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. It was the third-largest weekly rise ever and reflected what the institute called powerful seasonal flows of money, such as yearend bonuses, that usually are paid in January and deposited into interest-bearing accounts. The biggest weekly rise in fund assets _ $9.64 billion in the week ended Oct. 21, 1987 _ came after the stock market collapse as investors sought safe havens for their money. The second-biggest weekly rise was $7.62 billion in the week ending Jan. 13, 1988, largely caused by seasonal money flows. The institute, a Washington-based mutual fund trade group, also sharply revised its week-earlier figures on fund assets, originally reported as down by $955 million to $365.04 billion. Under the revision, assets rose $2.41 billion to $368.41 billion because 14 new funds were included. The revised total was a record until eclipsed by the latest weekly rise. The previous record of $386.27 billion was set Nov. 21. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 241 general purpose funds rose $1.26 billion to $124.50 billion, assets of 98 broker-dealer funds increased $3.65 billion to $160.59 billion, and assets of 144 institutional funds rose $1.91 billion to $90.14 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.80 percent from 8.06 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.92 percent from 7.94 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 38 days, down from 39 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.33 percent as of Wednesday from 6.35 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged at 5.07 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.90 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.92 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.93 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.95 percent; 7.89 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.90 percent; and 7.91 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices continued their upward climb Thursday after a brief bout of selling to make profits. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, No. 2 heating oil for February delivery, which rose 1.83 cents Wednesday, gained another 2.44 cents to settle at 69.32 cents a gallon. Other contract months showed smaller increases. The February contract for unleaded gasoline traded on the Merc advanced 1.17 cents to settle at 65.50 cents, adding to its 3.45-cent surge in the previous session. The February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 24 cents to $23.14 per 42-gallon barrel. The contract jumped 83 cents on Wednesday. Other contract months remained below $23 a barrel. Analysts noted that dealers quickly began cashing in on the week's runup in prices when trading began, but they said the momentum driving prices higher returned well before midday. Trading was active. No specific news was cited as having moved the market. But Peter Beutel, assistant director at Elders Futures Inc., said reports that the above-normal temperatures in the Northeast would drop by the weekend helped support prices. Prices surged Wednesday in reaction to a big decline in gasoline inventories.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Prices Tumble
By ROBIN STAINER
DOC.TEXT: Coffee prices plunged in London trading Thursday reflecting a supply glut. Coffee for March delivery slumped to the equivalent of almost $1,010 a metric ton, $33 below the 14-year low touched late last month and down $44.55 from Wednesday's closing level. The big consumers were holding off buying, according to analysts at coffee traders E.D.& F. Man. ``It's the well-known story of too much coffee and doubts that the market's safety-net can be restored quickly,'' one analyst said. ``The longer-term view is even more pessimistic with expected good crops from April onward from Indonesia and Brazil and the continuous offer of coffee from West Africa.'' The London market trades in robusta-type coffee, which is traditionally cheaper than the higher quality arabica variety grown throughout Latin America. Arabica prices are also depressed, but remain above their 14-year lows reached last October. Both markets plunged then, following the decision of the 74-nation International Coffee Organization in July to abandon its market-support role indefinitely. Its safety-net for prices of export quotas was suspended. Supplies of arabicas have been tightened by recent frosts in Mexico's coffee-growing region and the decision of Central American producers to keep 15 percent of their current crop off the market to help stabilize prices, traders said. There are also delays to shipments of arabicas from Colombia, El Salvador and Nicaragua and prospects of a worse than expected Brazilian arabica crop, according to Man. Brazil grows mainly arabicas, but also robustas. Informal consultations among producing and consuming countries on restoring the coffee organization's quota stystem have so far made little progress, according to experts at West German coffee specialists F.O. Licht. Producer and consumer officials said Thursday they expected no breakthrough on the issue when the two sides meet in London Jan. 16-17 for what promises to be a routine meeting of the coffee organization's 16-nation executive board. They said hopes of quick action may have been set back by differences between Colombia and the United States over Washington's decision to station warships off the Latin American nation's coast in an attempt to intercept drug shipments. The United States and Colombia _ respectively the world's biggest consumer and the second-biggest producer of coffee _ have so far been at the forefront of efforts to restore the coffee organization's quota system.

DOC.HEAD: Grains Futures Fall, Soybean Gain in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain futures prices fell and soybeans rose Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Volume was held down in anticipation of several U.S. Department of Agriculture crop reports. On other markets, livestock and pork prices were higher, precious metals were mixed, and energy futures climbed. Wheat settled } cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.04} a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to a { cent higher with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2} cents lower with March at $1.43{ a bushel; soybeans were a { cent lower to 2{ cents higher with January at $5.69} a bushel. Soybean futures were buoyed by a slight rebound in cash prices after farmer selling slowed from the pace set earlier in the week. Soybean prices also were supported by expectations of increased export sales. Wheat futures continued to show weakness due to the lack of export business. The USDA estimated the 1989 corn crop at 7.5 billion bushels, which was below expectations. Soybean production was put at 1.9 billion bushels, also lower than expected. The USDA reported farmers planted about 57 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, up 3 percent from 1989. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the following year. It accounts for about three-fourths of the total U.S. wheat output. Meanwhile, U.S. wheat stockpiles have continued to shrink, thus keeping market prices at high levels. Energy futures rebounded from losses suffered in early trading to post a gain on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The gain was led by heating oil futures, which surged on expectations of a return of cold weather in the Northeast, said analyst Peter Beutel of Elders Futures Inc. in New York. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 9 cents lower to 24 cents higher with February at $23.14 a barrel; heating oil was .33 cent to 2.44 cents higher with February at 69.32 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .57 cent to 1.17 cents higher with February at 65.50 cents a gallon. Despite being pressured by profit-taking, gold prices closed higher on New York's Commodity Exchange. Silver suffered a slight loss. Pressure on gold came from a relatively firm dollar and gains on the New York Stock Exchange, said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. The overnight gold bullion market was firm, although gold came under pressure from the rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Steel said. Gold was $1.40 to $1.60 higher with February at $415.60 a troy ounce. Silver was 2 cents to 3 cents lower with March at $5.365 a troy ounce. Livestock and pork futures were higher in light trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle prices were up sharply due to computer-generated trading. Further gains were checked by declining demand for beef and lower cash prices. Hog futures were supported by steady prices in the cash market, and frozen pork belly prices were boosted by commercial and commission house buying. Live cattle were .22 cent to .65 cent higher with February at 77.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .27 cent higher with January at 84.37 cents a pound; hogs were .08 cent lower to .33 cent higher with February at 51.27 a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.12 cents to 1.60 cents higher with February at 57.47 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Stronger in Europe, Gold Higher
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended slightly lower Thursday after a session in which dealers focused mainly on cross rates between foreign currencies rather than the U.S. currency. Gold prices rose modestly, with bullion for current delivery gaining $1.60 an ounce to $414 on the New York Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price of $413.60, up $2.35. ``It's essentially been a cross market,'' said Robert White, manager of corporate trading at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. ``It isn't so much the dollar. It's the yen against the market. It's the market against the Swiss.'' Swiss National Bank President Markus Lusser said Thursday that Swiss interest rates might remain above rates in West Germany for some time to prevent the Swiss franc from weakening further against the German mark. Higher interest rates would make the currency more attractive for investors to hold, and Lusser's comment drove the franc sharply higher. ``The market is just a bundle of nerves'' because there is no clear trend for the dollar, White said. Dealers are watching political developments in Eastern Europe closely for signs of instability, which might lead investors to rush into dollars as a safe haven, he said. Traders also are keeping a keen eye on U.S. interest rates for any sign of credit easing by the Federal Reserve, which would tend to make the dollar less attractive, he said. At the start of the day in Tokyo, the dollar slipped 0.03 Japanese yen to 145.27. The dollar eased further in London to 145.25 yen before closing in New York at 145.45 yen, down from 145.55 late Wednesday. Later dollar rates in New York compared with Wednesday included: 1.6795 West German marks, down from 1.6825 marks; 1.5065 Swiss francs, down from 1.5165; 5.7215 French francs, down from 5.7265; 1,253.75 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; 1.1562 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1585. The dollar rose slightly against sterling. The British pound fell to $1.6597 late in New York, down from $1.6625. In London earlier, the pound fell to $1.6575 from $1.6625. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Wednesday: 1.6800 marks, up from 1.6795; 1.5210 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7325 French francs, up from 5.7145; 1.9021 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8815; 1,258.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.00; and 1.1575 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1585. Gold also rose in London to a late bid price of $412.25 an ounce from $408.55 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $412.75 from $409.25. In Hong Kong earlier, gold jumped $6.10 to $411.75 an ounce. Silver for current delivery closed unchanged at $5.306 an ounce on New York's Comex after gaining four cents earlier in London to $5.34.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Hold Jobs They Never Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Danann in grafs 2, 7, 12 pvs; PICKS UP 13th graf pvs, `There's lots...; A longer version moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A majority of American workers are doing what they do for such reasons as simple chance or lack of choice, while just 41 percent hold jobs that they had planned, according to a poll released Thursday. The results indicate ``that many people are trapped at less than they could do,'' said Sharon Danann, research director at a Cleveland-based group called 9 to 5, National Association of Working Women. The survey of 1,350 people was conducted last October by the Gallup Organization for the National Occupational Information Coordinating Committee, a panel Congress created to make better use of job information. The poll, which asked a variety of job-related questions, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Other findings showed that about half of Americans say job stress affects their health, personal relationships or their ability to do their job; nearly one-third of the work force expects to change jobs within the next three years; and that 65 percent said that given a chance to start over, they would try to get more information about career options. While 41 percent of the employed respondents consciously chose their job or career, 18 percent got started in their present job through chance circumstances, 12 percent took the only job available and the rest were either influenced by friends or relatives. ``There's a real dilemma. The labor market isn't matching up well with what people are trained to do and what they want to do,'' said Jim Green, a labor historian at the University of Massachusetts. He said the results may indicate that many people view their jobs as ``necessary evils.'' Green and Ms. Danann said part of the reason people are in jobs they never planned is because most new jobs being created are in the service industry. Juliette Lester, executive director of the committee that had the poll conducted, said those results demonstrate the need for government and job counselors to improve the way they educate the public about career options. ``The people who are most in need are not getting it,'' she said, noting that only 21 percent of those without a high school degree had planned their jobs and 25 percent of that group had taken the only jobs they could find. In a separate finding, 25 percent of employed adults who responded said job stress or pressure had interfered with their off-the-job relationships, 20 percent said it had affected their physical health and 20 percent said it had affected their ability to do their job. But responding to the same question, 48 percent reported little or no job stress over the past year. The totals exceeded 100 percent because of multiple responses. Ms. Danann said more Americans probably suffer from job-related stress than admit it. ``There's lots of people who probably don't realize that's what it is, that their job is full of interruptions, or that they have multiple bosses telling them it's priority work, and that it's driving them nuts,'' she said. The poll also showed that 40 percent said higher pay would give them an incentive to accomplish more at work while 31 percent cited more recognition. Other incentives included additional training, chance for advancement and more control over their job. In another finding, 68 percent said there was no discrimination in the workplace, 5 percent said minorities are discriminated against but not women and 5 percent said women are discriminated against but not minorities. Ten percent think both groups are treated unfairly while 6 percent said women and minorities are treated better.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Says It Will Ban Smoking on All North American Flights
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines announced Thursday that it will extend a new smoking ban, scheduled to begin Feb. 25 on flights of six hours or less within the United States, to cover all its service in North America. Smoking will be allowed only on Delta's Europe and Asia flights. ``In expanding the smoking ban, we continue to respond to the wishes of our passengers,'' said Whit Hawkins, Delta's senior vice president for marketing. ``Over the years we have seen a dramatic decrease in the demand for designated smoking seats on our flights. At the same time, the two-hour smoking ban begun in 1988 has been very well received by our passengers.'' Hawkins said more than 70 percent of Delta's flights were affected by the ban covering flights of two hours or less. On the flights where smoking was permitted, only about 20 percent of the seats were designated for smoking, a decrease from 30 percent to 40 percent five years ago, he said. The latest ban will be effective on all flights within the United States, which includes Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico, as well as flights to the Bahamas, Bermuda, Canada and Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Opens U.S. Sales Office
DOC.TEXT: An independent Soviet newspaper that has chronicled the recent wave of reforms in Eastern Europe has become an advertising vehicle for several U.S. companies intrigued by the potential sales territory. Advertising space in Atmoda: the Journal of Perestroika, is being sold in Minneapolis by John Freivalds, who also is a foreign language business consultant. Freivalds, a Latvian native who now is a U.S. citizen, opened the downtown sales office after traveling back to his home country in May to obtain permission from the Latvian National Front, the two-year-old political party that publishes Atmoda. Atmoda, Latvian for ``awakening,'' is a weekly newspaper that promises access to Latvian decision-makers getting their first taste of economic freedom. ``The Soviet Union is changing,'' Freivalds tells potential clients. ``The Communists are not going to have the power they once had. You have to reach the new decision-makers. The new decision-makers read this (Atmoda). The society is still in flux, but given the ad rates, this is an inexpensive way to test the waters for your product or service.'' The newspaper's first U.S. ads ran during October. So far, five U.S. advertisers have run 20 ads totaling five pages. A total of seven advertisers have bought an additional 20 ads that will begin running next month, Freivalds said. He says he's lost about $30,000 on the venture, but plans to give the project two years before determining whether to continue. The 18-month-old Atmoda has a circulation of up to 100,000 for its Latvian edition and is distributed throughout the Soviet Union. Its estimated readership is 1.5 million, meaning that each copy is read by 15 people. The $600 cost of a full-page ad in Atmoda is the equivalent of three months' salary for the average Latvian. But it's roughly one-tenth of what U.S. newspapers with comparable circulation charge, said Andrea Luhtanen, vice president of the Haworth Group, a Minneapolis media services company. Freivalds said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's restructuring program is giving the most latitude to the Baltics _ Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia _ which once thrived as capitalistic markets. ``I've always thought that perestroika was invented by Gorbachev for the Baltic states, because they can remember what capitalism was like; they are closest to taking advantage of it,'' he said. The most successful U.S. companies in Latvia probably will be sellers of industrial products that can stimulate fundamental economic development. For example, Garden Way Inc., of Albany, N.Y., has sold 31 small tractors in Latvia at $3,000 each, Freivalds said. The company's agent has advertised in Atmoda since the fall, he said. Low-priced consumer goods also are in demand, said Freivalds. Event Sales, a Minneapolis company that sells surplus consumer goods, recently signed an Atmoda advertising contract, he said. But Freivalds said he's approaching corporate giants about advertising their products in the Soviet Union. ``That level of sophistication is not going to happen for 10 years, at least,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: M2 Money Supply Falls; M3 Rises
DOC.TEXT: The broadest measure of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Jan. 1, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M3 rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,046.4 billion from $4,044.4 billion the previous week. A narrower measure, M2, fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,221.4 billion from $3,227.3 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $805.2 billion from $802.3 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.3 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,196.0 billion, a 7.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,026.8 billion, up 2.9 percent, while M1 rose 6.7 percent to an average of $791.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $137 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $504 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $295.7 billion in the two-week period ended Jan. 10, down from $299.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Files False Advertising Complaint Against Diet Pills
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission said Thursday it had filed a false advertising claim against the maker and advertiser of ``Fat-Magnet'' diet pills, touted in ads as capable of clinging to fat before it shows. The commission, seeking about $5 million in consumer redress, contends the national advertisements falsely claim the pills contribute to weight loss and wrongly state the product is ``100 percent safe.'' The pills, which cost $20 for a bottle of 90, could be harmful for some people, possibly causing diarrhea or stomach cramps, said Marcy J.K. Tiffany, director of the commission's Los Angeles office. The ``Fat-Magnet'' pills were advertised in such publications as the National Enquirer, Cosmopolitan and Woman's Day. The product was available only by mail or telephone order. After the commission filed a complaint Tuesday, a federal judge issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting the pills' manufacture by Allied International Corp. and the product's advertising by Linder Ad-Vantage. The firms' assets also were frozen. The companies, based in Oxnard, have unlisted telephone numbers and officials could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth-Quarter Earnings Up 55 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Fannie Mae said Thursday its earnings soared 55 percent in the fourth quarter, an improvement it said was spurred by lower interest rates that produced a strong market for fixed-rate mortgages. Fannie Mae, formally known as the Federal National Mortgage Association, is a congressionally chartered but shareholder-owned company which provides money for home buyers by purchasing mortgages from lenders and packaging them into securities for sale to investors. For the October-December quarter of last year, net income totaled $237 million, or 90 cents a share, up from $153 million, 63 cents a share, a year earlier. For all of 1989, Fannie Mae earned $807 million, $3.10 a share, a 59 percent increase over 1988 when earnings were $507 million, or $2.11 a share. Fannie Mae President Roger Birk said that lower interest rates, and a decline in mortgage foreclosures and related losses boosted the company's performance.

DOC.HEAD: Julien Co. Cotton Merchant Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: The Julien Co., one of the world's largest cotton merchants, filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors Thursday, one day after three major creditors urged the court to intervene. The private company, founded and run by Julien Hohenberg of Memphis, estimated its debts at $344 million and assets at $160 million in filing for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. The company's problems apparently stem from speculation in cotton futures during the summer, analysts say. The filing came one day after three major creditors petitioned the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Memphis to put Julien into bankruptcy and appoint a trustee to run it. Bankers Trust Co., one of the creditors, renewed its request for a trustee Thursday. ``The Julien Co. does not have the management or the assets to run the company,'' said Bob Orians, a lawyer for the bank. Bankers Trust has $172 million in secured loans outstanding to Julien, he said. Judge William H. Brown set a hearing for Tuesday to consider the motion. During a break in court proceedings, Hohenberg refused to discuss his financial troubles or comment on reports that he recently lost millions of dollars on the futures market. His financial troubles became public last month when PaineWebber Inc. filed suit claiming Julien Co. failed by some $2.3 million to meet margin calls on cotton futures. Cotton analysts say Hohenberg may have run into trouble by buying futures heavily in the summer and fall expecting prices to rise. Cotton prices have fallen instead, with cutbacks in purchases by textile mills and a large domestic crop this year apparently contributing to the decline. Orians said Bankers Trust has paid the company's payroll for the past month. He told the court that the company has come close in recent weeks to having utilities turned off at its headquarters. Edward L. Montedonico, Julien Co.'s lawyer, said the company is likely to have more than 600 creditors. The company does business with numerous banks, farmers, textile mills, warehouses and shippers around the country and abroad. Montedonico said $19 million of the company's debts are unsecured. Most of the secured debts are covered by cotton stored in warehouses or in various stages of shipment around the country, he said. The judge directed Montedonico to notify creditors holding Julien Co. assets not to sell them to cover the merchant's debts. ``We've got to stop the flow of any assets ... until we get a handle on it,'' the judge said. Orians said the cotton securing Bankers Trust's loans may be sitting in hundreds of warehouses. ``We're in the process of determining where all this collateral is,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Broker Barred From Securities Industry for Waldbaum Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: Convicted stockbroker Robert Chestman agreed Thursday to be barred permanently from the securities industry, settling civil insider trading charges concerning A&P's acquisition of Waldbaum supermarkets. Chestman consented, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, to a court order permanently barring him from the securities industry to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission action. Chestman is currently serving a two-year prison sentence for his March 14 conviction in Manhattan federal court on mail fraud, perjury and securities law violations. His conviction is under appeal before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, said Chestman lawyer Elkan Abramowitz. The SEC and federal prosecutors accused Chestman of trading Waldbaum Inc. stock for himself and clients with illegal inside information about a pending tender offer from the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. The government alleged that a member of the Waldbaum family, Keith Loeb, tipped off Chestman to the pending bid before A&P announced a tender offer of $50 per share for Waldbaum stock outstanding. According to the SEC complaint, filed in New York in October 1987, Chestman netted $235,125 after buying 11,000 shares of Waldbaum stock for himself, Loeb and other clients at prices ranging between $24.37{ and $26 per share. In addition to the prison sentence, U.S. District Judge John Walker Jr. fined Chestman an amount equal to the illegal profits he made for himself and others. As part of the civil settlement, the SEC agreed that Chestman's fine would satisfy the disgorgement sought by the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Cotton Production Estimates Still Down
DOC.TEXT: Cotton production from last year's crop is estimated at 12.2 million bales, down 21 percent from the 1988 harvest, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. That was up about 1 percent from the December forecast, the department said in its report. Total area for harvest was estimated at 9.49 million acres, down 21 percent from 1988. The average yield was reported at an average of 619 pounds per acre, about equal to the 1988 average but up 11 pounds from the December estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Paints Gloomy Operating Prospects In Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Carol Sanger ...,' with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with Campeau turning over control of U.S. operations to trustees. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ^By JOHN M. DOYLE
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp. painted a gloomy sales picture Thursday for the next two years at its retailing businesses, in documents that also disclosed that a total liquidation of its stores might not be enough to pay off its debts. The Canadian corporation, which amassed huge debts in acquiring Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., disclosed its best and worse-case scenarios for the next five years in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the document released Thursday, Campeau projected that Allied and Federated earnings could fall by up to 6.4 percent in the 1990 fiscal year. The documents also indicated that even if Federated and Allied were completely liquidated, the sale proceeds still might not be enough to help pay the companies' combined total debts of some $8 billion. Both retail units face a Monday deadline to renegotiate a $2.34 billion loan from a syndicate headed by Citibank. On Wednesday, Campeau surprised Wall Street and Seventh Avenue by paying $100 million on schedule to numerous merchandise suppliers. On Thursday, Campeau's board effectively turned over control of the company's U.S. operations to outside hands. The board said in a statement it approved the transfer of control of the U.S. division, Campeau (U.S.), to trustees. It also recommended that the division appoint its own chairman and chief executive officer and its own board of directors, which would be composed of independent, U.S. residents. Campeau's chairman, Robert Campeau, said in the statement he only would remain involved in the company's real estate operations under the reorganization. In its filing, Campeau projected earnings for Allied and Federated would fall as much as 6.4 percent in fiscal year 1990 _ due to ``management distraction, limitations on the company's ability to negotiate better prices with vendors and increased promotions needed to stimulate business.'' _ before recovering in 1991. The corporation projected that it would return to a normal operating environment by the beginning of fiscal year 1992. Campeau projected Federated would have operating earnings of $483 million on sales of $4.92 billion for fiscal 1989 and Allied would have operating earnings of $273 million on sales of $2.74 billion. Campeau also stated that its projections had not been updated since it opened talks on Dec. 13 with major creditors about possible financial restructurings. The documents also stressed that the unusual operating problems facing the company made the projections highly uncertain. Another set of projections assumed that Allied and Federated might have to operate under increased restrictions imposed by suppliers and factors, which in turn could ``significantly impair their ability to obtain inventory.'' Inventory could be off by as much as $400 million retail compared to the projection for fiscal year 1990. There was no mention in the documents of seeking U.S. Bankruptcy Code protection from creditors. However, the document noted: ``There can be no assurance that restructurings can be completed on satisfactory terms, within a satisfactory time frame, if at all.'' Campeau's problems stem chiefly from the debt it acquired when it bought Federated in 1988 for $6.6 billion and Allied two years earlier for $3.4 billion. Part of the restructuring plan it already has mapped out involves selling Federated's Bloomingdale's department store chain, considered one of Campeau's most valuable possessions. Federated's other chains include Abraham and Straus, Burdines, Lazarus and Rich's. Allied operates the Bon Marche, Jordan Marsh, Maas Brothers and Stern's chains. The SEC document projected an after-tax price of between $3.40 billion and $3.70 billion if all of Federated's divisions were sold individually under the best circumstances. The price would fall to $2.55 billion to $2.70 billion the divisions were sold under ``distressed'' circumstances, such as in a bankruptcy reorganization. A fire sale of Allied's divisions would net between $1.2 billion and $1.35 billion, Campeau projected, compared to $1.60 billion and $1.80 billion in an ``orderly process.'' According to the documents, Federated has a total debt and accrued interest of $5.19 billion and Allied's debt with interest of $2.99 billion. The documents projected an after-tax liquidation deficit of between $1.68 billion and $835 million for Federated and $1.79 billion and $1.39 billion for Allied, depending upon the circumstances of a sell-off. Allied alone is expected to pay $113 million in debt service next year, $106 million in 1991, $379 million in 1992, $6 million in 1993 and $4 million in 1994 _ assuming refinancing.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Recall of Jarvik Heart Could Slow Research
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 9th graf pvs, `Clark was ...,' to ADD comments from user; SUBS 17th graf, `Symbion issued ...,' with one graf to ADD company comment; INSERTS 1 graf after 21st graf pvs, `In recent ...,' to ADD usage statistics. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration's ban on use of the Jarvik artificial heart could slow research in the field but probably won't affect patients needing temporary implants, medical experts said Thursday. But a major user of the device said he might defy the ban. The FDA, in a letter sent earlier this week and disclosed Wednesday, withdrew Symbion Inc.'s approval for continued investigational uses of its artificial heart, both as a permanent replacement and a temporary bridge for patients awaiting a human heart transplant. ``By removing the Jarvik, you take the first and main artificial heart player out of the ballgame,'' said Dr. Jack Kolff, a professor of cardiac surgery at Temple University in Philadelphia whose father, Dr. Willem Kolff, developed the first artificial kidney in 1943. ``That leaves a bit of a vacuum for those researchers who think there may be a future for an artificial heart,'' he said. Dr. Antonio Gotto, chief of internal medical services at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston and past president of the American Heart Association, said that because of the availability of alternative, temporary heart-assist devices the FDA's action probably won't have an impact on heart patients. ``But it does represent a setback in terms of time toward eventually getting a completely implantable heart,'' he said. The Jarvik heart, named after its inventor, Dr. Robert Jarvik of Utah, gained household recognition after it was implanted in Barney Clark on Dec. 2, 1982. He lived 112 days, his new heart tethered to a bulky external power system, before he succumbed to multiple organ failure. Clark was the first to person to receive a permanent artificial heart. Several others since Clark received the artificial heart, but recipients have been plagued by blood clotting and strokes. In Tucson, Ariz., Dr. Jack Copeland, head of the heart transplant program at the University of Arizona, said the ban means he and his staff could be faced with the decision of ``putting a device in anyway,'' either an artificial heart or related heart pumping helper, in a critically ill patient. ``And I think our decision right now would be to go ahead and use the device. ... we have good data, good statistics, we;re happy with the way the devices have worked, we think we can save lives,'' Copeland told a news conference at which he presented transplant candidate Paul Sicola, 48, of Old Bridge, N.J., who has been kept alive for 119 days with a ventricular assist decive. Sicola said he would advise FDA to ``leave the system alone.'' Copeland stirred controversy once before, using a different artificial heart without approval to keep a patient alive for 11 hours while he awaited a transplant. His team has used Symbion hearts in seven patients and assistance devices in 14. The FDA said that during two inspections of the Tempe, Ariz.-based company's facilities last year, it had found ``some serious deficiencies'' in manufacturing quality control, monitoring of research sites, servicing of equipment, training of personnel and reporting of adverse reactions to FDA. ``The agency felt the deficiencies were great enough that risks to patients were outweighing benefits,'' said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. He said the letter was sent Monday. Symbion issued a statement saying it had received the FDA notice and would ``release further information at the appropriate time.'' Dr. Donald Olsen, director of the University of Utah's Institute for Biomedical Engineering, said he was ``surprised and disappointed'' by the FDA's action and hoped it would not hurt future federal funding of artificial heart research in general, particularly for totally implantable devices. The permanent Jarvik heart consists of a fist-size pump that is implanted into the chest and which is attached to two plastic tubes connected to a large compressed-air power system contained in a large cart that must move with the patient. Withdrawal of the permanent Jarvik heart leaves only one other natural-heart replacement with FDA investigational approval, but that device is used only as a temporary bridge and only at Hershey Medical Center of Pennsylvania State University. In recent years, the Jarvik has functioned mainly as a temporary bridge in patients awaiting transplants. Alternatives to the Jarvik are available because other companies have approvals for such temporary implants and for left ventricular assist pumps that help the natural heart work without replacement. Copeland said Symbion hearts have been used in 155 patients, and pumping assistance devices in 55. Dr. Thomas Preston, chief of cardiology at Pacific Medical Center in Seattle and a vocal critic of permanent artificial hearts, said the Jarvik venture has been a failure. ``They've set the whole program back with premature useage of the permanent artificial heart,'' he said. ``Now the whole (artificial heart) program has a bad name because the thing didn't work.'' ``It's another sad instance of people in the medical profession rushing in for fame and glory and riches with great acclaim from the media and then disillusionment,'' he said. However, Preston said he hopes work continues on the technology ``because some day it's going to be better.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Estimates Florida Freeze Cut Orange Crop by 29 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 2nd graf to UPDATE with governor asking Bush for federal disaster assistance.
DOC.TEXT: Florida's orange harvest will plunge by 29 percent this year due to damage from the Christmas weekend freeze, yielding the smallest crop in 25 years, the Department of Agriculture estimated Thursday. Also Thursday, Gov. Bob Martinez asked President Bush to declare seven Florida counties disaster areas, and vowed to seek the declaration for more counties once citrus and sugarcane salavage operations are complete. The USDA's monthly crop forecast _ the first since the Dec. 24-26 freeze that iced fruit throughout the 700,000-acre citrus belt _ also projected a 13 percent drop in the grapefruit crop from earlier production estimates. The report is the first official estimate of damage to the citrus crop, worth $1.4 billion last season. ``This is the lowest estimated production since 1964-65,'' said Robert R. Terry, a USDA official who specializes in Florida citrus. Some industry officials have estimated losses at farm level at between $100 million and $200 million. Loss of added value from harvesting and processing are expected to be at least another $150 million. But the full extent of the financial damage cannot be calculated for months, until a full assessment is made of damage to trees. USDA analysts predicted 92 million 90-pound boxes of oranges would be harvested during the 1989-90 crop year. This compares with the 130 million boxes of oranges forecast in early December for the current season. The orange harvest in the 1988-89 season was 146 million boxes. The analysts are projecting a Florida grapefruit crop of 38 million boxes for this year, compared with the pre-freeze forecast of 44 million boxes. The 1988-89 grapefruit harvest was almost 55 million boxes. The USDA also estimated that Florida processors would pack 1.30 gallons of frozen concentrated orange juice from each box of oranges, a drop in the pre-freeze estimate of a 1.48-gallon juice ``yield.'' ``It's a pretty substantial overall loss, almost equal percentage wise to the 1983-84 season,'' said Terry. He said the December freeze ``could be considered one of the worst freezes of the century.'' Successive crop forecasts in the coming months are expected to be even lower as possible damage to trees is assessed. The final verdict on crop losses and tree damage will probably not be known until the end of the harvesting season, industry officials said. ``The juice will be just as good, but we're expecting a whole lot less of it,'' said John Smoak, president of Smoak Groves in Lake Placid. ``We were just getting back on our feet since the last two freezes.'' Temperatures dropped and stayed in the mid-teens and low 20s across the citrus belt during the two-day freeze last month. When ice forms in oranges, tiny cells burst and the juice dissipates. As the weather warms again, the fruit begins to dry up. Much of the fruit can be salvaged and processed into juice, and processing plants are operating around-the-clock as harvesters rush to get as much of the fruit off the trees as possible before it spoils. Don Farmer, assistant executive director of the Florida Department of Citrus, expressed concern about the Valencia crop, a prized variety which is not ripe enough to be harvested but is expected to show heavy damage from the freeze. ``There was obvious damage to this crop,'' said Farmer, who grows Valencias. ``Some of those won't be picked at all. They're on the ground.''

DOC.HEAD: UAL Chairman Asks Employees To Support Buyout
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of UAL Corp. warned employees of the airline company in a letter that a recapitalization under study by the board of directors could hurt the company and urged employees instead to support a buyout. ``It is time to decide whether we want to take control of our destiny and therein buy a majority of United Airlines or allow events to transpire as they may, and hope for the best,'' Wolf wrote, according to The New York Times. The Times said the letter was dated Tuesday and released Thursday. On Monday, UAL's board said it asked its financial advisers to study a recapitalization. Under such a plan, Chicago-based UAL would borrow money in order to buy back some of its shares. Recapitalizations also sometimes involve a special dividend to shareholders. The board's action was prompted by Coniston Partners, a New York investment group that holds 11.8 percent of UAL stock. Coniston had presented the board with a Monday deadline to negotiate a buyout or take other action to raise the company's stock price. The board, in a statement, also said it was still interested in a buyout proposal. Such a proposal from management and United's pilots union collapsed last year after it failed to obtain funding. The Times, quoting unidentified sources, reported that representatives of UAL's management and the airline's pilots and flight attendants unions met in New York on Thursday. Wolf met on Wednesday with representatives of the company's 19,000 salaried employees to discuss options faced by the company. In his letter to United's 70,000 employees, Wolf said that unless a buyout bid is devised, the board would put through a recapitalization, or a new board installed by Coniston would take the same step, the Times said. ``Do you want to allow the Coniston Partners to cripple United financially, or do you collectively want to pay for and buy a majority of the company?'' he wrote. Wolf said United would not be able to pay for the $19 billion in aircraft it has on order if the company funds a stock buyback.
